	<review>
		<date>2006-06-29</date>
		<username>daniel charchuk</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>Visually outstanding but poorly scripted</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>While this film is visually far superior to the original from 1968, the plot and characters fall far short, due mostly to a poorly written script and some wooden acting. Burton's style is out in full force on this one, and it works very well for the film, but the plot dives into action when it should be focusing on plot &amp; character development. The first third or so of the movie works very well, homaging the original while retaining its own style. Unfortunately, the story falters and the suspense, horror, and sci-fi thrills - which were built up very well - are sacrificed for the sake of big action scenes. The final battle is a complete mass, topped only by the unbelievable, albeit intriguing, ending. The twist defies logic in all its forms, but it's still cool to see. A disappointment, to be sure. Something tells me this would have worked much better as a sci-fi horror/thriller than an action/adventure.There are some intriguing concepts at play within the film, mostly dealing with the evolution of the apes and their culture. The fact that they all evolved from the monkeys that the humans took with them is quite an ingenious idea, made even more so by the fact that the apes all worship these simple monkeys. A nice jab at our own religious beliefs when Ari states that their story of creation is nothing more than a fairy tale. The ape culture is interesting because of its apparent similarity to, yet stark difference from, our own - seems to suggest that evolution turns out the same regardless of species. A thought, though - if the apes evolved from the monkeys who rebelled against the humans, then where did the humans on the planet come from? Definitely a plot hole. Still, the overall concept is quite good, marred unnecessarily by the poor storyline.Technically, the film is superb. The makeup, costumes, production design, music and special effects are all top-notch and very cool. The apes look, act, and move like real animals, not just humans in monkey suits. The score, especially during the opening credits, is excellent and quite appropriate for the film. The ape village is very Burtonesque, which suits it well. Some of the early scenes are startling in their dark beauty. Most of the cool shots in this movie are in the first half, save the final scene. The second half goes awry with silly battle scenes and lame attempts at character development. Once again, the script is to blame. The acting is all over the place, ranging from scenery-chewing (Roth) to mediocre (Wahlberg) to downright bad (the blond chick). In general, the apes seem to do a much better job than the humans - not sure why Burton felt the need to make the humans talk in this one; the muteness of humanity in the original is one of the contributing factors to its greatness. The only human that should matter in this film is the lead character - the rest of the humans are just animals to the apes, and if they can talk, it ruins the idea. Still, the film looks beautiful.All in all, this was a great disappointment. A director as visually skilled as Burton, a classic film just itching to be remade, and loads of money for effects? It's too bad the script fell far short - this would have been a modern classic. Still, the first half or so is great to just look at, if you ignore the inane plot and annoying characters. The twist, however cool, is nothing more than a sorry attempt to top the original's ending - but it's not happening. Burton should have just stuck to homaging the original ending, rather than trying to beat it. Maybe have Wahlberg encounter an ape Statue of Liberty - that would have been cool. Overall, a beautiful film marred by a poor script.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>

		<date>2006-06-11</date>
		<username>Bogmeister</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>A New Nightmarish World of Clever Apes</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>An energetic, adrenaline-charged and slightly surreal remake of the classic '68 original, still based on author Boulle's novel (oh, someone preferred the term 'reimagined' - as if 'remake' is a dirty word now - too late for such pomposity at this stage). But we can imagine what director Burton's penchant for nightmarish landscapes and dark fairy tales would look like if imposed on the well-known Planet of the Apes storyline. With such preconceptions, it's not at all a surprise what this film ended up becoming - in fact, it's fairly predictable, perhaps its biggest weakness. It's no surprise that many of those crowd shots of soldier apes here resemble the scary monkey-things from "The Wizard of Oz." Ironically, the first drawback for this version is its faithful adherence to the novel; the hero astronaut (Marky Mark) in this one really does travel to another planet, where the inhabitants (ruling apes &amp; underdog humans) speak perfect English. The explanation for this bizarro planet and its presumed natives in the final third is not nearly as elegant as the logical one in the classic '68 film. We're asked to go along with the fanciful concepts and not think it out very much - this is fairy tale madness, after all, dressed up as science fiction for the masses. Burton seems to be in conflict with himself here - at once the eclectic stylist at odds with presenting a standard summer popcorn flic for the consumers.Where Burton and some of his actors do succeed is in presenting most of the new ape characters. Roth pretty much steals the movie from everyone as the central villain, Thade. Interestingly, this film was more accurate than the original in that it understood that chimpanzees are the most violence-prone and bad-tempered of the apes in our reality (gorillas are actually more benign). Thade, a super-chimp for lack of a better term, is possessed of power on several levels (physical, social, political) and uses it in displays of ferocious antipathy. Roth so loses himself in the role that, even as I viewed this a 2nd and 3rd time, knowing who it was under that ape make-up, I still could find no traces of him. It's a triumph of make-up FX and stellar method acting. All the actors who play apes in this picture, including Bonham Carter and Clarke Duncan, succeed in dazzling the audience to such a degree that, unfortunately, all the ones playing humans, including the main lead, come off as very bland. The climactic battle between the two armies is exciting and we tense up some more as Thade's villainy appears to near an end. Then everything becomes abruptly copacetic on this weird world and the final (secondary) climax back on Earth still doesn't make sense to me, not after the 3rd time, and probably not when I see it a 4th time. I think Burton's just messing with us.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>

		<shortDescription>Please - don't remake any more classic films!!!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>If this were a standalone film, or the first time this story was made into a film, then it wouldn't be too bad. 	<review>
		<date>2006-01-26</date>
		<username>Max_cinefilo89</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Lots of style, little less substance...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The original Planet of the Apes (1968) will always be a landmark in the sci-fi genre (more specifically, the apocalyptic sub-genre). It's an excellent movie, which didn't need a remake, if not to make it more appealing to a new generation of film-lovers. Tim Burton's "reimagining" of the movie was interesting on paper, no doubt about that, but it's also the most disappointing film he's done so far.Burton already did sci-fi in 1996, directing the hilarious Mars Attacks!. Now, that movie may have looked like his most un-Burton-like project, but it worked, thanks to the witty script, which perfectly reflected the director's freaky sense of humor, and the terrific cast (Nicholson, DeVito, Natalie Portman, Pierce Brosnan et al). Planet of the Apes, on the other hand, contains the quintessential burtonian theme (outcasts feared by other people), and it's really, really dark compared to the original, but its strength is all in the style: from Rick Baker's utterly realistic make-up to Danny Elfman's "simian" score, the movie is perfect, technically speaking. It's the storytelling and acting that aren't always as good as expected.The screenplay, while repeating the same basic idea - human astronaut ends up on another world where intelligent apes have enslaved mankind -, is supposedly more faithful to Pierre Boulle's novel, especially the ending (I won't spoil it, but it's far less shocking than what Charlton Heston saw back in 1968), although it suffers from one detail: much of the original version's charm had to do, among other things, with the fact that humans didn't talk on the Planet, making Heston's presence more intriguing. In Burton's movie, they can talk, which leads to an obvious question: why did no none try to have a reasonable conversation with the apes? Sure, that would have killed the movie right away, but it just feels pointless to introduce this new aspect and not develop it.The other weak element is the acting, particularly the "humans": Mark Wahlberg has none of the charisma he had in Boogie Nights, and his co-stars (Kris Kristofferson, Estella Warren) don't impress that much either. It's the monkeys that deserve our attention, most notably Helena Bonham Carter as the human-loving scientist and Tim Roth as evil general Thade (a treat for fans: Charlton Heston plays Roth's daddy). They bring intensity to their characters and Carter in particular succeeds in bringing new life to one of the most loved primates from Franklin J. Schaffner's classic.Overall not a very bad film, but we expected more from the man who gave us the "new" versions of Batman and Ichabod Crane. Too much studio interference, perhaps?</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>

		<shortDescription>i thought i expected better</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The movie was great, but not as great as the original Planet of the apes which was made in 1968. 		<username>edtorelli</username>
		<score>0.3</score>
		<shortDescription>A Deception</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This movie is a deception, in the real sense of the word. When I heard about this flick, I though that this "re-imagining" would be at least visually better than the original film. Well, it's not. The new makeup is more complex than the appliances used in the firs film, but the apes are grotesque. Ari, for instance, has hilarious ape features, and so David Warner's character. The problem, I think, is the "realistic" sculpture of the masks, made by Rick Baker. I don't know if "realism" is a good choice in a movie called "Planet of the Apes". The general concept is quite bizarre, and realism can make things even worse.In the original, the characters looked like apes, but had a more sophisticated appeal, a noble aspect. It's very difficult to achieve this balance, and perhaps it explains why the makeup of the new "Planet" wasn't nominated for an Oscar. Add to that a bunch of apes running like rabbits, "primitive" humans that think and talk like evolved humans and poor sets, and you have a natural looser. But what really upset me about this film is the title: it should be "THE VISITOR", as Burton had originally envisioned. "THE VISITOR" is more accurate in the sense that the movie is a "re-imagining", not a remake.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>Apeing the classics.Even the few special effects and the tolerable makeup (unless you're wearing it) aren't up to snuff. The acting is barely sufficient to carry the undemanding plot: all that was required was to update the 1968 original with the current state of the art: and I mean ART. The only good idea in the film is the casting of Charlton Heston, who starred in the original.The remake's finale is worrisome with its latent opening for a sequel: let's hope it never does come about -- but as the saying goes, monkey see, monkey do.If someone from the film industry actually reads these comments, I would love to hear an explanation of how a scene with four-handed apes outrunning four-hoofed horses makes it through the final editing. Maybe this will become clearer in "Planet of the Horses," where the noble steeds take over the world mounted on very fast apes that run on all fours. Director Tim Burton demonstrated his genius with "Big Fish": one movie per species should suffice.</fullReview>

		<date>2004-06-21</date>
		<username>bjorn-5</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>Deeply flawed but beautifully made</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I'm ambivalent about which of the two is more significant: It's a beautiful movie, but the story has more holes than swiss cheese.I was impressed by the production values: the makeup, sets, editing, and such. I'm less sure about the costumes. (Most outfits appear to look like they're made primarily from vinyl.) In many ways, it's visually stunning. A lot of the things they did with ape culture, modes of expression, even movement were very creative. Though some turned out silly, like the "running".The acting was, on balance, pretty good. Some of the characters were preposterous (even ignoring the ape makeup), but in particular Tim Roth and (in stark contrast) Paul Giamatti were amazing in their roles. In some sense, just the variety of personalities shown in the apes was impressive.But the story had holes in it bigger than the ones the spaceships flew through. While I understand that it's a fantasy, rather than SF, given the "auteur", the inconsistencies in the plot, if you will, were too much for me. I can suspend disbelief for the big things, but the details are too much to handle. (Some of these questions may be spoilers.) How did the apes become masters of vinyl-making, when they can't produce a decent knife? Where did the horses come from? And for that matter, where were the gorillas from? Their "escape route" from the city was laughable. The climactic battle was *terrible*! And the "twist" at the ending evoked more stupefied laughter than awed thrill.Maybe upon repeated viewing, I can gloss over these flaws, but I don't think so.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2004-02-19</date>
		<username>zimbo_the_donkey_boy</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>racist?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I just watched this on tv. I agree with the earlier comments rating this as mediocre and illogical at every turn (within the bounds of the fantastic premise of course.) I haven't read most of the 1238! comments but don't see any bringing up an aspect which jumped out at me. __ To digress, I was stunned to see that, when the film Ghost Busters was turned into a tv cartoon series, Aykroyd's &amp; Murray's characters were transferred not unlike the originals but Ernie Hudson, the one black ghost buster, was replaced by an ape! Planet of the Apes strikes me the same way. __ I'm white and do not presume to speak for blacks but I cannot see how this movie, with only one token black human surrounded by otherwise entirely white humanity, can avoid coming off as comparing blacks to simians. Yes, I realize that this flick is presenting a lame, elementary-school-level case for liberalism. I do not however see that as negating the fact that, while the film repeatedly instructs us that slavery is bad and that intolerance is bad, the humans are basically purely white, which means that the other set of characters (the apes) must represent blacks. __ A weak claim is made that humans enslaved apes and now, after turnabout, apes have enslaved humans. The problem with that is that humans do not use apes as slaves. Hmm, who did whites used to enslave if not apes? Blacks. So then, if this society represents a reversal of our own, who must the apes represent? Blacks. __ Other fantasy films successfully make the desired point by either having characters of different colors or races on both sides, thus pointing out that intolerance is not inherently caused by racial difference, or by having characters with cultural differences which in no way resemble actual ethnic or racial groups. I am in no way saying that the apes in this film resemble actual blacks but I am saying that some of the characteristics (besides their ability to ignore the laws of physics) they exhibit are exactly how bigots used to make fun of blacks. __ Am I the only one here who was alive before the civil rights movement and thus what I'm talking about is totally foreign to the rest of your experiences? Please explain to me how I am reading things wrong, if I am.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Not as good as the original of course, but...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>In comparison to the original this remake suffers but because the source material is so strong, I found it to still be a more than worthwhile viewing experience. The makeup, props, special effects, settings, choreography, and sheer attention to detail are all first class as befitting a film of this scale and budget. However, while the entire supporting cast, especially Tim Roth, is very convincing and in fact is superlative in its performance, the star Mark Wahlberg never convinced me he was in this fantastic situation that almost defied description. He almost seemed 'ho hum' about it! Also in this version the underlying themes of ethics and philosophy and even the sheer sense of adventure and discovery seem to have been overshadowed by a more a conventional 'action movie' approach. Still the movie is marvelously entertaining, 7/10.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2003-11-28</date>
		<username>manalone923</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Tim Roth is great...Not worth the fierce hatred it's gotten, but still just average</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I'll state right off that this is a prime example of the burning backlash that resonated after this film's release: The Oscar for Best Makeup went to A Beautiful Mind. Apes wasn't even nominated!!! A SPECIAL Oscar was created for the original!!!And that's a problem. The costuming and, especially makeup, in the 2001 Apes is absolutely marvelous. But people nowadays just seem to despise the film, and Burton himself for having directed it. But this is not deserved, although I'll express my problems with it.The story in a nutshell resembles the original: A lone astronaut crashes on a planet ruled by talking apes, and must survive their prejudice against him. But whereas the original had a deeply philisophical plot and dialogue to provoke thought, the 2001 remake is little more than a glamorized chase scene, running too long.I believe Mark Whalberg is a fine actor, evidenced in films like Boogie Nights and the Yards. But here as main character Leo Davidson, he has little to do besides look awed and run away. Literally. There are some lines here and there suggesting what could have been deeper thoughts, but for the most part it's just plot city: React to the apes, run from them, find shelter, rally to defeat said apes. And the worst part is that the rest of the human characters are a mixed bag of nobodies, equivalent to what I call the "Shirts" of Star Trek lore. You know them, they're the extras who get killed defending the heroes whose names we actually know. Giving the humans the ability to speak does nothing more than hand them the chance to rebel more vocally. There's no explanation for why they can speak, and it doesn't really matter that they can. And worse, the fact that the apes are used to human speech takes away from one of the most powerful moments and subsequent scenes of the superior original, which of course is where Chuck Heston speaks for the first time.That does remind me of the fact that although there are a few too many silly puns (as with the original as well, to be fair), the opportunity to reference the original is met successfully too. Heston's famous line is mirrored by an ape this time, as is his famous last line from the first film. In fact Heston himself appears in a role built in irony: Not only does he play an ape this time around, but he also condemns the evil capacity of a gun, which must have made some of his NRA pals a little miffed.Aside from some fun moments like that, the movie's redeemable aspect is, of course, the apes themselves. Using the aforementioned excellent makeup, the actors in ape costume can now emote with the best of them. They snarl, sneer, smile, and speak mostly clearly. No more muffled sounds coming from the almost duck bill appliances that the 60's actors had to work with. The apes MOVE like apes too, loping about, running on all fours, using their feet to hold things. If the movie focused more on them and far, far less on the throwaway humans, the movie would have been much more enjoyable.What I did like, or rather love about the film, was Tim Roth. I saw the film in the theater multiple times, directly due to Roth's portrayal of the cruel main ape, General Thade. This character absolutely lit up the screen when he was on, delivering lines with the cruel ferocity and impatience of a madman just brimming over with contempt. He has passionate, naziesque hatred of the human race, and makes it no secret that he longs to exterminate them in any way possible. Roth chews the scenery and loves every minute of it, and it surely makes for the most entertaining part of the film. He swaggers, swings, and essentially becomes the most believable portrayal of a primate that I've ever seen. My favorite scene in the film is when he grabs Whalberg's leg from under him, tripping him onto the floor with a crash without even looking at the human. He then jerks Whalberg up and bends him over his lap, to pry open his mouth and look inside to see if a soul exists. Satisfied that he sees nothing, he pitches Whalberg back onto the floor without looking, as one would do to a piece of wadded paper being tossed aside. It's good, energetic stuff, and gives the film a very dark edge that the original didn't quite have.I've established that the film consisted mainly of scenes with Whalberg and other humans running, escaping, and otherwise walking away from the ape city and any other real interest. Now for the ending..I won't spoil it, but I must say this. The original film had one of the best shock twist ending in history, and was a very tough act to follow. This time around, there are two main twists, none very adequately explained or built up to, and at the end the viewer isn't left with awe but rather a shrug, as he ostensibly thinks "some of that was cool, but the ending was pretty lame and / or confusing." And since Tim Burton said he'd rather jump out of a window than direct another Apes movie, we'll probably never have a follow up.That's sad, considering that this movie WAS entertaining, but not really done right. The apes were very interesting, but at the sake of the expendable human characters. I left feeling as though the raw power and fierceness of the apes was represented, but not enough. And if the movie focused more on them, as I'd said, it would've been more entertaining. But I admit there would've been less story and conflict as well, so what can you do? Now if only General Thade was in it way more....Ahh, yeah.In closing, I found it a fun but disposable film. The original is still better and a way more engaging, thought-provoking film. The 2001 remake is kind of a more short-attention span flash-fest, with some fun stuff here and there but not much more to sustain your interest after a couple viewings. The makeup, costumes and scenery were great, and Tim Roth's General Thade was a blast. But past that, not too much to sustain interest. But I do maintain that it wasn't the horrifying, joke-and-cringe inducing wreck of flames that pop culture might be saying it is. Decide for yourself, but whatever you do don't blame Burton entirely. The man's done some great work, and he honestly tried. Besides, he didn't write the much-rewritten finished script.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Mediocre film, but succeeds in doing what it was made to.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I say. This movie, while poorly written, acted, and for the most part, executed, was entertaining and though provoking.Many of the reviewers don't realize that the movie is NOT a remake by any means, and obviously doesnt pretend to be judging by the fact that the plot is almost entirely different, and any messege the film tries to get across to the viewer is also quite different.The purpose of the film is to confuse and disorient the viewer and make them sit through the credits with a perplexed look on his or her face. The ending is much too bizzare to make any conceivable sense, and not even the director could clearly explain it.Though it falls short when it comes to the script and acting, the pace of the film is sporadic, and its clear that Tim Burton didnt give it his all, this is not a bad movie. Its an entertaining film that succeeds in doing what it was meant to. I give it a 7 out of 10.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2003-07-04</date>
		<username>JasonJayDelmonico</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Tim Burton Goes Mainstream</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Final Score: 7.0 (out of 10)With 'Planet of the Apes' (2001) and 1999's 'Sleepy Hollow' iconoclastic director Tim Burton seems to have been drifting toward the mainstream lately. This after forging a solid carrier on gothic, post-modern and often anti-climactic movies where Burton rejected all Hollywood conventions of pleasing an audience. Of the two, 'Sleepy Hollow' is more fun and more exciting. 'Planet of the Apes', taken on it's own right, is not a bad movie - if you accept that it's content to being just another mindless summer popcorn flick. It's a fun diversion for someone wanting to just sit back and stare at the screen (that is a compliment even though it doesn't sound like one).The movie looks great. It's probably his best looking movie. The makeup, costumes, stunts, cinematography, everything looks good. Which really helped pump up the entertainment (and the final score) when the script is giving us silly puns and 1-liners obviously designed be used in the trailer. The highlight: one of Danny Elfman's best scores since 'Men in Black'. He and Burton give this one a more "techno" look and sound then the other films. The movie is worth seeing just for Danny Elfman fans (which I am). The low-point: Mark Walburg's wooden acting. It's mostly because of this movie and actors like him that I divided up my 'Acting' category to score in two different sections: one for the Lead and one for the Supporting Players. Because while Walburg drags down the action, Helena Bonham Carter and Tim Roth are really giving their all behind those Ape costumes. Roth's rants and raves make for a great villain. Lastly, I loved the ending. It's the best part of the movie. I like the epic imagery of the final shot. I like the fact that it's open-ended enough to send the viewer scratching their head as to it's meaning. And I like how Burton has thrown in hints and lines of logic here and there (Lincoln "freed the slaves") to send us on that journey for a meaning- even if there isn't one. Try to follow me on this (my explination is not the best): This is the type of enigmatic ending people want when they see what they think is an otherwise brilliant movie "fall apart" or get "conventional" in the end by resolving itself (Signs, 28 Days Later, ect.). When a movie is mysterious people aren't happy with any ending. This is an ending that doesn't really end anything. Truly "open to interpretation". But this is coming from someone who doesn't think there is anything cinematically sacrilegious about remaking 'Planet of the Apes'. It was a movie for it's time and place and I get it's campy cult following, but a cinema classic to high and mighty to be remade? Hardly. It could be done and it could be done much better. The problem is that this movie will be remembered more for what it isn't then what it is. Burton and his writers had a chance to take this creatively fertile premise and really do something different with it - show us something edgy, that we've never seen before. It would seem like Burton would be a perfect fit for a PofA remake- well, the old Tim Burton. Yet, he does nothing different here. Instead of telling his own story he just remakes the original film sticking pretty close to it's existing framework but coloring in the lines with a glossier hue. As a result the movie isn't much better or worse then the original film - and it isn't helped by it's built-in lack of originality and clear reliance on the original film. I think, the only solid improvement Burton's film has is making the Apes more "ape-like". The imagery of them charging across the desert on all fours is a fleeting glance at how visionary, freaky and wonderfully twisted this movie could have been.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2003-07-02</date>
		<username>Andrew DiMonte (NoArrow)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Wow, the apes really need some prozak!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I know, the apes being villains, that they're not supposed to be the nicest of characters, but isn't it a little unrealistic that EVERY SINGLE ONE OF THEM walks around all day grunting and growling? The only apes in this remake that aren't mad all the time are Ari (Helena Bonham Carter) and Limbo (Paul Giammatti), and that's only because Ari is the "hero ape woman" and Limbo the comic relief. Of course, the humans in "Planet of the Apes" aren't really any better. They're either really nervous all of the time, or really angry. Maybe if both races calmed down a little, they'd have some peace!Aside from the prozak prescription, this was a reasonable remake. Not Burton's best, not by far, but his directing it makes it a lot better. The fight scenes are entertaining, and Tim Roth delivers as the evil General Thade. Unfortunately, Roth is the only actor who delivers a great performance. Sure, the others weren't bad, but they didn't match Roth's ability to basically "become the ape". Even Oscar nominee Michael Clarke Duncan moves a little roboticly sometimes.Still, a good, dark sci-fi thriller, 7.5/10.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>The planet or the movie?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Oh dear! This is the kind of venture that gives Hollywood a bad name.Talented people making a total dud of a movie. The original POTA was a great adventure movie with an interesting Sci-Fi premise. This version, however,is bleak, violent and muddled.The plot holds little of interest and many of the scenes are in darkness and simply unpleasant in tone. Mark Wahlberg must be the least charismatic leading-man of his generation and he annoys throughout.Danny Elfman's score is loud ,intrusive and headache-inducing. The ending is a bit of a mystery and countless geeks have speculated endlessly on this. However, by the time the ending came I didn't really care about this movie and its characters. Remakes can be done well but their very existence and the number of them indicate the lack of ideas in Hollywood.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2003-02-21</date>
		<username>silverzero</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Mediocre and mildly disappointing remake which lacks imagination.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Tim Burton's remake of Planet of the Apes is a very disappointing addition to his other films. Having seen Batman, Beetlejuice and Mars Attacks! I am surprised to see this unwelcome addition to his list. To be fair though, this is probably his first mediocre film. Its not a disaster and it has its good moments, but there's not enough fresh material in it to make it very memorable. Mark Wahlberg is the film's `hero' but the role really doesn't suit him. While in films like Boogie Nights and The Yards he had good supporting players, in Planet of the Apes he just can't carry the role. On the other hand, Tim Roth is very moody in his role as Thade, the film's menace. Helena Bonham Carter is good as the female monkey with a heart, but the make-up is unconvincing. Most of the other performances are standard but nothing award-winning. The film's direction is surprisingly bland giving Burton's usual atmospheric style. There has been a lot of controversy about the ending. I for one liked it and although it was a big surprise, I thought it was very clever. Overall, Planet of the Apes isn't a bad movie, but it could have been much better. It's good fodder for the eyes but after watching it, you'll probably forget about it straight away. 5.3 out of 10.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2003-01-31</date>
		<username>DaveBass</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Some Ramblings</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>CAUTION SPOILERS WITHINHaving just viewed this film last night, it is fresh in my mind and I wanted to make a few observations. Not a review per se, just some thoughts.Although flawed, it does have a few good things going for it. Rick Baker's work is truly amazing. The flexibility of the masks/make up used allows the actors to produce varied, expressive and very believable expressions. Nicely done.Most of the art direction and costume design is creative and well implemented. The ape army is cleverly and boldly realized.The acting, overall, is good, and especially in the case of Tim Roth, David Warner, Michael Duncan, &amp; Helena Bonham Carter. They help create believable, if somewhat two dimensional characters. The lovely Estella Warren does fine in an underwritten role.Danny Elfman's creative score, effectively covers a wide variety of moods ranging through suspense, comedy and militaristic combat themes quite well.And then there's the other side of the coin, an at times interesting, but largely wooden formula driven plot, with dialog suffering from a bad case of pun infestation.A few things that don't work:At no time did I get the feeling that Captain Leo Davidson (Wahlberg) was all that surprised or impressed that he had discovered a culture where apes could talk, and ran the planet. It was sort of like `hmmm, that's odd, talking apes in charge of the world, hey look over there, we don't have oak trees like that on earth, this is INSANE!'And then the escape from the ape city, whose route cleverly goes right through the center of about a half dozen ape houses, `we'll keep running through these houses until we find the forest, its got to be around here somewhere. Once we've checked all the houses we'll start searching for the forest outside.'What's up with people (and apes) flying twenty feet or more through the air when they are struck by any ape (not just the gorillas), not occasionally, but everytime? The great strength of apes? It would happen on earth. Lower gravity? Then apes would fly when humans struck them. Lots of stuntmen with springboards? Maybe.And then there's that one scene that just defies any logic, and I'm not talking about the `surprise ending'. Its when Captain Leo, wins the battle, brings a new understanding and compassion between apes and humanity, finds himself as the leader of a new world order, and then immediately hops in the space pod to return to earth. WHAT??? I mean, what's the hurry? He knows his crew have been dead for thousands of years, he's just won this planet's version of the Superbowl, the Nobel prize, and been elected President, clearly Estella Warren wants to jump his bones, and even Helena Bonham Carter's Ari is obviously intent on more advanced and exotic interspecies research. Even if he chooses not to lead this world through a new political, cultural &amp; scientific revolution, how about taking some time to smell the roses, you know, a few weeks to gather scientific samples to bring back, to help advance anthropology by studying cross cultural (and species) mating rituals, to work at turning his space pod into a two seater, or to even bring extra food and water for what is likely to be a long and possibly fatal journey? I just don't get it.Worth seeing and entertaining, even for its flaws.Six out of ten stars.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>Sample (sampleman411@earthlink.net)</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Monkey See, Monkey Do</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Almost everyone involved in the making of this movie is to be lauded for their individual creative efforts; this much is certain... great costumes, props, makeup, etc.My only problem with the end result of POTA is its emphasis on action, and very little attention to the human vs. ape and mankind philosophies so aptly and dramatically demonstrated in the original 1968 film on which the "reimagined" 2001 Tim Burton movie was partly based (The screenwriters who worked on this one also pulled information from Pierre Boulle's short sci-fi novel "Monkey Planet.").True, everything made nowadays must have one sense-throttling, action packed sequence strung almost imperceptibly to the next, never stopping to look at the wondrous 'flower' that made the 1968 film so unique. The original film was nature vs man, evolution alongside devolution, and an overall downward spiral towards mankind's oblivion (or pretty much the next worst thing, anyway, since people aren't totally extinct by the time the main character crash lands on either eponymous planet).The best things in the 2001 remake are the handful of pop references made first in the original movie, the references to modern (some 21st Century) attitudes ("I'm having a bad hair day," says one female chimp in Burton's version), and the overall upgraded feel and tone of the movie now that more than thirty-three years have elapsed in the world of cinema.Its a given to say that special-effects are a boon to this new, improved version. Yet, I miss hearing all that (somewhat) great dialog heard in POTA 1968.Everyone I know who's seen the Burton version has mentioned something about its ending, and the questions it poses. Let us all hope Simos (the name of the simian deity in this film) answers our inquisitive, and slightly confused, prayers in a rational manner... ...and will there be an even more confusing sequel to this reimagination?</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-04-29</date>
		<username>GPL</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>Infused with political undercurrent.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>There's only one thing worse than paying $8.50 for a movie that has an axe to grind: a movie with APES doing the axe-grinding.It's hard enough to suspend one's disbelief and get into this whole farce based, essentially, on Darwinistic evolution (which in itself is nothing more than ideological dogma, rather than anything truly scientific). But to believe, in a "relativistic universe," where we all supposedly evolved by pure chance without intelligent design nor moral purpose, a BEAST like an ape is going to develop a moral sense and espouse a knowledge of "right and wrong" (where this came from is never stated) is just laughable. And this is almost how the movie comes off.I would have been more able to suspend my disbelief had the apes--ALL the apes, been truly beasts. It would have been horrific and been, FINALLY, this remake's only shot at equalling (let alone improving over) its 1968 original by creating a more potent nightmare. Instead, it tries to re-create the original's formula--as if any of us would still be "oh'd" by the notion that this "actually could happen."Been there, done that.So, instead of exploiting the truly hellish potential of this concept, we are constantly reminded that this is a remake. No risks are taken. No opportunity missed to "sensitize our political ignorance" (thanks, Ms. Ape). For lessons on creating a masterful (read 'believable') science-fiction world, the makers should have studied Ridley Scott's ALIEN and BLADE RUNNER, or Cameron's TERMINATOR series.</fullReview>
	</review>

The part wasn't written terribly interesting (but think Sean Connery, John Wayne, Jimmy Stewart - a talented actor can *make* a part interesting). Doing a lot of standing around and staring, occasionally broken up by some moving around and staring, won't breathe life into a part.And when he did do something or speak, I found his character unsympathetic and centerless.Now, I didn't think much about the original while watching, because I think such comparisons are unfair and usually irrelevant. The movie could have been a lot of fun.</fullReview>

		<date>2002-03-30</date>
		<username>maxshreck</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Disappointing.......</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>When I heard that Tim Burton was doing a remake of the '68 classic,I (like any other Burton fan) was very excited at the prospect. I never thought that the original needed remaking, nor that it could be bettered (the twist ending, along with the Usual Suspects, is one of the best I have EVER seen), but nevertheless, I thought that, if anyone, Burton could put his own fresh, dark spin on the idea. However, the whole thing gave an impression of a Burton being constricted by studio bosses hungry to chock up another Summer hit by throwing in everything including the kitchen sink- check out the extras-filled DVD if ya don't believe me. Nice idea, wrong director. Burton is unparalleled for his alternative-style movies like the classic Edward Scissorhands. Here it felt like he was on a leash, his creativity tragically stunted.The make-up effects weren't much of an improvement on those of 1968, which only serves to highlight the superiority of the original. The acting, well, apart from those who were struggling under their ape-suits(Roth,Bonham-Carter,Clarke-Duncan), was poor- I agree with another reviewer who said that Wahlberg wasn't yet strong enough to carry off an action lead, and as for Estella Warren, well, I think we all know that she was only there to provide some Raquel Welch-style eye candy. The music,from the always dependable Elfman,was superb. The ending: lets face it, it was always going to be compared to the original's which, if not impossible, would be pretty damned hard to better. The ending to Burton's felt silly and tacked on,and smacked of an overall air of "please, be shocked!" whereas it actually only left punters scratching their heads and looking for refunds.If you're curious, wait until the video rental price drops down. If not a Burton or sci-fi fan steer well clear.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>a nice try</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The revision "Planet of the Apes" pretty much lived up to my expectations as a not-too-good nice try. 	<review>
		<date>2002-03-29</date>
		<username>San Franciscan</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Not as bad as you might think (and the ending DOES make sense!).</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I have been a Tim Burton admirer long before most others have (*I* first discovered him through one of his very first animated shorts, "Vincent", shown on The Disney Channel in 1984!). I've enjoyed a lot of his work--especially "Edward Scissorhands", which I feel is his best--and also have been bored silly by a bit of some of his other stuff ("Mars Attacks!"). I got a kick out of "Ed Wood", enjoyed "Beetlejuice" and was delighted by "Sleepy Hollow" and "The Nightmare Before Christmas" since they both seemed to be a return to his more traditional style.This film is by no means a match for the original 1968 masterpiece, but that doesn't mean it's not interesting or fun to watch. In fact, it's more interesting than I expected it to be. Sure, it's just treading water, but what redeemed it in my eyes and earned more respect in me for the script's concept than I otherwise would have had is the ingenious and wildly misunderstood ending.I'm not a huge POA fan, but that doesn't mean I don't admire it. While the original films were simply too dark, cynical and terrifying for me as a child, I admired them very much for their great intentions--that is, to use a sci-fi story as a metaphor for prejudice, intolerance and class problems (basically reminding us all that treating others as less than ourselves lowers us to the level of wild animals instead of beings with the ability and intelligence to treat each other with love, dignity and respect).My main complaint here is "Marky Mark". Lousy actor. He reminds me of Madonna skimping her way through such flicks as "Body of Evidence" and "Shanghai Surprise". He simply can't communicate emotion. Charlton Heston was wonderful as Taylor, a man who begins his dark tale as a cynical jerk who gets a taste of his own I-can't-stand-people-and-think-they're-no-good medicine and comes to realize that his attitude was the same one that led to the nightmarish situation he now faces. In this new version, Leo Davidson is simply bland and almost gives the impression that he's gotten himself as stoned out of his mind as possible just to avoid dealing with his dilemma. This makes it hard for the audience to identify with him, but even so the story's idea is so strong with its ending being so effectively jarring (even when trapped in a cornball script) that it can be frightening in its own right.Which brings me to the twist ending. Before I explain it, I just want to mention something: after reading all the comments both on here and made by paid critics, I am genuinely amazed as a writer how little people pay attention to the finer details of scripts! I guess the modern attention span of folks is so limited that such important details sprinkled throughout the story are lost unnoticed these days (a good example: Roger Ebert's comment that "all the apes' varieties don't make sense considering the film's logic"--YES, THEY DO! Look carefully in the beginning of the film and you will SEE WHY!).Tim Burton and his writers created the ending *VERY CAREFULLY*, and it is NOT--I repeat, *N*O*T*--just "tacked on"! All you need to do is pay attention, use logic and imagination to realize the gaps, and you will see that it is NOT really just some cheap setup for a sequel. In fact, going by the film's logic there isn't really any NEED for one, as the film stands on its own in its entirety!As if in outraged retaliation to the public's criticizing the finale, the videotape and DVD versions of this film contain a featurette re-showing various scenes and saying, "Watch carefully for clues that lead to the explanation of the surprise ending!" It further goes on to say that, just in case you are still too dense to get it, more information is further available on the movie's official webpage.***WARNING: MAJOR SPOILER AHEAD!***After seeing this film, I was easily able to guess what must have happened. I was delighted to find the info I've mentioned above on the internet later on and discover my theory to be correct!What basically happened in a nutshell was this: Thade was bloodthirsty for revenge (remember, he was never killed in the movie) and learned all about space travel through the information contained in the Oberon, salvaged and repaired Leo's ship, then attempted to pursue him through space and time. When Thade reached earth after following him through the temporal storm, he had arrived before Leo did. In vengeance, Thade set out to disrupt Leo's world the way that Leo had disrupted Thade's own. He led a rebellion of the apes and disrupted it into what we saw at the end of the movie before Leo's arrival.It would appear that Burton wanted a portion of his film to be the same way that such new films as "The Blair Witch Project" are... meaning, films that must also be experienced over the internet and through various other provided sources alongside the movie in order to completely understand them! In other words, asking the audience to use their intelligence instead of spoonfeeding all the information to them! Very ingenious. And different, too!That said, I for one am very impressed.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-03-22</date>
		<username>Nahret (centralcommand@cardassia.ch)</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>Not all that bad. But sadly, not good, either.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>There are two kinds of remakes: one, where people, for whatever reason, think, they should redo a film in the same way it's already been done before. Vertigo and Vanilla Sky come to mind. Then there's the idea of taking a premise of a movie and see what you would make of it. Tim Burton's Planet of the Apes falls into that latter category. As such, I will not compare it to the earlier movies. Sadly, it manages to under-deliver all of its own. It's the last half hour that ruins it for me. Until that point, I was entertained. The apes all look individual and very good. Although they go over the top in demonstrating the hideous conditions in which humans are kept, around 80% of films about social injustice go even further (Mad Max, anyone?). The action was fine, and, considering the genre, made a sufficient amount of sense. Apart from that, Tim Burton is one of my favourite directors, so it couldn't be all that bad, could it? Well, let's see.Spoilers ahead. Then, of course, they had to go for the happy-ending-that-isn't. How Attar was so easily convinced of Thade's treason, I'll never know. Just because a monkey - sorry, prophet - landed at the right moment, in the right spot? Speaking of which, what a prodigious coincidence! Give me a break.What really did it for me was the "shock-ending". Wasn't the guy going BACK in time? Does the Apeworld run on Anti-time (as seen in Star Trek TNG, All Good Things...)? Yes, we knew it could not end well. But we hoped it would at least make some degree of sense. Is that too much to ask?</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-03-21</date>
		<username>taikman</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Good, if you expect a standard action-science fiction tale, but not nearly up to the original</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>For those who haven't seen the original, this is a 'reimagining', which means that it shares some elements of the classic version but not others. Basically the stories involve a spaceman who lands on a planet where the barbaric humans are controlled by intelligent apes. This version is a good film, entertaining and with a surprising ending, but it lacks the punch and depth of the first edition.Tim Burton is my favourite director. 'Bettlejuice', 'Edward Scissorhands', the first two Batman films, 'Sleepy Hollow' - all excellent: macabre, gothic and filled with black humour. 'Apes' also looks great - the sets are spectacular and the makeup is amazing: the apes truly look real. What the film lacks is some of Burton's darker, slightly disturbing touches. It plays too much like a straight action/sci-fi flick, whereas the original was a powerful allegory for racism and animal rights as well as great entertainment.One of the reasons why the latter film doesn't match up to the original's power is because all the human characters talk. In the original the human's mysterious silence added to the theme of 'men as beasts'. Here that impact is gone, but they might as well not have bothered - the humans still have nothing interesting to say. It's the apes that have all the good lines and characterisation.Also, the ending of the original 'Apes' is one of the greatest in movie history, resonating with meaning, whereas this version's finale feels like a tacked-on surprise designed to set up sequels.The other main reason why the orginal is superior is that Mark Wahlberg lacks Charlton Heston's macho charisma in the role of the heroic spaceman. Heston was cynical, angry, confused. Wahlberg is bland.Nevertheless 'Planet of the Apes' is is a good movie, a cut above the average Hollywood science fiction film. However if I was given a choice of renting the original or the new version in a few years, I know which one I'd chose.6 1/2/10</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>Bobnessuk</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>...and the kitchen sink</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I've just watched this film on DVD. You know the one. Two DVD's worth which seems to incorporate every thing including the colour of the kitchen sink they used. Isn't it scary that this shows that they seemed to have taken everything into account except the script?I followed this ?reworking' up the point where the Space introduction ended and we ended up on ?The Planet of the Apes' and it was about here I realised how poor the film was.As a basic example; in the original, at least it had the sense to say that the reason society had evolved the way it had was because the humans were at the Stone Age level where they hadn't even developed the capacity of speech. As a result the apes had evolved faster than them and were able to dominate them. This reworking didn't even bother to do that. I don't think I'm being too pedantic by saying, if the humans could speak why were they still wandering around like caveman? It seems such a fundamental flaw to the plot, I felt it rather insulting to my intelligence.Then again, so many things seem to suggest that the script was written by a bunch of precocious High School students. As someone else has pointed out in these reviews; it's full of quotes from the original - including the famous `Damn them all to Hell!' ? which have absolutely no relevance to the current movie. You can almost see the writers of this thing sniggering behind their hands saying `I know, wouldn't it be cool if we put this line in!'The DVD shows they spent months on getting the make-up right, the movements of the apes right, etc. etc?we even had a very boring documentary about how much effort Danny Elfman put into writing this score, but who was looking at the story? Were the people behind this movie too frightened to say to Tim Burton because he's such a `visionary genius' that the film didn't make any sense?I dunno, what does it matter? This film was a commercial success so it must be good. The only small mercy I can think of is that that, once upon a time, Tim Burton seemed the obvious choice to visualise `Lord of the Rings'. After seeing this movie, thank goodness he didn't.</fullReview>

Skip this and watch reruns of FARSCAPE on the telly - far more entertaining. And why *is* Mark Wahlberg a movie star, anyway? The chimp astronaut had more charisma than Markie Mark.</fullReview>

		<date>2002-01-12</date>
		<username>campboy_tc</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>A curate's egg</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>For those not familiar with that expression, it dates from a 'Punch' cartoon of 1895, where a nervous curate is breakfasting with his bishop.Bishop: I'm afraid you've got a bad egg, Mr Jones.Curate: Oh, no, my Lord, I assure you that parts of it are excellent!So, parts of Tim Burton's 'Planet of the Apes' are excellent. The lifelike and varied ape makeup, combined with the effort that has gone into making the apes... well, apes, and more individual than the oppressed humans can manage to be, makes their society utterly believable. Helena Bonham Carter delicately brings out the character of Ari, shewing us that a full face prosthesis need not handicap a great actress, and Tim Roth camps it up completely as Thade (which you may not think is a good point).On to the bad parts. Mark Wahlberg does nothing to arouse my sympathy, or indeed interest. It doesn't help that his character is halfway between James T Kirk and Dorothy from the Wizard of Oz, and does not develop at all throughout the film. The plot is stupid, ridiculous and yet utterly predictable, and forces characters to act unrealistically. The eventual resolution is contrived and unsatisfying, it gives no extra depth to anything, in fact, it seems to be the only way the writers could think of to finish off the plot. The ending is tacked-on and inconsistent.I would recommend avoiding this film unless you really have nothing better to do, and no expectations of intelligence. But stylistically it's worth something, and Helena Bonham Carter's performance is worth adding a couple of marks, so reluctantly, i give it 4 out of 10.</fullReview>
	</review>

The original was very politically charged and had a philosophy behind. This remake was a pure action flick, no deep thoughts here. Tim Burton is as always an excellent director so the movie is visually pleasant to watch. The ending wasnt too good. I can see the idea behind it but it failed miserably and just left a bad aftertaste. While it really has nothing to do with the original movie (except apes that talk and rule the humans), it is really hard not to compare them two while watching the movie. 		<date>2001-12-17</date>
		<username>ericjg623</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>Style over substance</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This movie has great looks, the apes (with a few exceptions) really look apelike, you've got lush jungles, deserts, big, action packed fight scenes, and a whole ape city that looks totally realistic. Director Tim Burton wasted no expense or effort to make this a visual feast. Too bad he didn't put the same effort into creating a terrific story, especially since there was so much potential to work with. The 1968 original is considered a Sci-Fi classic, not just because of the story, but also the issues it dealt with. It used a society where apes are the top species to comment on and satirize our own society. There are moments of this in "Apes 2001", but mostly it's another big budget action film, only with actors in monkey costumes. As proof of this, the lead character, played by Mark Wahlberg (aka Marky Mark) is just another hotshot fighter jock, meaning there's no problem he thinks he can't solve by simply blasting the bad guy to bits. Which is a shame, since it would be much more interesting to see him outwit his enemies, thus showing who really was the superior species. Also, it doesn't help that the female lead, played by Helena Bonham Carter, doesn't even remotely look like a real chimp. I guess Burton &amp; Co. couldn't resist making her look sexy, complete with a fashionable hairstyle. So, ultimately what you have is lots of good looks, but not much in the way of brains. I'm looking forward to viewing the 1968 original, just to see how this film falls short by comparison. 5/10</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Liked it but didn't love it</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>My main beef with this flick was the lack of dialogue between Mark Wahlberg's character and the apes where he tries to convince them he is smart. That is what I remember mostly about the original; Charlton Heston was desperate to prove he was intelligent. I remember just feeling helpless concerning his plight, and aching for him to succeed. I would have felt the exact same way had that angle been explored more in this remake. Helena Bonham Carter's character doesn't go through that discovery, she believes in the intelligence of humans right away it seems. That fact alone made this version of "Planet of the Apes" far inferior to the original. Instead of just making it look more sleek, Tim Burton should have been more concerned with this thematic element, an element that in my opinion made the original so compelling.</fullReview>

		<date>2001-12-13</date>
		<username>Chris Warren</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Typically Burton - huge on style, light on substance</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>First up, I'd like to say that I liked POTA. It is absolutely gorgeous to look at. The make-up, effects, cinematography, costumes and sets are all pretty hard to fault. On the acting front, Tim Roth is utterly fantastic as General Thade and he just about makes up for the price of admission on his own.So what's the problem? Well as much as I want Mark Wahlberg star to continue to rise, I just don't think he has the charisma to carry Charlton Heston's role. Not that he was bad or anything, his acting is fine and he is certainly a lot better looking than Chuck ever was. But is he really the brave and indignant leader of the human race who defies the apes and their dirty paws? Maybe he would have been better as the plucky young male that defiantly chases after the hero (read George Clooney) after being told to stay behind with the others?But in Mark's defence, I don't think replacing him would have necessarily made the film any more satisfying. This was a difficult film (conceptually) to make when you consider how highly the original is regarded. Do you just remake it with the same emphasis of script and story, or if you are going to do something different, what do you change?So Burton does what he does best and creates a film that emphasises style over story, and action over acting (or actors). It worked for Batman and I think it does for POTA. Time will tell after the franchise has come and gone whether people criticise "POTA Forever" as not holding a candle to Burton's original!Enjoyable: 7/10</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-12-12</date>
		<username>C.K. Dexter Haven</username>
		<score>0.3</score>
		<shortDescription>Planet of mockery!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>About 5 minutes in after the opening titles I knew this was going to be a criminal miscarriage of what could have been. Character exposition in the opening sequence was axed in order to bustle the hero (or lack of one) into the so-called action as soon as possible. What results is a woefully underdeveloped series of events thrusting us along on an adventure that is laughable and miserably cheap. Tim Burton's influences lay in many obscure and cheesy drive-in sci/fi movies and TV shows of the past (which he actually tries to pay homage to rather than satirize) and it's not surprising that this film plays like Lost in Space meets One Million Years BC meets Claude Rains' version of The Lost World meets Planet of the Apes. If Burton felt that people would be excited at the prospect of seeing his own self-indulgent vision of the Book and Heston's classic, full of gawdy touches typical of his style, he was badly mistaken. His realization of Batman was far more successful.When I first saw the commercials for this movie I was immediately taken. Images of marching Ape armies and the atmospheric visuals inspired hopes of a science Fiction action epic like no other. Spartacus conquers the Apes as it were. Sadly it was all window dressing and the truly best parts of this movie are ALL in the commercial spots. What we are subjected to is an unspeakably badly written visual feast which belies a very limited budget lurking just below the surface. The only reason to see this abomination is for the costumes and make-up design, as well as the production design (aside from the space station and space suits which look to have been stolen from the 2001 prop vault).The original planet of the apes is not one of my top ten favorite films but it is an honest and intelligent piece of science fiction. Though a bit of a talk fest, it does bring up some very thought provoking issues (thanks to the great Rod Serling) and ends on one of the most powerful and stunning climaxes in movie history. It's a film deserving of its classic status and rated a better remake than what Richard Zanuck and Tim Burton have foisted on us here. In fact, Zanuck should be fined and his producer's license suspended as he was also in involved in making the original.Any and all intellectual content is missing leaving us with good actors buried under mounds of make-up. Except for Wahlberg, who should have just been buried. This guy is the most vacant action hero since Keanu Reeves in Speed. Aside from disobeying commands in order to rescue his chimp, his motivations are unwritten, leaving him to loaf from one scene to the next muttering little more than "hey" or "what" or "whatever", while glancing more than periodically at his Tandy hand-held. The guy has the intelligence and personality of a soapsud. An actor with a grasp of dead-pan humor might have made this character zing. Wahlberg just sits there, looking constipated as another IMDb reviewer mentioned.As far as the other cast members are concerned, what is the deal with Kris Kristoffersen. He has two lines then gets run through with a spear. Estella Warren is atrocious as the obligatory female human. She's no Raquel Welch in the looks department and is an even worse actress. Helena Bonham-Carter is wasted, as is Tim Roth as Thade and Michael Clark Duncan as his Right-Hand Gorilla. One wonders why they hired big-name actors to be unrecognizable under all that latex when they could have hired medium priced actors and saved some money on the budget. Marquee power I guess. As good as he is, Michael Clark Duncan just sounds like the guy who played Worf in Star Trek.As far as Charlton Heston's uncredited cameo as Thade's father, spouting familiar lines he used to condemn the Apes in the original, though here in reversed context: maybe in another script, with a better director for the material, it would have been sly and humorous. Not here. The same goes for other memorable lines quoted from the original.Much has been debated about the ending, which is about the only pure Burtonian stamp on the movie. It has no relevance other than to set-up a sequel (would anyone care to see it?). It pays homage to Serling and is a twist on the original's shattering ending, but really it comes off more of a tribute to Marty's nightmare sequence in Back to the Future Part II than anything else.What we're left with here, in the wake of other deficient hack jobs such as U-571, The Patriot, Pearl Harbor, and How the Grinch Stole Christmas, is a clear message that a great deal of Hollywood no longer cares about providing their audience with a well written and performed production once their marketing machine has lured us into the theatres. If people keep falling for it it's going to end up sealing the end of quality entertainment for good.Here's hoping that The Lord of the Rings doesn't turn out to be a mishandled treatment of Tolkien with GREAT commercials.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2001-12-03</date>
		<username>Caps Fan</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>Not bad, but still a disappointment</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Pierre Boulle's original novel of apes ruling an earthlike planet is an absorbing and truly terrifying piece of science fiction. Unlike the 1968 film version with Charlton Heston, this film retains (an Americanized version of) the original ending, which actually works pretty well. There are good scenes along the way too, but somehow, the story just doesn't quite make it. Excellent performances by Helena Bonham Carter and Tim Roth shore it up a bit, as does the superb make-up. In the end, though, poorish special effects, unmemorable music, and a seeming indecision on the part of the filmmakers as to whether to stick with the original story or write one of their own mean this movie just doesn't work as it should. Watch it by all means, but a classic it is not.</fullReview>

		<username>makemyday</username>

		<username>spoko</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>What a waste.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This movie was disappointing in so many ways. As my wife put it, they had so much to work with, and they completely blew it. I don't even know where to begin with how disappointing this movie was.The action sequences were non-existent. Times when there should have been a good scene (like the horse-ride through the camp, which could have been really great) were very detached from the action, and consequently quite boring. Both the cinematography and the editing in such scenes were really, well, bad.The acting was stiff. I guess Burton was trying to do this whole thing where people actually moved like apes. But that was annoying. And they seem to have spent two or three times as much time and effort on that as they did on more typical (and effective) elements of acting--you know, emotions, character development, little things like that.The CGI was pretty transparent. When Marky Mark first lands and is standing in the forest looking around, for example, it's SO clear that he's in front of a bluescreen. Ugh. The makeup, on the other hand, was really well done.The score was stifled, I thought. But maybe it was just because it had nothing decent to accompany/illuminate.I expected more cool references to other movies. 2001 was a completely obvious allusion, for example, and they only made one (probably accidental) allusion to it--when Pericles is about to take off in the pod. They could really have done a lot of cool stuff with that--both on the planet and in space. So, what was good about the movie? The makeup, as I already mentioned. That's it, as far as I can recall. Enjoy.</fullReview>
	</review>

A human rights activist named Ari (Helana Bonham Carter) frees Leo and Daena (Estella Warren). They all escape with others and soon become hunted by General Thade (Tim Roth). The group reaches the sacred ruins of CALIMA, and have a huge all-out battle between the ape army and the humans.This movie has intense action sequences, amazing make-up, a good score, fair visual effects, and great directing. 	<review>
		<date>2001-11-28</date>
		<username>Dan Franzen (dfranzen70)</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>King Simian's Mines</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>In 1968, the world's fascination with outer space was still largely in the science-fiction realm. Sure, we'd put some men in space, but no one had landed on any foreign worlds. We imagined, through the voices of such authors as Arthur C. Clarke and Isaac Asimov, interstellar travel and advanced civilizations. But all of that seemed to be part of the distant future in 1968.Here were are 33 years later, and while we haven't traveled to other galaxies or met any other civilizations (advanced or otherwise, Whitley Strieber's experiences notwithstanding), we have put a man on the moon and are hard at work on the international space station. In short, in 33 years we've come a long way, baby.Anyone who has seen the original 1968 Planet of the Apes knows that the ending is a real kicker. I certainly won't give it away here, because there's an entire generation that hasn't seen the movie and most certainly should. Suffice to say that the original is unique, not simply another sci-fi flick.The new one is termed a "rethinking" of the original. Tim Burton, who gave us Edward Scissorhands, Batman, PeeWee's Big Adventure, and Sleepy Hollow,is the director here, and the film is full of his stylish touch.Mark Wahlberg is Captain Leo Davidson, an astronaut in 2029 on a small space station that is conduction experiments on chimps. An electrical storm strikes, and a chimp is sent out to survey the cause. When the animal does not return, Davidson launches himself - against his commander's orders - to find him. Next thing he knows, his space pod is crash landing on an unknown planet inhabited by talking, aggressive apes - with humans as slaves.Davidson is captured by the apes along with other humans, but escapes. His plan - get back to where his pod crashed, find his GPS-like device that will allow him to locate his mother ship, and get back home. But it's a long way back to the pod, and he suddenly has thousands of apes after him.Luckily, he has on his side Ari (Helena Bonham Carter), a kindhearted ape who feels empathy toward the humans. Ari, of course, symbolizes animal lovers on Earth; she cannot understand why her fellow apes treat their humans so badly. "We can learn much from them," she claims, but her claims fall on deaf ears. Davidson, with the help of Ari, leads a small band of refugee humans (including the Daena, played by the delicious Estelle Warren) to his pod, where he makes some startling discoveries, none of which will be revealed here. (If you've seen the original and know the surprise ending, the discoveries Davidson makes are as intriguing as that ending.)Hot on the trail of the astronaut and his friends is the evil General Thade (Tim Roth) and his fiercest warrior Colonel Attar (Michael Clarke Duncan). The makeup jobs on all of the apes are astounding, and the actors are completely unrecognizable under their disguises. The general has been told by his ailing father (an uncredited Charlton Heston, who starred in the 1968 original) that humans, in the time before time, humans brought violence to their planet; now that apes dominate, humans must be destroyed.As with the original, this is a fascinating treatise not only on how we treat other animals but on how we treat ourselves. Is it truly accurate to say that humans are civilized and the apes are the savages? The film actually makes you think about such things, but it's no philosophical hodge-podge of mumbo-jumbo. It's a exciting, powerful movie, worth watching on just about every level.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>

		<date>2001-11-26</date>
		<username>Wes Alexander</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>APES is not so bad of a PLANET...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>PLANET OF THE APES: BThe plot of "Planet of the Apes" doesn't take much thought. Leo Davidson (Mark Wahlberg) crash lands on a distant planet run by ape people. They're scary, aggresive, and they hate humans. They inprision humans and make them slaves. But, Leo is the macho, egotistical type (a must for these kinds of movies). He breaks out along with the beauty Daena (Estalla Warren) with the help of ape Ari (Helena Bonham Carter). General Thade (Tim Roth, one scary looking dude) quickly finds out about this and doesn't take to it lightly. He gathers his whole army so they go searching for the humans. Attar (Michael Clarke Duncan) is humble assitant who is second in command.For about 45 minutes of the movie it wasn't looking so good, because of the character of Leo and his cliché. The characters were kind of a problem. They were old and tired. Ari posses the most heart, though. Also, a love triangle emerges between Ari, Leo, and Daena.. Th film seems scared, though, to take on the subject of "inner-species" dating. It doesn't, until about the last 30 minutes, give us anything we've already seen before. Except great make-up. But the thing about it is, it's a lot of fun. I picked up the problems I listed above, but really didn't care. Tim Burton, personally, is my favorite director. He has yet to make a bad film. He has a certain style that is dark and ominous, Here, it is muddled and doesn't show up until about the last 30 minutes. You can sense it's there but it doesn't show up until then."Planet" has one of the greatest endings of the year, which is the high point of the movie. It's also got some other neat twists in it along the way. So, despite it's many problem, "Planet" is an enjoyable, often funny, often scary, summer movie.Note: Pay attention to Danny Elfman's tremendous score. He had done most of Burton's films and each score is terrific. I don't feel he gets enough recognition, so I thought I'd mention it.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2001-11-24</date>
		<username>Victor Field</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Apart from Estella Warren, what do this and "Driven" have in common?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Spoiler for the ending (not the first one, as you may have guessed).Before the break we asked you what, apart from Estella Warren, do the new version of "Planet of the Apes" and "Driven" have in common?In both films the silver screen's most gorgeous pouter (Angelina Jolie? We don' need no steenkin' Angelina Jolie!) is one of the best things, and in both films one of the high points is watching her swim. Unlike the movie that several people here and elsewhere accurately dubbed "Drivel," however, this one does have some other stuff in its favour, but not enough to stop it from being second only to "Mars Attacks!" as Tim Burton's least interesting movie to date; note that I said least interesting and not worst, because Burton is apparently incapable of making a bad movie (he can, however, have his name on one - "Batman Forever" is billed as "A Tim Burton Production," but that was chiefly Joel Schumacher's fault).The man's never been hailed for his unwavering grasp on story, but his grip on the plot is even more tenuous than usual; he seems more interested in the look than the tale - the elements never really come together (especially the Wahlberg/Bonham-Carter/Warren "triangle," which never quite registers and explains why the ending is a bit weak). In fairness, Burton and the cast aren't helped by the script from William Broyles Jr ("Cast Away," the excellent TV series "China Beach") and sequel specialists Lawrence Konner and Mark Rosenthal (who did "The Jewel of the Nile," "Star Trek VI: The Undiscovered Country" and "Superman IV: The Quest For Peace" - is that warning bells I hear?), which doesn't give anyone much to work with and makes the first hour in particular a slow haul.The second half is all told an improvement, although it suffers from some hard-to-believe plot points (the phrase 'deux ex machina' comes to mind)...***SPOILER ALERT FOR THOSE READERS WHO STILL DON'T KNOW THE ENDING*** ...and the ending, though closer to the end of the original novel (in both the book and this film the hero returns to Earth only to find out, thanks to a memorial to the Tim Roth character, that the apes have taken over there as well), is clumsy, illogical and idiotic; see "Back to the Future Part II" for a similar twist, which at least had some credibility along the rules the film set itself. There must have been an easier way for Twentieth Century Fox to graft on a set-up for a potential sequel. (That's what you get for leaving Estella Warren behind, Wahlberg!)***END OF SPOILER ALERT FOR THOSE ET CETERA ET CETERA ET CETERA***Technically it's pretty good, with impressive Rick Baker makeup (although Helena Bonham-Carter's makeup, in addition to making her look a bit like B'Elanna from "Star Trek: Voyager," seems to be getting in the way of her speech), fine although non-staggering Industrial Light and Magic (and company) FX - the crash sequence and the climactic battle are standouts - and another good Danny Elfman score (although whoever decided to stick that Paul Oakenfold remix on the lengthy end credits should be taken out and shot). Some of the cast actually manage to come through the makeup, notably Michael Clarke Duncan and Tim Roth (although Mark Wahlberg looks more like an ape than the other humans), and the apes are actually pretty scary... but I miss Roddy McDowall. (Note that I haven't drawn any comparisons between this and the 1968 classic; it's not fair to do so, and I'm trying to look at this on its own merits.)Alas, Tim Burton movies shouldn't be enjoyed for their technical merits - they should and often do take you to another world. It's ironic that the first of his movies that really IS set on another world should ultimately fail to do so; lots of good things (I liked the slave trader, I didn't mind the links to the original movie - good on Charlton Heston for going uncredited, however - and I certainly enjoyed the big action scenes and some of the quieter pleasures, like the unofficial tour the humans take while escaping through the apes' city) but not a success. It's still better than the TV series or the last two sequels, however, but this isn't a real Burton movie. "Planet of the Apes" might have seemed more impressive had this identical movie been directed by Michael Bay, but from a real genius it's something to rank below his best work.But Estella is as sexy as ever, which is where we came in.</fullReview>
	</review>
