	<review>
		<date>2001-11-19</date>
		<username>Zach Klinefelter</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Visually Stunning, Impressive... and of course, Flawed Version of "Apes"</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I first became a fan of the "Planet of the Apes" saga when I was 12 years old. HBO was showing the original film and I came in on the scene in which Charlton Heston's Taylor was being interrogated in the apes' court. I was hooked from that moment on. I bought all five original films and watched all of them countless times and re-bought them when Fox put out the THX-Widescreen tapeset for the 30th anniversary. What did Apes do for me? Well, to begin with, it made me examine my religion. The end result? I determined I wasn't Christian. It also made me want to be a film director even more. THIS WAS WHAT SCI-FI COULD DO. Even the weakest entry of all, "Battle for the Planet of the Apes," was above standard sci-fi entertainment.So here I am, 22 years old, exploring religion, life, and directing my first ambitious independent film, which is even titled as a small homage to the fourth "Apes" film, "Conquest of Area 52" (there will be an IMDB entry on it next year sometime). "Planet of the Apes" is among my biggest reasons for wanting to make films and it's impacted the way I think as well.I've read the wonderful Pierre Boulle novel (and own the first printing, which I um, borrowed from my high school library) and I will be buying the "Apes" TV series on DVD. And of course, I saw Tim Burton's "reimagining" of "Planet" on opening day.From the beginning, I'm already biased. The original Apes saga was my Bible. To paraphrase, "Everything I Needed to Know I Learned From Apes." Heh-heh. Tim Burton... love the guy. He made "Ed Wood," one of my top ten favorite films. His unique visions and styles have always intrigued me. Admittedly however, Burton normally did not have strong points in plot or character development. His "Batman" films were a mixed bag, not showing enough of the psychology of what it meant to be Batman, but they were so visually entrancing that I am still able to watch them on their own merits. In fact, both "Batman" and "Batman Returns" get an 8.5/10 from me. "Mars Attacks" is a joy to watch on the right day, and the same goes with "Edward Scissorhands" and "Beetlejuice." By the time he directed "Sleepy Hollow," I felt that Burton had evolved so much as a visual storyteller that he really could not be judged for weak plot or character. That's the way he wants to be as an artist, so let it be.But...This time, he's done "Planet of the Apes." If it were anything else, like say a remake of "2001", I could still watch it and not crucify it. No, this new version is not anything worth crucifying. "Apes 2001", shall we call it, has the all the Burton standards- plot and character on the back burner, awesome visuals at the forefront. What sets Burton aside from say, the biggest hack of all time Michael "Pearl Harbor" Bay, is that while his character drama may not be the most engaging, it's not exactly boring or annoying. It's just SIMPLE. This version plays out like the 1968 version except cut down to the core: an astronaut crashlands on a strange planet, he gets caught, is imprisoned at Ape City, gets away with the help of a lovable chimp, goes into the Forbidden Area, finds out the origin of the apes, and leaves the apes to go home. That last part is the only thing really different in the overall structure, except this time, the film does not end there, and we get an ending which both pays its respects to Boulle's original novel and Franklin Schaffner's original film.There are several references this version makes to the original series. With the Apes army we get a nod to "Beneath." With the love story, er, triangle, there's a similar feel to Zira and Cornelius' plight in "Escape." The look of the astronaut costumes is very similar to those in the first two. And the origin of the apes rings in similar tone to the fourth film, "Conquest."Did I like it? I've only seen it twice, so its a bit hard to say that without going, "except for this... and that... and this... and that..." What I liked: the cinematography, the sets (which are never all that real-looking but invoke memories of illustrated children's books, which is a Burton constant), the movement and makeup of the apes (maybe the two most noteworthy things done here), the cameos by Chuck Heston and Linda Harrison (Nova from Apes I &amp; II). I also liked the love triangle between Ari, Leo, and the blonde; this was very humorous. Wahlberg didn't add much depth to a written character already lacking depth, but he certainly had the right expressions for his character. I wouldn't be particularly overjoyed by my stay on the Planet of the Apes either. Helena Bonham-Carter is always good in whatever she does, and her character in this was endearing enough to accept her makeup, which differs greatly from the others. Paul Giamatti's Limbo may be the best character of all, providing the most comic relief. Tim Roth as Thade is brilliant, as are the rest of the key players. I didn't appreciate that the social commentaries were sometimes rather clumsily slapped on; indeed a lot of the time they seemed like desperate attempts by Burton to put SOMETHING in there saying ANYTHING when the script had little to give him (Burton arrived on the project fairly late and had little time to shape the film).Overall, this 2001 version of "Planet" is far better than it should have been, given the success it had to live up to. It doesn't hold a candle to the original, and I certainly never expected it to. I'm glad Fox put a commercial artist in charge of it, rather than a commercial hack such as the afore-mentioned Michael Bay or Tony Scott. It may have been more intriguing had Oliver Stone worked on it (Stone was attached several years back).Tim Burton did the near-impossible for me: I didn't want to kill him after watching this. And for an Apes fanatic such as myself, that is saying a heck of a lot. Let's all hope that when Fox greenlights the sequel, they don't hand it over to Joel Schumacher. I'd take Ed Wood's Planet of the Apes over his anyday.I do have one quibble I think is more than worthy of consideration to even a non-Apes fan not familiar with the original series:We know where the Apes come from in "Apes 2001." But why the heck would that space station have HORSES on it?! Sorry, I'm not gonna take the old lame scientific explanation about how life on other planets must be similar. I may be a Darwin enthusiast, but come on. That's stretching it.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>

		<shortDescription>Good film, but the book is way way better. And 68' version is better too</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Maybe SPOILERS, maybe not. ( My english is not perfect, but it is much better than your russian :-) Once again I read Pierre Boulle's book and once again I'm wondering - WHY ? Why not Tim Burton neither ? couldn't simply adopt this book on screen word-by-word ? Why they were trying to change the story radically ? The story in the book is much more entertaining, surprising and significantly deeper in people-ape relations than in 68' and 01' films taken together ! Those who read the book will understand me well - the ending at the book is really shocking ! Of course, that half-destroyed Statue of Liberty at the ending of 68' film is very symbolic , but. I'll prefer not to say about 01' film ending sequence - it is in real Hollywood's style - heh, where can possibly crush your spaceboat - in the field, wood, river or ocean ? No !!! It will land right before the Lincoln Memorial in Washington, D.C. ! WHY ? Simply because this is an american film !So, if you like GREAT science-fiction plots, good acting, directing, music and special effects, then you will like this film. I'm just sorry for that book's story - filmmakers did a big mistake, when decided to rewrite it.My rating : 8 out of 10. But the 68' film is better anyway.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2001-11-14</date>
		<username>uds3</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Warmed-up or half-baked?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Like many others, I rather admire Tim Burton's artistic spin-outs, although for every BATMAN there is a MARS ATTACKS, and for every EDWARD SCISSORHANDS a SLEEPY HOLLOW. He had NO RIGHT however messing with PLANET OF THE APES, a great film that was majorly under-valued critically (NOT at the box-office) even on its release in 1968. "Are things so bad that BEN-HUR has to start mixing it with Gorillas?" proclaimed one dumb-ass reviewer! Wonder what he would have written about this?Well guys for whats its worth, here's my assessment! In a word, INSULTING to the original! (and to anyone in the audience of moderate intelligence.) Obviously geared towards two distinctly identifiable social groups: those who have never seen the original series and today's (for the most part) attention-deficient audiences, who just want some one-dimensional entertainment to accompany their popcorn (or ecstasy tablet). Burton is selling himself short here - he is worth more than that.PLANET OF THE APES (2001) is not categorically a turkey, the special effects are excellent, although the incessant use of digitizing becomes wearisome eventually. What IS wrong with it is loopy Wahlberg as an intergalactic Captain....I mean could you take this guy seriously? Would YOU rather fly to Alpha Centauri with Chuck Heston at the controls or under the direction of some guy who flashes his "jewels" while boogeying? Aimed at a "youthful," marketable audience, sure he's your man, but in the interests of credibility, Wahlberg is a 10-1 longshot! The film suffers from ludicrously unstable continuity with a script to match - it is sheerly a visual extravaganza. Obviously in an attempt to play down the social and paradoxical issues of the original (coz you might have to actually THINK!) Burton has gone for noise and movement.The marvellous ending of the 1968 film (probably only ever equalled in power by THE USUAL SUSPECTS) is replaced by an obviously tacked-on "lets not worry how to explain this - anything to leave us a sequel" finale. In the upshot, not the embarrassment Gus Van Sant's PSYCHO was, but totally unnecessary and totally unsatisfying!</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Too noisy monkey business?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Franklin J. Schaffner's 1968 version of Pierre Boulle's novel was the first film I saw when I started my moviegoing career at 13, so rather inevitably it would take a lot for this new one to surpass my wonderful experience from then.Except for Tim Burton's film to be pacier and noisier, one of the important differences is the fact that the apes here are apier (e. g. swinging in the trees and so on), and the ape masks and costumes have become more flexible which altogether should add up to some improvement.On the other hand the incessant onslaught of computer-generated special effects unfortunately dwarfs the actors much of the time (especially Mark Wahlberg), and further the philosophical aspects and debating are toned down compared to the old version.All in all this was somewhat of a disappointment. Certainly not because Tim Burton has made an un-professional or amateurish movie, but because I cherish Schaffner's film more for sentimental reasons and not least for having a more adventurous feel and a narrative flow (and drive) that is missing here.A circumstance I hardly understand myself as Tim Burton's film is choke-full of great images, noise, action and commotion in general.</fullReview>

Here is the story of Planet of the apes thanks to Tim1370.It is the year 2029: Astronaut Leo Davidson (Mark Wahlberg) boards a pod cruiser on a Space Station for a "routine" reconnaissance mission. But an aburupt detour through a space time wormhole lands him on a strange planet where talking apes rule over the human race. With the help of a sympathetic chimpanzee activist named Ari (Helena Bonham-Carter) and a small band of human rebels, Leo leads the effort to evade the advancing Gorilla Army led by General Thade (Tim Roth) and his most trusted warrior Attar (Michael Clarke Duncan). Now the race is on to reach a sacred temple within the planet's Forbidden Zone to discover the shocking secrets of mankind's past - and the key to it's future. Wanna watch a good movie with Estella Warren and Carmen Electra? Go see Perfume, two of the hottest babes in one flick! See only Planet of the apes for Estella!</fullReview>

		<date>2001-10-06</date>
		<username>MovieTrey</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Ome of the better summer movies</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Planet of the Apes was a real delight after a summer of disappointing movies. This summer has been one disappointment after another. First there was Tomb Raider, which was full of dumb cliches. Then there was A.I, which had too much hype behind it and was too long to keep your interest. After all the disappointments it's a real relief that the studios can still come up with a good movie. Tim Burton brings us another blockbuster hit. This is Burton's best work since Sleepy Hollow. Burton uses his unique techniques to bring the apes alive for the film. His artistic expertise that Burton displayed in the making of Planet of the Apes has probably made him one of the most well known directors today. The mere talent that Burton brings to a film makes him one of the most unique directors of our time. Mark Wahlberg is wonderful in this film. He plays Leo Davidson, a United States captain who crash lands on the planet and discovers that the apes rule the planet. This is a step up for Wahlberg from 1994's Renaissance Man, where he plays Private Tommy Lee Haywood. This is probably Wahlberg's best film since Boogie Nights. Tim Roth plays the evil General Thade, general to the ape army. He despises the human race. Charlton Heston makes a small cameo appearance as General Thade's Father, the only ape with a gun. Overall I gave Planet of the Apes a 6. If you liked this I would suggest renting Sleepy Hollow, Batman, and Edward Scissorhands.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Not Burton's best, but...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The fight scenes are tremendous, and although the twist is not quite up there with the best (That honour goes to The Usual Suspects and The Shawshank Redemption), it does make you think. However, the film feels like Burton-lite, like MI2 was John Woo-lite, the apes have caged Burton here. The aesthetics show flashes of his sensibility, but his gothic romantic style is virtually absent. Also, Mark Walberg and Helena Bonham Carter are poor and miscast.However, Tim Roth and Michael Clarke Duncan are superb, with a true apish spirit. 		<date>2001-09-29</date>
		<username>~PL~</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Beautiful images don't mean a good movie...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Planet of The Apes is a Tim Burton film. And, knowing that it is in Burton's habits to put spectacular and beautiful yet dark and mysterious images on film, I expected a "Planet of The Apes" with the same story than the original, but with a different perspective in the images. But I was somehow disappointed to see that, sure the images were nice, though not as amazing as "Edward Scissorhands"' or "Batman"'s, but the script seemed to have forgotten. The film lasts two hours, but you don't see them pass away, because you feel like nothing happens in the film, but everything is happening at the same time. The movie could be separated in like three chapters; The beginning, the core and the ending. That's it, no surprises, nothing special, except the images and Tim Roth's acting. This film wasted lots of potential interesting performances *Spoilers warning*(Kris Kristofferson doesn't even play a role, he only runs and die, and Helena Bonham Carter has a very hollow and empty role as an ape who has more feelings, and her feelings are so hard to see because of the limited facial expression due to the make up). Plus, they put Estella Warren wearing some kind of leaves made bikini, isn't that superficial and commercial? This is the first Tim Burton film that deceives me, and I hope it's the last one. This is a very good example of a movie which has special and make up effects as a structure. many people won't realize it, because they'll be fascinated by the images, but this blind attitude is exactly what the makers expected. Planet of The Apes is more a (commercial) vision of The Planet of The Apes by Tim Burton. It is not so identic to the original, I couldn't say it's a remake. The ending is good though, but is still pretty predictable. But really, you can't really get inside of the movie, because it is not attaching enough, all you can do is look at the images...I give it 4/10.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-09-29</date>
		<username>cjdevine78</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>See it - it's good!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>*MINOR SPOILERS*I liked this film. I went to the cinema, paid my money and was entertained for the 2 or so hours it was on. It is a good film. Not a great film, but a good film. Too often people compare it to the original (which in itself was hardly a cinematic masterpiece), stating silly things like; "Why can the humans speak?"... Because it's a different film! There's simply no reason why they couldn't speak!? They are the decendents of english speaking humans! "How can I not compare it?"... okay, they're both about monkeys! But the story line is completely different from that of the original. Star Wars and Star Trek are similar but the two are very rarely compared.The make-up is fantastic, the movement and acting is generally above par. The special effects are pretty awsome. The sets range from spectacular to pretty unimaginative, but this was possible intended (how interesting can you make a barron desert?)The statue of liberty style "twist" at the end isn't done in the same format. After seeing the original you would say: "Oooooh, right! That's what happened!?" After seeing POTA 2001 most say: "How the hell did that happen?" - though this has been critisised I think it was a deliberate attempt by Burton to give the viewer the option of drawing his or her own conclusions (yes, you have to use your brain!). Why people see this as an opening to a sequel, I don't know - it's not! There won't be a sequel... bets anyone?</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2001-09-27</date>
		<username>Onethought</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>okay fun</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The movie has some of the most elaborate makeups that somehow feel life like. All the apes walk with an "apey" wobble and the expressions they all make give an underlying realism only Tim Burton could have brought about. However his magic was lacking from the movie. The movie seemed to have a not so convincing or involving story twists I would have attributed to a re-creation(not remake) of a classic like this. It fails to make any lasting impression. Helena Bonham Carter does her bit well, so does the rest of the crew. Appearance by Charlton Heston (although barely recognizable) is memorable.As for the sound, it is very good. The LFEs are quite convincing and less distracting. The set of the planet matches with the score perfectly well.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2001-09-27</date>
		<username>snapcrackle66</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Monkey Madness at its Best</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Pick, pick, pick : ). Sure you can quibble about the details, but I grabbed the kids and took them to see it when it first came out and no one was disappointed. We all got a kick out of it and afterward we rented the original so that we could compare. The kids thought the newer version was better, but I suppose a lot of that has to do with the updated technology and all. Now that they've gotten hip to DVDs and all the features they include, they want me to get it for all the inside stuff so I suppose I'll preorder it here. The make-up jobs in this film were certainly much better than in the original. I expect that will make its category at the Oscars. I had no problem with the acting, Tim Roth is always great, look forward to anything he's in. I didn't get Wahlberg's performance till I thought about it a bit more and realized that was his character, a bit selfish and tunnel-visioned. He kind of deserved the ending ; ). And I rather enjoyed seeing a different version and wouldn't mind seeing more directors do this. Seeing the second version of Psycho mimicked shot for shot left me cold. This version of Planet of the Apes still dealt with the important issues and I'm glad for that. We all had a lot of discussion about the nature of human behavior and how we all need to get along somehow. I know the cynics are scowling now, but its true. I see some folks don't get the ending and I'm not sure I do either. Perhaps that was intended, because it was left wide open for a sequel. Anyway, I'm not going to quibble, it was enjoyable and fun to watch, worth the money. Lord knows we could use a little entertainment nowdays.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-09-23</date>
		<username>VirtualVoyager68</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Great new visionary Planet of the Apes</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Tim Burton has once again created a visually stunning and a "new" Planet of the Apes. It is NOT a remake; and never tried to be but another "tale" on the same concept as the old movies. The old ones were great as well - masterpieces in itself. But this DOES NOT reduce the great work that Tim Burton has done in creating this movie. A great movie and well worth watching in it's own rights. If you want the "old ones" - watch the old ones; if you want to watch a great new movie - watch this one. And WHY not watch both the OLD and the NEW ones.Happy viewing!</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-09-23</date>
		<username>Mercader79</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>Close. But no banana.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Perhaps there's no such thing as a bad Tim Burton film, but Planet of the Apes comes perilously close. Visually the make-up is generally impressive ? the overall effect of seeing so many simian humanoids at once is quite overpowering, even if most of the set-design is pretty unimaginative.Tim Roth's performance as a sort of Richard III ape is perhaps the most memorable ? his strangulated restless manner is reminiscent of the mortally wounded Mr Orange in Reservoir Dogs (although he wasn't a monkey). Bonham Carter is also impressive in a decisive departure from her flowery Merchant Ivory image. Only the make-up lets her down ? her visage seems to have been tampered with in an ultimately futile attempt to make her look her like an attractive ape. This fails. On the other hand, Estella Warren's Daena is far too much like a supermodel to look like a convincing native girl.So why does Planet of the Apes fail? Here are some ideas.1) Why do the humans on the planet speak? In the original film and the novella there was a direct human-apes reversal situation ? the humans could not speak or communicate anymore effectively than monkeys can on Earth. That was why the arrival of Heston's character stirred the waters. Here the humans are clearly ruled over by the apes, but given their supposed ?mastery of technology' which the apes lack, there seems no real reason why the apes should be so dominant. Burton seems to be striving for a civil rights parallel. Roth's ape even misquotes the reactionary Senator Barry Goldwater at one point. But this paradox still makes little sense.2) Too much of the dialogue is banal or just stupid. There are a number of signs the film is rushed.3) The ?comedy' orang-utan is annoying. 4) Wahlberg is no action hero. He got away with it playing a porn actor but not here. 5) The ending seems to be an attempt to echo that of the novella. Yet that made sense. This one doesn't. It is not clever, just inexplicable. I HEREBY DEFY ANYONE ON THESE PAGES TO EXPLAIN THE ENDING SATISFACTORILY! It's impossible - it's nonsensical.Overall, not a disaster, but highly disappointing.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-09-19</date>
		<username>Janeway-4 (cindyf@asconline.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Human See Human Do.......</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>There is a certain perception that is suggested when Tim Burton takes the helm of a movie. That perception is that you'll see something very different than the usual lint that's produced after good movies are tumbled about in the Hollywood dryer; with all their wrinkles removed, sickly pseudo fresh (like a Downey fabric sheet that touts it smells of `Fresh Rain' yeah right), and softened as not to cause chaffing. But Burton is different. Burton has vision. Burton is a visionary. I have uttered those words before in reference to his litany of twisted, incredibly clever and dark films. Burton's early shorts, Vincent and Frankenweenie, are things born of a mind and an eye that's capable of seeing the world through gray colored lenses. Pee-Wee's Big Adventure, Beetlejuice, Edward Scissor Hands, The Nightmare Before Christmas, Ed Wood, Batman, Mars Attacks?every one of these movies had that vision?that dig up the dirt up and put it under the light feel.Which is why then, with Planet of the Apes, I can claim as the only explanation for such appalling drivel is that Burton completely and utterly sold out for the lure of a `Big Budget Hollywood Summer Blockbuster'. Who better than Burton to `revisit' P of A (as Burton nearly screams in every interview that this is NOT a remake), one of the darkest and engaging sci-fi films made? But, here's the question: if this is not intended to be a remake, then why not cast that famous Burton vision on this piece and make it something more strange, more?dare I say?human? Take Burton's other films?the hero is most often an odd, socially maladjusted, misunderstood, feared, decidedly melancholy, alone, scared and scarred, but somehow better than the lot of others around him. His characters, in their own eerie way, show the more benevolent side of human nature.So, then Mark Wahlberg's self-serving Leo in P of A is someone NOT from Burton's world. So, then the `plot' (and I use the word `plot' with hesitation) of P of A is also something not Burtonesque. Thus the whole experience is such a total let down that it makes one wonder if big budgets and high profile stars stifles anything creative as easily as a 40ft wet blanket thrown on a single lit match (enter into evidence America's Sweetheart). Burton usually strives on lancing the boil of our perceptions and getting to the raw under layer of cultures?and P of A (the original was a hearty, if campy, examination and damnation of the snobbery of humans to dub ourselves as rulers of any planet) would seem to give Burton the chance to perform a wonderful social surgery.The gray colored glasses though were replace by the $green$ colored lenses, and so we are left with just another shell of a movie. The only vision Burton can see, for what are supposed to be genetically enhanced apes, is that they will emulate human social customs?they will form armies, they will have a senate, conduct dinner parties and sport Jackie O bobs; this is visionary? Hardly. In the end all we learn from Burton's P of A is the same thing we see in too many movies and the same thing we see in nearly every nook and cranny of the world; whoever can beat one's chest the loudest, whoever can physically beat the other side down, whoever has better weaponry will ultimately prevail. Burton had the chance to show a better way?instead he merely aped his lesser peers and created another loud, ridiculously expensive and mindless testament to violence.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-09-17</date>
		<username>LONGBOWSMAN145</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>apes in peril</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>PLANET OF THE APES was a film that sufficed but left me wanting more. The film stressed more, OZ style sets and costumes and great backdrops over gunplay. The script and story had a few continuity problems (probably due to editing) yet the film is a great update of the first two movies. I think the original series warts and all is the best. I liked this film and primarily the " camp by the water sequence" for the lighting and art direction. The film features an all star costumed cast. In the opening on the space station the name on whalbergs suit reads briefly "wahlberg". PLANET OF THE APES main problem was it's "too quick" resolution of the conflict and not enough exploration of the FORBIDDEN ZONE. A good film and well told also imaginative on the visuals and TOLKIEN novel visual flair. This is perhaps TIM BURTONS best film. Of note is the genre classic line "okay guys we only got one shot at this". The apes were too realistic I am a fan of the original chambers designs...yet these were utterly life like. Of note is the surprise ending in keeping with the 1973-74 animated series and an origianl draft by serling. One more note...the forbidden zone sequences look like some of the story boards for the DEHN scripted sequel. (fascinating)</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2001-09-17</date>
		<username>shaid</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Half baked cake</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>*SPOILERS *SPOILERS* *SPOILERS*The original is already a classic and here the makers got the chance to introduce the story to a younger generation taking advantage of the technical advantages of today while using one of the original director of today's Hollywood, Tim Burton, whose unique style is something that can give the edge the film needed. However the result is less than you expected from a technical or story and characters development point of view.As usual there are a list of good and bad things and I'll start with the good ones:- Make up - Almost perfect. The actors look like apes and you would not guess that there are real actors under the masks(I won't be surprise if the make-up will win an Oscar). That saying there are some reservation. While the man apes are perfect the female apes are less good. They look like actors and not like real apes. The decision to let the apes walk and jump like apes do is used to a great effect and is the big advantage of the film.- The dark tone of the story is been reflected in the dark cinemtography. Even when there is light it is not a strong one but it is moody and dark.- Music- As usual the music from Danny Elfman is effective and serve the film.- Tim Roth as General Thade is excellent and his performance convey the menace and the hunger for power that exist in his character.That all I can say that was good in the movie. The list of bad things will be longer:- Mark Wahlberg as Capt. Leo Davidson is weak. He doesn't carry the film on his shoulders and moreover he is not as strong as Tim Roth's Thade. How can anyone see him as a messiah is beyond my understanding.- In the original film the main female character, Dr. Zira(Kim Hunter), was a scientist. She fought for the humans to have equal rights because she think they are intelligent but she could not prove it because all the humans in that film couldn't speak. The arrival of Col. Taylor(Charlton Heston) gave her the tool to prove her theory because he could speak. Beside that she was a strong and believable character. Here the main female character, Ari(Helena Bonham Carter,) is been portrayed as "human lovers". There is no reason why shy thinks like that or what made her change her mind in such an hostile environment towards humans. It doesn't help that her performance is so weak and her contribution to the film is less than zero. In general the female apes are less convinced than the men apes.- Towards the end of the film,the chimpanzee that was sent in the beginning of the film and that we thought has already died, re-appear,out of nowhere. This development in the story is very contrive and served only as mean to end the battle between the apes and the human. How the chimpanzee has survive the magnetic storm. Your guess is as good as mine. Another development that strike me as contrive is the decision of General Thade's aide to simply turn to the other side just because he doesn't believe The General anymore. Why has this happened? Through the whole film that aide is a loyal servant. He has no reason to doubt The General so what happened now? Was it enough for him to hear Cat.Davidson's words in order to change his heart? In short no logic in both events.- The ending doesn't help making the film coherent. The only explanation i can think of is that the storm was not only a jump through time but also a jump through dimension. Otherwise the whole film stand on very weak basis and the ending make the whole film illogical.- I like Tim Burton. I have seen every film his has done(not all perffect) and I would continue to see his films. However something is missing from this film. He is in his best when he direct projects that he initiate or are close to his heart. His best films were the ones that have an outsider as a hero that Burton, as an outsider himself, can identify with. I didn't have the feeling that he was fully committed to this project, probably because he was hired to direct this film and didn't initiated it.At the end I was very disappointed. Something that looked good and promise to taste good turned out to be not as good as it should and could have been. Just like an half baked cake. It looks good from the outside but it taste bad because someone forgot to put some of the ingredients that would have make the best in the world.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-09-14</date>
		<username>hawkeye-65</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Best watched when someone else pays for it!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>NOTE: For those who haven't seen this film, please do NOT read my review. I will be outlining the plot, or lack thereof, in my critique.Several years ago, legendary scriptwriter William Goldman lamented that it was no longer fun to ridicule current films. The present author agrees, citing Hollywood's limited imagination and obsession with proper packaging. One example can be found in Tim Burton's `reimagined' Hollywood's classic, Planet of the Apes. Mr. Burton is known for the Batman series, The Nightmare before Christmas, and Beetle juice. His Planet of the Apes is another dark foreboding film aimed at summer moviegoers.Burton correctly did not compete with the original movie's screenplay written by Rod Serling. The creator of The Twilight Zone was inspired by Pierre Boulle's satirical novel Monkey Planet. Now one can buy the novelization of the Tim Burton film. As one local paper observed, Burton created another contemporary action film. A US Air Force pilot marooned on a strange planet, pleas for us to love our neighbors, as we would love ourselves. In other words, Batman passed through the Stargate to discover EnemyMine. The author is grateful that he did not have to pay to see this forgettable remake. However, one should keep perspective and view this film as part of Hollywood's highly successful strategy as an electronic baby sitter. Its core audience is probably unaware that Planet of the Apes launched the first commercially viable nerdocracy nine years before Star Wars.What was Planet's secret? Great costumes, breath taking special effects, eye-catching explosions, token comic relief and of course sex appeal. The film team cut and pasted this formula onto the script but added his trademark: darkness protects evildoers. Instead of swaggering through Gotham's streets, these nefarious characters literally swing from tree to tree. Then our hero with the subtle last name of Davidson leads his people into the Wilderness. Meanwhile eye candy masquerading as characters diverts the male lead's attention: Helen Bonham Carter and Estella Warren. His young male audience secure, Burton enlisted living legends Charleton Heston and Kris Kristofferson ostensibly to develop the plot. However, the author suspects they were bait to lure the Baby Boomer generation.Thus, one can discern a movie's full power without distractions like plot or dialogue. One applies this Zen-like state when watching Burton's film. You should suspend disbelief when learning that the US Air Force in 2068 cannot prevent a rogue space launch. Then Mark Walberg, our Rambo-like hero, travels thousands of years into the future not because of technology. He is a cosmic Dorothy sucked into a space tornado that accelerates his vehicle past 88 miles per hour. Once in Oz, the newly arrived prophet reveals several millennia of tradition as a lie.How does he do it one might ask? Because Marky Mark is charismatic and bright. His character only needs a couple of days to gather a band of followers and discover the ruins of his old space station. Somehow falling out of orbit, the facility's nuclear power plant and computers still work. Our intrepid Spaceman discovers the truth: On Space Station Oberon, human and apes astronauts lived in happiness. Then the chimp Semos, like the Serpent in the Garden of Evil, spread hate.Apparently, Burton's filmmaking team believes that current moviegoers are unable to grasp ambiguity. Whereas the original film showed a world of mute humans, Burton's world is one where man had nothing to say. Heston's conflict at the ruins in the Forbidden Zone revolved around the clash of ideas. Kung-fu trained gorillas fought ideological issues the original film never resolved.In conclusion, the author believes he is too harsh. After all, the movie had hot leads, good production values and the plot was enough to keep me awake. My favorite part was ending, partially because the torture was over. However, another reason was Burton's ending was reminiscent of Boulle's finale. In the novel, our hero lands his spacecraft at a Paris airfield is met by a police car. Which was driven by a gorilla.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-09-12</date>
		<username>wgaa</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>The Evolution of the Ape...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Those of you who watched this version of that 1960s sci-fi classic about intelligent simians on a mysterious planet having dominion over mankind in the distant future were probably in for a little surprise (assuming you've seen the original).I would have to say that this latest film incarnation by Tim Burton is not at all a remake, but rather a retelling of the apes story from a perspective of pure fanfare and entertainment. Yes, there were several references throughout the movie on the morality of treating fellow humans, apes or any walking-and-talking being alike with respect and contempt. But there is a difference between this year's version and the original classic starring Charlton Heston.In 1968, the original `Planet of the Apes' revolutionized the sci-fi genre through its shocking image of mankind's future on the Planet Earth. Of how an inferior species such as the apes could grow in power and intelligence to rule over humans, largely because mankind itself had used weapons of mass destruction on each other, therefore contributing to a series of events leading to ape domination. Because the 1960s were such a turbulent time both politically and socially for the American people, the youth could especially empathize with the film's antiwar message. I'm sure no baby boomer will ever forget the gut-wrenching conclusion of Heston pounding his fists on the beach sands and damning all of humanity to hell after feasting his eyes upon a half-buried Statue of Liberty. Such scenes reflected the frightening times of the Cold War and Vietnam War, both looming as a shadow over the U.S. and other countries during that decade, and the whole movie itself directly reflected the mood of the times.Burton's version is quite a departure since it focuses on simple adventure entertainment and stunning visuals rather than any symbolic metaphor on the dangers of a worldwide engagement in nuclear war, or for that matter, any epidemic. Instead of Planet Earth being the venue, Burton seems to have taken us to another world in another galaxy, therefore giving us a fresh take on the apes story. At least this time around, the human slaves have the ability to talk. I will never forget such scenes as Mark Wahlberg's pet chimpanzee landing in his space capsule from the sky during the climax of the ape-human battle. These and other highlights made `Planet of the Apes' the escapist formula it deserves to be. There are many inside dialogue references to the original `Apes' film, but I suggest you go see that version first in order to catch them all here.The movie is also blessed with a bunch of gifted performers. Mark Wahlberg is OK as the chief protagonist. But Tim Roth practically steals every scene he is in as the villainous ape general Thade. With his experience as a stage actor, Roth magnificently portrays an enemy who is thoroughly corrupt and demonic with no hint of remorse. Helena Bonham Carter provides an example of simian benevolence through her open-minded chimpanzee character. And Michael Clarke Duncan, being the huge man that he is, is at times terrifying as a gorilla commander. Oh, and yes, keep an eye out for cameo appearances by Heston and Linda Harrison, stars from the original `Apes' movie.One common element between the two versions of `Planet of the Apes' is that both have a shocking finale, but for those who have not seen either, I will go as far as that! For sheer pleasure, I rate this 8/10.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-09-12</date>
		<username>Dodger-9</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>Planet Horrorwood</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>POSSIBLE SPOILERSAs with many of you reading this, I love both Planet of the Apes (1968) and the films of Tim Burton.However, like oil and water, the two are not a great mix.I like the fact he had a brave stab at one of Hollywood's best sci-fi movies and Rick Baker is bound to get an Oscar for his work on the make-up.However, that script and plot left a lot to be desired.There are little things that bug me, not the huge sweeping visions of apes thundering across the planet in Braveheart mode.When astronaut Mark Wahlberg puts his hand on a thousand year old door lock, it opens with barely a problem. If I leave my car door closed for a month it seizes up.And when Mark crashes his space pod at the end, he strolls from the wreckage like he's just got up from his chair to make a cup of tea. Where is the logic in simple inertia and seized up mechanics. It doesn't take a genius to apply these little things that make all good sci-fi films work. Okay, it doesn't have to be Nasa approved but it does have to have a modicom of reality we can all relate to.2001 has been one of the bleakest years in living memory for movies and the news. Planet of the Apes will not be remembered for turning things around but merely burying them in a deeper pile of misery.If you only watch one film this year, make it Moulin Rouge and leave Tim Burton's flawed offering well alone.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>

For sheer pleasure, I rate this 8/10.</fullReview>

		<username>Sybok (Sybok@gmx.de)</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Don´t forget it is a FANTASY movie</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>WARNING! Don´t read if you didn´t see the movie yet!At first I have to say that I didn´t see the original movie yet (shame on me!) but I don´t consider this to be important for this review. As I´m a Tim Burton-Fan, I had to watch the new "Planet of the Apes" - and I liked it.It is a great movie, full of fantastic pictures - the great comic-style, which I love Tim Burton for. The soundtrack is perfect, the special effects are great and , what is the most important: the story is very entertaining and full of suspense.Of course, as many of you did, you could ask many logical questions as: - Why are there horses on the planet? - Why are there different races? - How is it possible for a few humans and two apes to ride through a complete camp of aggressive apes? - Why does the chimp land exactly at the moment when Leo is about to lose his fight? - How is it possible for a small spaceship, to fly from the planet of the apes back to the earth? And why does it only take three minutes? - Why does Estella Warren wear lipstick? - Why is the earth full of apes at the end?I read many questions like this, and of course there are many more you could ask! But please don´t forget, it is a fantasy movie! A fantasy movie doesn´t need to be realistic, and it also doesn´t want to be!Nobody asks why it is possible to hear noises, when space ships in Star Wars shoot at something - although it is impossible to hear noises in space! A fantasy movie lives of exaggerations! Why do you always bother about realism in fantasy films? If you want to watch a realistic movie, then you should watch a drama or something, but no fantasy or science-fiction movie! - Or at least, don´t wonder about exaggerations!Of course it was not a perfect movie. Mark Whalberg really didn´t act very well, and I often asked myself why Estella Warren is in this movie. She is always in the middle of the plot, looking beautiful but speaking only five sentences over the whole movie.But altogether it was a very nice movie. I will have to buy the DVD as soon as it is available!Therefore 8 out of 10.Well, I think I will watch the original movie soon, but I´m not looking forward to compare the movies!</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2001-09-08</date>
		<username>director9ff</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Wanted to die</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>No, I'm not reviewing "Tomb Raider," or even "Hobgoblins," but a film somewhere along that line: The remake of "Planet of the Apes."It might be unfair to judge something without seeing/reading/whatevering the original, and I haven't. But I nearly did once, and after watching a few minutes, I left. I couldn't do that with this one, because I came with my brother, his teacher, the teacher's son, and the son's friend, and couldn't go anywhere else. [sob] Just kidding there.I have got to start coming into movies with NO expectations. When I want an okay film, it sucks; when I think it'll be bad, it is; and whenever I think it'll be good, it's okay, and that isn't good enough. Here, I thought it would be bad. Tim Burton's remake (I'm not calling it a reimagining, it doesn't deserve such a title) was such a bad film, that whereas I thought in the theater, it was closer to the "okay" line, now I think it was closer to the evil of Tomb Raider. (Maybe it exceeded that.) Quite a turnabout!I'm an 11 year old (and am awfully smart for my age), and I had to do homework for a week-and if you knew me, you would know that I wouldn't consider it without a bribe-to see this. I barely got by, and after leaving, I said to myself, "I did a week of homework for THAT?!" It's that bad.The only redeeming part was the ending. And even that sucked. (Spoilers ahead, just as you would expect from me.) I mean, the first part was stupid-the apes caused the humans to mutate like that? (It was subtler, but that's the general point.) The final scenes where he gets back to Earth were cool-replacing the Abraham Lincoln statue with an ape-but it leaves a plot hole bigger than my lust for death after the film. If Earth's humans get turned into apes like that, how the f*** did Leo stay human? (I'll leave out the words next in my mind, because the IMDb would reject this thing.) Plus, how does the theater audience stay human? (Just kidding, but still...)This is the type of film that makes people consider suicide. Name a worse film that I haven't seen, and I'll consider seeing-and destroying-the film. No? FiguresRating: -2537396746584475673/6 (Lately, that thing hasn't been working.)</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2001-09-08</date>
		<username>Asteri-Atypical</username>
		<score>0.3</score>
		<shortDescription>Watch it for the effects, not the story</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I had mixed feelings about this film.Let me start by saying my enjoyment would have been greatly increased had this been a pseudo-sci-fi, action, ape-based flick that stood on its own merits instead of being associated with "The Planet of the Apes". There were certainly things in this film which made it worth seeing.Despite what is said, the visuals and effects were interesting. There was enough story to at least hold the interest of most.Sadly, what it lacked are those elements which made the original PotA good. The original had weak effects to be sure and the plot even had its problems. Nonetheless the depth of the plot, the debate about the content of man, the thoughts and concepts that were classic, are all missing. I would have hoped that in a "re-imagining" the philosophy and concepts would have CHANGED; but not that they would have been omitted.I still use illustrations from the original to elucidate points. I didn't walk away with such a feeling from this movie. The debate between superiority of human vs. ape has been reduced to scant allusion to racial tension. There is enough illogic to not deserve itemization (the horses have already been discussed quite throughly). Worst of all was the ending. My friend and I are quite familiar with sci-fi, fantasy, irony and great literature. We "get" most every reference. However, BOTH of us looked at each other and said "huh"? While there may be some explanations for this they didn't even establish enough clues for some healthy hypothesizing. It seemed just "thrown in" and out of context with the rest of the movie.To close out the critique I will just state that there is a positively tragic movement in Hollywood to "dumb down" every creation. It's like Hollywood has the touch of mental mediocrity. You'd think for scores of millions of dollars they could somehow come up with a story and content worth the millions of dollars of effects. Give us something that can stimulate our minds, not just our senses. I fear this "re-imagining" fell prey to this phenomenon.That being said, I return full circle to the fact that this movie enough going for it to have been enjoyable were it to stand on its own (and taking into account the current brain-dead state of today's Hollywood scripts). There were a couple homages to the original movie which gave us a laugh or two. As I said, the effects and even visual composition were worth seeing. If you wish to see a movie to go "ooooh" and "aaahhhh" over the effects as opposed to the "invisible effect" approach (where you are engrossed in the story, not aware of the visuals being "effects"), then you will enjoy this.I would recommend watching this. Just enjoy it for what it is and don't expect a level of content comparable to the original. At the very least, this movie is FAR beyond the level of any "Apes" SEQUELS, which had thoroughly useless plots without the concession of good effects.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-09-08</date>
		<username>The Letter P</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Quit moaning</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Sometimes I wonder if people go to the cinema purely for the purpose of moaning and sniping about the films they see. While I will admit that far too many films are moronic today, so to are far too many of the audience. The original Planet of the Apes is undoubtedly a good film with some stunning moments ( it's wonderful how a film gets elevated to the level of masterpiece when people need a reason to moan about its sequel / remake ), but the potential was in the premise for a different type of film. For all the original's strengths I think you'd be hard-pushed to claim it was exciting, or visually interesting. Tim Burton has seized the opportunity to explore these possibilites, resulting in a highly entertaining if undemanding film. As a complete redraft of the original it is ultimately a very different entity, but it in no way embarrasses the original nor takes anything away from it. Honestly, what do the 'how dare they do this to a classic film' brigade imagine is going to happen? Do they think the original is going to cease to exist? That from now on people will only ever discuss the remake? Unlikely. There is little in this film that will cause much discussion, but then I've never heard anyone discuss the original either. And yes, the ending is obvious and not as good as the first one ( as the most known 'twist' ending of all time they could scarcely have repeated it ), but there is nothing in the original that scarcely comes close to the amusing satire on human behaviour to be found in the first half of Burton's remake. Most important of all (and this goes out particularly to those who decry the tarnishing of the original 'classic'): This movie is FUN. You can't say that for the '68 version...</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-09-07</date>
		<username>Indy-52</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>null</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I have to say it. Tim Burton's retelling of Planet of the Apes is more fun than a barrel of monkeys.OK, that's off my chest. No more monkey puns, I promise.Seriously, though, Planet of the Apes is one rip-roarin' summer outing, filled with thrills, action, adventure, wit and bits of funny (dare I say, monkey) business. I know, I know, I promised.And for those film buffs who are fond of the original, Burton's version includes a couple tips of the hat to that movie.Mark Wahlberg stars as Capt. Leo Davidson, a deep-space pilot whose ship gets drawn into a magnetic field and hurled into the future. He crash lands on a planet where apes are the dominant species and humans are hunted, captured and sold into slavery.Despite being darker than the original, Burton's film is not as heavy handed nor as sanctimonious.Some of the movie's flashes of humor are surreal as well as typically Burton: An organ-grinder ape with a midget or an elderly ape taking off a wig and removing false teeth as he prepares for bed. Then there are the parents who buy a little girl as a pet for there young daughter. The seller advises the parents to get rid of the girl before she reaches puberty: "One thing you don't want in your house is a human teen-ager," he says. You don't have to be an ape to realize the truth in that statement. Touches such as these are what stamps this movie with Burton's brand.Lines that hearken back to the original movie are sprinkled throughout: The first words spoken by an ape to Davidson as the astronaut is regaining consciousness and grabs the simian's foot to try righting himself are: "Take your stinking hand off of me, you damned, dirty human." Anyone familiar with the first version of the film will, of course, recognize the irony in that piece of dialogue.Another of Burton's in-jokes is to have Charlton Heston, star of the original, play the chimpanzee father of Tim Roth's Gen. Thade. The young chimp goes to visit his dying father. Both have one thing in common, a hatred of humans. With his dying breath, the elder spews out his vile: "Damn them, damn them all to hell," he says before expiring. That is the famous line Heston's Taylor shouted at the conclusion of the original after discovering the planet's terrible secret.The performances throughout are top-notch. Wahlberg plays Davidson not as some gung-ho hero, but as a confused and somewhat frightened explorer who only wants to return home. He is reluctant to lead the human rebellion; his only objective being to find a way off this upside-down planet. This hesitation is what makes his character believable and vulnerable.Roth is ferocious, cunning, cruel and savage as the fascist chimp who wants to rid his planet of all vestiges of humanity. He leaps and bounds as if he had springs on his feet. It is a masterful turn.Helena Bonham Carter is Ari, the chimp who believes that apes and humans can live in peace and as equals. Hers is a smart, compassionate characterization.Michael Clarke Duncan is big and brutal as Attar the gorilla aid to Thade who blindly follows his leader until his faith is shaken.A fine comic outing is given by Paul Giamatti as Limbo, the ape slave trader making a living off the misery of the humans he captures. As the battle between apes and humans looms, the cowardly Limbo pleads, "Can't we all just get along," echoing the words of Rodney King.Much of the success of Planet of the Apes goes to Burton's technical crew, especially production designer Rick Heinrichs and the legendary Rick Baker who created the ape makeup.Burton's musical collaborator, Danny Elfman, provides another fine score, though it is not as memorable as his work on Batman or Sleepy Hollow.The movie's only letdown comes at the very end where Burton tries to outshock the finale from the 1968 original. He comes close, but falls short.Otherwise, Planet of the Apes is what a summer movie should be: An amusement park ride filled with lots of action, stunts and a few laughs. This is one feature in which the expectations lived up to the pre-release hype.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-09-05</date>
		<username>hernebay (franz.schmidt@btinternet.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>An insult to the intelligence of 12-year-olds</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>As a committed fan of the original movie, and also of the under-rated TV series, I felt duty-bound to see Tim Burton's reinterpretation, despite the off-putting hype. What I saw can be simply and honestly summarised. Special effects (the least consideration of any cinema-goer whose IQ achieves triple figures), very good. Make-up, very good (Thade especially). Mark Wahlberg's acting, monosyllabic and wooden. Helena Bonham-Carter's acting, a little better than her usual low average. In my native England this movie carries a 12 rating (i.e. suitable for viewers of age 12 and over), which slightly over-estimates the level of intellectual maturity required. A complete absence of plot and character, but a superabundance of noise and violence. Much jumping and gratuitous aggression from the apes, considerable banality from the humans (especially Wahlberg). Given the considerable resources available to Burton we are entitled to something considerably less moronic than this flimsy, catchpenny movie, which cynically exploits brand loyalty and the reputations of director and cast. The truth is that this film will not bear scrutiny six months from now, let alone in a decade or so's time. None of this will matter. Mugs like myself have ensured that it was a box-office smash. More fool us.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Superfluous</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I've read somewhere that this is the worst movie Tim Burton has ever made. Well, for that, its pretty cool !On the other hand, there is nothing in it to get in any way excited about it. Just a very average science fiction story. Well the surrounding are made very nice. The apes really look and behave like intelligent apes. But the story itself lacked any noticeable inspiration, except maybe some nice jokes - such as apes fearing water. On the other hand, there where story holes, and unexplained parts. 	<review>
		<date>2001-09-03</date>
		<username>Graham Hughes</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Marky Mark and the Monkey Bunch</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>It's hard to be objective with this new vision of Planet of the Apes, as the overwhelming desire to compare it with the 1968 original is almost too much to bear for any would-be movie critic with too much time on their hands. However, a word of caution ? they are two very different movies. The original, with its world-weary Heston, moralising anti-nuke plot and the gee-shucks-can't-we-all-just-get-along narrative, plays out like one of the better episodes of Star Trek. Tim Burton's take on the simian planet is a million miles away (literally) from the Franklin J. Schaffner version, and so we have the action and the hokey chimptalk, but none of the social relevance. This, quite frankly, damns the film, damns it all to hell and makes it yet another summer blockbuster of running about and shooting at nasty things.However, considered out of the context of the whole Apes saga, this is a damn fine no-brainer popcorn-flick with plenty of action, plot twists, rugged heroes and monkey madness. Helena Bonham Carter makes a decent chimp, Tim Roth makes a decent psycho-baddie and Mark Wahlberg makes a decent, well, underwear model. There is enough to keep your average film junkie happy and the movie does not outstay its welcome.Hollow, but entertaining nonetheless, Planet of the Apes (2001) is not a bad film and is only disappointing when compared with a) the original b) Tim Burton's back catalogue. It's also a damn sight better than the four sequels and the TV spin-offs. Come to think of it, The Simpson's Planet of the Apes Musical may not be such a bad idea after all...</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Planet of the Grapes (Sanitized version)</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>When I took my son to see this, I tried to set my expectations real low, as I had read the reviews. The visual eye-candy is 100% brilliant, and it's not a disagreeable way of passing 2 hours, so what's wrong? Unlike the original film, the humans haven't regressed mentally, in fact they seem quite cultivated. The film contains no real challenges, no warning of ecological disasters. This film is just a "product" there is no religion, no politics, no racial problems. In fact humans and apes can get along just dandy, just with a twist of the director's pen.This is the Planet of the Apes series "Phantom Menace". Tim Burton: remember the anguish we all felt in the original film when we saw all human history reduced to the head of the statue of liberty poking from the sands... THAT WAS CINEMA!!!</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2001-09-02</date>
		<username>mentalcritic</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>On second thoughts...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Maybe I don't enjoy this film more than I would enjoy the original Planet Of The Apes films, or even the television series, but Tim Burton's recreation of them has gotten a pretty raw deal, all the same. People scream that the makeup effects weren't well done. Well, what do you expect from an attempt to synthesise human faces with ape bodies? I felt they were done just the right way... such that they looked like apes but the actors were still recognisable.Tim Burton's deft touch in the set design and photography lends his usual dark edge to the film, making it far more grown-up in appearance than the pastel-like sequels to the original Planet Of The Apes, especially the television series. Everything looks a lot more believeable, and the sets appear much more functional. The Omeron looks much more like a deep-space research station, and the flight pods look more like they were designed for their purpose.Mark Wahlberg is good as a caring human being, and I really believed in his compassion for the monkey, but he doesn't quite possess that leader quality. I think it would have been better if he'd been supported by one or two more humans from the space station. The ending, such as it is, had me a little perplexed too. Here is a man standing on the verge of a brave new world where men and other members of the animal kingdom can be educated to work together in harmony, he has a beautiful woman who wants him, and he decides to go home. Sorry, I just couldn't buy that, but then, it's pretty plain to me that the Earth of 2001 just sucks.Still, with all the barbs about inter-species arrogance, reverse racism, and the origins of cults, Planet Of The Apes is one film that should be given a fairer hearing. Maybe the critics of today just need to put down their Bibles, their filmmaking guides, and their prejudices towards old, outmoded special effects, and just lighten the hell up.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2001-09-01</date>
		<username>CyberPredator</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A different take on the Ape concept.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>When I first saw the original "Planet of the Apes" film on DVD, it blew my mind. It was such an incredibly moving film and was so brilliantly well done. Even the 1968 ape make-up was amazing. So when the 2001 film came out, I was anticipating seeing it.My first sitting of the film was somewhat mixed. The opening progresses quite quickly and jumps straight into the point rather than dilly-dallying with any character development. There was an awful lot that happened in the film, and I didn't really get the chance to process it all until after the film had finished. That's not to say that the plot was hard to follow; it just took me a while to process everything that had happened. During that delayed reaction, I commented rather negatively on the film, but once I'd processed it all I appreciated the film a lot better, and thus the film was much better.During my second viewing of the film, I saw it for what it was: really good sci-fi action film. That's not to say that the re-working of the film is a bad thing: the remake gives a fresh angle on the ape concept, which can be a great thing if it's executed correctly. And the 2001 version of "Planet of the Apes" executes it brilliantly.In the modern film, genetically-enhanced monkeys pilot survey pods through unexplored space while the humans stay safely on their space station. When one such monkey is lost in an electromagnetic storm, pod pilot Leo Davidson (Mark Wahlburg) decides to attempt a rescue. With his navigation instruments down, Leo crash-lands on the planet of the apes....just as an ape hunting party is rounding up a fresh wagon-load of human slaves.Critics will say that the new film completely ignores Pierre Boulle's original novel, but it doesn't. The modern story is very different certainly, but it is still closely tied with the novel. Human-sympathising ape Ari (rendered absolutely superbly by Helena Bonham Carter) suggests a reason for why Earth's apes don't speak ("the way you treat them; maybe they don't want to"), which comes from Boulle's original novel. And the movie's ending (one that'll make you gasp out loud) is lifted straight from the original novel.Everything about this film is excellent: the modern ape make-up is amazing, the peformances are of an incredible standard (especially Helena Bonham Carter and Tim Roth as the human-hating ape Thade), and the characterisation is just as superb as in the original film. The film is brutal enough to make a statement about man's inhumanity to man (and ape), yet there is still a definite humour in the ape parodies of society.This truly is a great film. Go out and enjoy it.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-09-01</date>
		<username>Dean` (soulstormred)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Its Planet of the Apes, set for a new target audience.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Unfortunately I've seen a few bad reviews of this film floating about, at first i thought that this was because of the films somewhat confusing ending. Now i see that people didn't get the idea behind the new film. The film IS a 're-imagining' or whatever you want to call it, and it is not a 're-make.' If you go to the cinema expecting to see the original 'Planet of the Apes' only with different actors and better effects you will come away feeling disappointed, if you go expecting to see a Tim Burton film on a par with the likes of 'Sleepy Hollow' and 'Batman' and with different messages behind it you'll get what the film was trying to do. This is a problem of any film trying to do something thats been done before, the film its self is lost in the comparisons, take 'The Phantom Menace' for example, if you hadn't of seen 'Star Wars' you'd probably thing it was a great film on its own.Long story short: They've taken the original 'Planet of the Apes' and set it to a new target audience. Take that into account when you see it and you'll see a truly great modern film.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2001-09-01</date>
		<username>nicki-25</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Better than the critics</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>*** spoilers ***I neither do belong to the core-fans category for the classic movie from 1968 nor am I a huge fan of Tim Burton movies. Nevertheless I think Burtons "re-imagining" is better than the critics generally say about it. The center problem is I guess that most people stay with comparing it with the original version although Burton always said he invented new characters and therefore it's not a remake. OK the story-line first is comparable and actors re-appear in the new one but the way Burton used these elements for his new version, is partly very funny and sometimes cynical. I like the scenes when Attar (Michael Clarke Duncan) tells Davidson (Mark Wahlberg)"Take your stinking hand from me, you damn dirty human" (remember Heston when he shouts out this one in the original but then dedicated to the apes) or Charlton Heston appears as Thades (Tim Roth) father and telling him about the former power of the humans because of owing guns (that is cynical, especially when Heston tells this and I liked it). But the Burton version has a strong visual accent, perfect make-ups of the apes main-characters (Thade, Attar, Ari, Limbo), a break-through performance by Roth and an interesting story why these apes do rule the planet. It's quite entertaining and - come on - for what further reason was this movie produced? Some things - very independently from the original - could have been made better, for example the acting of the human roles. I guess that Wahlberg in his role as crash-landed pilot is physically strong but not very emotional. He does not seem to be very surprised to find himself in a world upside-down. That's sad because I think he can act quite superb. Estella Warren is only there because they needed a kind of female human that attracts the male moviegoers I guess. She never does find a real part in the movie. There are also logical mistakes in it, some scenes are superfluous (especially some scenes in Ape City) and the ending is strange but what's the point? It's a movie on a blockbuster-concept and it's made for the masses. With this target I guess Burton has done a solid job.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Einstein's nightmare: the time roundabout...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This is one of those films that you just watch once and desist to watch it again. I must confess something: I never liked very much Tim Burton's cinema, and this time it wasn't an exception. The worst thing I find in this film is the whole plot. It's so strange that I'm sure that even Tim can't give a proper explanation.From now on: WARNING, SPOILERS AHEAD.I always heard that time travels are mathematically possible if we follow Einstein's theory. I also saw films like Back to the Future where a change in the past affected the future. But I never saw a film where a change in the present could affect the past. What happens in this film is so weird that it needs a powerful explanation to make it acceptable. As powerful as a second movie, and maybe that's just what Tim was thinking.Here: END OF SPOILERS.Behind the makeup, Helena Bonham Carter looks more like Michael Jackson than like an ape girl, Mark Wahlberg's character is plain and insipid, and the film as a whole is quite boring. I have seen much worse films this year, but this one is bad.5 or 6 out of 10.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2001-08-30</date>
		<username>mikeandrachael</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A typical Hollywood attempt at a remake...typical failure.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Everyone we talk to agrees: Planet of the Apes 2001 is a disappointment. Did they spend a ton of dough to make it? Yes. Is it a blockbuster like Armageddon, Independence day and the like? Almost. Did Shrek and even American Pie 2 make more money (which means more warm bodies and eyeballs)? You bet. Without giving away the weak plot, Tim Burton has screwed up, and had his first bad story, bad acting and his first sell-out. When analyzing a movie, I look at the director's choices: cast, editing style, photography, dialogue and subtext. Cast: Mark Wahlberg deserves a huge movie, he deserves the cash and the popularity. Michael Clark Duncan is typecast as a big tough guy. Tim Roth plays a good bad guy. Helena Bonham Carter could have been replaced by anybody. The savage humans were poorly used, and where did the female human store her MAC makeup kit? Editing: Typical use of quick cuts, swish pans, high speed shutter shots, typical of current batch of action films, usually disguising a bad action sequence. Photography: adequate, did not give away effects, slow motion overused in action sequences. Dialogue: Terrible. Granted, even the Star Wars films have crappy dialogue, but the actors pull it off. Much of the conversation is trite, and the exposition is blatant. The humans should not speak, making the astronaut all the more unusual to the humans and the apes. Subtext: Not enough of it. They hardly touch upon the whole issue of the sensitive apes wanting to free the humans. And the sappy speech by Helena about the human who came from the stars...gimme a break.That being said, the makeup was good for the men, bad for the women, overdone for the female human lead. The sets were overdone. If they had metal helmets and spears and shields, why are the cages made out of wood. The whole time for bed escape scene was too campy for this film. Finally, as a movie that keeps one's interest, this movie fails. About 30 minutes in, I wondered if it was over yet. Thank goodness it's over now. Rule the Planet? I'm afraid not, Tim. Stick to superheroes and Johnny Depp. And if you've got Kris Kristoferson on your payroll, I think the world is ready for Pee-Wee Herman and the Last Crusade.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2001-08-29</date>
		<username>mikerichards</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>Of man, apes and lip-gloss</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>'Planet of the Apes' was originally made in 1968 and turned out to be a box office smash, despite a rather limp plot and none too subtle allusions to the racial problems wracking America. It went on to spawn a number of weaker sequels and a short-lived TV show with ever decreasing results.Having said that, any of them have to be better than this luke-warm effort from Tim Burton. The studio was clear that this was not a sequel or remaking of the first film, it was a 're-imagination' - but it is quite clear that imagination is one thing missing from this movie.As with almost all big studio movies in 2001, the plot has been released back into the wild and is noticeable by its absence. To make up for this oversight the movie lurches from set-piece to set-piece throwing off any semblance of thought and coherence. Rather than have a plot, the movie sets up all sorts of gimmicks to get the heroes out of difficult situations. Mark Wahlberg has a gun in his survival kit, uses it to scare off some hostile apes. But two minutes later the gun is destroyed - oh no, what will they do now? No problems, right at the end of the movie ANOTHER gun is introduced from thin air to help out the heroes. Why not just keep the first one, or not have a gun at all?Instead of having the heroes, (or heaven forbid), the audience think, the movie always plays dumb. The climax is set in a ruined space ship that has been sitting in the desert for thousands of years. This ship (a hugely impressive set) has rusted through almost entirely, collapsed in places and is filled with sand. Yet little tiny switches work first time, convenient doors open and close with satisfying swooshing noises and there are video clips to explain the plot to the hard of thinking. There is simply no magic to the film, no satisfaction in working it out for yourself.And when its not playing dumb, it has gaps in the logic that make you go 'eh'? For instance, if the apes and the humans are both only on this deserted planet because of a crashed space ship, where did the horses come from?Is there anything worth seeing? Yes, Tim Roth's performance *IS* excellent, he does convince you that he is playing an ape and has a fine time chewing the scenery in the finest pantomime tradition. This is helped by some truly astonishing prosthetics used on his face. The rest of the ape designs are less successful, particularly Helena Bonham Carter's mask which is so thick and expressionless that she looks like a Muppet and forces her to talk with an irritating lisp.But if there is one thing that sums up all that is wrong with the film it is Estella Warren - beautiful, blond and completely and utterly pointless. Long lingering shots are devoted to her pouting and flicking her hair, but she does nothing else. Perhaps it's my age I couldn't help but think of Raquel Welch in 'One Million Years BC', but at least she had the decency to be chased by a dinosaur, Ms. Warren just stands in the background like a sulky teenager appealing to the teenage demographic. Perhaps I'm being too hard on her, because she does provide a tiny glimpse of hope for humanity. Apes may well be ascendant, mankind is reduced to savagery and the whole edifice of Western civilisation has come tumbling down but thanks to Estella Warren we know there is a bright future for orthodontistry, a girl can be sure of a fabulous leg wax and there is no shortage of non-smear lip gloss. A planet run by apes doesn't sound quite so bad now does it?</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
