		<fullReview>Wow what a great blast of a movie . This is not a remake of the original so be forewarned . The premise is the same but the story line is not , most people like me were left dazed ,confused and shocked esp at the ending .what a cool movie.SPOILER ALERT**** -- dont read below unless you want to .contains ending spoilers.The ending has Marky Mark going back through the time warp storm in space back to earth and his chronometer shows him going back to his own time.Yet when he crash lands in Wash DC , he gets out and looks up at the statue of Lincoln which is now a statue of General Thade ,the ape from the future planet of the apes . And the police are all apes that show up. Id like to see what they do next for an encore . If you go by the original movies , he should have been on the earth of the future when he crash lands at the beginning .But how could that be possible by going into the past and earth is changed as well to an ape planet at the ending ..I agree with some other comments . One theory is that when he goes through the time storm after the lost chimp and into the future that he does not land on future earth but actually another planet in the future. Somehow the chimp does not go through the time warp and just floats off in space and the spacestation crew that are looking for Marky crashland at present while looking for him on the same planet without time warping. This sets off a chain of events leading to the future Planet of the Apes and that the humans are descendants of the spacestation crew and the apes are evolved from the apes that were test subjects on the station. Also near end of movie the chimp arrives in the future which is more confusing , leaving us to believe that somehow the chimp mustve landed here in the past as the apes had knowledge of his return as foretold. Then the chimp somehow takes off again to arrive in the future.And then after Marky takes the chimps spacepod to return to Earth its overrun by apes yet hes back in his own time . Somehow maybe the apes of this future planet used technology from the crashed spacestation to follow marky but ended up going back way further than he did and overtook earth . Thats a possibility but very confusing.Another theory is , he was on earth of the future .that even though it looks like he is nowhere near earth ,that the storm somehow sends him there in the future and when he leaves at the end ,it sends him back in time to earth as well. thats its a slingshot ,so even though it looks like hes traveling away from the planet ,its really only a time warp and hes traveling in a circle with just time changing.Only problem with that is , the spacestation he was on ,they come looking for him and crashland on the planet obviously way before he does. In the movie ,the ruins of the spacestation are a thousand yrs or more old.Could it be that the time warp only threw them a few yrs forward and marky a thousand ? And if it was earth why when they crash landed couldnt they get help ,where were the people?. And what really happened to the chimp,did he land in the past and then the future or what ?. So many paradoxes.Im guessing that the Planet of the Apes is not Earth. That somehow the chimp sets off the events in the past leading to its creation. The human slaves are the descendants of the spacestation crew sent looking for marky .The chimp somehow gets to the future Planet of the Apes, how he does that is a future mystery for a sequel. That the Apes use the spacestation technology and somehow get to earth much further in the past,obviously before the 19th century as the Lincoln Monument is now a monument to Gen Thade. Being highly intelligent and advanced they could have gone back just before Lincoln was around and changed history and thus Thade takes Lincolns place somehow. Too many theories .Wait for the sequel and let hollywood figure it out ..I liked it regardless of confusion.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>What do you want from a summer movie?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Wow! Lots of comments here, and most of them negative!It wasn't that bad. Tim Roth was terrific (villain of the year?), great special effects, great action, great humour, even some satire. What else would you want from a summer movie? Not the best or most logical script in the world, and not a patch on the original movie, but this is not unknown in a remake. If you believe what you read Hollywood has been trying to make a new "Planet Of The Apes" movie for years, and Tim Burton was the man who actually managed it. For that at least he should be applauded.The ending didn't really make any sense. Many people have already commented on the ending, and I will not add to the comments here. What I would say is that I wonder if Tim Burton, who has said that he will not be involved in a sequel, chose this ending as a challenge to whoever will be doing the sequel - and surely there will be a sequel. 		<date>2001-08-28</date>
		<username>Andy-154</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Wonderful</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I was hoping I would enjoy this film and I did!!!!Planet of the Apes really is a wonderful and engrossing film to watch. It has a unique look throughout, with some wonderful and vast sets and locations. The scenery is always slightly different, and that makes it interesting to look at.The conversations between the characters are involving, entertaining and in places even charming. There is some very amusing humour in there as well, nothing hilarious, but enough to get a laugh from the audience.... "There's nothing you want around your house LESS than a human teenager" for example, or the Ape with false teeth!The plot is also good. And to a certain extent keep you wondering what will happen next. Mark Whalberg is excellent as the main character. He's just the type you want in a film like this. Lets face it, you wouldn't want Sylvester Stallone or some other muscle bound 'Conan' type bloke down there. But Whalberg makes a very believable main character. General Thade's character is fantastic throughout also.Finally, you know throughout that SOMETHING will happen at the end. It was inevitable. And what IS at the end was very satisfying, hard to get your head around, but really cool none the less.And anyone who thinks that your a shallow individual for thinking that a 're-make' (or re-imaging) is good, is totally wrong. Planet of the Apes is a fine film that entertains throughout and doesn't disappoint anywhere......... and thats ALL anyone can ask for!</fullReview>

		<date>2001-08-27</date>
		<username>Chris Beyond</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Look at all them fancy monkeys!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I guess I should warn you that there are a few minor spoilers in this review. So if you don't want to know even minor details about the plot, do NOT read on... (but judging how much money the film made over the weekend, most of you have already seen this film...twice.)I went in to Tim Burton's PLANET OF THE APES really expecting to see one of the worst films ever. This was a surprise since I love every Tim Burton film I've ever seen (definitely not counting Batman 3 &amp; 4 which he produced, but had no other evolvement and it shows). From his first big screen film Pee Wee's Big Adventure, to my favorite Ed Wood, to the recent Sleepy Hollow, I've admired his style and direction...though most of his films seem to have been edited overnight in some parts.His latest is a "more faithful to the original book" adaptation of the french book; Planet Of The Apes...and just so you don't get upset while watching the film, the book is NOT set on Earth like the original was. In case you were born in the eighties and never knew the joys of playing with the Mego toys of the same name back in the 70s, I'll explain the basic story. A guy gets trapped in a space-storm that flings him to a world where monkeys rule and people don't. Yep, that about sums it up.The book was adapted to film in the 70s starring Charlton Heston and a bunch of similar guys with beards. I believe that the original's sequel Return To The Planet Of The Apes won a special achievement award for Best Beard in a Speaking Role. Not much is known about what happened to those beards after the 70s. I'm sure we'll see an "E True Hollywood Story" about those beards one day, but I digress...Actually one of the first things that sticks out in this new version of Planet Of The Apes is the lack of beards on most of the human characters. Mark Whalberg (of Boogie Nights) plays beardless human astronaut Leo who trains geneticly engineered monkeys to fly spaceships. When one of his monkeys gets lost, he follows it into a space-storm that hurls him to the planet below. This is where the story most of you all know kicks in. Leo is hunted down by human-like bearded apes. Soon he meets a human woman named Daena, her father, a chimpanzee woman who believes in Human Rights, and an orangutan slave trader who deals in humans.So basically we get a peek into Ape society and meet General Thade played by Reservoir Dog star Tim Roth who hates all humans, but loves to jump around and make monkey noises.I won't give any more story away, but lets just say that man and monkey fight and surprisingly the Apes do NOT throw poo. If there is one way to catch a human off guard it would be to throw "monkeypoo" (which, by the way, is my 1 word review of the film Monkeybone) at them. Actually, if they did throw copies of the movie Monkeybone at the humans they would have surly been destroyed much like our own society almost was when it was released.Ok so I liked this movie... There were a few things that bugged me like the make-up on the female "apes" and all the "wired" jumping and, of course, some of the dialogue. But in the end it's a movie about a planet where apes rule and people don't (see 3rd paragraph above). It's campy and yet interesting.Mark Wahlberg continues to bury his Marky Marc image in a role in which Keanu Reaves would have said "Whoa" a lot like in all his films.Helena Bonham Carter's Ari character is actually interesting unlike Estella Warren's Daena character who stands around gape-mouthed for most of the film.The make-up is excellent. Can't get much better `cept for the female apes that I mentioned already.And, YES, there is a "twist"...just not the one you remember. Check it out. Also look for cameos by Danny DeVito and George Clooney. If you blink, you'll miss them. And also look for interesting twists on dialogue from the original film.So, again, I went to this film with the most lowered expectations due to a lot of bad pre-press, but came out liking the film a lot. I'm actually going to see it again and you KNOW I'll buy the DVD when it comes out too. So go...enjoy. Buy candy at the liquor store and sneak it in. $2.00 for candy? Please!Reviewed by Chris "Beyond" aka Chris S. Morrill</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Tim Roth as the Feral Chihuahua</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I REALLY wanted to like this movie. I'd hoped Tim Burton would bring the same clarity of vision he brought to Sleepy Hollow, Ed Wood and even the first Batman. Instead, he gave us the second Batman: some great visuals, a few strong archetypes and a terrible script. Tim Roth as the feral chihuahua was ridiculously over-the-top and not in a good way. Perhaps Rick Baker should've stopped punching Estella Warren in the mouth long enough to find her motivation. Or at least a personality. This was a straight-ahead, cliched escape movie, with no pause for character development. The ending wasn't as bad as many suggest and is definitely feasible if you consider that Thade's ultimate fate is left up in the air. It'll take some explaining but it's possible. All in all, I'm hoping Burton will take a pass on the sequel and let someone with stronger STORYTELLING skills take over. NOTE TO JOEL SCHUMACHER: THIS DOES NOT MEAN YOU!</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>It could easily have been so much better!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>*******************************************Spoilers all the way, don't read this if you're planning to see the movie.SPOILERS! SPOILERS! SPOILERS! SPOILERS! *******************************************I am not going to say anything major about the plot, as it has been related better before.This movie irritates me a great deal. It could easily have been so much better, by some simple adjustments.This film has a lot of plotholes, and most of them could easily have been avoided.1. The language problem Both apes and humans speak english. Pretty stupid if the two species have been on the planet for 1000'nds of years. Why couldn't the two species have spoken some unknown language which Davidson could have been taught in some months' captivity among the apes. This could also have given us a better chance to learn more about ape history and ape culture.2. What are the characters motives for doing certain things? This is a big problem, perhaps the biggest in the movie. A. Why do Thade hate humans so enormously? B. Why do the slave trader switch sides so easily? This could have been better explained. C. Why did Leo Davidsom escape so soon? Wouldn't it have been more sensible to learn more about the place he had come to? D. Why did the blond bomb have a role in the movie at all? Her actions didn't have any significance. E. Why did Ari return to general Thade if she was interested in "The human cause". F. Why did Attar turn against Thade at the end of the movie? H. There are much much more...3. I believe there was something about a man coming from the stars. If this was better explained it could have made Thade's killing of the two space-arrival spotters more easy to understand. It could also perhaps have explained why Attar switched side in the ending.4. There are more, but i gotta go to bed now...------- Im not sure if i will comment much on the ending of this movie as i'm not sure if i understood it. Here are some ways it can be understood. (Perhaps...)A. They were at the earth all along by some strange twist of fate and Davidsons actions altered history so that we got an "Ape" Lincoln. That does not explain that it said general Thade on the statue though. I don't like this explanation, and i hope it is not correct.B. The travelling through and forth in the magnetic storm got Davidson into some other dimension beside ours, where Thade was a hero. This could explain why there were fairly nowadays police equipment and cars when the cops showed up.C. Thade may have travelled back to earth and changed history there after Davidson had gone. We have to note though, that the cops seemed to be evolved apes. This seems to suggest that it must have been a vast amount of time since Thades arrival and Leos arrival at earth. Difficult difficult... Another problem: If Thade and the apes fixed the Oberon in some way, and got it flying, isn't it kind of strange that the original crew didn't managed that some time directly after the crash? Even sophisticated technology is best BEFORE it has been lying around for some thousands of years...This is perhaps just rubbish, and i will be very thankful if someone did this explanation better than me!!!</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Was it written by Chimps?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Well I have just seen the movie and all that I can really say is that it is O.K., not a masterpiece or a total dud. The main problem I had, apart from the well signposted ending, was the fact that the constantly changing tone. The script goes from standard sci-fi to action movie to almost a love story, along the way there are attempts at slapstick and satire. There is even a bumbling sidekick! Towards the end it really lost the plot, don't want to give anything away( but trust me you will easily guess the ending) On the plus side the make up and acting were very good.*******SPOILER ALERT*******************SPOILER ALERT************The ending is quite simply a tacked on piece of nonsense, many people have posted ideas about it but none of them hold water. The writers needed a "surprise" ending and from the looks of things used the first one that came to hand. I know that it was the ending used in the book, that does not make it any better.Overall the bad points outnumber the good points but its close.</fullReview>

		<username>adam ferguson</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>possible ending?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Beware! Spoilers for those who have not seen the movie! I'll just question one glaring plot flaw I have not yet read, before I offer a possible ending to the movie. In discovering the 'mayday' message on the Oberon where Leo finds that he has unwittingly caused all the events etc. We hear the female animal/chimp handler stating that the monkeys have started killing them all. If this were the case, how could humans have eventually out - populated the planet 4 -1? With this and the horses (and certain aspects of the ape civilization) these to me are the major let downs in the story. I quite liked the time paradox angle. And remakes will always be viewed with scepticism by a generation old enough to have enjoyed an original.I watched it without any plot info on purpose (so it could unravel honestly and maybe I could enjoy it more) Anyway, I mostly did enjoyed it until the end then I got the impression there was enough plot for a sequel jammed into the last 15 mins. So if I sum up a few of the plot twists: Apes are descendants of our genetically engineered space cadets. They are deeply religious - except for Thades' bloodline (was his great grandaddy the violent one in the cage they were talking about in the beginning?) Ok we've got that sorted. I think that Leo's character was fairly honestly acted by Wahlberg. He didn't really care about any of the people or apes but just used them to get back to his ship (or what he thought would be his ship). So if for a minute we agree that he is a selfish individual, and that he has no choice but to rally the human troops or be killed by the approaching ape army even quicker (and ignore all that 'we can do it' crap) Heres my version of the ending: The second pod comes down with his chimp mate onboard (this is ok as we know the cosmic whatever has cause this time displacement) Leo doesnt just walk over to it and start man-handling the 'deity' as I'm sure the Gorilla Commander would have taken him apart. But the Space cadet bounds out into Leos arms in Friendship at least giving the still pumped up ape army something to think about for a minute. General Thade who lets face it is not going to calm down for even Simo himself goes all out to kill Leo as he is obviously threatened by the possible shift of power. The Fighting kicks off again and in the scramble Simo is killed, Thade has to kill his own Commander (who is religious) and Leo makes a run for the pod and escapes. In his escape into the sky we see the human element being once and for all dealt with by Thade and his now un-opposed command. Leo enters the cosmic anomally again and is ejected on the other side to what he can visibly see is earth (maybe just thinks he is lucky) he chooses america and flies in etc. Then the end could play out as written. I know I've rushed that a bit but at least it would have tied in the twist ending more plausibly. It also keeps with his selfish character, the total ape population of the 'final' planet and with the overall dark tone (Thankyou Mr Burton) of the movie. The overall massage of these films is what B******s we as a species are. So why even attempt a happy ending, and then mess it up even more with a meaning less twist at the last minute?</fullReview>

		<date>2001-08-21</date>
		<username>Lonixcap</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>More Bang For The Buck, But Marky's No Chuck</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I wanted to like this film, because the 1968 original had a strong impact on me. This is a very good movie, but it suffers from Mark Wahlberg's boring, one dimensional performance. Heston's Taylor in the original goes through a tremendous physical and emotional transformation and takes the audience with him. Mark's acting is a lot like James Franciscus in the first sequel-very wooden.The film also seemed thick and claustophobic, never really allowing itself to breathe. And the music-somebody tell Elfman that less is more, there's too much underscoring here. The supporting cast fares better, with good performances from Tim Roth, Paul Giamatti and Helena Bonham Carter, who channels a bit of Kim Hunter's Zira for good measure. The physical production-sets, costumes, effects, and of course, the makeup are quite impressive.The other major liability is that there's no equivalent to the philosophical jousting between Taylor and Dr.Zaius, hence there's not enough emotional meat for the audience to sink it's teeth into, so the plot twists are almost telegraphed in advance. The Rod Serling-type ending was cool,and you almost have to compare this to the original film, because it's nothing like the book, either. It's obvious a sequel is coming, and they'll do better if it's in the spirit of 1971's Escape from the Planet of the Apes. I give this 3</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-08-20</date>
		<username>modius</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A reimagination of a cult classic?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Without a doubt, the 1968 Planet of the Apes was one of my favourite science fiction movies of the time. Indeed, a whole generation grew up on the concept of "going ape" over the numerous sequels and the inevitable tv-spin off. So when I knew that Planet of the Apes was going to re-done, I was jumping for joy - at last a real chance to put a big budget to an original concept penned by the author of the book which inspired the Planet of the Apes movies. CONTAINS SPOILERS But with the movie, came casualties - fortuently, Tim Burton, director of Batman (1989), bravely took on the mantle that other directors (i.e. James Cameron) would not take on - the poision chalice that was to "revisit" the planet of the apes. Burton claims this version is a reimagination of the cult classic, but it is clear that Burton wanted to outdo the original in every way possible, and in some areas he certainly succeeds.The costumes, the make-ups, the sets, the direction and special effects is brilliant, and a much darker version of the original, but special effects and costumes do not make a good story. And this is where Burton falls down.The 1968 version of the planet of the apes illustrated and concentrated on pressing issues of the day, namely civil rights, racisim, and to some extents, animal welfare and slavery. The 2001 version, in contrast, doesn't answer or ask questions on any specific issue outside civil, the effects of time travel and animal rights. In fact, it seems to taken more from the Amercian Civil War, rather than today's issues.The plot revolves around a space outpost near Saturn's rings - that use's highly trained and intelligent chimps to do missions that humans won't do - one chimp is sent through an electrical storm to a planet, and Mark Walberg goes to rescue the lost chimp - only to find himself on the planet of the apes. Without revealing too much of the plot - it transpires that Walberg blames himself (with good cause).Yet, with all its dark and well developed speical effects, Its clearly intended as a summer blockbuster movie, it could have been so much more - espically from director, Tim Burton. I expected something wierd yet stragely compelling, yet we have a summer blockbuster movie that tries to get "bums on seats" without a good script and story that was compelling enough.We have the hero, Mark Walberg playing as wooden as I've ever seen him - in a constant state of concentration, with little emotion. Fortuently we have the over-the-top bad guy Tim Roth as General Thade and the wonderful Helena-Botam-Carter to keep the story moving at a fast pace. But sometimes the pace is too fast, there seems to be no time to look around, no time to actually dig at the concepts, the ideas, the questions that it was trying to raise to society, whereas the original stopped and took the time to create concepts and build on the ideas with the ability to ask the questions, and then answer them in a concise and logical way.Some may criticise it for being a trashy summer movie, and in some ways they are right. This isn't one of Burton's best - and nowhere near the original 1968 version - but if you took it as a standalone movie without comparing it to any other Ape movie - perhaps I can agree that it is indeed a good, watchable film - but it lacked the vigor, the charm of the original - and the ending was confusing, yet logical.Thade had gone back to Earth and caused a revolution in the same way that Walberg had done on the Planet of the Apes - the whole story is very similar to the novel - but there is one problem, how did Thade know where Earth was? No-one told him where it was, nor did he know what it looked like. In either case it was a clever ending, perhaps a bit too clever for its own good - because it made the audience confused.Of course the rumors behind the movie fuel the confusion. Was it true that Burton had edited the film right to the last minute? Were scenes cut that would have made the film more of a soul? Did Burton steal the ending of a General Thade sitting in the Lincoln Memorial stolen from someone else? Were there really five different endings? All these questions don't detract from the enjoyment of the movie - but it does make one ask where the soul of the film was and what it was trying to achieve.Throughout the movie there are many problems. For example, throughout the film I kept trying to figure out why, in the year 2029 did the American Space Force use Chimps, and not satellites or other robotic system to investigate the electrical storm? The planet that Walberg lands on is certainly not Earth, as it has two moons - yet, how does Thade (indeed, the whole ape civilisation) move from the planet to Earth? Why, when Walberg goes back in time, doesn't he try to stop himself or his ship from going into the storm? And why, when Walberg goes to Earth does he go straight for Washington, instead of Cape Caveral? Did NASA move its lauch facility to Washington DC?Despite the plots problems, the confusing ending (was Walberg really on Earth all that time or not?), and the general feeling that it had been rushed. I did enjoy the film, and it did make me think about the issues that it wanted to raise, but I just didn't think about the issues or feel enjoyment of the film as much I enjoyed and thought about the original Planet of the Apes - perhaps I'm giving the original too much credit, and Burton not enough - perhaps I demanded and expected too much and cared too little to what Burton was trying to do, trying to say with the film. Nethertheless, the message was lost in amongst the special effects and little care and detail to attention of the main concept of the film.Overall: An average, yet an enjoyable movie. 7/10</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>response to some questions.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>i know i am nnot meant to directly respond to another post, but i think these questions need to be answered:*******SPOILER ALERT************Q. How did the clock in the mini-spacecraft know what year it is? You see the year quickly moving forward - on what signal or date is this based?A. I dunno. But it turned out to be innacurate anyway, as Davidson was actually in the past.Q. In the original movie, the humans could not talk. This made it believable that the apes would treat humans like animals, because in our own world, animals do not talk. One of the biggest problems in this remake is that the humans CAN talk. This makes the idea that they would be treated like animals ridiculous. You can bet that if apes could speak English in our world, we probably wouldn't keep them in zoos, animal rights notwithstanding.A. Remember when Americans kept black people as slaves? I beleive they could talk, but it made no difference to their 'masters'.Q. How is that when Capt. Davidson (Wahlberg) lands on the planet, he enters it in the future, but when the main ship crashed on the same planet going after him, it was thousands of years in the PAST? Wouldn't the time be the same for both - after all, they are going through the same space-time distortion?A. The distortion was unstable, so it spat anyone that entered it out at many different points in time. Hence Davidson, the Monkey, and the main ship all entering at different times.Q. It's never clearly explained how the chimps mutated to become apes, and intelligent, English speaking apes at that.A. In the film it is mentioned that they were genetically engineered apes. After arriving on the Planet and killing the humans on the ship, thy evolved into English speaking apes.Q. How did the apes get from their planet to Earth and replace all the humans? A. The apes never left their planet. There planet was in fact Earth. Davidson landed on Earth in the PAST, therefore affecting the future. Since he didn't kill General Thade, we are meant to assume that after Davidson left to return home, Thade escaped from his captivity, got the apes to join him again and dispatched all the humans. So when Wahlberg returned to Earth in the FUTURE, it was populated by apes.Anyway, that's how i understood the movie.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Very dissapointing</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Tim Burton... Planet of the Apes... what could be a better combination? Well, pretty much anything. I was very disappointed by this movie. First the good - it is visually stunning, as you would expect from a Burton movie; there are a couple of good performances, particularly Helena Bonham Carter who is outstanding. Sadly that's it.Now let's get to the bad and the ugly. The story is so full of plot holes that you'll weep with anger. Didn't anyone bother to read the script? Its nonsense. Characters do things that are obviously absurd and have no internal logic. An example (warning: very minor spoiler), when they get to a river crossing guarded by part of the Ape army, Leo tells us that they can't go around because they don't have time - they have to ride through. But then they wait hours until the dead of night before doing that. The only reason they wait is to make the visuals of the "ride through the camp" scene more dramatic. This makes no sense. It is literally nonsense. And don't even get me started on the ending... its meaningless.Its not just one scene, almost every point in the movie is gibberish if you think about it for more than 2 seconds.Beyond that the characterizations are non-existent. Apart from Leo and a couple of the apes, no one has a character. Who on earth are the humans? What motivates them? Would we care about them if they all got thrown into a giant meat grinder? No we would not.What is most annoying is that this could have been a great movie. The visual execution is stunning. The apes look real and move as you would expect an evolved ape to. They must have spent so many hours and so much money on that aspect of the film. Why did they only spend 26 minutes and $2.80 on the script?Finally, however much of a cliche it has become and however cheesy the costumes where, the 1968 film at least tried to be about something and its famous ending was genuinely related to the point of the film and was truly shocking. The new Planet of the Apes has no point; its ending is a crass setup for a sequel. What a waste of a great potential.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>It took three writers to finish this?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This movie was a rank defiling of the memories I have from childhood of the Planet of the Apes movies and TV shows. I don't know if I was more disturbed by the fact that the acting was bad, the makeup occasionally laughably bad, or the nagging feeling that the end was rushed and limited because they were running out of money... hard to tell. But I have decided the majority of the blame should sit on the shoulders of the writers, who obviously just punched the clock and saved their best stuff for something else. It is impossible to build a good movie without a good script.I'm sick of seeing movies like this one, that cash in on a big opening weekend before word of mouth can get out that it stinks. I'm also sick of seeing movies where it is obvious that the writers ran out of steam and rather than take time to make a good product, just churn out another piece of mediocre crap. Everything doesn't need to be high art, but decent entertainment is a good aspiration.</fullReview>

So Calima when Mark scrubs the rest of the dust away was actually Caution Live Animals (And there was me thinking that Calima was homage to Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom).I can't understand why people are confused about the ending to Tim Burtons remake. What Tim Burton is trying to say, is that as Darwin's evolution tells us, we are direct descendants from apes, now that Mark and his scientist friends, they have tampered with the evolution process, and now the apes are direct descendants from humans. And the statue Mark sees isn't Thade or anyone else but An "Ape"briaham Lincoln (I know corny joke).Another thing is that according to the (TWIST) ending he was on earth all along so therefore where did all those people come from in the ape world? 		<date>2001-08-19</date>
		<username>snodes</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Dumbing down for the current generation?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Whether written or film, Sci Fi works best when it's either ahead of it's time and cautionary, or of it's time and satirical. The original Apes' films fell in the latter camp, using the generation gap of the late 60s, the optimism and expectancy of the moon shots and (increasingly) the racial tensions building up in the states as its themes. Tim Burton's film does neither, living with the glib message that "we should, uh, just all get along and live with each other".Though there's a fair amount of spectacle to enjoy and a cracking performance from Tim Roth, POTA is ultimately unsatisfying. Up to this point in his career Burton was part of that small (miniscule?) group of American directors who had managed to deliver witty, scary, ironic, enjoyable films AND managed to get them distributed to your local McMultiplex. POTA sadly whiffs of compromise and poor editing ending up being confused and confusing.Go and see it (at the end of the day it IS fun) but don't let the phrase "hang on, why...?" appear in your mind at any point and don't be be tempted to wonder that if, in 30 years during which we've been able to shrink computers to a tenth of their size and digital watches have come and gone, monkey make-up still looks as ropey as it did when Roddy McDowell first started piling it on to spook Charlton Heston.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>possibly a spoiler - fantastic adaption of the original</shortDescription>

		<username>eshy76</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>Weak second half of the film capped by nonsensical ending</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>* WARNING - THIS COMMENT CONTAINS SOME SPOILERS *I haven't seen the original movie, so I watched this with a completely open mind, without any expectations (except for the fact that I expect Tim Burton films to be top notch!)... ...anyway, the movie starts off in great enough fashion with some nice special fx. Burton does well to convey the Wahlberg character's sense of desolation after crashing on the planet and an interesting subplot ensues, involving Helena Bonham Carter's ape character and the attempt to escape from their masters. Tim Roth is absolutely outstanding as the general - you won't see a more expressive pair of eyes! The love triangle element with Estella Warren's character (what a beauty!) is also fairly well handled.The film simmers along nicely for the first half and then completely degenerates towards the end. The first absurdity is when (*SPOILERS AHEAD*)Wahlberg's monkey jets in and stops the battle - the scene just looked silly, it did not look like it could turn the tide of the battle...then later the henchmen (sorry henchapes!) of the general capitulate too quickly without really being convinced.And the "twist" ending was just well...incomprehensible I thought...another writer here said he found it easy to understand because it was a take on the original film's ending....but for someone like me who hasn't seen the original, I just thought - huh? Was it meant to be a "what-if?" scenario, or was it a direct consequence of what had happened before? I couldn't get my head around it...maybe I'm thick...need to think about it a bit more, but I suspect that I still won't get it...Overall - a good first half to the movie....great performance from Roth and Wahlberg was good too...Burton got the visual style of the film spot on and the costumes and ape make up were just awesome and any special fx used looked good...unfortunately, plot holes and inconsistencies in the second half of the movie undid all the good work and effort put into the rest of the film.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Could have made it better (Contain Spoilers)</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I haven't seen the original version of the film so I can't compare the two versions. I just saw this film and I must admit, they could have done a better job. The special effects were good and there were some funny moments but the plot had a lot of holes in it. Capt. Leo Davidson was captured, sold as a slave and escaped on the same day! How realistic is that? There were too many unexplained scenes. Why did the Army Commander kill those two apes that told him about the crash? How did they know this particular human was from space? Why did the General switch sides? It may be a fiction but even a fiction can be made more believable. It was a good film but it could've been much better.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-08-18</date>
		<username>ambassadorforhugs</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>I'm not sure what to think.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I haven't seen any of the original Planet of the Apes films so I can not compare the remake to any of them. However, I do know how the original Planet of the Apes film ends and I would say that it seems a much easier ending to understand. Don't worry, I won't give any spoilers for either film.The acting was very good, especially Tim Roth as Thade and Bonham Carter as Ari. I don't understand why others have complained about the poor acting. The special effects are also unbelievably brilliant in every department and a lot of effort was put into the little things like the behaviour and mannerisms of the apes.However, there are plotholes and the ending is very confusing. This doesn't mean it doesn't make sense as so many people have claimed. No offence to anyone but you should really make sure you understand the ending and it's relationship to the rest of the film before you judge it. I myself don't understand the ending 100% and am therefore making an effort to find out what it means.Some of the plotholes pointed out by others are minor and don't really make the film any less enjoyable. Then again, I don't fully understand what happens in the film so maybe the plotholes are significant. Anyone who claims to understand the end can feel free to explain it to me.Possibly the poorest area of the film was the action scenes. They just weren't exciting enough.All in all, although I didn't fully understand the ending, the film is entertaining and definitely worth seeing. I might change my mind if I ever see the film on video, seeing how the special effects and sound effects were breath taking, but I'm sure I won't ever consider this to be a dismal pointless movie. There's just too many clever ideas for that too happen and I can't stop thinking about the film now.My provisional rating: 7.5/10.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>FigNewton</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>Not Going Ape For This One</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I had anxiously anticipated the release of this movie since I first saw the trailer. It looked promising, exciting and fun. As I sat through this movie I was wondering..."Why am I sitting through this movie?" "Planet" leaves much to be desired. The only thing great about this movie are the visual effects. If you love effects, you won't be disappointed. I like effects but not in place of a good story line which this movie certainly lacked. I saw the original and was floored by the awesome story told. This version said nothing. It had no balance, no texture, no nothing but lots of awesome effects. I guess Hollywood thinks audiences today are too brainless to follow a plot that they feel they need to entertain us with an all you can see buffet instead of giving us some credit to THINK! I was disappointed to say the least. But the effects were great! :)</fullReview>

		<username>veej209</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Not as bad as every one keeps saying(*SPOILERS)</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>(BEWARE: SPOILERS ARE COMING UP PRETTY SOON - STOP READING IF YOU HAVEN'T SEEN MOVIE YET!!!) First of all, what was up with all those apes smoking bongs? that was really messed up! it was so random and unnecessary! i thought it was hilarious, though! Not to mention Ape-raham Lincoln at the end! That was a priceless (and some would say tasteless) mockery of a beloved American president. plus, i never knew apes could jump through the air like the warriors in ;Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon&amp;lt and who ever heard of a man kissing an ape-human?! That was just wrong; very. very wrong.Anyways, This movie does have many holes in it's plot, and the acting at times is very sub-par, but the basic story and the surprise ending at the end are at the least thought-provoking. Yes, the first one has a great ending, but i am very glad that this one took an entirely different route with it's overall plot (although the basic "planet ruled by apes" premise is still there). reading the previous reviews, it is obvious that those who didn't like the movie obviously didn't fully understand the surprise ending. You see, Thade, the ape-villian, never died at the end. he just sat around in the spaceship after helplessly shooting his flare gun, and after mark wahlberg went off, he somehow found a way to work one of the spaceships. Just like how that one ape said, "Thade will stop at nothing to get you." So, thade flew up into space, inadvertently went into the space time warp area, and flew way back in time. There, he became Ape-raham Lincoln and emancipated (yes, kinda cheesy) his fellow apes from the shackles of...well, you get the point. Then he dies and becomes a hero representing freedom and liberty to all ape-kind. Kinda interesting to think about. It's so bizarre and strange that it made for a genuine surprise in this movie-goer, even despite the fact that i was expecting some sort of twist.that still doesn't justify apes getting faded on bong hits, though.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-08-17</date>
		<username>Darren Coe (darrenc@grampian-software.co.uk)</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>I'm confused</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>With it's excellent effects and direction this film was always going to be a big summer hit and unfortunately that has given them the excuse the forget about the plot. The film starts well enough dropping clues and introducing the main human. It flows along nicely with alot of references to the original film ('Take your hands off me you damned dirty human'). There is a humour and darkness to the film that can only be provided by Tim Burton as well as his trade mark scarecrows. But as with all good things, what was right about this film came to a crashing end and that comes at the end. The initial plot resolution seemed to be an afterthought and then the 'shock' ending was illogical and did not seem to tie in with events in the rest of the film. If anybody has any theories as to how the ending is possible please let me know as we haven't been able to work it out.So for effort, cast (especially Estella Warren), direction and initial plot I give this film 6 out of 10. But it would have been higher had the ending been better.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-08-17</date>
		<username>(darrranT)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Review of the film - caution comments on Ending!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>&lt;Caution, possible spoiler comments here!&gt; I have just seen the movie and to be honest I do not know if I really liked it or not. There were some great aspects of the film, some of the characters had real depth, the acting and special effects were very good, and the general feeling of the Ape world was certainly believable. The problem for me was that firstly the initial plot twist was very obvious from the first minute of the film (expecting a twist, a space station with Apes and Humans above a strange world - an unusual space occurrence, straight from Startrek Next Generation?) and I'm still actively puzzled by the ending.&lt;Do not read onwards if you have not seen the film and wish to do so&gt; The end of the film, the hero locks general thade in a zoo with supreme irony, kisses the ape, kisses the girl and fly's back to earth (surprisingly quickly for a space exploration shuttle). He arrives to find that General Thade has beaten him to it, and that Apes evolved as the superior species to man on Earth. That's where I get confused, was it a parallel universe (star trek again?), in which case how did Thade get there? Was the Ape planet actually earth, and after 'Leo' leaves the planet he returns to find that millennia have passed and Thade had taken over and become the leader? Is it all a coincidence, why have the timelines changed on earth? how did Thade appear as Abraham Lincoln and just how did Apes invent fire engines and police cars etc when Charlton Heston himself (Thade's dying father) had told us that Apes lacked the creative genes necessary to do this?In conclusion, I think I liked the film, it is amusing, thrilling and intelligent. The ape effects are really good, and whilst some characters are nicely developed, there is a shallow element to some. The ending does have me mystified, but its possilbe that I missed the point.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-08-17</date>
		<username>trevor.hickman</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>PoTA - Never send a monkey to do a man's job</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I wanted PoTA to be my favourite film of the year, which on reflection it probably ended up being. Lacking the originals social comment, and released at a time when the World's social ills and insurgency are less than in Charlton's '68 original, the film nevertheless provided good action sci-fi and a clever (if not a bit confusing) ending.HBC gave a good performance, and Roth probably outshone Wahlberg as the mean and devious Thade. A great looking film, well delivered by Tim Burton, who was the ideal director to carry the primate adventures into 2000.Burton brought subtle humour to the film (which I had anticipated being a lot darker than it turned out). The orang-utan love pastiche, the little girl as a pet, and the two card playing apes - one calling the other a "Cheater" (Cheetah).A lot of acknowledgements were given to it's father film. Several quotes and a cameo Heston. I preferred the fact that the apes on Burton's planet were unarmed, other than with clubs, the original (especially the TV series had them kitted out with all sorts of weaponry). It was a shame one of the original underlying mantra of "ape shall never kill ape" was dropped, but by and large it stayed relatively true to it's original.Overall: A good re-working. 8/10</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-08-17</date>
		<username>imajk</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Plot holes, yes. But, please, slavery not one of them!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Yes the movie has some pretty serious plot holes, all described in other reviews and won't be repeated here. I don't want to ridicule other reviewers, but to suggest that the apes would not enslave humans, or consider them savages because THEY CAN SPEAK ENGLISH and display intelligence is unbelievable baffling. The very point of the whole D*** movie is to point out how unfair and bigoted people (or apes) can be. Of course it's illogical, that is the point !!! Has no one heard of the basically continuous human history of enslavement of our fellows ???? Funnily enough there was ample evidence of intelligence and language there, even English, and yet slavery went on! All this real life enslavement with one hell of a lot less motivation (greed basically) than is provided the apes in this movie. Please if you are going to go on and on about plot holes at least stick to safer ground. Do the other plot holes really detract from the movie, decided for yourself. I thought the whole look and feel of the movie made up for the its other shortcomings, and that it was a worthy remake of a much loved classic.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>famousgir1</username>

		<shortDescription>A Very Impressive Movie.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I've seen the original Planet Of The Apes and I think it's very good but this 'new updated version' is even better. 	<review>
		<date>2001-08-16</date>
		<username>room102 (plasmapool@gmail.com)</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>Rule the planet</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>After all those reviews and comments, I feel that I have to add mine.I'll start with the things I liked:The make-up is fantastic. The always-amazing Rick Baker did an incredible job here and created some truly realistic apes - I'll risk in saying that it's probably the best ape make-up ever made, and - as some people have already mentioned - a lot better than the make-up used in the original series. I especially liked the make-up for Thade (Tim Roth). My least favorite is the make-up for Ari (Helena Bonham Carter), which looks quite different from the rest; I guess Rick wanted her to look "half-human" (a similar approach was used for the wolves animatronics in the 1994 "Wolf"), but for me it was too distracting, as it looked too fake. Actually, she's the ONLY ape who looks fake.In addition to the make-up, costumes (Burton's regular Colleen Atwood) and sets, I realized that what makes the apes especially realistic is their movement and their use of space (jumping all the times, using trees and roots, etc.). This aspect is another credit point for Burton, who always put special attention to the behavior and movement of the characters (Lisa Marie as the Martian Girl in "Mars Attacks!" immediately comes to mind) and made the actors go to "ape school".Danny Elfman's score is always fantastic and this one is no exception. The use of primitive tools and jungle motives in the main titles is great. It starts quietly, as a simplified and primitive tune and builds up (as usual in Danny's themes) to a march piece of heavy metal instruments, "like bars closing in", as one review described it. While the theme reminded me past works such as "Men in Black" and "Dead Presidents", other cues reminded me of Danny's earlier works such as "Mars Attacks!", "Edward Scissorhands", "Batman Returns" and the "March of the Dead" from "Army of Darkness". Now that I listen to the soundtrack, the final part of the track titled "The Return", which ends the movie, seems to be highly influenced by the work of Bernard Herrmann (Danny's mentor).One thing that I liked about the plot *SPOILER ALERT* is the added explanation for the apes being "smart" - the genetic treatment, which is unfortunately ruined totally later on (I think. Depends on how you understand the ending). *END OF SPOILER*Two bits that made the movie entertaining for me were the parts of Limbo, the slave trader (played by the hilarious Paul Giamatti), and the two guest appearances by Glenn Shadix and Lisa Marie (as Senator Nado and Nova) - I wish they had a bigger part in the movie.And now to the things I didn't like:First of all - Estella Warren. From the very first moment she appears on screen, early in the movie, I felt her casting is wrong. Except for putting her as an attraction for the male audience (me amongst them), I saw no reason for using an amazing blonde model, dressed in small rags, for this part. It simply distracts you from the movie and damages its realism. I wanted to see Lisa Marie in this role, just so she could have a bigger part, but this one wouldn't solve the real drawback -Aside for the casting of Estella Warren, the role of Daena (and her entire family, for that matter) seems absolutely redundant - She has almost no interaction with the hero, and seems to exist only to fill the role of the traditional "blonde girl the hero kisses at the end" - not to mention that this kiss seems completely out of place, since they had no interaction before that. The same, though on a smaller scale, goes for the rest of her family, which seems to be "dragging" along with the hero for no apparent reason.I think the biggest drawback of the movie has to be its script. There are lots of things to say about it, and I'm not sure where to start. Here are several points: The script (especially the last quarter) seems like a big mishmash of bits from the movies in the earlier series; The script has no "social meaning" at all - the writers seem to have taken an everyday-life cruel behavior towards animals (and a politically-correct objector) and reverse the roles, without debating any valuable issue; None of the characters seemed to have depth and we get no reason for Ari being so fond of the ugly humans; *MAJOR SPOILERS ALERT* The fact that the apes and humans, who live as primitives without any technology and don't know what a gun is, are not a bit surprised by digital gadgets, spaceships and "a weapon that blow-up everyone", in addition to the fact that is made by primitive humans who can't invent anything; The ending that didn't make much sense to me, other than trying to give a shock and a surprise that would be different from the one in the original movie - one which you simply can not top; This in addition to the disappointment in revealing (a minute earlier) that the "planet of the apes" is indeed a strange planet and not Earth (which, as I mentioned earlier, destroys the rather good logic that was built up to this point). For a moment I thought the writers were trying to play a trick on us: because we were expecting to hear that the humans destroyed Earth, we instead see that apes have overtaken Earth - so perhaps they are the ones to destroy it? But then, the earlier planet is not Earth?; There also seem to be some plot-holes concerning the time traveling, both of the money and the spaceship itself; I also found it highly unbelievably, after the money came down from the skies, that all of the apes, who up until then considered humans to be filthy and primitive, decide in an instant that humans and apes are equal - the only reason for that seemed to be that the writers needed to get to the end of the movie. *END OF SPOILERS*</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2001-08-15</date>
		<username>Russ Graeber (russ_nick@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>LET'S GET A FEW THINGS STRAIGHT - SPOILERS AHEAD</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The original planet of the apes movie (and arguably three of the four sequels) were much loved by folk around the world - and quite rightly so. As Hollywood is always on the look out for a safe film based on an old movie/TV show that was much loved (when are they gunna remake Land Of The Giants?) and that is guaranteed to be a hit, it's a wonder it took this long to do a POTA re-make. Bearing in mind the sort of churlish, mind numbing, spirit crushing gruel that Hollywood has become so good at delivering the citizens of the world, POTA (2001) was not all bad.SPOILER AHEAD In a plot sense, there were holes all over the place.1. The Oberon only seemed to have humans and chimps - so where the devil did all the gorillas and orang-otans come from?2. In the year 2029, can it really be easier to train a Chimp to control a pod than automate it some how? I betcha HAL could've controlled it remotely, and that's using late 20th Century technology.3. Why did Attar turn on Thade at the end? He said Thade lied to him, but about what? Also, we are expected to belive that Attar will gruesomely kill his old master, and then suddenly start sprouting Gandhi like dogma about apes and humans living together in harmony. I THINK NOT. General Urko would not have dropped his bundle like this.4. Where did the gorillas develop this fear of water from - current day gorillas are prepared to wade through water.The ending is like something out of a 50's masterpiece. However, a 50's masterpiece would leave the ending alone. I'll be surprised if we don't see a new Planet Of The Apes franchise developing. The sequel will explain how the apes took over earth. It should not be explained, any more than the ending of any Twilight Zone story need to be explained.POTA 2001 is worth a look - you may even enjoy it 6.5/10</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2001-08-14</date>
		<username>Alan Yim (alany@telusplanet.net)</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Consistency please...and a different ending.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Where should I start? The hype for this movie came out months before its release and generated a lot of interest, including mine. Mind you I've never really seen the original movie, at least not all of it. But from the promos and interviews, this was Tim Burton's version of the movie, which was basically a bit more up-to-date, realistic, and cutting edge. But I couldn't help but wonder what or who would allow the ending they chose to be shown. Let me warn you that there may be spoilers in this review.The basic premise to this movie revolves around a scientist (Mark Wahlberg) getting stranded on a planet years into the future. The situation arises because of a strange anomaly they encounter in space and at the time, humans were using chimps as test pilots to send into unknown or high-risk situations. Their test pilot was sent in to examine the anomaly (which was to do nothing more than to do a fly-by) and suddenly vanished. Wahlberg's character, being the softhearted scientist, against wishes flew in to rescue the test pilot and himself disappears only to reappear hundreds of years into the future to crash land on a strange planet. He discovers very quickly that humans are not the dominant species on this planet but apes are and he is quickly rounded up to be a slave. His only driving goal from that moment on is to escape and somehow get back to his crewmates.To be honest, the storyline isn't very strong, nor is it overly intelligent. The audience is given a very basic premise and is told to go along with it. However, if it weren't for the ending, I think a lot of people wouldn't have minded. There are little things throughout the movie that make you wonder how it's possible that something could happen. One of the major ones is that in the future on this strange planet, apes have evolved into intelligent speech cable creatures. But they allegedly came from the science station that Wahlberg's character came from as a result of them coming to search for him and crash landing on this planet. However, the science station was using chimps as their test pilots so where did all these apes come from?? As well, there are humans on this planet, which the movie at one point indicates that the entire crew of the science station was killed by the chimps when they turned on them. Where did all these humans come from?and the horses?? Yes there are horses! It seems for the sake of making this movie they made a lot of assumptions and conveniences but the audience is not that dumb. They will pick it out and they will remember when the sequel comes out. There's no doubt about the sequel. The ending was left in such a way that a sequel would be created. Was there anything I liked about this movie? Well they did remain accurate on ape movements and that element created a sense of fear and menace that the apes in the original movie didn't quite have. The make-up and special effects were pretty good but then Tim Burton has always been good at those areas. Overall I wasn't overly impressed. The movie was acceptable up until the ending and after what I saw for an ending, it kind of ruined everything prior to that. It sounds like I'm being harsh but if you don't believe me, go ahead and see this movie. Just don't write back to me complaining about it because I warned you. On a scale of 1 ? 10, I give it a 5. I thought it could have been much better. Not enough time spent on developing a reasonable and logical plot line.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-08-14</date>
		<username>leon123</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Great!!! (SPOILERS AHEAD)</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I saw it and thought that it was awesome, baby! (A little Austin Powers lingo there). I know many of you didn't like or understand the ending, but I think I do. Now I don't know if this is what Burton had intended, but here's MY take on things. (Again, if you haven't seen it yet, STOP READING!)The astronauts at the beginning are investigating this anomaly in space and decide to send the first monkey into it for a closer look. Wahlberg goes after the chimp into the time warp, and also disappears. Obviously, the whole crew follows them in an attempted rescue. But then, towards the middle, the crew turns out to have arrived on the planet BEFORE Wahlberg. Leo arrives after they do (some 3000 years later), and the chimp arrives after Leo. This is the exact REVERSE order they went into the time warp. (Still, this does not explain the horses, so I guess that does go as a goof!)Later, when Thade is trapped in the spaceship and is not killed off, I saw EXACTLY what Burton was going to do! I thought he was going to show us that in the second movie, but he teased us with it in THIS movie: Thade somehow escapes the ship, gets his band of Apes together, comes back to the ship, and escapes in it with his apes to Earth, probably in a period post American Civil War (after Lincoln). They fight the world, take it over, deface the Lincoln memorial, and put General Thade's face on it. Many years later, Mark arrives back on Earth, and finds that Apes rule! Again, note that Leo leaves the planet before Thade, but arrives on Earth AFTER Thade, the exact same thing that happened before. This is the only logical and obvious explanation of what happened. Anything else would make for a bad sequel. (Hope I haven't given away the sequel :))</fullReview>

		<date>2001-08-13</date>
		<username>Kielle</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Disappointing</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I admit that I've only seen the original for the first time this month (though I'd seen a making-of-the-series show and thus was aware of the basics), and I acknowledge that this new version is only supposed to be inspired BY the original -- not a faithful adaptation. Therefore I was prepared to accept the new movie on its own merits.Even so, I walked out of the theater scratching my head and wondering why they'd bothered doing it at all.Yes, I love Tim Burton. Yes, the costumes, make-up, and sets are amazing. Yes, it was fun, had some good lines, and featured some marvelous acting on the part of Helena Bonham Carter, who was remarkably believable in her chimpanzee-inspired mannerisms and movements.Other than that...so what?Without spoiling too much of either movie, I have to say that the message of the original was far more intelligent. It really made you stop and think: who's right, who's wrong, do we have any right to judge the apes or should we learn lessons about our own failings in theirs? This one was merely simplistic summer-movie fare, with a predictable plotline I was correctly forecasting as little as five minutes into the movie.(Yes, and I easily guessed the "surprise twist ending" everyone is raving about. Yawn. You want a REAL surprise twist ending, go watch "Sixth Sense" or "Unbreakable.")Last but not least, I find it interesting that Heston's character was likeable precisely because he WAS such a crusty cynical old b*****d. Wahlberg's "brash hotshot pilot" persona conforms to almost every "hero" stereotype in the book...and, thus, is entirely bland and uninteresting, though I do not knock him as an actor. I DO give the writer(s) full credit for not going the obvious route with the annoyingly "perfect leggy blonde" potential love interest, but other than that...well, not much I can say.In short: rent the original and pretend you don't know the ending. You'll get your money's worth.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2001-08-13</date>
		<username>giancarlo de lisi (giancarlorocks@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>The Planet has been Ruled!!!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Many emotions struck me while watching one of the summer's most anticipated films ?Planet of the Apes'. Yet, the emotion that struck me the most was that of ingenuity. Director Tim Burton proves himself as an ingenious filmmaker and he proves it twofold in this exciting, inventive and thrilling film. The sets are spectacular, costumes are terrific and Danny Elfman's musical score captures the essence of the film as he does with all his musical compositions for Burton's films. The producers of the film have stressed that this is not a remake, but more so a ?revisiting' of the original. Anyone who compares this film to the original is gravely mistaken due to the mere fact that the 2001 version has been dichotomized by one of the ?soon to be' legendary alternative filmmakers - Tim Burton. This film widely separates itself from the original as seen from its' first frame and takes off on a whole new different direction. The film opens with a great credit intro. sequence displaying Danny Elfman's fierce musical score which sets the film's tone not as an unrealistic fantasy, but as a rousing sci-fi/adventure. The opening scene depicts Wahlberg's ill-fated space station attempt at conducting test runs with the ape species. After a mishap forces him off the ship, Wahlberg's character Leo Davidson finds himself crash landing on a distant planet ruled by apes. This is where the fun begins? Director Tim Burton puts a classic spin in this film invoking the notion of role reversal. In this planet, humans are the pets, the slaves, in essence humans on that planet are all the things we as humans on this planet earth shape and torture our inferiors to be. A great scene is one of the very first that immediately displays the intelligence of these iron fist creatures conversing around the dinner table about the threat of the human species. Enter this year's ultimate movie villain ? General Thade. The incredibly underestimated and unrecognizable Tim Roth plays this overachieving ape villain who is hell-bent on the total annihilation of all humans with fierce audacity and destruction. Upon the dissection of this film as a cinematic lesson, one will discover many ?plot holes' - (Did Leo Davidson and Ari, his rebellious ape escort have a love affair?) Many more plot holes - (Did Leo Davidson and Estella Warren's human rebel Daena also have an affair?). Mysterious deaths not explained - (Why exactly did one character so unexpectedly sacrifice himself for the sake of others and the rest of pack continue on as if nothing happened?) These mind-benders as well as others will occupy the intelligent filmgoer's mind for quite some time after the film.Yet, these questions can all be put to rest because Burton does not set out to win awards with this film (Except for Best Make-Up come Oscar time for Rick Baker). This film is merely a means of the best of the ?popcorn blockbusters' this summer. As well, we see Burton's maturity as a Director in relation to the grandeur of a film. Let's face it ? the revisiting of the classic apes' films is a huge undertaking. And for Tim Burton to create and present a richly satisfying, fun film is quite the achievement. Anyone who expects a brash film course should not watch this film. This film wants the audience to have fun and to dwell into a world never seen before in this uniqueness. Therefore in this sense, the film scores some big points in terms of imagination and vision. The film makes it a point of paying ?homage' to the originals yet distancing it enough so it is not afraid to make fun of itself. Furthermore, despite its surreal qualities, fantastic set pieces and incredibly true to life ape creatures brought to life by a wonderful cast, the film's major drawback is that it seems too dark and animalistic for its' own good. We are all aware that Burton's visionary uniqueness is brought forward with dark sets and spooky visions. Yet, it seems as if Burton intentionally wants us to know this is his creation even when we are entangled within the film, resulting in the darkness and primal aesthetic being overused. But in an odd way this is what adds to the genius and excellence of it all. Resulting in this film easily regarded as one of Burton's best films.Giancarlo's Rating: ***</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-08-12</date>
		<username>Snap Dad (rwgordon@students.latrobe.edu.au)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>this movie is not bad.... give it a chance...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>a huge fan of the original (and the following sequels), i came into this movie hoping to like it. luckily i was impressed straight up with the costumes and the sound effects especially... they really have an impact.the ape world that burton creates is similar to the original, humans are slaves to apes, the exception in this case is that the humans can speak...after a number of in-jokes for die hard fans and guest cameo's etc, the movie settles in to tell it's story... with the original movie giving it's shock ending, i wasn't sure where the answers would come from, but the script was wonderfully inventive with the matter it had to work with. a number of different aspects are explored in this movie that were covered across the entire apes series.and so is it any good? i think, if you liked the original movie and the series then you'd find it interesting to watch just to see what they did with the story. if you don't what all the fuss is about, perhaps don't bother... i don't think this would work as a movie on it's own...interestingly, a lot of people seem confused about the ending, stating it doesn't make sense. i agree... there are no "clues" given about as to why the movie ends that way, so just run with it... enjoy the irony, laugh at the audacity and unfullfilled expectations and sit back and wait for inevitable sequel ;)</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>Nick</username>

		<shortDescription>"Damn Tim Burton!! Damn him to hell!!"</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Remakes can sometimes be as good as the original from what I hear, but in this case, its just wrong! 	<review>
		<date>2001-08-12</date>
		<username>Just_Voards</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Not as bad as some say, and not as good as others say...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>***SPOILERS*** ***SPOILERS*** Yes, here's another person so full of their own opinions that he feels compelled to post them on the internet. Here's my $0.02:First off, I agree with Leonard Maltin that POTA 1968 is a near-classic. However, people who espouse the movie's cultural importance are exaggerating to a certain extent. Let's "talk turkey" for a moment. The chief concern with POTA 1968 was to produce a well-scripted, entertaining family movie. Concern #2 was that the Ape prosthetics were believable and not something the audience would laugh at. Here's a little bit of trivia: As revealed in Arthur C. Clarke's "The Lost Worlds of 2001," Stanley Kubric and he were furious that POTA beat out 2001:A Space Odyssey for a special make-up effects Oscar. Go figure.The political commentary was tertiary. It was craftily woven into the script but was not the key purpose of the movie. Indeed it was so well written some viewers didn't even realize they were watching a work containing political metaphors and social critique. In fact 20th Century Fox studio exec. Richard Zanuck himself didn't even see those aspects of the movie, or to this day refuses to admit they exist. It is of some note that he produced POTA 2001.Modern day viewers who criticize POTA 1968 (or even go so far as to say the 2001 version in better) should keep in mind that we watch a movie with eyes affected by the era that surrounds us. The perceptions of a person who watched this movie when it first came out (or during a re-release sometime in the 70's as I did) will not be the same as someone who watches it for the first time today. I can only imagine what disparaging comments viewers in thirty years are going to say about the vapid quality of Hollywood excreta nowadays.Now let's look at POTA 2001 piece-by-piece: Script: I had a bad feeling when I saw three screenwriters, three executive producers plus a full producer!!! Whoah! This is just way too many hands dipping their opinions into the cake mix. It's no surprise that the story often screeches to a halt or leaves viewers scratching their heads in confusion. I won't go into the plot contrivances and holes except to say that Tim Burton should have asked for at least five more drafts.Make-up: Who needs to say anything more about this? One of the best parts of the movie. Previous user comments say all the chimpanzee women look like LaToya Jackson. Don't you think this is just the teensiest bit racist? I guess I'm the only one who thinks Ari (and Helena Bonham Carter for that matter) is pretty.Sets: Burton only directed this, folks. He didn't write, produce or design sets. However, it still comes off feeling like a peek into Burton's mind: dark, grim and definitely moody. The set direction is somewhat claustrophobic. Though this may be purposeful, it doesn't quite match the expansiveness conveyed by the long shots of the city.Acting: There's a reason so many of us love Tim Roth. I agree that his Thade will go down in the annals of cinematic villains. Are some of his lines incomprehensible because of the way he speaks? Yes, but Tim Roth sometimes mumbles and grumbles with any of his roles. So what? At least he's not Estella Warren. Guys think this woman is beautiful? Yuck. That's beside the fact that she couldn't act her way out of a paper bag. Why did they decide to have the humans talk anyway? Nothing was added to the story by their dialogue. Then again, almost none of the dialogue adds anything to the story, so what the hell. Carter is okay as Ari, Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa gets a decent role, David Warner is still alive and kicking, Mark Wahlberg is cardboard and emotionless (though this may be on purpose to reflect most modern day men) and the cameo by Chuck Heston is simply priceless.The ending: The next part is a bit spoily, so proceed at your own caution. As far as the ending is concerned, this is going to be disparaged and debated amongst pro and anti groups for some time. First off, before you put down a movie, try reading the book (for those that don't know - that's what you do with books; hold them in your hand and read them.) As stated in another user comment, the Boulle novel took place on a world other than Earth. When the astronaut returns to Earth we get a similar situation as in POTA 2001. But how could this coexist with the explanation of the ape origins in the 2001 movie? Simple, as explained in another user comment, with Thade recovering Davidson's pod, repairing it, and learning how to use it. In fact if a person thinks about what's going on instead of just letting their mushlike brains stagnate, this adds new irony to the end wherein Thade does to Davidson's world what Davidson did to Thade's. On the other hand, much of the rest of the movie cultivates our brains into mush so it's not surprising the end did nothing but confuse most viewers.Yes, this theory is hard to believe. But the entire premise of the third Apes movie, Escape from the Planet of the Apes, is based on Cornelius, Zira and a worthless throwaway character finding Taylor's ship, lifting it out of hundreds of feet of water, learning how to use it, finding fuel for it, and somehow managing to travel back in time with it. And all this is back story; it is never explained. At least Thade knows exactly where Davidson's pod is. And we're talking about a pod, not some multi-thousand ton craft. It's sitting no more than thirty feet below the surface of a tiny pond. Also, Thade has a tutor: the Ape Davidson left behind. However, it's a stretch even for someone who suspends his disbelief as easily as I that a little pod has 1) The power to achieve the velocity to break free of the planet's gravity well as well as 2) Fuel capacity to travel from Saturn to Earth.All this being said, I enjoyed this movie. Why? Because it was fun. Tim Roth was Damn scary. Wahlberg was convincing as a bland, everyday "stranger in a strange land." Much, though not all, of the supporting cast makes the world come alive to a certain extent. There's just enough of a story and hints of character development to pique interest, though granted not enough to last the entire movie. There are a lot of little things that are likeable, such as the tongue-in-cheek references to the 1968 POTA with the lines, "Get your stinking hands off me you damn dirty human!" and "Damn them all to Hell!" There's the reference to V'Ger (Star Trek: The Motion Picture) and Zardoz (Zardoz) with the name of the forbidden "Calima." POTA 2001 has it's flaws, but what doesn't these days? If you don't want to risk 8-9 bucks, go see a matinee.To the people who say "This isn't science-fiction": Let me put it this way: If I film myself lighting a match, that's science. If I film myself lighting a match in a cro-magnon setting, that's science fiction. Don't be a sci-fi snob.</fullReview>
	</review>
