	<review>
		<date>2001-08-06</date>
		<username>MadReviewer</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Not As Good As The Original, But Still Reasonably Entertaining</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Tim Burton's "Planet of the Apes" is not a remake of the original version of the film, but rather a "re-imagining" or different take of that original material. Wise move. The original "Apes" is a film that still holds its own as an all-time sci-fi classic; pretty much any attempt to remake it faithfully would wind up like Gus Van Sant's remake of Hitchcock's "Psycho". . . a pale imitation of greatness. By "reimagining" the original film, Burton gives himself the opportunity to start with the established mythology of the "Apes" series, as well as the ability to travel in a new direction with that mythology. The end result? The new "Planet of the Apes" is nothing Earth-shattering (pardon the pun) -- in ten or twenty years, it won't be looked at with the same reverence or respect as the original "Apes" -- but it's still good, and brings enough new ideas to the table to make a reasonably entertaining film.The story, which ranges in spots from good to barely mediocre, possesses some serious gaps of logic and suffers from an awkward opening. The first fifteen minutes of the film makes little sense, and lurches along aimlessly for awhile until it stumbles into the heart of its story. (Examples of some nonsense: Couldn't chimp-piloted ships simply be controlled by computers? Would highly experimental exploration pods be able to launch from a space station just by one rogue pilot punching in a two-second launch sequence?) The opening of the film admittedly does make more sense by the end of the film, but it's still not very good. It appears as though the writers thought of a solid middle and ending for their version of "Planet of the Apes" . . . but had no idea how to get the story past the opening credits to that middle and ending. The weak beginning seems like their best attempt to get the story moving to those points. As for the rest of the story, it contains a lot of good, even original elements, but some points are glossed over in a rather hurried fashion -- there's little effort made to explore some plot threads, and some of the explanations as to how and why things happen in the film are either weak or come completely out of left field. The story's excellent . . . for a second draft. I've read that Twentieth Century Fox rushed this new version of "Planet of the Apes" into production. Too bad. The story and script could've been excellent -- and more important, solid throughout -- with some more work.Despite the uneven story, though, director Tim Burton does a nice job, given the script he has to work with. If nothing else, Burton has a knack for giving films an eccentric look, and his version of "Planet of the Apes" benefits greatly from his eccentric touch. He evokes a lot of the weird imagery of the original films (the weird scarecrows, the desolate landscapes) without ever blatantly stealing from them. He also does a great job when it comes to focusing on the smaller, quieter moments in the movie -- for example, there's a macabre scene where a child ape puts her pet human in its cage for the night that manages to be disturbing and funny at the same time. Burton, though, doesn't appear to have a clear idea of the overall tone of the movie. In "Planet of the Apes", he goes for a blend of action, comedy, and seriousness . . . but the blend doesn't always work. Some of the humor seems out of place, and the action often seems stilted, as if Burton didn't know what to do with the apes apart from having them leap around menacingly. The film is one of Burton's better efforts, but much like the script, the direction contains a few distinct weak spots.As for the actors . . . again, it's a mixed bag. The apes comprise the stronger half of the cast, which makes sense, since the apes are the weirder of the two groups - and Tim Burton specializes in weird. In regards to the human characters, Burton would've been better off making the humans in his version of "Planet of the Apes" more like the humans in the original film - mute. Apart from the protagonist Leo Davidson (Mark Wahlberg), none of them add anything of import to the film anyway. The highlights of the individual actors come from mostly from the main characters. Tim Roth nails the part of villainous General Thade perfectly - he's one of the best sci-fi screen villains to appear on screen in quite awhile. Wahlberg plays Captain Leo Davidson in a manner similar to Heston in the original film; he's a man who's not terribly interested in contemplating how he arrived at a planet ruled by intelligent apes . . . he just knows he wants to leave. Fast. He's a pragmatic hero, one who reluctantly tries to help others in distress, but doesn't want to die in the process. Also worth mentioning is Paul Giamatti, who provides some much-needed comic relief as the peculiar orangutan slaver Limbo. On the other side of the acting coin, the biggest disappointment came from Helena Bonham Carter as Ari. Given the poor quality of her character in the screenplay, she does what she can for her character, but all she really does for the whole film is to go around being nice to humans. Period. Some reasons as to WHY Ari feels so passionately about helping humans would've been nice.Tim Burton's `Planet of the Apes' is an action movie that manages to take some of the influences of the original `Apes' films, and then creates something eccentric and new. Does it always work? No, although in general, the good outweighs the bad. Is it better than the original? Absolutely not. In a summer filled with blockbuster duds, though, there's something to be said for a film that provides some thrills and some fun, and the new `Planet of Apes' does exactly that. Overall, it's an enjoyable film; it's just not a spectacular one. Grade: B</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-08-06</date>
		<username>Brian Williams</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>Lots of wasted potential</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This could have been a great movie, but they dug themselves into a hole and then couldn't figure out how to get out. I enjoyed the up until the "battle" scene. Then things stopped making sense. Leo's big plan turned out to be a dud. The humans should have been wiped out. Then, even though the highly trained human pilot crashes not once, but twice, we are expected that the chimp pilot experiences none of the same problems and can land his pod without difficulty. Why does a cute chimp landing in a space craft make the apes suddenly believe that the humans aren't so bad after all?Then there's the stupid "suprise" ending. The whole movie is based on the premise that the smart apes evolved from genetic engineered apes that crash landed on the planet with the humans. So why are we supposed to suddenly believe that Leo would crash land in a second parallel world where Washington D.C. looks just like ours, but everybody is an ape instead of a human? This ending had nothing to do with the rest of the movie.It had potential, but it bombed instead.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>They made it dreck, Semos help us</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Maybe I should have been smarter, maybe I should have been wiser. However, when I went to see this, I was hoping, maybe even expecting, something intelligent that represented science fiction. However, this was not science fiction, and did not have an ounce of intelligence in its overly-long body. The movie is crap. It is dreck.First, I was not expecting the original. The original had a very '60s or hippy mindset about how humans destroyed the earth, and nature took over. That wouldn't go over now. So, I asked myself, what could they do to the movie to make it more modern. It seemed to me that they tried by making it be a metaphor for class wars, or political racism. But that was soon abandoned. Eventually it became the usual. A watered-down post-apocalyptic-like road movie (or escape, whatever).I was too busy searching for some sign of intelligence to tell you how the acting was (it could have been good, it could have been horrible). Visually it was stunning if you have to resort to that. And the score was wonderful (thanks Danny Elfman). But for the rest of the movie, skip it. I was so frustrated that before the ending came up, my Gatorade bottle was a crumpled mess.SPOILERS****SPOILERS****SPOILERS*****SPOILERS****SPOILERS*****SPOILERSThe end of the movie was just pure hilarity. Maybe I wouldn't have found it so funny if I hadn't called it before it actually occurred. Right as Wahlberg got into the pod, I asked my friend, "Wouldn't it be funny if Earth was taken over by apes?" Lo and behold, it happened. And with police cars and everything, it kind of reminded me of "Monty Python and the Holy Grail"'s ending. The Jefferson monument was a hark back to those cool cartoons where they would blow up Mt. Rushmore and it would turn into the villains face. Maybe I shouldn't be so judgemental, but that was the only redeeming part of the whole movie (and for all the wrong reasons).END SPOILERS2/10</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-08-05</date>
		<username>NJMoon</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Monkey in the Middle</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Here's a rarity - a review of POTA that's not a rave or a pan. Obviously it is a good-looking film, with terrific costumes, photography and make-up. It is also usually compelling storytelling - not Pierre Boulle's PLANET but not the original film either. Points for originality for sure. I like that the humans could speak - their lack of speech in the first film was never effectively explained. Even though the film is fleet, there is a noticable lull after Neil and company have successfully fled ape city. Burton wisely gets right on to the film's conclusion and (surprise) ending post haste. But while the story flies by, the character development is non-existant and the love story is divided between the female of TWO species. To be fair, our leading man is not the most compelling actor - but Heston was no Olivier either. The story has multiple holes - where did the horses come from anyway? There's no sign of any non-ape or human life except these equines but no clue is given as to why there are no other creatures about. The cameos by Heston and Harrison are badly handled though the refs to first film are fun for fans. The surprise ending manages to combine the shock of the original with the option for a sequel.Burton's film lacks the scope and epic feel of it's inspiration and it will doubtless join the LOST IN SPACE film on the rental shelves. Now if someone were to make Boulle's vision - that would be something.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>Andrew Benjamin (abenja1@bu.edu)</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Good movie but nowhere near original</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Planet of the Apes is a pretty good film but it had its ups and downs. The movie is about a astronaut named Leo (Mark Whalberg) who gets sucked into a portal and lands on a planet where apes rule. Tim Roth plays Thade, an army general who hates all humans. His right-hand man Attar (Michael Clarke Duncan) follows and executes all of Thades orders. Leo escapes with the help of a compassionate ape named Ari (Helena Bonham Carter) and is now a fugitive on the run from the apes. This movie I liked but I don't think was 100% perfect. I thought the make-up was not as good as the originals. The acting was pretty good by my standards. Like all Apes movies, the endings have to twist which this one did. Overall this movie was good, and recommend to sci-fi fans, but probably not to Apes fans because it really wasn't a remake in my book.8/10</fullReview>

		<date>2001-08-05</date>
		<username>Desidario J. Codinera (dcodinera@yahoo.com)</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Please stop comparing. Wahlberg is 'Leo' not 'George'.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Please note that Planet of the Apes (2001) is not a re-make of Planet of the Apes (1968). It's a re-telling of the story. And please look up the word "re-make", which in the context of "filmmaking", means "to make a film using the same story as that of an old film". To expand on that definition, it's means that in that same story, all the same characters are used like that of the original story, and the script is, more or less, the same. Examples of true re-makes include Sabrina and Psycho. POTA (2001) is not a re-make, because Mark Wahlberg's character was Leo Davidson, not Col. George Taylor. If 2001's version was supposed to be a re-make, you would see Tim Burton use the same characters, but he did not. So it not a re-make. Please stop comparing. Comparing 2001's POTA to 1968's POTA, is like comparing Tim Burton's Batman (1989) to 1966's Batman: The Movie!!!!!! They are not the same!!!!!!!! That's sound ridiculous!!!!!The title for both films are the same, but that's it...the plot is different, the characters are different....stop comparing....My review of Tim Burton's POTA is very positive. I was very impressed with this film. POTA (2001) was one of a few films I was willing to go see in a theatre this year, and I was not disappointed. Kudos to Burton and the cast and crew of POTA (2001). No need to make people understand the film, if they can't use their own heads. GO SEE POTA (2001) TODAY WITH AN OPEN MIND if you haven't seen it yet...OR SEE IT AGAIN, SO YOU WILL SEE THINGS YOU MISSED THE FIRST TIME AROUND, and enjoy it even more, like I did!!!Can't wait for the DVD for this one!</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-08-05</date>
		<username>Francisco Huerta (fjhuerta@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Avoid the comparisons. Just enjoy it.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>So many people are angered about this film... it's quite obvious something is going on here.Mainly, the fact that, being a remake, this movie had to stand up to the original one. A huge risk that Tim Burton took, and seemingly, with bad consequences.I was born 6 years after Charlton Heston went bananas on the original. I have *never* seen it. Once it was on TV, and I lost interest after five minutes. Not because it was a bad film, mind you, but because it looked too dated for me to watch, and I was in that terrible phase known as "adolescence". It would have been uncool to watch a '68 movie. I will correct this mistake later, when I buy the original "Apes".Anyway, I came into the movie theater with only one image of the original movie forever burned in my mind: the epic Statue of Liberty climax. I purposely avoided all reviews of this film, so as not to spoil the fun. And I found myself deeply immersed in another Burton fantasy, where reality is as dark and grim as the lush landscapes that are always depicted in his worlds of madness. He is an expert in depicting outcasts (as in Batman, Sleepy Hollow and Edward Scissorhands), and although Mark Wahlberg wasn't as strong as Johnny Depp, Jack Skellington (or even Michael Keaton) as a main character, he was credible enough. Helena Bonham Carter is still incredibly seductive, even under tons of makeup and (gasp!) a beard. The rest of the characters are convincingly depicted, and the makeup excels.Again, not knowing the plot of the original, the only thing I disliked about this movie was that during the first half hour it dragged a bit. I guess that was due to the number of characters that were introduced. Afterwards, the movie turns quite philosophical (at least, IMHO). Was it directed at racism (which, from what I've seen, is still alive in the U.S.)? At animal cruelty? Was it a veiled message that we, as a thinking race, are doomed to remain evil and cruel with each other for all time? Or was Burton only trying to entertain us? (I doubt the last assumption). Whatever it is, this is one of those rare movies that open up a world of possibilities due to the use of metaphors. In a way, very similar to fairy tales, where the main character has to have enough resources to thrive and survive in a hostile environment...*SPOILER AHEAD* *SPOILER AHEAD* *SPOILER AHEAD* ...that is, unless you realize this is a mythic story and not a fairy tale, and that the ending has an amazing twist. One that, if sequels are avoided, could be one of the best endings in *ages*.Mr. Tim Burton, please, DON'T make a sequel, and you will have done a homage to the original series. The ending is just *perfect* as it is.I hope watching the original movie doesn't change my mind about this one.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Great... but not amazing.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Planet of the Apes is definitely a good movie. No, it's not as good as the original of 1968, but it really is an entertaining movie. The make-up they used to create the illusion of apes being the dominant species is breathtaking and quite realistic looking. I'd say that's one of the strongest points of the film.As for the storyline, it is changed up from the original. In fact, it is a very different story all together. However, this does not change the fact that this is a good movie and I'm willing to bet just about anyone who goes to see it will like it too.You've probably all heard about the surprise ending (which isn't that much of a surprise... me and my friend managed to guess it right!) DOES make sense. Really, trust me it does. I don't know, certain people might look at it from certain and different angles... but I managed to come to the conclusion that no matter what time or planet your on, the apes still manage to evolve and overtake the humans. That may not make much sense to you if you haven't seen the movie, but it will.All in all, I do recommend seeing this movie. I went to see it with my friends and we all agree it was a good movie. 	<review>
		<date>2001-08-05</date>
		<username>moviereviews</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>The Ending (Obviously, Spoilers)</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>***SPOILERS*** ***SPOILERS*** I really enjoyed this movie. As remakes go, I thought it was done well. It did justice to the original, while changing enough of the story to make it unique on its own. As for the ending, when I read through the other comments posted on this site, I realized that many people did not understand it or they have alternate explanations to what I believe. Unfortunately, these other explanations do not make sense. Therefore, I will explain the ending to clear it up. First of all, and this is the most important fact, the planet that Mark Wahlberg crash lands on is not Earth. The whole story and everything that happens on this planet is a separate issue from what has happened on Earth when he returns. When he does return, he finds that Earth is now controlled by apes, obviously leading us to the question of how it happened. Well, we are given the most important piece of information to understand this, the statue of General Thade. We then know that he is the one who led the apes to the control of the planet. The next question would be how he accomplished this task. Well, he must first get to Earth in order to affect any change there. And the only way to get to another planet is to fly there in a ship. What ship? The one that Mark Wahlberg crashed in and the one that General Thade knows all about. How will he fly or learn to fly it? The chimp pilot that is left on his planet. So basically, here it is. General Thade is alive when we last see him. He escapes or maybe just pretends to accept the changes that have occurred on his planet. In order to flee the planet and perhaps to get some revenge against the human who changed his world, he salvages the ship from the water, somehow repairs it, assuming it needs to be repaired, since all we know for sure is that it had a rough landing, and then learns to fly it with the help, possibly by force of the chimp pilot. He travels back along the same route as Mark Wahlberg and enters the storm. He is transported back in time, but farther back then Mark Wahlberg. Once there, he leads a rebellion of apes on Earth against humanity and wins. That's it. It is simple and makes perfect sense and contradicts nothing we saw in the movie. And it is not even a new idea. If you have watched the old movies, and have seen "Escape from the Planet of the Apes," you will remember that the apes got to Earth in almost the identical way. They salvaged Charlton Heston's ship from the water, somehow repaired it and learned to fly it and returned back in time to Earth. I actually think that is part of the reason this ending was used; as a throwback to one of the elements of the old movies. Of course, this ending is a stretch to the imagination, but this is science fiction and the fact that it is possible is all that is required. If you have watched the old Planet of the Apes movies, you will know that the stories stretched the line of believability even thinner. This ending also adds the irony that is needed in these types of stories. Mark Wahlberg changes the course of history on another world and then leaves to go back to his own, but is thwarted by General Thade, who basically does the same thing to his world. Now he is stuck on Earth in an even worse environment then the one he wanted so badly to leave.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-08-05</date>
		<username>dlavender3 (dlavender3@home.com)</username>

		<fullReview>***SPOILERS*** ***SPOILERS*** The "suprise" ending that the trailer harks about was not really such a suprise. I saw it coming but it still makes no sense at all.If he travels back to his own time and lands back on earth how did what he did in the future effect the present? How is it that there is an Abraham Lincoln ape at the Linclon memorial. Flawed cop out ending</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2001-08-05</date>
		<username>Paul Chambers</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Much to like, much to hate</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>There's a lot to admire about the remake, and a lot to hate.It's an admirable attempt at a re-imagination of the saga but, please - why, oh why, were certain scenes played for laughs?The underlying story is so intrinsically interesting that surely it warranted a serious approach. Do serious approaches exist in modern American cinema? Would "Soylent Green" contain line-after-line of Arnie's witticism if they were to make it now?I'm not a huge Science-Fiction fan - for the most part, because most of these films never suspend my disbelief - but they can work, and they only work when they're played straight.I know that on rewatching the original, many have commented on Heston's bad acting or the film's just plain silliness in places, but give it the one credit it deserves - it played the concept straight-as-die.Most detrimental comments of the original derive from a certain misplace nostalgia:On rewatching, we feel like the film lets us down in some way - That's because our memory of the film is stronger than the film itself, and it tells us that we should expect so much more because the incredible premise of the story has haunted so many of us for so many years.All I asked of the remake was that it treated the story respectfully.I knew I shouldn't go in there expecting a comparable ending or a scene-by-scene remake, but does a re-imagination mean we have to deal with Paul Giammatti's ridiculous slave trader, or Wahlberg's cardboard stock hero one-liners, Heston's embarrassing cameo or the Senator's wife's home-in-the-Hamptons dialogue?Take the remake's phenomenal art-direction, make-up and effects, (and Tim Roth's amazing performance) mix it with the originals heart and you'd have one hell of a movie. Instead we have an off-the-shelf, early 21st century popcorn pusher. Come on Burton, what ever happened to the kind of imagination you had when you enthralled us with Scissorhands?</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-08-05</date>
		<username>dlavender3 (dlavender3@home.com)</username>
		<score>0.7</score>

I saw it coming but it still makes no sense at all.If he travels back to his own time and lands back on earth how did what he did in the future effect the present? 	<review>
		<date>2001-08-05</date>
		<username>jerk1483</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Comparison to original luckily stops at the first credit</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Yes, I too caught that AMC Planet of the Apes festival back in 1998 and learned the whole, convoluted chronology of the original series. I also learned that somehow, apes just learned to talk on their own, a lot like evolving, but maintained their hunched appearance and brutish looks. You couldn't call the original series science fiction, because it wasn't really based on science. In fact, in order to really enjoy any of the original films, you had to forgive a lot of fuzzy logic.This new "revisioning" of the original film makes a whole lot more sense of how apes learned to talk and walk upright and possess all those "human" qualities without having any overt explanation scene. It just makes sense on its own if you really think about it. You don't have to though.Anyway, Mark Wahlberg proves again that he was never supposed to be a hip hop star and acts his way very effectively through this pretty darned intelligent film. First off, leave it to Tim Burton to make comedic yet emotionally trying jabs at bestiality. If you see the film, you'll see what I mean. Secondly, we see how operatic life in politics can be, and still be fun.Tim Roth leads a tremendous supporting cast of action movie veterans. Of course, you won't recognize any of them through the amazing make-up. The action is amazing, and artfull while the story moves at a locomotive pace.Honestly, this movie never stops. And we all expected a big twist ending, better than the original, but instead, we get a twist ending with such a huge sequel come-on that I almost vomitted. The ending manages to work, come out of left field, and tickle you pink, all at once. I was either elated or nauseous, I can't decide. Overall, a really good film. Better than the original, possibly. The 68 classic had no limitations as to how high morally it could reach. So this new revisioning decides to change gears. Don't walk in expecting a social commentary. Walk in expecting a summer rollercoaster ride with a seemingly infinite shelf life. Your grandkids will be asking you if you actually saw it in the theater.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-08-04</date>
		<username>backseat-2</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>You have to really try hard in order to like this one</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I was not going to comment on this piece of stylistic dreck. Then I saw reviews from some folks who claimed that the movie was actually quite clever and people who disliked it were clearly not paying attention to the details. So, I carefully rethought the major plot points (there are few, so this was easy), and have a few spoiler type comments. Perhaps those who have not seen the movie yet can bone up on these thoughts and then see if I am still missing something.1) The monkeys in the beginning are genetically engineered to be smart, so that is why they were able to become dominant on the planet....OK, so one little chimpanzee crash lands on a planet with no monkeys. A whole bunch of years later, this chimp has not only acted like a plant seed and sired lots of other monkeys (of different species, no less) without sex or other monkeys to mate with. That IS intelligent. But wait, there WAS something about the 'crashed' mother ship that the hero finds on the planet...maybe our hero mated with those, but no, they are dead by the time he arrives. So maybe the apes on the planet came from the monkeys on the mother ship instead. This is lots better! It could explain how they turned into gibbons, gorillas, orangutans, and every kind of ape EXCEPT chimps, and this in a very few years. I guess that they were genetically engineered to evolve in amazing ways too. I could go on and debunk every argument I have seen for any part of this making sense, but I don't have all day. The plot in this regard is pure nonsense, and that is pretty much it.2) Humans had developed genetically engineered monkeys on Earth, and these clearly had also taken over, so the hero returns to Earth and finds out that they have become dominant there too. Well, I seem to have missed how this would change Abraham Lincoln into a monkey. Perhaps the symbology was just too extreme and the Old Abe thing a bit overboard. OK, then how did the Earth ape culture know the name of the general on that other planet to celebrate him? It was pretty clear that the hero's mother ship was not near Earth, but maybe the time warp ALSO send him back to Earth as well. Or not. The coincidences really need to pile up for this to even begin to be plausible. And since the film makers did not contrive the plot development to demonstrate any such path of reasoning, I don't think THEY actually had thought it through either. They just came up with a stupid and unsupported twist for the end of the movie. If you really need for the movie to make sense in order to enjoy it, then go ahead and rationalize meanings to your heart's content.3) By the way, it was pretty realistic that a huge and obviously orbital-space-only mother ship was able to land on a planet at all, much less intact. Enough so that the apes and humans on board could survive to populate another planet. Enough so that the engine(s) still work after so many years. Right.4) It was pretty clever for the film makers to suddenly let a tiny shuttle craft become capable of interstellar travel. Even WITH time warps, etc.The upshot is, this movie has no real level of excitement, no plot worth mentioning, no character development, no internal logic, unreliable presentation of core 'facts' to the audience, and precious little entertainment value. The money makeup was pretty decent though.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>DJones</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Edward Scissorhands trip to Planet of the Apes</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I have been so often disappointed in the past going into movies with high expectations: Indianna Jones and the Last Crusade, Phantom Menance, Batman, to name a few. So I suppose my learned skepticism somewhat saved Planet of the Apes for me. I had absolutely no expectations for this film, after having enjoyed the first one so much. And of course, the new version does not live up to the original. The original was filled with layers of political, racial, and sociological themes; and it had an incredible ending. And who can match the tortured, almost humorous essence of Heston. Oh, and it was fun too. But the greatness of the original does not make the new version a bad movie. In fact, it was in my opinion quite an enjoyable movie. It surpasses the original in terms of its visual effects. While the theme/story is more simplistic, it is very well told; it moves very fast and fluidly, yet is not so packed with chaotic action (see Armageddon) that it does not allow for slower moments that can be saviored. For example, there is a great scene with Heston in a cameo. I wonder if he knew what he was saying when he said it: humans are deceptive and dangerous and are even more so because they have guns; beware of them? Not exactly the NRA's mantra. Anyways, he had a great cameo. There are many other humorous moments as well. Basically, the movie did not take itself seriously. It tipped its hat to the original without trying to mimick its feel. It is obvious Burton wanted to have some fun with this movie, paying tribute to the original while at the same time trying to give this movie its own unique perspective. I believe he succeeded and I believe that that is the movie's saving grace.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>JGaryWise</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>The ending just ruined it for me</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I think Tim Burton has shown in the past that the aesthetic and his love for 1950's B films are the predominant factors in how he goes about his work, and this time it was the latter that ruined that work for me. Time and again, Burton has disregarded the entire concept of suspension of disbelief, and that's fine, but when the end of your film is as ludicrous as that of the new Planet of the Apes, it makes one forget the positives the film may have presented. Not as good as the original (what remakes are?), I found everything in the film to be 'acceptable', even some of the cheesier heroic scenes from the Wahlberg character, but the ending just went too far. That drastically changed my impressions of the film, which I was thinking of as a 5 or a 6 until the finale reduced it to a 3. Wait for HBO: You won't be missing much.</fullReview>

		<username>thrillhouse678</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>maybe the best movie of the summer</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>when i went to see this movie with a group of my friends, my expectations were low. I figured it would be a cheesy ripoff of the first, since i already knew it had little to do with the original. i also used to like mark wahlberg in movies like three kings and the perfect storm, but the more i see him in interviews and in public, the more i wished his career died with the funky bunch. however, this movie was a very pleasent surprise. The make up was incredible, especially when you take into consideration the massive cast who all needed to be made into apes. i was also impressed with the way the actors who were portraying the ape characters moved and acted like the real animals. also, i was able to put mark wahlberg's over-all annoying behavior when he's off camera aside, and really enjoy him in this movie. the only thing i didn't really buy was the relationship between mark wahlberg and estela warren, who plays a very hot slave woman, human of course. towards the end of the movie you get the feeling that there is supposed to be a deep meaningful relationship between them, that simply wasn't built up enough. the only other low point was when mark wahlberg kisses the ape woman who has been helping them. this was supposed to be a very sensitive part of the movie, but the audience on hand that day responded with a resounding "EEEEWWWWWWW!!!" One of my friends even yelled, "GO FOR THE BLONDE!"(Warren) No one laughed at his joke but everyone felt the same way. the best part of this movie was the ending, which i would never give away. but i will say it meets, and nearly outdoes, the original ending. with all of the big summer dissapointments i've seen in the last few months, Planet of the Apes was easily worth the money, do yourself a favor and see it.9/10 stars or if you go by the four star rating: 3 1/2 out of 4</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2001-08-03</date>
		<username>Gordon Werner (gordon@amazon.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>OK ... so it wasn't the best movie ...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>So I went to see Planet of The Apes at the Cinerama theatre here in Seattle (nice giant 65ft screen, wicked sound system, etc ...)I think that all I can really say is that this movie was no academy award winning piece of art, however it wasn't the terrible production that people make it out to be here in the user comment section of IMDB.Of course, like all the other crud coming out of Hollywood, this film was definitely aimed at the dumber bunch of us humans ... i.e. the lowest common denominator, then again it is a summer popcorn movie.Anyway, I enjoyed this movie for what it was ... simple fun.Now, having read many if not almost all of the comments posted here, let me answer a few things that people have been asking and in most cases incorectly answering. SPOILERS AHEAD!!!!!1) Time &amp; Place / Where &amp; When: The film begins in an orbit around/near Saturn in 2029. Mark Wahlberg's character goes through the "storm" and gets booted to about 2329 (according to the ship's computer) and crashes into an uncharted planet with multiple moons ... in close proximity to a number of other planets which in no way resembles our solar system (past or present)... i.e. it is not Earth.2) Mark Wahlberg's spaceship: There is no way that anyone on the ape planet could salvage the ship. a) no technology available b) ship's electrical system is fried (that's why it crashes) and what wasn't destroyed on planetary-entry was surely destroyed while underwater c) the pod crash-landed on a planet. its broken. d) the capsule's window/door was blown off by explosive bolts e) its under water f) nobody knows how to fly it (well except for the Pericles ... but I don't think he is going anywhere soon)3) The "ancient" gun: General Thade's lineage was said numerous times to lead directly back to the progenitor of their current species. The ape that killed most, if not all of the humans after the crash ... who killed them with a gun.5) The Oberon wreck: 1) We did not know when the Oberon crashed into the planet, but since the storm was messing up their systems (remember the power going out?) it is safe to say that the station was pulled into the vortex so to speak. It probably got kicked backwards quite a bit. Remember, the pods went through numerous time-jumps becasue they were powered and had lots of forward momentum. So, the ship crashes way way in the past on the same planet that Mark Wahlberg lands on in the future. Apes escape and continue evolving ... (it is possible that there were other animal species (maybe not horses) on the station (it was afteral quite large) like Gorillas, etc ...) Station has three fuel tanks (2 empty and 1 full) and a nuclear powered electrical system ... which seemed to be shut down until Mark Wahlberg's character reactivated it. He said it would keep its power for 1000 years or so ... but if it was turned off ... well who knows. As for the ship surviving at all ... who knows. It seemed to be in the desert (dry air preserves things) and it was in the "forbidden zone" so it wasn't messed with so it could have lasted a long time in its current state.6) When the ape's attack and they start the main engine, it is highly probable that most of the apes would have survived ... albeit badly burned becasue the engine exhaust was not pointed parallel to the ground, but rather upwards at an angle ... the point of the tactic was not to kill but more to confuse/scare the apes.7) Thade is doomed. He cannot escape the ship's control room for a number of reasons: a) the only hand that can open the door left the planet. b) considering the glass wall/door survived impact from space into a planet without breaking probably means nothing on the planet is going to do the trick c) nobody likes him8) Someone asked why he was in such a hurry to get home? Well, would you want to stay in a primitive world when you had the opportunity to go home to all that you know and loved?9) When Mark Wahlberg's character re-enter's the storm, he clearly re-arrives back in the orbit of saturn and he clearly sets course for earth where he crashes. The chronometer on his computer display also indicates that he is back to 2020 something or other ...If anything is true ... I would have to say that when they jumped in time and space they also jumped realities. Saturn = mystery planet Present = way in the future Humanverse = apeverseon the return trip, he didn't manage to jump back from apeverse &gt; humanverse although he did get the time and space parts correctNow for my personal issues with the logic:1) Where did the horses come from2) If the original apes killed the remaining crew from the space station, where did all of the humans come from (remember humans purportedly outnumbered the ape population)3) If the humans are also descendants from the space station, and the apes evolved along with them, wouldn't the resultant society have been a bit more egalitarian?4) if the ape's planet really was a "mirror" to our own ... shouldn't all of the politicians have been humans?Well that's my take on this film ... again ... you can't go into summer event movies expecting anything to be really good ... you just have to enjoy films like these for what they are ... mindless entertainment (that costs $200 million or so to produce)</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2001-08-03</date>
		<username>Absinth</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>The original story re-imagined. Amazing!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>When 'The Haunting' flopped at the box office while the ultra-low budget 'Blair Witch Project' became all the rage, it was a prime example of how the most sophisticated high-tech special effects don't guarantee a good remake of a classic movie (or, for that matter, any other movie). Consequently, I expected much the same when I heard of the 'Planet of the Apes' remake: today's advanced effects, prettier actors perhaps, and essentially expensive rehash. Tim Burton's version of the classic epic is a pleasant surprise. Sure enough, the movie does have dazzling special effects--the most impressive beyond a single doubt Rick Baker's ape makeup. And the actor's are, for the most part, new-millennium pretty (even some of the apes). But the story has also been completely and compellingly re-imagined and re-created. This is a new tale which has little in common with the original movie except that they are both based on Pierre Boulle's book--and that they are both excellent. The attention to (often hilarious) detail in Tim Burton's movie is delightful, and for those who remember the original 'Planet of the Apes' well enough, there are also a few pleasantly twisted nods to the classic to discover. The story moves along at a brisk pace and never fails to involve, making the movie seem shorter than it is, and the plot surprises in intelligent ways during the final part of the action. Another wonderful thing to observe is how well the makeup allows the actors behind it to bring their characters to life. While the masks in the original films were impressive, they allowed for little more than moving mouths and the occasional twitching nose. The masks in the new movie, on the other hand, accommodate a seemingly unlimited range of facial expressions. It takes more imagination to picture that there are human faces behind the makeup than it does to accept the simian characters as genuine. This new 'Planet of the Apes' is indeed not a remake, but an original movie based on the same novel that inspired the first one. A strong story, solid characters, AND amazing special effects, that's the stuff the 'suspense of disbelief' is made of. Let's just hope it won't suffer from the same sequel-itis as the original.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-08-03</date>

		<date>2001-08-03</date>
		<username>paulo20</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>Typical Burton cheese (spoilers, maybe)</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Not much I can add that others already haven't. This is a typical Burton movie where story is sacrificed to visuals. There is barely enough story to provide an excuse for all the lush visuals to exist.The movie is entertaining enough, but why does nobody give a crap about script anymore? This movie could have been so much more but its only real contribution is to advance ape make-up technology. It's not a movie I'm anxious to see again; very few films made these days seem to have that quality.All the various flaws in the film have been pointed out already, but there is one thing I'd like to address and that's the question of female chimpanzees being the sexually dominant one. First off, why introduce this "fact" if it's not going to be explored? Second, it's not correct. There is an offshoot of the chimpanzee, the bonobo, (which tends to walk upright as often as not) where the female is more dominant, but in the main species (the one which scoots around on all fours), the male chimp rules the roost and I don't think this film was cognizant of bonobos or much of anything else, for that matter.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-08-03</date>
		<username>(webbitup@aol.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>non-stop action, non-existent story, marginal.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Compared to the original, it has much better effects, much more realistic looking scenes and ape-suits. But the story just falls flat.Essentially, the story runs along so darn quickly that the hero never seems to stop and think. He never considers options, he never hesitates for a moment, and he never takes a wrong turn. As a result, the audience never stops to think, or worry, or wonder.Because the story is racing, the characters are never developed.What we want is: a roller coaster ride, where riders are hurled and twisted and turned and jerked around, with lofty highs and gut-sinking lows.What we get is: a rocket ride, shooting at a target 2 miles away, straight ahead, with the end always in sight and closing quickly.It's okay, but not great. I was left longing for Charlton Heston's (the original film) agonizing, pondering gaze. We *FELT* him struggling with the situation. We felt his pain. Not so here.It's a rental.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-08-03</date>
		<username>moviebuff</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>I'll be seeing this one again.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This was my most anticipated film of the year and I was not disappointed. Like many others, I have been a huge fan of the original Planet of the Apes since I first saw it in 1968 and had great misgivings about a remake. Once I learned that Tim Burton was to direct I knew that I would be seeing something wonderful. There isn't any other director around today that I would have picked to make this film. I was also delighted to learn that he was not just remaking but re-imagining the entire story which opened up huge possibilities. The result is an exciting, rousing adventure with thought-provoking ideals that set it apart most of the bang and blow-up action films put out today. It manages to keep many of the elements of the original that made it so enduring while adding new twists to the story. The make-up by Rick Baker is astounding. Certainly his best work to date. The cast is uniformly excellent with special kudos to Helena Bonham-Carter, Tim Roth and Paul Giamatti. This film must be seen on the big screen. I'll certainly be seeing it again at least once if not more.</fullReview>
	</review>

The first film stands on its own, of course, but it was an inspired idea to go back to the novel in order to give this new film its own edge.</fullReview>

		<username>thrillhouse678</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>maybe the best movie of the summer</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>when i went to see this movie with a group of my friends, my expectations were low. I figured it would be a cheesy ripoff of the first, since i already knew it had little to do with the original. i also used to like mark wahlberg in movies like three kings and the perfect storm, but the more i see him in interviews and in public, the more i wished his career died with the funky bunch. however, this movie was a very pleasent surprise. The make up was incredible, especially when you take into consideration the massive cast who all needed to be made into apes. i was also impressed with the way the actors who were portraying the ape characters moved and acted like the real animals. also, i was able to put mark wahlberg's over-all annoying behavior when he's off camera aside, and really enjoy him in this movie. the only thing i didn't really buy was the relationship between mark wahlberg and estela warren, who plays a very hot slave woman, human of course. towards the end of the movie you get the feeling that there is supposed to be a deep meaningful relationship between them, that simply wasn't built up enough. the only other low point was when mark wahlberg kisses the ape woman who has been helping them. this was supposed to be a very sensitive part of the movie, but the audience on hand that day responded with a resounding "EEEEWWWWWWW!!!" One of my friends even yelled, "GO FOR THE BLONDE!"(Warren) No one laughed at his joke but everyone felt the same way. the best part of this movie was the ending, which i would never give away. but i will say it meets, and nearly outdoes, the original ending. with all of the big summer dissapointments i've seen in the last few months, Planet of the Apes was easily worth the money, do yourself a favor and see it.9/10 stars or if you go by the four star rating: 3 1/2 out of 4</fullReview>

		<date>2001-08-03</date>
		<username>Gordon Werner (gordon@amazon.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>OK ... so it wasn't the best movie ...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>So I went to see Planet of The Apes at the Cinerama theatre here in Seattle (nice giant 65ft screen, wicked sound system, etc ...)I think that all I can really say is that this movie was no academy award winning piece of art, however it wasn't the terrible production that people make it out to be here in the user comment section of IMDB.Of course, like all the other crud coming out of Hollywood, this film was definitely aimed at the dumber bunch of us humans ... i.e. the lowest common denominator, then again it is a summer popcorn movie.Anyway, I enjoyed this movie for what it was ... simple fun.Now, having read many if not almost all of the comments posted here, let me answer a few things that people have been asking and in most cases incorectly answering. SPOILERS AHEAD!!!!!1) Time &amp; Place / Where &amp; When: The film begins in an orbit around/near Saturn in 2029. Mark Wahlberg's character goes through the "storm" and gets booted to about 2329 (according to the ship's computer) and crashes into an uncharted planet with multiple moons ... in close proximity to a number of other planets which in no way resembles our solar system (past or present)... i.e. it is not Earth.2) Mark Wahlberg's spaceship: There is no way that anyone on the ape planet could salvage the ship. a) no technology available b) ship's electrical system is fried (that's why it crashes) and what wasn't destroyed on planetary-entry was surely destroyed while underwater c) the pod crash-landed on a planet. its broken. d) the capsule's window/door was blown off by explosive bolts e) its under water f) nobody knows how to fly it (well except for the Pericles ... but I don't think he is going anywhere soon)3) The "ancient" gun: General Thade's lineage was said numerous times to lead directly back to the progenitor of their current species. The ape that killed most, if not all of the humans after the crash ... who killed them with a gun.5) The Oberon wreck: 1) We did not know when the Oberon crashed into the planet, but since the storm was messing up their systems (remember the power going out?) it is safe to say that the station was pulled into the vortex so to speak. It probably got kicked backwards quite a bit. Remember, the pods went through numerous time-jumps becasue they were powered and had lots of forward momentum. So, the ship crashes way way in the past on the same planet that Mark Wahlberg lands on in the future. Apes escape and continue evolving ... (it is possible that there were other animal species (maybe not horses) on the station (it was afteral quite large) like Gorillas, etc ...) Station has three fuel tanks (2 empty and 1 full) and a nuclear powered electrical system ... which seemed to be shut down until Mark Wahlberg's character reactivated it. He said it would keep its power for 1000 years or so ... but if it was turned off ... well who knows. As for the ship surviving at all ... who knows. It seemed to be in the desert (dry air preserves things) and it was in the "forbidden zone" so it wasn't messed with so it could have lasted a long time in its current state.6) When the ape's attack and they start the main engine, it is highly probable that most of the apes would have survived ... albeit badly burned becasue the engine exhaust was not pointed parallel to the ground, but rather upwards at an angle ... the point of the tactic was not to kill but more to confuse/scare the apes.7) Thade is doomed. He cannot escape the ship's control room for a number of reasons: a) the only hand that can open the door left the planet. b) considering the glass wall/door survived impact from space into a planet without breaking probably means nothing on the planet is going to do the trick c) nobody likes him8) Someone asked why he was in such a hurry to get home? Well, would you want to stay in a primitive world when you had the opportunity to go home to all that you know and loved?9) When Mark Wahlberg's character re-enter's the storm, he clearly re-arrives back in the orbit of saturn and he clearly sets course for earth where he crashes. The chronometer on his computer display also indicates that he is back to 2020 something or other ...If anything is true ... I would have to say that when they jumped in time and space they also jumped realities. Saturn = mystery planet Present = way in the future Humanverse = apeverseon the return trip, he didn't manage to jump back from apeverse &gt; humanverse although he did get the time and space parts correctNow for my personal issues with the logic:1) Where did the horses come from2) If the original apes killed the remaining crew from the space station, where did all of the humans come from (remember humans purportedly outnumbered the ape population)3) If the humans are also descendants from the space station, and the apes evolved along with them, wouldn't the resultant society have been a bit more egalitarian?4) if the ape's planet really was a "mirror" to our own ... shouldn't all of the politicians have been humans?Well that's my take on this film ... again ... you can't go into summer event movies expecting anything to be really good ... you just have to enjoy films like these for what they are ... mindless entertainment (that costs $200 million or so to produce)</fullReview>

		<username>tricky_2</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>This is bad science fiction, and a wasted opportunity.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>*Warning contains vague spoilers, but nothing specific*I liked Aliens. I did not like Independence Day. I liked Contact. I did not like Red Planet. I liked the original Planet of the Apes. I did not like Planet of the Apes (2001), not even a little.From the opening of the movie until the end, I found the cinematography to be amatuer, I was never able to get into the movie as it appeared fake, a movie set.Not one human character in the movie could act, with the male and female human leads being horrible actors (Mark W. and Estella W.) and badly cast. The worst scenes in the movie are when these two are together, she in her "just from the salon" hairdo and inflated lips, and he with his immature camera presence nearly made me groan out loud when they were on screen together.The human characters were all over the place with a polished butler and maid, a grizzled old bushman, an african-american with face-scar tatoos, and the hot babe, all speaking perfect English that they learned in their tribal villages in the mountains...The only two actors of note in the movie, Tim Roth (as the Chimpanzee General Thade) and Michael Clarke Duncan (as the Gorilla Commander Attar) were quite good, with great fierceness and expression, but their excellent performances only showed the flawed performances of the other actors, even Helena Bonham Carter (as Ari the Chimpanzee Humanist) performed poorly in this movie.The makeup I heard so much about was very good for the ape males, but I found the ape female makeup to be far inferior and distracted me from their characters so much that I could not enjoy watching them.Many times during this movie I wanted to groan out loud, especially at the ridiculous events that completely ignored science and probability. Humans randomly running through ape quarters kept bumping into every character you had met previously, how convenient. Two spacecraft getting hit by random time distortions show up at the same time in the future. Apes killing apes without remorse, even hundreds at a time.The ending is just plain stupid, won't mention it here but most people walking out of the theater hated the "surprise" ending. A surprise ending is supposed to have been foreshadowed during the movie, this ending was just pulled out of someone's rear for shock value.Rating: 1 Star out of 5Some good recent movies to see: Memento, Sexy Beast, Snatch.</fullReview>

		<date>2001-08-03</date>
		<username>jake-179 (jakeb610@aol.com)</username>
		<score>0.2</score>
		<shortDescription>Terribly Disappointing</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I expected so much from this movie. I was very excited to go see it, and I hoped that this would be the one good movie this year, after a long, long list of absolutely TERRIBLE movies for 2000. Of course, it did not break the trend. This movie was just as terrible as all the other over-hyped crap that came out this year. SPOILER ALERTA little warning here: I am going to reveal the ending. But it is of no consequence because the movie is total garbage and the ending makes no sense, so when you see the movie for yourself you wont even care how it ends, you will just be hoping that it DOES end!A laundry list of complaints: The script has too many holes in it to be forgiven. There is WAY too much dialogue. So much so, this movie cannot be considered an action movie. I almost fell asleep! The make up for the apes was not as great as everybody makes it out to be, and the actors have a really hard time spitting out their boring lines with those big, prosthetic teeth in their mouths. Its very distracting. The acting is poor and the sets are TOTALLY CHEAP! The Monkey City looks like something out of the Pirate Tour at Disney Land. I mean REALLY CHEAP! There is no edge to the movie. The viewer should keep in mind that this movie was rated PG-13. There is very little violence, and when a character does die, the camera conveniently cuts away to something less disturbing, giving the movie a very "MADE FOR TV" feel. I mean it looks like something slopped together by the Sci-Fi Channel. Humans should have been getting ripped in half like so many phone books at a strong man contest. But they weren't. Also, Tim Roth's character of General Thade was acted well, but he had nothing to work with! He was supposed to be the big, evil protagonist. But in the movie, we never see him do anything all that evil. Instead, he just grimaces in an evil way and hops around a lot when he gets mad. By the way, there is a lot of unbelievable jumping in the movie. It looks terrible, you can almost see the wires and the harnesses on the actors. It does not look like they are jumping at all, but SWINGING through the air. At the end we discover that all these stupid apes evolved from the experiment apes on board the crashed space station. But there are MANY species of apes inhabiting the world, and there were ONLY chimpanzees on the space station! This is ONE of many, many plot holes in the movie that are just unforgivable. Then, at the end, the little chimp flies his space pod down to the planet and makes a PERFECT three point landing and then hops out like a little pro. Marky Mark INSTANTLY jumps in to the SAME exact pod and flies off to space and then tries to land it, but totally crashes it for NO explained reason. Is the chimp a better pilot than Marky Mark? HOW STUPID!After CRASHING his perfectly good space pod, Marky Mark discovers that he is on a planet just like Earth, but again, totally ruled by Apes. And he sees the "Lincoln" memorial, and there is a statue of General Thade with a STUPID Lincoln like hair do. The ending makes ABSOLUTELY no sense at all and it was the final down point to an already over-long, boring, and under-achieving film. These are just a few of the glaring plot holes in the script. Doesn't anybody proof read scripts in Hollywood anymore? I hated this movie, I was disappointed by this movie, I was BORED by this movie, and I strongly, STRONGLY recommend that you do not see this poor waste of celluloid.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Ah, Tim, you've done it again!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>For anyone who has seen the original "Planet" movie, this must have been quite a giggle, as it was for both my husband and I when we went with our children.Great movie! Truly loved that fact that Tim took the old story and gave it a totally new look and meaning.Make-up aside, the actors must have worked quite hard with someone who knew primates of varying "classes," and while I have to admit that I was hard-pressed to believe "interspecies relationships," considering the various mixed marriages of humans, why not primates?Someone stated they didn't like the movie because the primates couldn't swim across the water. Ever do any research? It's true, they don't swim; they sink and drown. And anyone who has ever been to the zoo should ask the keepers about the accuracy of some of the primates with various "missiles" such as food or feces. They are DARNED accurate! :)I loved that Tim used people from the original movie! Anyone notice Charleton Heston? Or that he was anti-gun? What a blow to the NRA! :)I loved Tim's use of action, movement, reality, fear, emotion and just plain FUN throughout the whole show.Perhaps some of the people who really didn't like the movie should go once more, with a very open mind, and see the movie for what it is: an excellent story of what COULD be, WILL be, or WAS...Grade from our family: A+</fullReview>

		<date>2001-08-03</date>
		<username>outpost44</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Insulting, Predictable and Pathetic</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Planet of the Apes... I highly recommend you spend your money on something else. It was insulting, predictable and pathetic.Good Points. The opening titles.Bad Points. The quasi-science was just plain ignorant and hard to follow. Where was he? On Saturn? On Earth? And I thought Star Trek was bad with "Using the forward deflector array to spew gravo-metric techno-trash gibberish!" Just blame it all on an "electro-magnetic storm " or a "quantum sigularity tear in space-time" syndrome.The old plot was a masterpiece. Burton tried to impose a new plot but it was not creative enough to be thought provoking or intelligent in the least. His allusions to the old film were obvious and over-used.NOT A SPOILER: But what most really really really sucked - TIM BURTON'S SURPRISE ENDING!! The ending was not only bad, wrong in so many ways, but really inappropriate. It just wasn't funny (except maybe to Burton). It was an insult to audience, Charlton Heston and the makers of the first movie. Actually, Wasn't this ending already in a Simpson's episode!In all, a disappointment. Especially since he had such a unique opportunity to do something really good.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-08-02</date>
		<username>thehockeyczar</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>"Damn Them All to Hell !"</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The new installment to the "Planet of the Apes" saga is a skillfully made film. It combines a new adaptation to the familiar story of the original. However, it is by no means a remake. The new movie has some very striking similarities, but is a new and different film. This "Planet of the Apes" uses enough of the now famous content, that made the original great, to sell it to the older fans, as well as a new story to win over a younger generation which would not properly understand the social gripping message of the 60's version. This film is clearly Tim Burton's best work. The cast does a very good job, especially considering all of the makeup. Charlton Heston steals the show as Gen. Thade's father, proving once again that no one does a "Planet of the Apes" film like Mr. Heston. Despite the overall excellent nature of this film, it is flawed in one major aspect. This film has no star quality. No offense to Mark Wahlberg, but he is not capable of carrying a summer blockbuster by himself. Mr. Wahlberg is a fine up and coming actor, but he has not yet reached the point in his career (and maybe never will) where he can open a film by himself, let alone a major film such as "Planet of the Apes". Wahlberg tries his best to play the reluctant hero, but the key word is "tries". He lacks the major presence that Charlton Heston provided in the original. Wahlberg is unable to sell himself as an "action star". His lines are not believable, and are quite commonplace. In order for such a film to have been properly done it would have required a big time action star. That star could only have been Arnold Schwarzenegger, whose name was mentioned for the Wahlberg role. His presence in the film would have made a big summer hit into a mega summer blockbuster. Just imagine Arnold delievering the lines "I'll be back..you dirty apes!" If the casting directors have any sense they will make sure that Arnold is back when they make the sequel. Despite all of this it was still a very entertaining film. 3.5 out of 4 stars.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-08-02</date>
		<username>sevenwords (pjr13@yahoo.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>The whole movie is flawed...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>WARNING: I will be talking about the ending, and possibly some other events that may "ruin" it for you. Just so you know.Yes, the script was bad, no charater development, useless people (Warren). most of those are talked about in the other reviews.Yes, as I said before the script is pretty bad, but some things can be the actor's fault. Some of mark's (leo davidson) lines were very poorly delivered. In my opinion, marky shouldn't have joined the Funky Bunch, and he should have gone to acting school (or a better one if he already has). Besides him, everyone one's acting was pretty good, but some of Duncan's deliveries were also poor.Yes, I liked this movie, but I did like the original better. It seemed that everything that was wrong with the original, was good in this one, what was bad in the new one, was good in the old one. Was Burton trying to make it better, and just missed the things that were good, concentrating only on the bad parts?Yes, the ending was bad. When Marky (leo) landed on earth (it wasn't the same planet, the solar system is our own, and it is earth when they show the large picture). He lands on the steps, and sees that the memorial now has Thade's head on it. The cops pull up, apes jump out, in full cop clothing, they pull guns on Leo. About this time I put my head in my hands, and just lost it. I laughed for a couple minutes, because of how rediculous it was. Hoping, that there was more, but no. Sure to be more if and when there is a sequal. Will it be a reimagining of the second original (lets hope not)?Yes, many people have tried to explain the ending. This specifically mentioned before in the movie contradict those theories. I have my own, which, fits EVERY thing mentioned in the move. It's not a realistic ending, but it FITS with EVERYTHING.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2001-08-02</date>
		<username>Rik Davis (davishouse@mail.com)</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>a thoroughly enjoyable film</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Despite all the bad reviews "Planet of the Apes" is a thoroughly enjoyable film. Perhaps Wahlberg, while clearly trying to avoid the over the top melodrama of Heston's character, could have been a little more passionate at times, but the apes, especially Thade and Ari are wonderfully portrayed with a rich dimension helped along by Rick Baker's fabulous makeup effects.You must bear in mind that this is 21st century post-cold war America and this is a Tim Burton film. There is no substantial socio-political commentary here, although there are plenty of gentle nods to racism, classism, sexism, religion, and the rest---along with several well placed winks at the original production [including a splendid cameo by Heston]. This is much more of a "fish out of water" and "search for belonging" movie that is Burton's specialty.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-08-02</date>
		<username>marz1966</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>so,how do you review an 800 pound gorilla?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Ah! Planet of the Apes. I remember seeing the now classic 1968 science fiction film as a boy growing up in Indianapolis,Indiana on late night television with my younger brother and my dad. It was some of the more pleasant moments of my childhood,but that's a tale for another time.Ok,fast forward to 2001. My wife and I took in this flick on a nice friday afternoon(matinee) and I must say this: Rick Baker is a GOD! His make-up is fantastic!Breath takingly real. He is going to get his seventh oscar for this or at least,nominated. Danny Elfman's score was magnificent! That man is a genius. Tim Burton did a good directing this although,it was a very weak script. Mark Wahlberg does ok. I mean,it's no oscar performance.He just acts like a man who just is determined to get off where the apes can talk.Helena Bonham Carter,I tell you,no matter how much make up they put on her,she still has presence and beauty that cannot be denied.(Even though there is one scene that sent a chill through my bones.eeeewww.)Tim Roth and Michael Duncan Clark both make worthy bad guys for this film..but i wanted a little more from the script to make them MORE menacing..alas that was not to be. Now, don't go to this film to expect a masterpiece. Just go and enjoy yourself.Ignore(if you can) the bad dialouge and plot holes.Sit back and relax.It's a little bit of escapism that is worth the matinee price.(Key word:Matinee) The ending leaves a kind of twilight zone feel and perhaps a hint of a sequel,but hopefully they will have a better script with the next one.</fullReview>
	</review>

I expected a total remake of the movie (same exact story, same characters, etc.). However, this movie has a more easy-to-understand story.</fullReview>

		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>No action + bad script + bad plot = Shockingly bad movie</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Q: What do you do when an action film has little or no action?A: You start analyzing script, plot, character development, acting ability...etc.Guess what? The script is poorly written and contains major plot and character inconsistencies. The plot (and about 10 sub-plots) never gains continuity or momentum. And we learn virtually nothing about the characters. I know I shouldn't be worrying about this, but when there is no action, what else is there to do? I guess the acting was OK--I mean, Tony Danza's not in it.Tell your friends not to see this movie if they want action. This is not an action film!P.S. Mark Wahlberg's character seemed to adapt very well to being hurtled through space and time, crash landing on a planet, and being captured and enslaved by talking apes. I wish I could adapt that well.This movie stunk with a capital "S".My two line review of this movie is "Shockingly Bad". I expected so much and got so little.Go rent the first one--please!</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2001-08-02</date>
		<username>solidusx4</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Great movie, if you understand it</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>When I walked out of the theater, I was initially disappointed; I thought it was nothing special, and didn't really understand the ending. After one day of trying to figure it out, I realized that this new version of POTA is great! A lot of the people who say it 'sucked', obviously weren't paying attention. Complaints about the super-strength of the apes, and the exaggerated leaps are wrong. The apes were GENETICALLY ENHANCED, that's why they EVOLVED and turned into the talking apes that they are. How else would the apes have revolted against the Oberon crew, unless they had that strength? The ending, although extremely confusing, is good for two reasons: would you REALLY want a cliché ending where Wahlberg goes back to Earth and lives happily ever after, and it causes discussion and deep thought even long after the movie is over; something that is rare in movies today. Roth's performance steals the show, while Wahlberg does an OK job (not like you'd expect him to be spectacular anyways).</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-08-02</date>
		<username>mbeyer</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>Oh, so THAT'S the surprise ending</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Surprisingly contrived maybe, or surprisingly pointless. The original had a memorable twist at the end, so I suppose they felt they needed one too. I'm torn between whether the idea behind it was bad or just poorly executed. Either way, I can see why they didn't want it to leak out. It wasn't a horrible movie. The effects were decent and the make-up was outstanding, but I just couldn't help thinking all the way through that I should have been enjoying it more. I tried, but it just wasn't happening. None of the people I saw it with really felt satisfied at the end. And the Goofs page for this film should be pretty interesting once people get going. Maybe my expectations were a little too high, but I was glad I saw it at Matinee prices.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-08-02</date>
		<username>thehockeyczar</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>"Damn Them All to Hell !"</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The new installment to the "Planet of the Apes" saga is a skillfully made film. It combines a new adaptation to the familiar story of the original. However, it is by no means a remake. The new movie has some very striking similarities, but is a new and different film. This "Planet of the Apes" uses enough of the now famous content, that made the original great, to sell it to the older fans, as well as a new story to win over a younger generation which would not properly understand the social gripping message of the 60's version. This film is clearly Tim Burton's best work. The cast does a very good job, especially considering all of the makeup. Charlton Heston steals the show as Gen. Thade's father, proving once again that no one does a "Planet of the Apes" film like Mr. Heston. Despite the overall excellent nature of this film, it is flawed in one major aspect. This film has no star quality. No offense to Mark Wahlberg, but he is not capable of carrying a summer blockbuster by himself. Mr. Wahlberg is a fine up and coming actor, but he has not yet reached the point in his career (and maybe never will) where he can open a film by himself, let alone a major film such as "Planet of the Apes". Wahlberg tries his best to play the reluctant hero, but the key word is "tries". He lacks the major presence that Charlton Heston provided in the original. Wahlberg is unable to sell himself as an "action star". His lines are not believable, and are quite commonplace. In order for such a film to have been properly done it would have required a big time action star. That star could only have been Arnold Schwarzenegger, whose name was mentioned for the Wahlberg role. His presence in the film would have made a big summer hit into a mega summer blockbuster. Just imagine Arnold delievering the lines "I'll be back..you dirty apes!" If the casting directors have any sense they will make sure that Arnold is back when they make the sequel. Despite all of this it was still a very entertaining film. 3.5 out of 4 stars.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>

		<date>2001-08-02</date>
		<username>Rik Davis (davishouse@mail.com)</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>a thoroughly enjoyable film</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Despite all the bad reviews "Planet of the Apes" is a thoroughly enjoyable film. Perhaps Wahlberg, while clearly trying to avoid the over the top melodrama of Heston's character, could have been a little more passionate at times, but the apes, especially Thade and Ari are wonderfully portrayed with a rich dimension helped along by Rick Baker's fabulous makeup effects.You must bear in mind that this is 21st century post-cold war America and this is a Tim Burton film. There is no substantial socio-political commentary here, although there are plenty of gentle nods to racism, classism, sexism, religion, and the rest---along with several well placed winks at the original production [including a splendid cameo by Heston]. This is much more of a "fish out of water" and "search for belonging" movie that is Burton's specialty.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>so,how do you review an 800 pound gorilla?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Ah! Planet of the Apes. I remember seeing the now classic 1968 science fiction film as a boy growing up in Indianapolis,Indiana on late night television with my younger brother and my dad. It was some of the more pleasant moments of my childhood,but that's a tale for another time.Ok,fast forward to 2001. My wife and I took in this flick on a nice friday afternoon(matinee) and I must say this: Rick Baker is a GOD! His make-up is fantastic!Breath takingly real. He is going to get his seventh oscar for this or at least,nominated. Danny Elfman's score was magnificent! That man is a genius. Tim Burton did a good directing this although,it was a very weak script. Mark Wahlberg does ok. I mean,it's no oscar performance.He just acts like a man who just is determined to get off where the apes can talk.Helena Bonham Carter,I tell you,no matter how much make up they put on her,she still has presence and beauty that cannot be denied.(Even though there is one scene that sent a chill through my bones.eeeewww.)Tim Roth and Michael Duncan Clark both make worthy bad guys for this film..but i wanted a little more from the script to make them MORE menacing..alas that was not to be. Now, don't go to this film to expect a masterpiece. Just go and enjoy yourself.Ignore(if you can) the bad dialouge and plot holes.Sit back and relax.It's a little bit of escapism that is worth the matinee price.(Key word:Matinee) The ending leaves a kind of twilight zone feel and perhaps a hint of a sequel,but hopefully they will have a better script with the next one.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Oh, so THAT'S the surprise ending</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Surprisingly contrived maybe, or surprisingly pointless. The original had a memorable twist at the end, so I suppose they felt they needed one too. I'm torn between whether the idea behind it was bad or just poorly executed. Either way, I can see why they didn't want it to leak out. It wasn't a horrible movie. None of the people I saw it with really felt satisfied at the end. And the Goofs page for this film should be pretty interesting once people get going. Maybe my expectations were a little too high, but I was glad I saw it at Matinee prices.</fullReview>
