He is going to get his seventh oscar for this or at least,nominated. Danny Elfman's score was magnificent! That man is a genius. Tim Burton did a good directing this although,it was a very weak script. Mark Wahlberg does ok. I mean,it's no oscar performance.He just acts like a man who just is determined to get off where the apes can talk.Helena Bonham Carter,I tell you,no matter how much make up they put on her,she still has presence and beauty that cannot be denied.(Even though there is one scene that sent a chill through my bones.eeeewww.)Tim Roth and Michael Duncan Clark both make worthy bad guys for this film..but i wanted a little more from the script to make them MORE menacing..alas that was not to be. Now, don't go to this film to expect a masterpiece. Just go and enjoy yourself.Ignore(if you can) the bad dialouge and plot holes.Sit back and relax.It's a little bit of escapism that is worth the matinee price.(Key word:Matinee) The ending leaves a kind of twilight zone feel and perhaps a hint of a sequel,but hopefully they will have a better script with the next one.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-08-02</date>
		<username>23skidoo-4</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Rod Serling would be proud</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Tim Burton has managed to take a science fiction classic and "reimagine it" in a way that manages to be both faithful to the themes of the original film, while accommodating today's action-demanding audiences.Of course in many ways the film IS superior to the 1968 original. Rick Baker's makeup is a marvel, and more than makes up for his King Kong debacle of 25 years ago -- even though they still can't seem to create an ape mask that doesn't make the actors lisp. The action sequences are fast-paced and brutal, and the actors do such a marvelous job ... er ... apeing the moves of primates you're forgiven if you think Burton tossed a silverback or two into the melee just to liven things up.Mark Wahlberg is a disappointment as Leo, coming off as a one-dimensional jerk. The only times he shows any real humanity is when he interacts with a favorite (real) chimp, though he's certainly capable in the action sequences.Helena Botham Carter as the cute, human-loving Ari is the best thing in the movie, presenting a very well-rounded character when she isn't making lovey dovey eyes at Leo (best not to think about it too much). Estella Warren as a sexy slavegirl gets to show off the best lips in Hollywood, engage in an aborted catfight with Ari, wear very little, and go off in a huff of jealousy when Leo seems to want to spend more time with Ari. I get the strong feeling her best moments were left on the cutting room floor. It's always good to see David Warner and Kris Kristofferson, though their time on screen is brief.Tim Roth is fun and scary to watch as the villain, Gen. Thade, while Michael Clarke Duncan makes a menacing figure as Thade's right hand ape.Look fast for Linda Harrison -- the original slave girl in the original movie. Rick Baker himself also appears as an ape. And Burton's longtime love Lisa Marie makes her obligatory appearance, with a funny bit as a snotty, horny ape.The biggest laugh in the file comes from an otherwise dramatic cameo by original film star Charlton Heston. I won't spoil the reasons why it's funny -- only clue: it's not just in the dialogue.Nor will I spoil the ending. I was confused by it at first until I realized... it was CLASSIC Rod Serling. Once I realized Burton was paying homage to the Twilight Zone -- and let's not forget Serling co-wrote the original film -- everything fell into place.My only advice to Burton is to let sleeping apes lie and not attempt to reimagine the other films in the original Apes series. This is a good one-off, but best to move on to the next idea.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2001-08-01</date>
		<username>(drumstuff@collegeclub.com)</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>remake or re-creation... weak either way</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Crash landing... capture... escape... battle... the end. Intricate plot isn't it? Burton decides to sidestep any meaningful themes in this film, and that's a shame. There are a dozen social issues that could have been examined in the movie, but apparently Burton was in a hurry to get to the Braveheart-style Ape vs. Human battle. As for the acting: Wahlberg was a jerk, Roth was too dramatic, Michael Clarke Duncan was bland, and Estella Warren hardly said a word. The only worthwhile performance was from Helena Bonham Carter. As for the ending, it's sad that Burton felt he had to match (or top) the original by throwing in that outrageous ending. He fell short by a longshot. I suppose the movie was entertaining if you didn't compare it to the original... but can you really watch it without comparing?</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-08-01</date>
		<username>jokis (jokis82@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Great movie, but doesnt stay true to the originial</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I remember watching the original, with good ole NRA leader, Charleton Heston. I remember it being meaningful, instead of this new-age "save the little people" approach that try to teach us animal rights and how humans are cruel and unpredictable.Let me just get this out in the open, the ending sucked. Sure it was a surprise, but it made no sense and it forces a sequel to explain it. I would've enjoyed it better if it was more like the original (and not the book).If you've seen the original, it's nothing like this version. He lands by himself and is quickly thrown into the conflict. A minor change (that I wasnt expecting, actually) was that he could talk as soon as he landed, where in the original it took Heston a while to talk. Dr. Zaius is back, thrown in a comedic role thus losing the serious role he had back in the original. Again, it's just a matter of taste. If you want a reved up, updated classic...this is the movie for you.Something has always bothered me. It was in the original and in this one as well (I dont know if it's the same in the book as well), but why doesnt the main character get that HOT human chick? He seems more interested in that female monkey! Sheesh, Estella Warren is very VERY hot, and she's a Canadian as well! ;) That chick from the original was hot too, but she's like 4 000 years old now... :(The effects were there, the musical score was there...the plot and development of characters was not. We get a sense of the theme, but neither the main character or his human friends are developed in any way.Overall, it's a very enjoyable movie, however they took a lot from the original that hard-core fans such as myself dont like.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-08-01</date>
		<username>IceBoxWoman</username>
		<score>0.3</score>
		<shortDescription>Disappointed and offended</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Although I'm not a fan of the previous Planet of the Apes movies (I've never seen them), I was pretty excited about seeing this remake/sequel.Unfortunately, I was very much unimpressed with what I viewed. The special effects were great, the scenery was realistic, and the cast seemed to be very talented (opinion not based on this movie). However, they were lacking in one MAJOR department: the script! As someone said before, I agree that you and a bunch of your friends could have written a better screenplay for the movie than these talented, well-paid writers did.There were many interesting directions this movie *could* have taken and didn't. I noticed that in the beginning of the movie, the woman scientist on the spaceship mentions that with chimps the female is dominant sexually. Of course, this led me to think; `What an interesting twist to the movie! The female apes could be really domineering instead of the males!' But instead the comment seemed to hold no relevancy to the rest of the film whatsoever! It turns out there were hardly any female apes at all, and those were hardly very aggressive.Maybe I shouldn't have gone to see the movie with such high hopes for a great flick, but I did. I am officially insulted at spending good money on a film that seemed to have lots of possibility but no delivery. For those of you who haven't seen the movie and plan to, my advice to you is to go into the movie with lowered expectations and maybe you'll appreciate it more than I did.5 out of 10</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-08-01</date>
		<username>Swift-12</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Good Housekeeping Seal for brainless summer fare</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Short on substance and long on flashy peripheralia (ie, costumes, art direction, FX) -- which is my typical lament of the past ten years of film history. Mind you, it's NOT A TOTAL WASTE OF TIME, but Marky Mark, er Mark Wahlberg, can't carry the film. Estella Warren needs a few more pounds of collagen in her lips, and Kris Kristofferson's role was a throwaway. On the plus side, the humorous Paul Giamatti got a lotta laughs, and Tim Roth was thoroughly despicable and frightening.Some of Marky's weakness is due to the script changes... the humans can talk. Ok, so then what makes Wahlberg so special to the apes? They don't even comment on his spacesuit. Talking humans is a serious stray from the crux of the Swiftian novel by Pierre Boulle, with its Gulliver's Travels -like reversal of species. Meanwhile the second half of the flick degenerates into a long chase and so-called-epic-sized battle, neither handled well. While the film surpasses the original in costumes and FX, it owes everything to its 1968 precedent. ie, the introduction and exposition of the apes moves much quicker because of our familiarity of the original.The apes themselves are superior to the original in make-up and movement and cultural detail. The ape city is more impressive. But while the specifics of the FX are more impressive than the first, they are nevertheless over-the-top. Even the Foley artists-- every step, every wrinkle of fabric, every thump of the chest is horribly amplified (maybe it was just the damn multiplex whose volume levels were through the roof). In regards to the FX-ridden films of recent years, I was reminded of Laurence Olivier's remark about make-up (which doesn't apply to this film's make-up; it does apply to FX and film-making in general): exagerrate only one detail of a character (the long nose of Richard III, for ex.), otherwise the whole face becomes a meaningless mass of putty -- the performance becomes marred, not enhanced. The same rule applies to FX. Director Burton and most of our FX-crazy film-makers would do well to quit poring over every little technical doo-dad and spend more time on dialogue and plot.Oh, and I can't stand physics-defying FX ... apes that leap 20 feet in the air... apes that aren't vaporized by a horrendous rocket blast but are merely stunned for a few seconds... apes that punch a man so hard he flies 15 feet off the ground (when such a force would decapitate him)... men who survive being knocked 15 feet off the ground and arise to get knocked 15 feet off the ground a second, third, and fourth time (this isn't the mark of the character's heroism; it's the mark of a director's sadism. If he's not sadistic, then he's immaturely fixated on the visuals of slinging a body through space.) The opening segment provides a more plausible explanation, if you demand some kind of logical time-anomaly reason which the first version lacked. But then the time paradox in the closing really falls flat. It seems tacked on for the sake of an obligatory Time-Paradox twist. And for the obligatory sequel.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-08-01</date>
		<username>eldorno</username>
		<score>0.3</score>
		<shortDescription>What a load of bananas</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>You wanna see a bunch of guys in ape suits? Okay, this is your film. You wanna see good acting? Go far far away, as far as you can from this movie. The only one worth his weight in bananas is Tim Roth, but don't go expecting to see his Four Rooms/Resevoir Dogs personality because you'll never recognize him. Kudos to Roth for actually ACTING. Everybody else, well, I stick out my tongue and beat my chest at you. And who would have thought that all of Charleton Heston's classic lines would be hijacked by the apes themselves? And this "incredible new twist-ending"? They could have brainstormed a thousand years and never come up with anything sillier.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2001-08-01</date>
		<username>spaceman2112</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Roger Ebert missed the main point</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>In case you missed Roger Ebert's review, he didn't like Mark Wahlberg's role as a hero, or his lack of heroism in the movie. He must have been asleep during the part where his character points out to Carter's female ape character, that "...we are not alike, you care about everybody else but yourself." For me, this whole statement defines the movie. He only wants to go home. He only cares about himself. And all without the arrogant 'attitude' we're used to seeing in movies. It's either Look at me I'm cool, or Look at me I'm a hero, Wahlberg's character and final decision in the movie pave the way for turning upside down everything you ever thought you knew about what's really going on. A perfect sci-fi where the seemingly explainable goes unexplained.The plausibility of the opening year at 2029? A stretch...only if you believe we're in the same reality, which you will find out becomes one for the X-files. The original 1968 movie left you with a shock, so you could figure out the timeline and the ape evolution. This movie doesn't try to shock, as many are thinking it's supposed to. It's actually supposed to make you THINK who came first, human or ape? You will realize that you would have never reached this point if Wahlberg walked the path of the true hero.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-08-01</date>
		<username>Gotno</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Whack to the Max!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>First off I expected a good movie, similar to the other movies from Tim Burton. There wasn't much good in this movie that I could see. It starts off with a space ship that has a strange resemblance to the Quake symbol. The space ship also somehow has gravity even though it doesn't spin or have any explanation as to how gravity is achieved. The other thing that was kinda weird was that Marky Mark puts on a space helmet right over his t-shirt so if he was actually exposed to space he would die, it didn't even seal.Okay, the movie is okay, the costumes, and masks are great. But obviously all the budget went to those rather than making a good movie. It had great potential but just never got to the good level.The time travel isn't explained well enough and the obvious screwy ending is setting the viewer with a to be continued feeling. Suggesting that maybe a sequel will be coming even though most sequels are terrible. The movie had too much money making stuff in it and not enough Tim Burton.If you want to see this movie I would suggest waiting until the video comes out because I felt like I was always one step ahead of the movie, including the ending. It was not worth $8!</fullReview>
	</review>

A stretch...only if you believe we're in the same reality, which you will find out becomes one for the X-files. The original 1968 movie left you with a shock, so you could figure out the timeline and the ape evolution. This movie doesn't try to shock, as many are thinking it's supposed to. It's actually supposed to make you THINK who came first, human or ape? You will realize that you would have never reached this point if Wahlberg walked the path of the true hero.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2001-08-01</date>
		<username>(drumstuff@collegeclub.com)</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>remake or re-creation... weak either way</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Crash landing... capture... escape... battle... the end. Intricate plot isn't it? Burton decides to sidestep any meaningful themes in this film, and that's a shame. There are a dozen social issues that could have been examined in the movie, but apparently Burton was in a hurry to get to the Braveheart-style Ape vs. Human battle. As for the acting: Wahlberg was a jerk, Roth was too dramatic, Michael Clarke Duncan was bland, and Estella Warren hardly said a word. The only worthwhile performance was from Helena Bonham Carter. As for the ending, it's sad that Burton felt he had to match (or top) the original by throwing in that outrageous ending. He fell short by a longshot. I suppose the movie was entertaining if you didn't compare it to the original... but can you really watch it without comparing?</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-08-01</date>
		<username>jokis (jokis82@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Great movie, but doesnt stay true to the originial</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I remember watching the original, with good ole NRA leader, Charleton Heston. I remember it being meaningful, instead of this new-age "save the little people" approach that try to teach us animal rights and how humans are cruel and unpredictable.Let me just get this out in the open, the ending sucked. Sure it was a surprise, but it made no sense and it forces a sequel to explain it. I would've enjoyed it better if it was more like the original (and not the book).If you've seen the original, it's nothing like this version. He lands by himself and is quickly thrown into the conflict. A minor change (that I wasnt expecting, actually) was that he could talk as soon as he landed, where in the original it took Heston a while to talk. Dr. Zaius is back, thrown in a comedic role thus losing the serious role he had back in the original. Again, it's just a matter of taste. If you want a reved up, updated classic...this is the movie for you.Something has always bothered me. It was in the original and in this one as well (I dont know if it's the same in the book as well), but why doesnt the main character get that HOT human chick? He seems more interested in that female monkey! Sheesh, Estella Warren is very VERY hot, and she's a Canadian as well! ;) That chick from the original was hot too, but she's like 4 000 years old now... :(The effects were there, the musical score was there...the plot and development of characters was not. We get a sense of the theme, but neither the main character or his human friends are developed in any way.Overall, it's a very enjoyable movie, however they took a lot from the original that hard-core fans such as myself dont like.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-08-01</date>
		<username>IceBoxWoman</username>
		<score>0.3</score>
		<shortDescription>Disappointed and offended</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Although I'm not a fan of the previous Planet of the Apes movies (I've never seen them), I was pretty excited about seeing this remake/sequel.Unfortunately, I was very much unimpressed with what I viewed. The special effects were great, the scenery was realistic, and the cast seemed to be very talented (opinion not based on this movie). However, they were lacking in one MAJOR department: the script! As someone said before, I agree that you and a bunch of your friends could have written a better screenplay for the movie than these talented, well-paid writers did.There were many interesting directions this movie *could* have taken and didn't. I noticed that in the beginning of the movie, the woman scientist on the spaceship mentions that with chimps the female is dominant sexually. Of course, this led me to think; `What an interesting twist to the movie! The female apes could be really domineering instead of the males!' But instead the comment seemed to hold no relevancy to the rest of the film whatsoever! It turns out there were hardly any female apes at all, and those were hardly very aggressive.Maybe I shouldn't have gone to see the movie with such high hopes for a great flick, but I did. I am officially insulted at spending good money on a film that seemed to have lots of possibility but no delivery. For those of you who haven't seen the movie and plan to, my advice to you is to go into the movie with lowered expectations and maybe you'll appreciate it more than I did.5 out of 10</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-08-01</date>
		<username>Swift-12</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Good Housekeeping Seal for brainless summer fare</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Short on substance and long on flashy peripheralia (ie, costumes, art direction, FX) -- which is my typical lament of the past ten years of film history. Mind you, it's NOT A TOTAL WASTE OF TIME, but Marky Mark, er Mark Wahlberg, can't carry the film. Estella Warren needs a few more pounds of collagen in her lips, and Kris Kristofferson's role was a throwaway. On the plus side, the humorous Paul Giamatti got a lotta laughs, and Tim Roth was thoroughly despicable and frightening.Some of Marky's weakness is due to the script changes... the humans can talk. Ok, so then what makes Wahlberg so special to the apes? They don't even comment on his spacesuit. Talking humans is a serious stray from the crux of the Swiftian novel by Pierre Boulle, with its Gulliver's Travels -like reversal of species. Meanwhile the second half of the flick degenerates into a long chase and so-called-epic-sized battle, neither handled well. While the film surpasses the original in costumes and FX, it owes everything to its 1968 precedent. ie, the introduction and exposition of the apes moves much quicker because of our familiarity of the original.The apes themselves are superior to the original in make-up and movement and cultural detail. The ape city is more impressive. But while the specifics of the FX are more impressive than the first, they are nevertheless over-the-top. Even the Foley artists-- every step, every wrinkle of fabric, every thump of the chest is horribly amplified (maybe it was just the damn multiplex whose volume levels were through the roof). In regards to the FX-ridden films of recent years, I was reminded of Laurence Olivier's remark about make-up (which doesn't apply to this film's make-up; it does apply to FX and film-making in general): exagerrate only one detail of a character (the long nose of Richard III, for ex.), otherwise the whole face becomes a meaningless mass of putty -- the performance becomes marred, not enhanced. The same rule applies to FX. Director Burton and most of our FX-crazy film-makers would do well to quit poring over every little technical doo-dad and spend more time on dialogue and plot.Oh, and I can't stand physics-defying FX ... apes that leap 20 feet in the air... apes that aren't vaporized by a horrendous rocket blast but are merely stunned for a few seconds... apes that punch a man so hard he flies 15 feet off the ground (when such a force would decapitate him)... men who survive being knocked 15 feet off the ground and arise to get knocked 15 feet off the ground a second, third, and fourth time (this isn't the mark of the character's heroism; it's the mark of a director's sadism. If he's not sadistic, then he's immaturely fixated on the visuals of slinging a body through space.) The opening segment provides a more plausible explanation, if you demand some kind of logical time-anomaly reason which the first version lacked. But then the time paradox in the closing really falls flat. It seems tacked on for the sake of an obligatory Time-Paradox twist. And for the obligatory sequel.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-08-01</date>
		<username>eldorno</username>
		<score>0.3</score>
		<shortDescription>What a load of bananas</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>You wanna see a bunch of guys in ape suits? Okay, this is your film. You wanna see good acting? Go far far away, as far as you can from this movie. The only one worth his weight in bananas is Tim Roth, but don't go expecting to see his Four Rooms/Resevoir Dogs personality because you'll never recognize him. Kudos to Roth for actually ACTING. Everybody else, well, I stick out my tongue and beat my chest at you. And who would have thought that all of Charleton Heston's classic lines would be hijacked by the apes themselves? And this "incredible new twist-ending"? They could have brainstormed a thousand years and never come up with anything sillier.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2001-08-01</date>
		<username>spaceman2112</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Roger Ebert missed the main point</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>In case you missed Roger Ebert's review, he didn't like Mark Wahlberg's role as a hero, or his lack of heroism in the movie. He must have been asleep during the part where his character points out to Carter's female ape character, that "...we are not alike, you care about everybody else but yourself." For me, this whole statement defines the movie. He only wants to go home. He only cares about himself. And all without the arrogant 'attitude' we're used to seeing in movies. It's either Look at me I'm cool, or Look at me I'm a hero, Wahlberg's character and final decision in the movie pave the way for turning upside down everything you ever thought you knew about what's really going on. A perfect sci-fi where the seemingly explainable goes unexplained.The plausibility of the opening year at 2029? A stretch...only if you believe we're in the same reality, which you will find out becomes one for the X-files. The original 1968 movie left you with a shock, so you could figure out the timeline and the ape evolution. This movie doesn't try to shock, as many are thinking it's supposed to. It's actually supposed to make you THINK who came first, human or ape? You will realize that you would have never reached this point if Wahlberg walked the path of the true hero.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Apes excellent...ending not!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>In this version of "The Planet of the Apes" the apes get all the attention and deservedly so. Mr.Wahlberg does a walk-through, which is all that is required of him. 	<review>
		<date>2001-07-31</date>
		<username>superbob92</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Rather entertaining, rather memorable, rather good</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I think Burton did well in creating Planet of the Apes for a generation that did not know it, and as well, keeping the ones who did satisfied. The acting by the human-played apes was marvelous, mannerisms such as hoots and grunts in amusement, anger, or excitement were quite well done. Burton was also able to create a scientifically logical theory behind the concept, engineering the thought that the primates were tampered with in the human image, and taught English when they were genetically engineered, which all of course was fantastical but eerily plausible. The ape culture was intriguing as well.There was moments where I was saying, "Wow, that was a really great idea". However, there was also times when I found myself saying, "Jesus Burton, not that!", although the latter was less common.All throughout his career, Tim Burton was trying as hard as he could to balance entertainment with his cinematic vision, and this time he struck gold.All in all, Planet of the Apes is not the kind of remake that people who loathe action films would enjoy, nor people who despise art films, but if you have no preference (Or you can at least stand both), the new Planet of the Apes is truly great science fiction! My only complaints were the blonde supermodel (Paper thin character), and some really lame dialogue(More character developement would have been nice too). Both a B movie and a cinematic marvel (If it's possible).Ah, and on a final note, Helena Bonham Carter (the period-piece-princess) made a rather attractive chimpanzee!</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-07-31</date>
		<username>Hitch-46</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Avoid POTA entirely, go to the zoo...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Ok...so, normally when I head out to the movies I have a pretty good idea of what I'm going to get. I made the mistake of expecting something from this, um, 'pseudo-remake' of Planet of the Apes. It looked fantastic (the make-up and costuming was amazing...) and the score was rather intriguing...but the 'acting' was, well, sub-par (to put it nicely). I don't know what was going through Tim Burton's head.At no point during the film did I think that any of the characters (simian or otherwise) were believable. The dialogue (what there was of it, anyway) was appalling. Characters acted rashly for no logical reason, and there didn't seem to be any cause for these actions. The super-intelligent apes treated the humans like dirt...but why? There was no explanation for anything.The worst example of this lack of explanation comes at the end. I won't say what happens (don't want to ruin the 'fun' for everyone), but its absolutely impossible and it really doesn't make sense. Sure, it was jaw-dropping...but only since it was utter nonsense...As opposed to the original, I don't know what Burton's purpose was (other than &lt;chi-ching&gt; $$$). Well, in any case, kudos to Carter, Roth, Duncan and the rest of the apes for going to school and learning to act like an ape. And as for the 'human' cast, maybe they should have gone to a school to learn to act like, well, a human (emotions are an integral part of life)...The bottom line is: if you want to look at a bunch of animals, go to the zoo...oh...and stick to the originals...</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2001-07-31</date>
		<username>Fred Arm (fha@bigfoot.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Disappointed, insulted and fed up</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>What more can be said about the new Planet of the Apes (POTA)? Truly, this so-called summer blockbuster insults moviegoers with its trite storyline, excessive and inappropriate violence, monochromatic acting, inaccurate, contradictory and illogical sequences, implausibility, lackluster performances, and poor direction. To call this a remake of the original 1968 version is tantamount to pouring ketchup on a gourmet meal. The makers of the original POTA and the author of the original book must be gnashing their teeth in absolute outrage. What is wrong with this puppy? Let me present a few examples:· In the beginning sequences, what four-star general would ever tolerate such insubordinate language from a mere captain? Or for that matter, what general would speak so contemptuously to his star crewmember?· What rational human being and ostensibly highly trained military officer would flagrantly disobey his general and subject himself to such an absurd physical risk to reclaim his monkey?· If the apes used the humans as a valuable resource such as servants, why would they treat them so abusively defies all reason. To use humans to pull the cages of other humans is a waste of valuable resources, when they could have just as easily used horses that would have accomplished the task far more efficiently.· The original POTA had various elements of their society that were sensitive and intelligent. Why make them all appear to be such a raving band of lunatics, particularly their leader?· Does this Mark Wahlberg have any emotion at all? Clearly, he could have emailed his performance in rather than waste our time and money to watch him go through his ridiculous antics.· When in the initial scenes the humans are escaping from their cages, does it make sense for them to dash through bedroom after bedroom rather than simply flee the premises? Clearly, the scenes are a poorly contrived vehicle to bring some humor into this dismal display of MTV chaos that no doubt stimulates the average junior high school student to gape in wonder and awe.· Why in the world would the leader of this unruly zoo seek to destroy all the humans? There are no electronical or other mechanical assets to assist them in their daily living. It seems they would simply be destroying their own major assets.· If the original ancestors of the apes were these chimpanzees contained in the spaceship's cages, where did the gorillas and the orangutans come from?· If as Mark Wahlberg states in the spaceship that the nuclear power of the ship lasts for thousands of years, why is it that it is only good for one thrust to knock out the ape's attack? If that was indeed a blast from the ship's engines, it would surely have fried all the chimps to a crisp, not merely knock them out so they could regain consciousness all at once to resume the attack.· This story has been used so many times and in so many forms that it defies all descriptions of triteness and predictability. I cannot imagine any writer worth his salt turning out such dribble unless severely brain-damaged, high on drugs or alcohol, or simply senile. I further question the inaction of the director Tim Burton when presented with such nonsense. Does he believe all audiences are retarded? Perhaps so.In any event, I've spent far too much of my valuable time with this poor excuse for entertainment. If Hollywood continues to turn out such poor excuses for amusement, we are doomed as the world leader in the entertainment industry</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-07-31</date>
		<username>Robert Beckhusen (kvant@mitsi.com)</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>A Chance to Go Ape Ruined by Tedious Audience Junkfood</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Contains SpoilersNo one can expect a remake to equal up to the legendary sci-fi classic even with all the special effects and ape costumes in the world. Well considering that Mark Wahlberg doesn't show a single expression beyond ?stupefied' doesn't help either. It's also his character, Leo Davidson, who gets transported to the future after he dives into a nebula of testosterone.If you need me to explain the plot, go out and rent the 1968 version. But Burton and friends took liberty with adding typical action flick characters and scenes that'd not find home in the 1968 classic. Like General Thade (Tim Roth), who sets himself apart from all other Apes by talking in a series of near incomprehensible grunts. Or Karubi (Kris Kristofferson), who not surprisingly sacrifices himself to save everyone else because he's old (originality?). The movie, like the entire franchise, is hauled into a dark alley and beaten to death, kicking and screaming the entire way.One thing that I loved so much about the original was it's unique score, primarily composed of drums and horns. The opening of the remake has exactly that, even better. I loved the opening score, yet that's the problem; it was only used during the opening. I faintly remember hearing it in the background for about twenty seconds later in the film. But Burton and Elfman decided to follow traditional boring action movie music, the kind that makes you want to attack the screen in a flurry of shotgun blasts.I sat bored through most of the movie. It's really really boring; half the scenes are dominated by General Thade bouncing off the walls and howling `Get the humans!' Or Mark Wahlberg (who can't be surprised by anything, even landing on a planet rules by tyrannical apes) heroically taking the lead with lines such as `Uhh?we've gotta escape?' Scenes invite groans, such as Wahlberg's insta-army. Once the escaped humans, and their ape companions have made if far enough away from the ape city, an army of humans come to join them. What's so terrible about this scene is that the army comes in from all directions simultaneously. In the next five minutes an army of humans are ready to go. Also, the ape city was walled off, with no room for expansion, what are they trying to wall out? Or in?You may remember Charlton Heston's kiss to Dr. Zira (Kim Hunter) in the original. Considering that Helena Bonham Carter's character Ari is nearly a spitting image of Dr. Zira (the reason why I liked her the most in the film) it isn't surprising that she gets a little smooch from Mark Wahlberg. This is the big disappointment in Burton's `Apes'. Here is a chance to go over the top and really screw with the audience. Why didn't spaceman Leo Davidson sleep with Ari? Instead of kicking the audience in the ass, he's just invited snickers from the audience moms. If you're making a movie about a planet that's ruled by tyrannical monkey-men, how can you not go over the deep end? The 1968 version was a great movie with mixed satire, the remake fails.From the way I sound, you must think I hate this movie. The remake had some redeeming features I loved. I loved the ape costumes and how director Burton used the apes in a more primordial fashion. In the original the apes stood up and ran straight. In the remake Burton lets them run hunched over and perform bouncing leaps. The greatest thing about the remake? The ending of course, I won't spoil it, but it's genius. It doesn't make sense, it doesn't have to (just look at the title to the movie).The remake should've been titled 'Mark Wahlberg vs. the Planet of the Apes' because that's what it is. Instead of producing a social satire that explores dual bestiality and the inner workings of a nations ruled by apes (which would've been great). Burton throws a summer action movie at us with little redeeming features and wooden characters (except Ari, of course).</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-07-31</date>
		<username>ericsinla</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Style over substance for the most part, some laughs save it (almost).</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The new and "re-imagined" Planet of the Apes is for the most part an extravagant exercise in style over substance. The make-up ( which is the real star) in this movie is good but somehow seems over done. Tim Burton's direction is interesting but his talent can't make up the movies spotty script. The original though dated was a far more focused movie throughout making it's twist of an ending a classic. This "Apes" also has a twist of an ending but is less effective, leaving it's audience with more of a belly laugh than anything else. Also, Marky-Mark is no Charlton Heston...and how those "humans" that speak English as well as anyone seemed a bit silly as well. In fact 'silly' may be the best way to describe "Planet of the Apes-2001." But if you want a nice light night out at the movies without too much thought, perhaps this ones for you. **1/2</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-07-31</date>
		<username>treehgrmjk (treehgrmjk@aol.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Where do we go from here?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Tim Burton is my favorite director, he's never made a bad movie...(Mars Attacks! isn't bad, just grossly misunderstood), but I have mixed feelings about some of his decisions. As an aspiring film maker, I understand that in order to get paid, one must first appease the investors, (studio's). Burton however has managed to do this, without compromising his art, up until now. It seemed that Burton wanted to make a...for lack of a better word, darker movie, that addressed some perverse issues, but was forced to back up by a force off camera. (Perhaps the whole bestiality issue would have been interesting?) there were plenty of other issues that could've been explored but weren't. I loved the little details however, the ape with the music box and the human midget as his pet, it was great, you really got a sense of culture, I just wish I saw more of it. Many of the issues in the film were great?but there could've been more. I also felt that the political aspect of the film wasn't addressed. Perhaps a scene that took place in the ape senate would have been interesting. (Or maybe that's just the Sparticus inside me talking?) I really would have liked to see Glen Shadix a bit more. As usual, the film was visually stunning...but for the first time ever, I feel that Burton has sacrificed substance for style. The film was eye-candy indeed, but lacked that human, (or ape...sorry), quality. Marky's character was also lacking. He was the outsider, Burton's on-screen alter-ego...why would Burton not developed him more? Burton's renowned for glorifying the "outsider"...how could he let this one slip? He got Carter's character right, why would he over-look the obvious freak? Last but not least is Elfman. His score was lacking as well. That beautiful sense of pensiveness or melancholy wasn't present in this score. Perhaps I'm getting too picky, but like so many others, I expected so much more. I'm not criticizing Burton for "selling out"?(after-all, isn't that the goal of every director)? And I didn't think this was a bad movie, as a matter of fact, I liked it and thought it was a good movie?I just hope that Burton doesn't compensate his art for the sake of a sequel again.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>(benc7ca)</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Apes excellent...ending not!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>In this version of "The Planet of the Apes" the apes get all the attention and deservedly so. Mr.Wahlberg does a walk-through, which is all that is required of him. The rest of the humans are negligible; it is the apes which dominate the screen and the story and all are excellent. The ending chosen was unnecessary; the shock and surprise value was nonexistent. Much better to have gone for something completely original rather than a re-interpretation of Heston's famous last scene which WAS a shock and a surprise.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2001-07-31</date>
		<username>superbob92</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Rather entertaining, rather memorable, rather good</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I think Burton did well in creating Planet of the Apes for a generation that did not know it, and as well, keeping the ones who did satisfied. The acting by the human-played apes was marvelous, mannerisms such as hoots and grunts in amusement, anger, or excitement were quite well done. Burton was also able to create a scientifically logical theory behind the concept, engineering the thought that the primates were tampered with in the human image, and taught English when they were genetically engineered, which all of course was fantastical but eerily plausible. The ape culture was intriguing as well.There was moments where I was saying, "Wow, that was a really great idea". However, there was also times when I found myself saying, "Jesus Burton, not that!", although the latter was less common.All throughout his career, Tim Burton was trying as hard as he could to balance entertainment with his cinematic vision, and this time he struck gold.All in all, Planet of the Apes is not the kind of remake that people who loathe action films would enjoy, nor people who despise art films, but if you have no preference (Or you can at least stand both), the new Planet of the Apes is truly great science fiction! My only complaints were the blonde supermodel (Paper thin character), and some really lame dialogue(More character developement would have been nice too). Both a B movie and a cinematic marvel (If it's possible).Ah, and on a final note, Helena Bonham Carter (the period-piece-princess) made a rather attractive chimpanzee!</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-07-31</date>
		<username>Hitch-46</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Avoid POTA entirely, go to the zoo...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Ok...so, normally when I head out to the movies I have a pretty good idea of what I'm going to get. I made the mistake of expecting something from this, um, 'pseudo-remake' of Planet of the Apes. It looked fantastic (the make-up and costuming was amazing...) and the score was rather intriguing...but the 'acting' was, well, sub-par (to put it nicely). I don't know what was going through Tim Burton's head.At no point during the film did I think that any of the characters (simian or otherwise) were believable. The dialogue (what there was of it, anyway) was appalling. Characters acted rashly for no logical reason, and there didn't seem to be any cause for these actions. The super-intelligent apes treated the humans like dirt...but why? There was no explanation for anything.The worst example of this lack of explanation comes at the end. I won't say what happens (don't want to ruin the 'fun' for everyone), but its absolutely impossible and it really doesn't make sense. Sure, it was jaw-dropping...but only since it was utter nonsense...As opposed to the original, I don't know what Burton's purpose was (other than &lt;chi-ching&gt; $$$). Well, in any case, kudos to Carter, Roth, Duncan and the rest of the apes for going to school and learning to act like an ape. And as for the 'human' cast, maybe they should have gone to a school to learn to act like, well, a human (emotions are an integral part of life)...The bottom line is: if you want to look at a bunch of animals, go to the zoo...oh...and stick to the originals...</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2001-07-31</date>
		<username>Fred Arm (fha@bigfoot.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Disappointed, insulted and fed up</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>What more can be said about the new Planet of the Apes (POTA)? Truly, this so-called summer blockbuster insults moviegoers with its trite storyline, excessive and inappropriate violence, monochromatic acting, inaccurate, contradictory and illogical sequences, implausibility, lackluster performances, and poor direction. To call this a remake of the original 1968 version is tantamount to pouring ketchup on a gourmet meal. The makers of the original POTA and the author of the original book must be gnashing their teeth in absolute outrage. What is wrong with this puppy? Let me present a few examples:· In the beginning sequences, what four-star general would ever tolerate such insubordinate language from a mere captain? Or for that matter, what general would speak so contemptuously to his star crewmember?· What rational human being and ostensibly highly trained military officer would flagrantly disobey his general and subject himself to such an absurd physical risk to reclaim his monkey?· If the apes used the humans as a valuable resource such as servants, why would they treat them so abusively defies all reason. To use humans to pull the cages of other humans is a waste of valuable resources, when they could have just as easily used horses that would have accomplished the task far more efficiently.· The original POTA had various elements of their society that were sensitive and intelligent. Why make them all appear to be such a raving band of lunatics, particularly their leader?· Does this Mark Wahlberg have any emotion at all? Clearly, he could have emailed his performance in rather than waste our time and money to watch him go through his ridiculous antics.· When in the initial scenes the humans are escaping from their cages, does it make sense for them to dash through bedroom after bedroom rather than simply flee the premises? Clearly, the scenes are a poorly contrived vehicle to bring some humor into this dismal display of MTV chaos that no doubt stimulates the average junior high school student to gape in wonder and awe.· Why in the world would the leader of this unruly zoo seek to destroy all the humans? There are no electronical or other mechanical assets to assist them in their daily living. It seems they would simply be destroying their own major assets.· If the original ancestors of the apes were these chimpanzees contained in the spaceship's cages, where did the gorillas and the orangutans come from?· If as Mark Wahlberg states in the spaceship that the nuclear power of the ship lasts for thousands of years, why is it that it is only good for one thrust to knock out the ape's attack? If that was indeed a blast from the ship's engines, it would surely have fried all the chimps to a crisp, not merely knock them out so they could regain consciousness all at once to resume the attack.· This story has been used so many times and in so many forms that it defies all descriptions of triteness and predictability. I cannot imagine any writer worth his salt turning out such dribble unless severely brain-damaged, high on drugs or alcohol, or simply senile. I further question the inaction of the director Tim Burton when presented with such nonsense. Does he believe all audiences are retarded? Perhaps so.In any event, I've spent far too much of my valuable time with this poor excuse for entertainment. If Hollywood continues to turn out such poor excuses for amusement, we are doomed as the world leader in the entertainment industry</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>

Instead of kicking the audience in the ass, he's just invited snickers from the audience moms. If you're making a movie about a planet that's ruled by tyrannical monkey-men, how can you not go over the deep end? The 1968 version was a great movie with mixed satire, the remake fails.From the way I sound, you must think I hate this movie. The remake had some redeeming features I loved. I loved the ape costumes and how director Burton used the apes in a more primordial fashion. In the original the apes stood up and ran straight. Instead of producing a social satire that explores dual bestiality and the inner workings of a nations ruled by apes (which would've been great). Burton throws a summer action movie at us with little redeeming features and wooden characters (except Ari, of course).</fullReview>

And I didn't think this was a bad movie, as a matter of fact, I liked it and thought it was a good movie?I just hope that Burton doesn't compensate his art for the sake of a sequel again.</fullReview>

I won't say what happens (don't want to ruin the 'fun' for everyone), but its absolutely impossible and it really doesn't make sense. Sure, it was jaw-dropping...but only since it was utter nonsense...As opposed to the original, I don't know what Burton's purpose was (other than &lt;chi-ching&gt; $$$). Well, in any case, kudos to Carter, Roth, Duncan and the rest of the apes for going to school and learning to act like an ape. And as for the 'human' cast, maybe they should have gone to a school to learn to act like, well, a human (emotions are an integral part of life)...The bottom line is: if you want to look at a bunch of animals, go to the zoo...oh...and stick to the originals...</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2001-07-31</date>
		<username>Hitch-46</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Avoid POTA entirely, go to the zoo...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Ok...so, normally when I head out to the movies I have a pretty good idea of what I'm going to get. I made the mistake of expecting something from this, um, 'pseudo-remake' of Planet of the Apes. It looked fantastic (the make-up and costuming was amazing...) and the score was rather intriguing...but the 'acting' was, well, sub-par (to put it nicely). I don't know what was going through Tim Burton's head.At no point during the film did I think that any of the characters (simian or otherwise) were believable. The dialogue (what there was of it, anyway) was appalling. Characters acted rashly for no logical reason, and there didn't seem to be any cause for these actions. The super-intelligent apes treated the humans like dirt...but why? There was no explanation for anything.The worst example of this lack of explanation comes at the end. I won't say what happens (don't want to ruin the 'fun' for everyone), but its absolutely impossible and it really doesn't make sense. Sure, it was jaw-dropping...but only since it was utter nonsense...As opposed to the original, I don't know what Burton's purpose was (other than &lt;chi-ching&gt; $$$). Well, in any case, kudos to Carter, Roth, Duncan and the rest of the apes for going to school and learning to act like an ape. And as for the 'human' cast, maybe they should have gone to a school to learn to act like, well, a human (emotions are an integral part of life)...The bottom line is: if you want to look at a bunch of animals, go to the zoo...oh...and stick to the originals...</fullReview>

		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Tim Tim Tim... You're killing me here..</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>BAD MOVIE!!! It's just that simple... This was a horrible movie...As Charlton said in the 1st movie... "YOU BLEW IT ALL UP!!! DAMN YOU!!! DAMN YOU TO HELL!!!" Little did we know he was talking about the remake..</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2001-07-31</date>
		<username>mcguffin-7</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>Another attempt at a remake of a great film that ultimately fails</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Usually they blame the director when a film goes awry...but I'm afraid that this time the blame must be put on the moviegoing audience. I actually can't believe the overwhelmingly positive response by fans and critics alike to this movie!Okay...it looks great...but there are several major flaws...first, did anyone else notice how a few of the apes (Paul Giamatti's "Limbo" in particular) too closely resembled The Grinch?...second, notwithstanding the great acting by Tim Roth, everyone else seemed stiff as a board...third, and most importantly, and without revealing the ending, did anyone else notice how preposterous it was for that ending to be possible? There is NO possible way that the events at the end of the film could have followed anything that came before it. Instead of a twist ending that meant something, we are left with a sense of confusion that seems to have been tagged on to make jaws drop...until common sense prevails and you realize that they couldn't figure out how to end it in a realistic manner.I guess that the average moviegoer will walk away semisatisfied at what amounts to little more than style prevailing over substance...something we have too long settled for...but as always, most people will forget about it as soon as the next overblown hyped summer blockbuster comes along!</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>Jason Kolman (jwkrock@yahoo.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Not the best movie I've ever seen, but a darn fine one!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Tim Burton never ceases to amaze me. His eye is second to none and his films have that "look" to them. My neighbor commented that the 2001 version of "Apes" was the best movie he's ever seen in his entire life. While I wouldn't go as far as saying that, it was still well worth the price of admission!I'm not much in the way or writing long, drawn out comments, but let me just say that the ending MAKES this movie, it was the perfect fit, even if it was a tad predictable, I couldn't help but grin and give a silent "oh, man!" to it.My only major problem with the film is Mark Wahlberg. He is a fine and up and coming actor, but I haven't latched onto him yet. Perhaps one day I will. He's hot right now, and he's certainly better off than his "Marky Mark" days.As far as other standouts, Paul Gianetti is a riot as Limbo, and Charlton Heston is excellent in a cameo apprerance!Highly recommended viewing.***1/2</fullReview>

		<date>2001-07-30</date>
		<username>MetroRev (metrolang@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>Boy, did i sure wish this was a re-release</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I'm not going to get into any of the murky details of the film. I won't talk about the little amounts of acting because i blame that on the writing. I won't get into the details because, like i said, they are murky at best. This is a two hour effects powerhouse except that when you look under the hood for the engine you realize what's running the show is a bunch of monkeys. THe movie fell short in too many areas for me and the cool monkey outfits and such could not overcome this. There were more plot holes than in a slice of Swiss cheese and each and every hole was a dark, endless one. Spinning you deeper into a vast array of nonsense and excuses to get Marki Mark to his next ordeal with the monkeys. I would only recommend this movie to those who love completely mindless action movies and for big fans of Marky Mark walking around breathing heavy and doing nothing much else. Other than that i would not recommend this to my worst enemy. It was a formulaic mess and a shameless attempt at using a classic story that has become part of our culture to make money and make the hollywood big-wigs smile a little wider and their wallets a little fatter. Kudos to them because as i've read now that the movie grossed 70 million over the weekend. They made the perfect, mindless fodder that thousands of kids go screaming to the theaters to watch. They'll think the apes are cool and Marky Mark is cool and in the end that's all that matters. In the end Tim Burton, whom i once cherished as a director, will be regarded as a master mind. Why? Perhaps you should look under the hood and ask him yourself as he tosses your oil filter out and makes a bigger mess. "Hey Tim! Why not a 're-imagining' of 2001 next!"</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-07-30</date>
		<username>Moika</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Nothing compared to the original!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>They clearly had a good idea to work with. It was also called Planet of the Apes. Why they chose to take a perfectly good idea and change into a bad idea is beyond me. This movie was designed to please thirteen year olds. Lots of monkeys jumping around and some cool special effects. Those of us who have seen the original and know that it was an intellectually effective movie, should generally be disappointed with this sad re-make. Don't get me wrong, the apes were cool looking and the special effects were decent. In fact, take the monkeys of today and put them in the Charleton Heston film 34 years ago and you'd really have something. I don't want to spoil the film for anyone so I won't, but what is the deal with the end? Those of you who have seen it know what I'm talking about. This is a perfect example of poor story telling, from completely undeveloped characters who suddenly play a somewhat surprisingly important role in the protagonists actions, to scenes which have even the most intelligent of critics at a loss (in reference to the end).I gave this movie 6 out of 10 because as I said, the monkeys are cool. I love Tim Roth and they obviously spent a great deal of time teaching the actors to act as apes. However, this is never enough to make up for a bad story (those apes evolved awfully fast). See it if you wish, but if you wish to see an updated Charleton Heston picture, don't bother. Just watch the original.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-07-30</date>
		<username>Mbira314</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>you'll love it or hate it</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Despite many of the earlier comments here, the 2001-model "Planet of the Apes" is very much a Tim Burton movie. If you liked his earlier material, you ought to love this one. All of his usual trademarks are here; wild visuals, freaky settings, great music (courtesy of a slightly-more-restrained-than-usual Danny Elfman), and a sense of atmosphere that borrows from Art Deco, old vampire movies, and a few spectacularly bad acid trips. Of course, his OTHER trademarks are here, too: Minimal (or No) attention to telling a coherent story, one-dimensional characterizations (usually excepting the main character), and undeveloped themes. If you think about it, he hasn't really told a solid story with a beginning, middle, and end since "Pee-Wee's Big Adventure" back in 1985! If you're a Burton fan (like me), you've overlooked these weaknesses in his earlier gems like "Edward Scissorhands," "Batman," and "Beetlejuice." And I predict that you'll do so again when you see his newest creation.However, if you're not willing to play ball Burton's way, you'll probably hate this with a passion. SPOILERS FOLLOW!There are more holes in the plot than there are in every other movie you've ever seen combined. (How did Davidson travel from Saturn to Earth so quickly at the end? And in a tiny ship that's apparently built for traveling short distances? And can't possibly have been designed to survive atmospheric entry? Why did everyone who went through the Magnetic field end up in vastly different time periods, while the Planet was always in the same place in its orbit? Doesn't it move? Or does the field move with it? And where did the horses come from? Maybe they were on the ship too? As part of another set of ill-defined experiments?). But these plot problems didn't bother me any more than the origin of the ice blocks that Edward Scissorhands kept in his castle, or the way that Vicky Vale's camera magically appeared every time she needed it. As I said, you can either overlook Burton's lack of attention to the plot, or not.Character developments and motivations are all over the place. Much of the dialogue is cringe-inducing. The only actors who give memorable performances are in the ape costumes (Tim Roth, Helena Bonham-Carter, Michael Clarke-Duncan, and Paul Giamatti in particular); the human characters seemed to be a distant afterthought, almost as if Burton wanted to make a movie with an all-ape cast, then decided much later that it couldn't work. Mark Wahlberg, brilliant in "Boogie Nights" and "Three Kings," seems out of his element here. He doesn't exactly do a bad job, he just seems unclear on what his character is supposed to be doing. The script doesn't even give him a single moment of surprise when he first sees talking apes and the cities they've built.And you'll either love the ending or hate it. I thought it was great, even if it didn't make much sense.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-07-30</date>
		<username>(Adam-95)</username>
		<score>0.2</score>
		<shortDescription>A Stinker! Absolutely Horrible!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This is by far Tim Burton's worst film. Some nice visuals and performances don't offset a truly terrible script. Also, further enhanced by an audience-groaning stunner of a bad ending. A waste of time and money--Burton's a fine director who should stay far way from big-budget studio-tampered behemoths like this. Ugh.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2001-07-30</date>
		<username>TeamRockwood</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>It looks great! And the script? It looks great!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I can't say I didn't enjoy POTA, but it's not really groundbreaking either. Yes, the apes look great and yes, the sets look great, but do ANY movies really look bad anymore? Especially ones that cost this much. I'm usually pretty forgiving about overlooking minor plot holes, but after a while in POTA, you reach a breaking point. Other people here have provided plenty of spoilers, so I don't think I need to detail them.Ultimately it comes down to this: should you see it in the theater? I'd say yes, but barely. It's a big-screen kind of flick. But once it gets to the rental store, you'd be better off renting the original.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-07-30</date>
		<username>Kurt Depner (mukor@zianet.com)</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>Some amazing technical achievement but...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Planet of the Apes is a breathtaking spectacle, a technical masterpiece highlighted by Rick Baker's remarkably emotive simian make up. This is an exciting film, one that sets up beautifully at a near future research station in some unidentified area of space. Once Mark Wahlberg arrives en medias res at the Primate Ruled Planet, we are carried through a remarkably other world, a masterpiece of set design. In addition, choreography of primate movements is entirely believable, a foreign yet familiar fusion of primal simian movement and human barbarism. Where the film begins to show its warts is its inability to follow up on the plot premises it establishes. Various mentions and trappings of mysticism, which serve the film well, disappear under the relentless pacing. Wahlberg's prophecied astronaut is not significantly charismatic enough nor spiritually aware enough to be the centerpiece of a film that wants badly to do more than simply be another big, dumb action movie but seldom achieves more than those humble lows.And in the end, an error in editing, direction, writing, or all of the above brings a film to lows that I was perfectly will to accept, warts and all. The last 10 minutes almost ruined the film for me (and I won't spoil it for everyone but ask yourself it makes any sense at all when watching it). This is one of the most insufferably bone-headed, senseless finales in filmmaking history.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-07-30</date>
		<username>Muse-2</username>
		<score>0.2</score>
		<shortDescription>Plot does matter</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>As usual, Burton is brilliant at production design, but the characters suffer ... and suffer ... until in the end no one is doing anything for any reason but that Burton thought it would be neat if they did. The ending in particular is laugh-out-loud preposterous. Oh, what a shame. He should really stick to producing.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2001-07-30</date>
		<username>Justin J. Petersen (jurassiraptor@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>0.1</score>
		<shortDescription>Two hours of your life you wish you could get back.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Tim Burton can deny it all he wants, but Planet of the Apes (2001) really is a re-make... and a poor one at that.But even without comparing it to the original (which is far superior in too many ways to even begin listing here), I can honestly say that this movie left a bad taste in my mouth, and dreams in my head of how I would better spend the 6 dollars I wasted if I ever run into the studio exec who gave this film the green light and demanded that he pay me back.The movie drags on and on, and quickly overstays its welcome. What few special effects are in the movie (make-up, set design, and stunts are totally separate categories, and should never be included under the heading of "visual effects") could have been much better. The ape makeup is Oscar-quality good, and is perhaps the only thing in the movie worth noting.The story seems like someone accidently dropped the screenplay into a wood chipper, randomly taped pieces of it back together, and then tried to shoot the movie from that: The story leaves us wondering too many things that are not explained, and most of what is explained is downright laughable. This movie is funny when it tries to be serious, and never funny when it tries to be humorous. I was so bored watching this, I tried counting (and lost track of) all the plot holes, but the big one at the end completely made me lose faith in this movie as anything but a 99-cent corner store rental to watch with your friends during a night of serious drinking games.Excellent talent like Tim Roth, Paul Giamatti, Michael Clark Duncan, and Charlton Heston (and even the far less-tolerable, media flavors-of-the-month "Marky Mark" Wahlberg and Helena Bonham Carter, whose names we probably won't even remember in two years) are wasted in this contrived piece of junk. I never once felt anything for any of the characters in the film... except maybe sympathy for being trapped in such a lousy movie.This film is extremely unrealistic (even assuming that you accept the idea that evolved apes have formed a civilization, which itself is an excellent premise for a film, but a premise that could have - SHOULD have - been handled much better than this movie does it).In a summer boxoffice where intelligent dinosaurs roam, a misunderstood ogar finds love, and deceased Egyptians seek vengence, Planet of the Apes (2001) brings nothing of interest or quality to the table. I usually come out of a big-budgeted, heavily-marketed, action/effects movie ready to get right back in line and see it again. But this movie made me wish I'd never gotten in line to see it in the first place.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-07-30</date>
		<username>bz03m3</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>The late Rod Serling would be proud of this ending created by Tim Burton....</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>What is all the buzz about the ending to this movie?!? I almost fell for all of the bashing that you IMDB fan-critics were saying about the ending to this movie. Luckily I watched it for myself. Whew!!!! What a creepy ending!!! I walked out of the theater thinking about it. It kind of gave me that eerie feeling like the end of the Blair Witch Project. I think Tim Burton took the right direction in going this route with the ending. When I thought about it it made sense to catch us off guard with this version to the end. I mean if you saw the original Planet Of The Apes you already knew what to expect for the remake but Burton fooled us all and I think some of you fan-critics do not like being catched off guard like that. Despite the fact the battle at the end was stop short due to a "MONKEY" arrival and despite the fact that Estella Warren was the only "female human" that looked like she had access to a hair stlylest and a makeup person this movie was AWESOME. You know whats scary....after watching Sleepy Hollow and Planet Of The Apes, Tim Burton is starting to grow on me. Damn!!! I never thought I would say that....</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-07-30</date>
		<username>Steve (iuseamac)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Come on, people!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>There are movies which invite deep thinking and reflection; there are movies that do not. This movie is of the latter type. Don't expect deep plot or social meaning--remember, it's just for fun! The original had pretensions of social commentary, while this version is obviously designed to be enjoyed. The effects are great, the script adequate and it is one of the few movies I've seen this summer that haven't left me feeling cheated. 8 out of 10 from this movieholic.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2001-07-30</date>
		<username>mjrei</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Great special effects... Painfully bad script and plot.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I went to this movie with real anticipation considering the great cast, Tim Burton at the helm and thoughts of the classic 1968 original.Anticipation is the only thing this movie offers. It's awful! If they had let me in for free, I would have asked for my "walking in back."The makeup was amazingly good, but 20 minutes into the movie, the great special effects could not make up for what was painfully obvious. The plot and script were just downright laughable!This is a "see jane run" script and plot nearly all the way. Really, it's that bad. No... on second thought, it's worse.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-07-30</date>
		<username>Konrad Olen</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>It could have been... but it isn't.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>WARNING: May contain minor spoilers!( C+ ) I have mixed feelings about this movie, but overall impression is negative. It definitely was not what I thought it would be. and what it could have been if not for some painfully obvious flaws. And despite the `re-imaging' it is still inferior to the original 60's version. Simply, it doesn't offer much more than what I've already seen in the trailer.One thing is true: the movie did have some amazing special effects and the makeup. Both of these crews did a phenomenal job. The make-up effects were simply extraordinary, and of course, far better than in the original. But again, with the budget they had, the high expectations from the public and the special effects and make-up wizardry we've already seen in the movies, we already expected it to be great. I have only one complaint: the artists tried to make the female apes too feminine and human-like. Simply put, the make up for the female apes wasn't as convincing as the make up for the males, but no big deal.When I first saw the trailer, I was astounded. However, one thing bothered me ever since then, and it was the human characters-more particularly, their appearance. They were all. too pretty. Handsome. Beautiful. This had always set off an alarm in my head, especially if I have high expectations for a movie, like I had for the Apes. Such smooth and pretty faces are all right in such small TV shows like The Relic Hunter or Xena: Warrior Princess. But in a huge sci-fi motion picture like Apes, I expect some reasonable detail and realism. And as the movie progressed, I found that the apes were more believable than the humans and that's not necessarily a good thing, since I know I should be rooting for the humans, but I just didn't feel any sympathy towards them. The characters seemed shallow, and the only real feelings and emotions that I encountered in the movie, were those of the apes.Imagine: you find yourself in a word that has been turned upside-down, and suddenly you're a slave to the apes. You eat whatever they give you. You sleep whenever you're not needed. You work hard. You wear the same clothes everyday, and you haven't bathed in a very long time, or haven't had the chance to practice any kind of hygiene for that matter. And to add to the list, you're beaten and kept in an atrocious environment. Then, you happen to stumble upon a mirror. how would you think you'd look like? Well, if you happen to be a male, I can almost guarantee that you wouldn't walk around clean-shaven, with a nice, smooth and bright complexion. And if you're a female, your hair won't be nice and curly (even if the curls are natural, they wouldn't look too good), and you would have light traces of lipstick or any kind of makeup. And here's where Tim Burton really disappointed me, because I've always thought of him as a director who pays attention to detail. However, the slaves almost shine for goodness-sake! The only reasonably believable character was Kris Kristofferson's character, but unfortunately, he's not in the movie long.The human clothes are torn, dirty and so on. But notice the `beauty' in this movie: Daena, played by Estella Warren (I'm not really sure if this character was necessary. I rather think not). Yes, her clothes are dirty and ragged, but conveniently crafted as well. It's as though, these slaves had their own fashion designer that was forced to work with dirty scraps of material, but still managed to create a nice little dress with a cut to show cleavage and nicely narrowed in the waist to accentuate her great body, and cut nice and high to show her great legs. Like I said before, that's all great for a little TV show like Xena or Relic Hunter, but here of course, I expected higher quality filmmaking.Mark Wahlberg was good, but he wasn't great. I didn't think he projected his emotions well, because I didn't feel his pain, or shock. To think that Wahlberg's character encounters not just talking apes, but loud, human-size, scary-looking talking apes. If that's not enough to defecate in your own pants, I don't know what is. But Wahlberg's character gets over this realization unusually quickly.The movie was worth seeing just for the apes. Not only were the makeup and costumes terrific, but also the actors underneath it all. Two apes in particular stick in mind: Thade (played by Tim Roth) and Limbo (played by Paul Giamatti) used effectively as a comic relief. Both roles were very convincing and the makeup on these particular apes was incredible. But Thade, the evil General, impressed me the most. I thought it was a great character, superb makeup and phenomenal acting by Tim Roth.And finally comes the ending. Understandably, there is nothing the writers of this movie, or Tim Burton could have done to overwhelm the ending of the 1968 version-that movie delivered a punch in the gut like few movies have. It was possibly one of the greatest, most powerful endings of all time. But what they have done in this version is simply ridicules. This movie would not have been so bad if not for the last few minutes of the film (which feel incredibly rushed) and a pathetic attempt shock the audience in some new way. I think they failed miserably and I found the ending laughable rather than shocking.Overall, the movie wasn't bad but it was very disappointing. The visuals were great, and so were the apes, but everything else seems to need a lot of work. Too bad-it really could have been something great.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-07-30</date>
		<username>ebenmac</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Pedestrian Planet of the Apes</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>As one who reveres the 1968 original, I admit to approaching this "reconstruction" with some amount of skepticism, but I was determined to go in with an open mind. I tried to like it but in the end I'd have to deem this attempt at a new "Apes" as a disappointment.Sure, Tim Burton's masterful visual style and Danny Elfman's evocative musical scoring are in full effect as always, but in service to a mediocre script that plays like a typical action movie. The pointed social commentary of the original film, released at the height of the civil rights movement and the Vietnam War is not quite as effective here.Sure, there's also a couple of plot twists that rival the final revelation of the original. A couple of classic lines from the original are cleverly worked in, and Charlton Heston, who carried the first picture and made us believe in the story, this time plays an ape. Nice touch!But the bottom line is, there's nothing new here to justify the time and expense of this film. I expected more from Tim Burton!</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-07-30</date>
		<username>tito (anthonymansoor)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Big Letdown</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I went to see this movie opening night and boy was dissapointed. I'm not a big fan of Tim Burton. But I saw Mark Whalberg in three kings and The Perfect storm and he wasn't ha;f bad. I also thought that Helena Bonham Carter was great in Fight Club. The Movie starts off alright. It had excellent makeup and fairly good special effects. The acting wasn't bad either. Up until the ending it was about a c+. But once it got to the end it was downhill. I was just plain p***ed off. I reccomend seeing this just so u can see what i am talking about. My final rating. D.</fullReview>
	</review>
