		<date>2001-07-30</date>
		<username>BDFielding</username>
		<score>0.3</score>
		<shortDescription>Lookit the Monkeys! Plot?! What?!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Well, I won't pretend to be a professional critic... just a guy who saw a terrible movie. I'd been hot to see 'Apes' since it was first announced so I went to see it on opening night. When the lights came back up I sat still, stunned at the atrocity I had just witnessed.Let me see if I have everything right... the days on this planet are what... 100 hours long and the planet itself is sometimes huge, other times somewhat larger than a football field, but not by much. The continuity problems were a constant, and I do mean CONSTANT distraction. The story line was insulting to even the most forgiving sci-fi fan and the acting, well... for the humans it was tepid at best.Now... the apes themselves. Hands down, the technical Oscars will be gobbled up by this movie and deservedly so. Despite all of the flaws, the work put in by Mr. Baker and the actors themselves &lt;Tim Roth was, as always, fantastic&gt; to give a complete and realistic image of a talking monkey made 'Apes' worth the trip. Just don't go in there expecting anything more than a technical spectacle and you should be fine. Me? I expected so much more.... and I wish the kid had been left to the apes. Who the heck was he anyway? I didn't even know his name yet I am expected to care? Sigh... go.. see the movie... but check your brain at the door.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-07-30</date>
		<username>eagle1-8</username>
		<score>0.3</score>
		<shortDescription>Not Good.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This movie was, well, not too good. Okay, I'll admit, the actors did good monkey imitations, but that's about ALL that went well with this film. The characters were unbelievable, seeing as they made stupid, spur-of-the-moment decisions that tended to make no sense whatsoever. The plot was also a mess. Imagine, taking the three main Star Wars movies, and crushing them all into a two hour movie-would you have any idea of what was going on, or why??? No. This is what Planet of the Apes feels like-rushed. Not to mention, the ending: what was with that??!?!?!?! There were so many plot holes and inconsistencies that I still don't know what happened, or WHY. With this movie, you leave the theater going, "Huh?" It's not a great way to spend 2 hours, trust me.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-07-30</date>
		<username>james_dean9800 (james_dean9800@yahoo.com)</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Tim Burton, Please Help Me, I'm Freaking Out Over Here!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Well, I'm not going to lie to you but, YES, I did enjoy this movie. The special affects were decent to good, the makeup was excellent, and the scenery had some room for improvement. Characters such as Thade(Roth), Attar(Duncan), and Ari(Carter) were mostly flawless, With my hat going off to Mr. Roth for his more than excellent portrayal of the "Ape General". Leo(Wahlberg) was well... about what I expected from Wahlberg (He was a better Dirk Diggler then Leo Davison), and Daena(Warren) was either to attractive for her part, or should have had more lines, (i may have enjoyed this movie more if her and her family were developed a little more) but whose to complain. This movie also laid good homage to the original '68 version, especially With Heston's small part as Thades father. No matter what others may say, Yes I liked the original just as much, however, i think the whole way the plot unfolded was definitely more complex then its predecessor. This version doesn't only question race(which it may or may not supposed to do), however it definitely questions religion and evolution more. SPOILERS AHEAD I'm not going to bore everyone reading this huge comment on plot summary, because you'll be able to read it in 99% of the other reviews on this movie. SPOILER ALERT On the other hand getting to the ending. Someone please tell me what Burton was thinking. Not that it was bad, but what does he want people to think happened. Some people say it was obvious that it was Earth all along, but could you be sure of it, I distinctly remember seeing two moons ( I even went to see the movie twice just to prove to myself that they were there) It couldn't be earth with 2 moons could it?? So maybe its not earth that they're on the whole time but, first of all where do they get horses, was that the only animal originally there? And how the hell did Thade get to earth and lead a revolution. Does he brake out or is he lead out, and by himself find a way to do space travel to earth, somehow to lead a revolution of apes on earth?Who knows maybe When Leo passed through the electrical storm he passed between parallel universes, or dimensions. Does he even land back on earth? Maybe he lands back on the same planet in the future and they have similar statues to earth??? Am I just looking in to it to far. I wish Tim Burton would just give us a straight answer, Please oh Please, don't ruin it with sequels. Tim if your out there just tell me what you wanted everyone to think, because personally my mind is going in circles trying to pinpoint what the explanation, Hey maybe its just to be left open with the intention to drive us to think about it this much.If any of you see this and have a definite ending reasoning please email it to me.8.5/10 (It had some room for improvement, but it makes you think(For me way to much).)</fullReview>
	</review>

How did such cheesy dialog and typical action movie twists and turns get by him. Maybe they should never give large action movies to more artistic smaller budget directors. They get so swallowed up the studio machine protecting it's investment in a franchise and happy meal tie-ins kinda way. I bet someone like John McTiernan might have actually been a better choice. We'll have to see what he does for Rollerball. This movie makes Mighty Joe Young look like a Dickens classic.</fullReview>

Some people say it was obvious that it was Earth all along, but could you be sure of it, I distinctly remember seeing two moons ( I even went to see the movie twice just to prove to myself that they were there) It couldn't be earth with 2 moons could it?? So maybe its not earth that they're on the whole time but, first of all where do they get horses, was that the only animal originally there? And how the hell did Thade get to earth and lead a revolution. Does he brake out or is he lead out, and by himself find a way to do space travel to earth, somehow to lead a revolution of apes on earth?Who knows maybe When Leo passed through the electrical storm he passed between parallel universes, or dimensions. Does he even land back on earth? Maybe he lands back on the same planet in the future and they have similar statues to earth??? Am I just looking in to it to far. I wish Tim Burton would just give us a straight answer, Please oh Please, don't ruin it with sequels. Tim if your out there just tell me what you wanted everyone to think, because personally my mind is going in circles trying to pinpoint what the explanation, Hey maybe its just to be left open with the intention to drive us to think about it this much.If any of you see this and have a definite ending reasoning please email it to me.8.5/10 (It had some room for improvement, but it makes you think(For me way to much).)</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>The late Rod Serling would be proud of this ending created by Tim Burton....</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>What is all the buzz about the ending to this movie?!? I almost fell for all of the bashing that you IMDB fan-critics were saying about the ending to this movie. Luckily I watched it for myself. Whew!!!! What a creepy ending!!! I walked out of the theater thinking about it. It kind of gave me that eerie feeling like the end of the Blair Witch Project. I think Tim Burton took the right direction in going this route with the ending. When I thought about it it made sense to catch us off guard with this version to the end. I mean if you saw the original Planet Of The Apes you already knew what to expect for the remake but Burton fooled us all and I think some of you fan-critics do not like being catched off guard like that. Despite the fact the battle at the end was stop short due to a "MONKEY" arrival and despite the fact that Estella Warren was the only "female human" that looked like she had access to a hair stlylest and a makeup person this movie was AWESOME. You know whats scary....after watching Sleepy Hollow and Planet Of The Apes, Tim Burton is starting to grow on me. Damn!!! I never thought I would say that....</fullReview>

		<username>Steve (iuseamac)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Come on, people!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>There are movies which invite deep thinking and reflection; there are movies that do not. This movie is of the latter type. Don't expect deep plot or social meaning--remember, it's just for fun! The original had pretensions of social commentary, while this version is obviously designed to be enjoyed. The effects are great, the script adequate and it is one of the few movies I've seen this summer that haven't left me feeling cheated. 8 out of 10 from this movieholic.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Great special effects... Painfully bad script and plot.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I went to this movie with real anticipation considering the great cast, Tim Burton at the helm and thoughts of the classic 1968 original.Anticipation is the only thing this movie offers. It's awful! If they had let me in for free, I would have asked for my "walking in back."The makeup was amazingly good, but 20 minutes into the movie, the great special effects could not make up for what was painfully obvious. The plot and script were just downright laughable!This is a "see jane run" script and plot nearly all the way. Really, it's that bad. No... on second thought, it's worse.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2001-07-30</date>
		<username>Konrad Olen</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>It could have been... but it isn't.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>WARNING: May contain minor spoilers!( C+ ) I have mixed feelings about this movie, but overall impression is negative. It definitely was not what I thought it would be. and what it could have been if not for some painfully obvious flaws. And despite the `re-imaging' it is still inferior to the original 60's version. Simply, it doesn't offer much more than what I've already seen in the trailer.One thing is true: the movie did have some amazing special effects and the makeup. Both of these crews did a phenomenal job. The make-up effects were simply extraordinary, and of course, far better than in the original. But again, with the budget they had, the high expectations from the public and the special effects and make-up wizardry we've already seen in the movies, we already expected it to be great. I have only one complaint: the artists tried to make the female apes too feminine and human-like. Simply put, the make up for the female apes wasn't as convincing as the make up for the males, but no big deal.When I first saw the trailer, I was astounded. However, one thing bothered me ever since then, and it was the human characters-more particularly, their appearance. They were all. too pretty. Handsome. Beautiful. This had always set off an alarm in my head, especially if I have high expectations for a movie, like I had for the Apes. Such smooth and pretty faces are all right in such small TV shows like The Relic Hunter or Xena: Warrior Princess. But in a huge sci-fi motion picture like Apes, I expect some reasonable detail and realism. And as the movie progressed, I found that the apes were more believable than the humans and that's not necessarily a good thing, since I know I should be rooting for the humans, but I just didn't feel any sympathy towards them. The characters seemed shallow, and the only real feelings and emotions that I encountered in the movie, were those of the apes.Imagine: you find yourself in a word that has been turned upside-down, and suddenly you're a slave to the apes. You eat whatever they give you. You sleep whenever you're not needed. You work hard. You wear the same clothes everyday, and you haven't bathed in a very long time, or haven't had the chance to practice any kind of hygiene for that matter. And to add to the list, you're beaten and kept in an atrocious environment. Then, you happen to stumble upon a mirror. how would you think you'd look like? Well, if you happen to be a male, I can almost guarantee that you wouldn't walk around clean-shaven, with a nice, smooth and bright complexion. And if you're a female, your hair won't be nice and curly (even if the curls are natural, they wouldn't look too good), and you would have light traces of lipstick or any kind of makeup. And here's where Tim Burton really disappointed me, because I've always thought of him as a director who pays attention to detail. However, the slaves almost shine for goodness-sake! The only reasonably believable character was Kris Kristofferson's character, but unfortunately, he's not in the movie long.The human clothes are torn, dirty and so on. But notice the `beauty' in this movie: Daena, played by Estella Warren (I'm not really sure if this character was necessary. I rather think not). Yes, her clothes are dirty and ragged, but conveniently crafted as well. It's as though, these slaves had their own fashion designer that was forced to work with dirty scraps of material, but still managed to create a nice little dress with a cut to show cleavage and nicely narrowed in the waist to accentuate her great body, and cut nice and high to show her great legs. Like I said before, that's all great for a little TV show like Xena or Relic Hunter, but here of course, I expected higher quality filmmaking.Mark Wahlberg was good, but he wasn't great. I didn't think he projected his emotions well, because I didn't feel his pain, or shock. To think that Wahlberg's character encounters not just talking apes, but loud, human-size, scary-looking talking apes. If that's not enough to defecate in your own pants, I don't know what is. But Wahlberg's character gets over this realization unusually quickly.The movie was worth seeing just for the apes. Not only were the makeup and costumes terrific, but also the actors underneath it all. Two apes in particular stick in mind: Thade (played by Tim Roth) and Limbo (played by Paul Giamatti) used effectively as a comic relief. Both roles were very convincing and the makeup on these particular apes was incredible. But Thade, the evil General, impressed me the most. I thought it was a great character, superb makeup and phenomenal acting by Tim Roth.And finally comes the ending. Understandably, there is nothing the writers of this movie, or Tim Burton could have done to overwhelm the ending of the 1968 version-that movie delivered a punch in the gut like few movies have. It was possibly one of the greatest, most powerful endings of all time. But what they have done in this version is simply ridicules. This movie would not have been so bad if not for the last few minutes of the film (which feel incredibly rushed) and a pathetic attempt shock the audience in some new way. I think they failed miserably and I found the ending laughable rather than shocking.Overall, the movie wasn't bad but it was very disappointing. The visuals were great, and so were the apes, but everything else seems to need a lot of work. Too bad-it really could have been something great.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-07-30</date>
		<username>ebenmac</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Pedestrian Planet of the Apes</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>As one who reveres the 1968 original, I admit to approaching this "reconstruction" with some amount of skepticism, but I was determined to go in with an open mind. I tried to like it but in the end I'd have to deem this attempt at a new "Apes" as a disappointment.Sure, Tim Burton's masterful visual style and Danny Elfman's evocative musical scoring are in full effect as always, but in service to a mediocre script that plays like a typical action movie. The pointed social commentary of the original film, released at the height of the civil rights movement and the Vietnam War is not quite as effective here.Sure, there's also a couple of plot twists that rival the final revelation of the original. A couple of classic lines from the original are cleverly worked in, and Charlton Heston, who carried the first picture and made us believe in the story, this time plays an ape. Nice touch!But the bottom line is, there's nothing new here to justify the time and expense of this film. I expected more from Tim Burton!</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-07-30</date>

		<fullReview>I went to see this movie opening night and boy was dissapointed. I'm not a big fan of Tim Burton. But I saw Mark Whalberg in three kings and The Perfect storm and he wasn't ha;f bad. I also thought that Helena Bonham Carter was great in Fight Club. The Movie starts off alright. It had excellent makeup and fairly good special effects. The acting wasn't bad either. Up until the ending it was about a c+. But once it got to the end it was downhill. I was just plain p***ed off. I reccomend seeing this just so u can see what i am talking about. My final rating. D.</fullReview>

		<username>BDFielding</username>
		<score>0.3</score>
		<shortDescription>Lookit the Monkeys! Plot?! What?!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Well, I won't pretend to be a professional critic... just a guy who saw a terrible movie. I'd been hot to see 'Apes' since it was first announced so I went to see it on opening night. When the lights came back up I sat still, stunned at the atrocity I had just witnessed.Let me see if I have everything right... the days on this planet are what... 100 hours long and the planet itself is sometimes huge, other times somewhat larger than a football field, but not by much. The continuity problems were a constant, and I do mean CONSTANT distraction. The story line was insulting to even the most forgiving sci-fi fan and the acting, well... for the humans it was tepid at best.Now... the apes themselves. Hands down, the technical Oscars will be gobbled up by this movie and deservedly so. Despite all of the flaws, the work put in by Mr. Baker and the actors themselves &lt;Tim Roth was, as always, fantastic&gt; to give a complete and realistic image of a talking monkey made 'Apes' worth the trip. Just don't go in there expecting anything more than a technical spectacle and you should be fine. Me? I expected so much more.... and I wish the kid had been left to the apes. Who the heck was he anyway? I didn't even know his name yet I am expected to care? Sigh... go.. see the movie... but check your brain at the door.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-07-30</date>
		<username>eagle1-8</username>
		<score>0.3</score>
		<shortDescription>Not Good.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This movie was, well, not too good. Okay, I'll admit, the actors did good monkey imitations, but that's about ALL that went well with this film. The characters were unbelievable, seeing as they made stupid, spur-of-the-moment decisions that tended to make no sense whatsoever. The plot was also a mess. Imagine, taking the three main Star Wars movies, and crushing them all into a two hour movie-would you have any idea of what was going on, or why??? No. This is what Planet of the Apes feels like-rushed. Not to mention, the ending: what was with that??!?!?!?! There were so many plot holes and inconsistencies that I still don't know what happened, or WHY. With this movie, you leave the theater going, "Huh?" It's not a great way to spend 2 hours, trust me.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-07-30</date>
		<username>james_dean9800 (james_dean9800@yahoo.com)</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Tim Burton, Please Help Me, I'm Freaking Out Over Here!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Well, I'm not going to lie to you but, YES, I did enjoy this movie. The special affects were decent to good, the makeup was excellent, and the scenery had some room for improvement. Characters such as Thade(Roth), Attar(Duncan), and Ari(Carter) were mostly flawless, With my hat going off to Mr. Roth for his more than excellent portrayal of the "Ape General". Leo(Wahlberg) was well... about what I expected from Wahlberg (He was a better Dirk Diggler then Leo Davison), and Daena(Warren) was either to attractive for her part, or should have had more lines, (i may have enjoyed this movie more if her and her family were developed a little more) but whose to complain. This movie also laid good homage to the original '68 version, especially With Heston's small part as Thades father. No matter what others may say, Yes I liked the original just as much, however, i think the whole way the plot unfolded was definitely more complex then its predecessor. This version doesn't only question race(which it may or may not supposed to do), however it definitely questions religion and evolution more. SPOILERS AHEAD I'm not going to bore everyone reading this huge comment on plot summary, because you'll be able to read it in 99% of the other reviews on this movie. SPOILER ALERT On the other hand getting to the ending. Someone please tell me what Burton was thinking. Not that it was bad, but what does he want people to think happened. Some people say it was obvious that it was Earth all along, but could you be sure of it, I distinctly remember seeing two moons ( I even went to see the movie twice just to prove to myself that they were there) It couldn't be earth with 2 moons could it?? So maybe its not earth that they're on the whole time but, first of all where do they get horses, was that the only animal originally there? And how the hell did Thade get to earth and lead a revolution. The characters seemed shallow, and the only real feelings and emotions that I encountered in the movie, were those of the apes.Imagine: you find yourself in a word that has been turned upside-down, and suddenly you're a slave to the apes. You wear the same clothes everyday, and you haven't bathed in a very long time, or haven't had the chance to practice any kind of hygiene for that matter. And to add to the list, you're beaten and kept in an atrocious environment. Then, you happen to stumble upon a mirror. how would you think you'd look like? Well, if you happen to be a male, I can almost guarantee that you wouldn't walk around clean-shaven, with a nice, smooth and bright complexion. And if you're a female, your hair won't be nice and curly (even if the curls are natural, they wouldn't look too good), and you would have light traces of lipstick or any kind of makeup. And here's where Tim Burton really disappointed me, because I've always thought of him as a director who pays attention to detail. However, the slaves almost shine for goodness-sake! The only reasonably believable character was Kris Kristofferson's character, but unfortunately, he's not in the movie long.The human clothes are torn, dirty and so on. But notice the `beauty' in this movie: Daena, played by Estella Warren (I'm not really sure if this character was necessary. I rather think not). Yes, her clothes are dirty and ragged, but conveniently crafted as well. It's as though, these slaves had their own fashion designer that was forced to work with dirty scraps of material, but still managed to create a nice little dress with a cut to show cleavage and nicely narrowed in the waist to accentuate her great body, and cut nice and high to show her great legs. I didn't think he projected his emotions well, because I didn't feel his pain, or shock. But Wahlberg's character gets over this realization unusually quickly.The movie was worth seeing just for the apes. Not only were the makeup and costumes terrific, but also the actors underneath it all. Two apes in particular stick in mind: Thade (played by Tim Roth) and Limbo (played by Paul Giamatti) used effectively as a comic relief. Both roles were very convincing and the makeup on these particular apes was incredible. But Thade, the evil General, impressed me the most. I thought it was a great character, superb makeup and phenomenal acting by Tim Roth.And finally comes the ending. Understandably, there is nothing the writers of this movie, or Tim Burton could have done to overwhelm the ending of the 1968 version-that movie delivered a punch in the gut like few movies have. It was possibly one of the greatest, most powerful endings of all time. But what they have done in this version is simply ridicules. This movie would not have been so bad if not for the last few minutes of the film (which feel incredibly rushed) and a pathetic attempt shock the audience in some new way. I think they failed miserably and I found the ending laughable rather than shocking.Overall, the movie wasn't bad but it was very disappointing. The visuals were great, and so were the apes, but everything else seems to need a lot of work. Too bad-it really could have been something great.</fullReview>

		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Tim Burton, Please Help Me, I'm Freaking Out Over Here!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Well, I'm not going to lie to you but, YES, I did enjoy this movie. The special affects were decent to good, the makeup was excellent, and the scenery had some room for improvement. Characters such as Thade(Roth), Attar(Duncan), and Ari(Carter) were mostly flawless, With my hat going off to Mr. Roth for his more than excellent portrayal of the "Ape General". Leo(Wahlberg) was well... about what I expected from Wahlberg (He was a better Dirk Diggler then Leo Davison), and Daena(Warren) was either to attractive for her part, or should have had more lines, (i may have enjoyed this movie more if her and her family were developed a little more) but whose to complain. This movie also laid good homage to the original '68 version, especially With Heston's small part as Thades father. No matter what others may say, Yes I liked the original just as much, however, i think the whole way the plot unfolded was definitely more complex then its predecessor. This version doesn't only question race(which it may or may not supposed to do), however it definitely questions religion and evolution more. SPOILERS AHEAD I'm not going to bore everyone reading this huge comment on plot summary, because you'll be able to read it in 99% of the other reviews on this movie. SPOILER ALERT On the other hand getting to the ending. Someone please tell me what Burton was thinking. Not that it was bad, but what does he want people to think happened. Some people say it was obvious that it was Earth all along, but could you be sure of it, I distinctly remember seeing two moons ( I even went to see the movie twice just to prove to myself that they were there) It couldn't be earth with 2 moons could it?? So maybe its not earth that they're on the whole time but, first of all where do they get horses, was that the only animal originally there? And how the hell did Thade get to earth and lead a revolution. Does he brake out or is he lead out, and by himself find a way to do space travel to earth, somehow to lead a revolution of apes on earth?Who knows maybe When Leo passed through the electrical storm he passed between parallel universes, or dimensions. Does he even land back on earth? Maybe he lands back on the same planet in the future and they have similar statues to earth??? Am I just looking in to it to far. I wish Tim Burton would just give us a straight answer, Please oh Please, don't ruin it with sequels. Tim if your out there just tell me what you wanted everyone to think, because personally my mind is going in circles trying to pinpoint what the explanation, Hey maybe its just to be left open with the intention to drive us to think about it this much.If any of you see this and have a definite ending reasoning please email it to me.8.5/10 (It had some room for improvement, but it makes you think(For me way to much).)</fullReview>

		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Planet of the Lip Gloss</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>First of all, I would like to say I liked the film... in spite of all the problems I had with it.The ape make-up rocked! If not for Ari's (Helen Bonham Carter) "too human" make-up, it wouldn't take you too long to forget that they were actors only made up to look like apes. Tim Roth WAS Thade! Both Tim Roth as General Thade and Paul Giamatti as Limbo deserve a nod come Oscar time. Unfortunately the majority of the cast looked as though they were phoning it in.In a couple of scenes you could see that Estella Warren was wearing heavy lip gloss but this could be a cinematography problem as in another scene it appeared as Mark Wahlberg was also wearing lip gloss.As for the story, it is one that a non sci-fi fan would assume was "good" science fiction, however it wasn't. The plot had holes the size of Texas and there was no sign that anyone had tried to fill them. The original movie ended with a "Gosh WOW!" and this one ended with a "what the f..., HUH?" I can still remember coming out of the theatre after seeing the orginal for the first time with a sense of wonder. Of course that was back in a time when the thought of the human race nuking itself to oblivion wasn't that big a stretch. I was thinking about the ending of that film for weeks, I doubt I'll be thinking about the ending of this one tomorrow. One good thing to say about the ending is that it more closely echos the ending the book "Monkey Planet" by Pierre Boulle than the original film did.Having said all these nasty things, there is still much to enjoy about this film. The direction was very good and the score was delightful. The music over the opening credits was very much an homage to Jerry Goldsmith's original score.One can only hope that the inevitable sequel can shed some light on the confusing ending.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>No points for originality or creativity, +2 points for visuals, +2 points for make-up, +1 point for Helena B's excellent work, and +2 more for the director being Tim Burton (his stories are always fun.) I liked the movie for the most part, a good 70% of the movie. There are some really bad scenes, but they're mostly countered by the wonderful Helena Bonham Carter role as Ari. I dunno, but she's the sexiest Chimpanzee I've ever seen. Almost to the point of contemplating beastiality. But does Ari count? Thank god it was a movie. The best way to enjoy the film is to think of it as a Twilight Zone episode. i think it pays a great homage to Rod Serling (co-writer of the 1968 original) and his strange, almost predictable, but twisted endings. Go see it if you're a Burton fan, and/or if you liked Sleepy Hollow. 7 points.</fullReview>

		<username>lonchaneyjr</username>

		<shortDescription>A Disappointing and Disjointed Mess!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Let me start by saying that I am a huge Tim Burton fan. I consider his visions on film absolutely fantastic! I see Tim's hand in about the first 2/3rds of this film.The last 1/3rd seems like the work of "suits" rather than "artists. While the film has a certain awesome visual style-give Rick Baker the Academy Award for Makeup right now-we are constantly challenged to suspend disbelief for shallow plot points and trite dialog. Forget character development. Forget logic and check your brain with your ticket stub. The ending (which I will not reveal here so as not to spoil for those who have not seen yet) is a nightmare. I understand that there were possibly 5-7 different endings- maybe a DVD Special Edition or definitive director's cut could make more sense than this "barrel of monkeys." Hollywood get original. Less effects more story. No more sequels - I'm feeling sick.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2001-07-29</date>
		<username>Glen C Mackie (macey)</username>
		<score>0.3</score>
		<shortDescription>No apes were harmed in the making of this film</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This is the sort of disclaimer I expected in the credits. That's the level of the humor here. The make-up was absolutely incredible. The design of the ape soldiers awesome. The script? Sit in a room for five minutes with a couple of friends. Think of a few everyday human situations. Now think of the same situation with an ape in it. Write down what you think would happen, (try and be funny about it) - Once you've written a few pages you'll no doubt no have your own version of the Planet of the Apes script sitting right in front of you. Basically a bunch of quickly thought up ape jokes and a story that had characters with shifting, mis-placed, heavy-handed or non-existent motivation.Some examples of why I didn't like this film? SPOILER ALERT - SPOILER ALERT - SPOILER ALERT PLOT AND ENDING MENTIONED - Who really cared when the boy fell off his horse in the battle if he lived or died? His arrogance got him there, his inept horse riding got him stuck. Why was he even in the film? - There seemed to be a thinly veiled attempt at satire and role reversal on animal rights. But when the humans get a chance what do they do? Bash ape heads in as the apes did to them. What's the story point - The strong survive? Violence with superior numbers is the answer? A mixed message especially when the sympathetic 'hippy' ape is seen helping the humans fight. - The humans out number the apes 4 to 1 we are told early in the film. In the battle we see humans and apes fighting fairly equally. Whose going to win? Hmmmm...So what was the point of this bit again? - Bonham-Carters sympathetic ape comes across as a bleeding heart hippy. Not very likeable. And not very smart. If only she'd played a more political role against the main bad guy Thede instead of straight out verbal confrontation and an embarrassing attempt at seduction later in the film. - It was like a comedy, that wasn't funny. The humour involved taking a human situation, replacing them with an ape, and making them a joke about them using their feet instead of hands (this particular joke was used twice in the film!) - The writers never stopped to question why apes, evolving without human influence, would be playing Basketball in T-shirts? - Sci-Fi films need to create a believable world, no matter how fantastic the setting, in which to tell the story. Way too often I would think 'If they can do this then why don't they do this...' and my mind would wander off. Too many inconsistencies. - The sets looked like sets. - Burton's usual visual eye was not apparent until the battle. - The ending is just stupid. Where did all the helicopters and the fire truck come from. If I'd have laughed at the jokes this would have been the punch line. But I didn't laugh at the jokes and this was an insult. Apes in police hats on motorcycles... I'm hoping it was supposed to be a joke. I just didn't find it funny. END OF SPOILERSFrom the director of 'Mars Attacks' not 'Batman'. It's watchable crap, but like Pearl Harbor, it's crap I'll not recommend to you, nor ever sit through again.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-07-29</date>
		<username>Robert Moore (rmoore1159@aol.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Talk about having a monkey on your back..</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Tim Burton delivers once again. When talk first began about an update for "Planet of the Apes" I was taken back when it was first reported that Arnold "The Terminator" Schwartzenegger was tapped to play the lead in the James Cameron directed film. Thank all that is wholly that Burton took over. Could anyone really see Arnold delivering such lines as "get your stinking hands off me you damned dirty ape!" Talk about your comedy films.Burton, who is probably best known for his dark and mysterious works such as "Batman" (the first one and only really worthy one) and "Sleepy Hollow", has scored once again with his retelling of "Planet of the Apes" By showing a certain reverence to the original ( the above referenced line by Heston is now spoken by one of the apes ) as well as certain character names (Nova for one) he has given it an original twist and (although I must admit a somewhat confusing) ending that will have people talking in the breakroom for days about it.The actors, story all of it is first class and well worth the admission price. Remember, these aren't your 1968 apes. Burton has them behaving less human and more ape-like, complete with hanging off the ceiling and grunts and squeals. But then again, when a director like Tim Burton takes on a project as daunting as "Planet of the Apes" he must feel the pressure of having the monkey on his back.This is two hours of make believe that will do just that -- make you believe. enjoy.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-07-29</date>
		<username>Joseph Makled (makledrealtor@mediaone.net)</username>
		<score>0.1</score>
		<shortDescription>A grand opportunity missed.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This is without a doubt, Tim Burton's worst film to date. I've read other reviews of the film and agree with the general consensus that the score (Elfman) and the makeup/special effects (Baker, etc.) were spectacular. Of course they were! Why shouldn't they be? With the current level of sophistication we enjoy in special effects and advanced makeup/prosthetic applications there is no excuse whatsoever for shabby makeup and crappy effects. What are we left with after the glitz? Stuntmen jumping 20, 30 and 50 feet into the air again and again and again. That particular effect was so overdone throughout the film as to render it completely flaccid by the end of this piece of garbage. Plot? There was none, really. This was purely an action film with a "screenplay" that was written by and for idiots.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>I just got home from seeing this movie. I went in not expecting much, but boy did I get a surprise. This movie very definitely does the original justice, and then some. 		<username>MyOpinionIsFact</username>
		<score>0.2</score>
		<shortDescription>Awful... almost as bad (and the same) as Battlefield Earth</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>What a terrible, terrible movie! I had a high expectation for it too. It's a shame. I'll give the make-up artists (e.g., Rick Baker) credit. Bravo. And Danny Elfman's opening score was interesting. But otherwise, this movie was utter crap. (small spoilers follow) First we get this DS9-like space station shot with the wonderful title card that informs us that it's the year 2029!!! Hello! I knew right then that this was going to suck. Science fiction needs to be smart. Then he finds himself on the Ape Planet and the next 90% of the movie is just simple "escape and chase". Yawn... But to try and make it interesting they throw in some cliché and ever-not-so-subtle comments on racism and religion. The script was lousy, let's face it. Then the end of the movie improves slightly (this doesn't say much) until we get the "surprise" ending. Whatever. Tim Burton has the imagery skills but except from Edward Scissorhands and Pee-Wee's Big Adventure, I'd say he's a failure as far as making good stories. The similarities between Planet of the Apes and Battlefield Earth are remarkable. And considering how lousy that movie was, why would anybody allow this script to pass? Certainly a better movie could have been made from the same idea. Oh well, it already has.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>(freakezette@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>Get your hands off my money, you damn dirty apes!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I will give this movie some credit; it's not just a remake, which is probably the best thing it has going for it While the make-up is great, the film ends up being too serious to be campy, too silly to be taken seriously, and there are more loose ends than an unraveled sweater. (Which are sure to be tied up by the obviously sequel that the end sets up)Mark Walberg's tries to find his monkey and lands on a planet where Monkeys are superior and humans are the lesser primate. The make-up is astounding, and Mark proves to be a pretty good no-brain action star. Tim Roths is a pretty good monkey-gone-bad, but as I said before, this movies too silly to be taken seriously and his intense performance is kind of lost.After it's revealed how the monkeys got the way they were, (and why their english was so good) the plot just get's silly and builds up too a fairly laughable ending. The blond girl, Estelle, isn't bad as far as models-turned-actresses go, but her character serves no purpose other than to give 14 year old boys something to look at. Plus, even with more makeup than the cast of Cats used for 20 years, the best apes-actor is still the real thing, Mark's chimp Pericles, who gives a better performance than half his human-cousins.It's not a bad movie, it's a style-over-substance movie, but hell, so's most everything else that's at the theater. But underneath the latex it's just a campy monkey movie destined for cult stardom.To quote Troy Mclure "I guess you made a monkey out of me!"</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-07-29</date>
		<username>justinmorrison</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Best movie ever!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Well, not really... but it was a lot of fun. For all those who didn't like it, I'm curious what you were expecting. Did you really expect a movie about angry talking monkeys to be a masterpiece? Yes, it has it's flaws, but for the most part was well executed. Tom Rothwas pure evil, some have said that he was "too evil", but isn't that the point of a super-villain? His character was over the top, and I loved it. The only real flaw for me was that Mark Whalberg kept slipping into Dirk Diggler, but I was able to ignore him for most of the film. As for the ending, it was great. I don't think that it was supposed to be logical, so stop whining! It was a great over the top way to end an over the top film/concept. So...go see it, expect to be entertained, not educated and you will love it!</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2001-07-29</date>
		<username>charles buss</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Movie: A-</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>In my opinion this is a fine film and deserving of better treatment than its gotten here. Tim Burton brings his unique bag of tricks to a film that is perhaps uniquely suited to them. His dark Gothic visuals blend surprisingly well with the topic. The plot contains much of his trademark satire, which replace the heavy moralising of the first film and makes for lighter, more summereaque fare. The cast has its ups{Helana Bonham Carter and Tim Roth being the standouts} and downs {most of the human actors seem to be chosen for their physical archetypes}. The Danny Elfman music is superb as always, adding to the powerful action scenes which stress the sheer physical strength pf the apes . The only major criticism I have is the bizarre ending, which does come as a small shock to those who haven't had it given away for them by some useless trailer trash. But it doesn't mesh well with the rest of the film and actually to me makes a sequel harder to visuallize. All in all, I think this movie is the most entertaining film this summer {altho' that's not saying a lot}, worth your time and money and deserving of better reviewers {both for and against} than have been shown here so far.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-07-29</date>
		<username>Arkaan Semere (alistair72@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Entertaining, but.... (spoilers)</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>First off, let me say that I found the original overrated. Not bad, but not a 'classic'. When I heard they were remaking it, with Cameron at the helm, I was extremely worried (I dislike everything the man's done in the 90's, with the exception of True Lies, which was fun). When it turned out to be Tim Burton, I felt that maybe he could make this movie truly 'relevant', with sharp satire, and perhaps a little human development. Alas, it wasn't to be. Understand that I think that Burton is a director who's style often overwhelms the substance of any film he's shooting (note, see Sleepy Hollow). That said, he brings enormous creative energy to the film, and is to be respected for massing the talented crew he has. I'm glad to hear the people mentioned Danny Elfman's score, his best. It hooks you from beginning to end, and has the strength to become a contender at this year's oscars. Thunderous, rousing, brilliant, the score is better written then the script for eliciting a dramatic response. Special credit must be given to Rick Baker, the only Hollywood make-up artist whom I've heard of (he's acheived a celebrity status if you will). His simian creations are remarkable, and allow the actors to act through their make-up. Well, that would be more true if the actors had something to act. The script makes no attempt to achieve any form of nuance or subtlety. It eschews what could have been a satire, and asks us to accept fight scenes and stunt work. Discussing the stunt work, it is phenomenal as well. Again, the technical achievements of this film are not to be ignored. The film is fairly entertaining UNTIL..... The climax. What is supposed to be a pulse-pounding scene proves to be a series of cliches, and a horrible use of deux ex machina, and the ending is fairly silly and unnecessary. As for the actors, many attempt to act, but many have nothing to do (the humans). However, the performances by Helena Bonham Carter and Tim Roth are excellent. No kidding, but I think Roth deserves an oscar nomination (as it stands now). His scenery chewing performance as General Thade is energetic and outstanding. Having said that, expect this to win a make-up oscar, and receive a nomination for best score, but it's not a film to rush out and see.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-07-29</date>
		<username>garuda4</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Visually stunning but otherwise same old Hollywood plot line.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Tim Burton presents a magnificent movie for the eyes, but alas opts for the usual poor screen play. I left the movie feeling that I had been well entertained. The magicpecial effects, make-up, musical score all produce a feast of movie fantasy. The ape-ing is inspired. Tim Roth, as the fanatical Chimp General, is worth the price of admission alone. Paul Giamatti has some nice moments, but no-one else is given much to do except to imitate apes or fearful humans. The female chimps look too much like the original Kim Hunter, bereft of facial hair and facial creases.As usual with these kinds of movies the throw away line is ever present, and some make for a good snicker or two. I wonder how many people caught the irony of Charlton Heston defending gun control!It's really best to see this movie with your inner child on your lap, and leave the critical adult home. This is especially true for the ending which gives a momentary smile of pleasure at it's salute to the original, as long as one doesn't think about how it doesn't make any sense!</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>Brandon Chance (closefocus@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Should have been straight to video</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>If you want to see a movie with a textbook example of horrible writing, acting and directing, this is it. This film is packed to the hilt with cliches, unrealistic reactions of characters to their situations, and completely uninteresting characters, with the exception of a couple of the apes. The makeup and production design is of course, very good, but, LESSON TO HOLLYWOOD:::: IF THE SCRIPT AND THE CHARACTERS SUCK, NOTHING ELSE IS GOING TO MATTER, NO MATTER HOW MUCH MONEY AND TECHNICAL TALENT YOU DUMP INTO IT. Whew, glad I got that off my chest. The real tragedy here is that James Cameron was going to direct this at one point. What a shame to think of what could have been....</fullReview>

		<date>2001-07-29</date>
		<username>DR.Z</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A big rotten banana</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This was one colossal waste of time. Some unbelievably goodmake-up (was that Tim Roth under that General Thade monkey-face?) and costumes (more cool leather outfits than amotorcycle jamboree) and art direction were thrown away on a plotthat could have been written by the proverbial 1 millionchimpanzees with typewriters and infinite time. Wahlberg justdoesn't have the majesty of Heston in the original, and comesacross as a teenager locked in the monkey cage of the zoo afterdark. Estella Warren may show someday that she can act, but youcould have placed any supermodel in her role (my vote is HeidiKlum...but I digress) and had no ill effect on the movie. A puremoney grab for the spin-off ape dolls and the inevitable sequel. Ijust got the impression that there were a lot more connectingscenes that were lopped off in the interests of time (let's hope so,anyway, otherwise Tim Burton's slipped on a major banana peel). The DVD may give us clues, but in the meantime, save this one forthe discount Tuesday...</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2001-07-29</date>
		<username>BobbyG</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>A Big Jumbled Mess</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Like many I had my hopes up when I went to see this film. Like most, I love the original film because it had a great story along with fabulous camera work, music, makeup and costumes. The remake is nothing like the original and I knew that going into it. Burton's Planet of the Apes has great things (set design, matte' paintings, special effects and makeup) in it, but the story and pacing are disappointing. The mood is too claustrophobic. There are no interesting characters (Markey Mark the underwear model can't fill Heston's loin cloth). Cliche's are abundant. Tim Roth's character is a little too evil and over the top. The humans talk and have nothing to say. It would have been preferable to keep them mute like the original. Maybe my point of view has been warped by the excellent 1968 version. Burton's work ended up being one big jumbled mess. I even took a short nap in the middle. My 12 year old son woke me up by grabbing my shoulder and when he saw I was dozing said "oh my god." I guess he liked it (he actually called it "OK" as we departed the theater).</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>Brian-272</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>The apes are among us.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I never saw the original 1968 Planet of the Apes, which was extremely popular but I decided to give the 2001 version a watch. Tim Burton once again proves just how great and Gothic that he can direct a movie, Burton has the darkest touch of anyone in Hollywood. Being a Bigfoot enthusiast a movie like Planet of the Apes is just a must see for me. This movie is more than just about a human who has to battle an ape for the rights to get along on the planet. Apes are shown and portrayed as being very smart and clever Burton must have done his homework as he well showed in this movie for example apes bury their dead and of course they can't swim, and Bigfoots are the same way! I strongly believe that apes and bigfoots are among us all anywhere that is proven with the ending of this film!</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2001-07-29</date>
		<username>Nigel St. Buggering</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Burton slips slightly, but still very entertaining</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This new version (I can't quite call it a remake) of a sci fi classic doesn't seem determined to light up brain cells, question our place in nature, or examine our society and our attitude toward "lesser beasts". It's just a good, exciting science fiction adventure film, and on that level, it succeeds quite well with only a few small stumbles.Tim Burton remains the only director I can name who has never made a film I don't like. You might call me biased, but I do go into every new Burton film afraid that this will be the one. Fortunately, I'm still waiting.So why is this not a remake? Well, there are no characters from the original story (either the novel OR the film), and the situation is significantly altered. While still being the story of an astronaut who lands in a strange new ape-dominated world, very little else is the same. Only a few lines of dialogue intended to evoke the 1968 film remind us.What's good? First, of course, is Rick Baker's absolutely astounding makeup. The original appliances still stand up quite well, so this was a nightmare assignment for any makeup artist. Baker is one of the very few who could handle it, and handle it he does. There has never been such amazingly detailed, expressive work in the history of film; the actors are able to come right through the latex and hair. Too much praise cannot be heaped upon his work. Then there's the patented Tim Burton visual approach; this is easily his best-looking film since "Edward Scissorhands", and really helps to lend the proceedings an otherworldly appearance. The acting from the performers in the roles of apes is uniformly excellent, particularly Tim Roth in one of the most frightening villain roles I've seen in years. He truly gives the impression of being dangerously unpredictable; a genuinely great movie psycho. Mention must also be made of Danny Elfman's score, his most dynamic and interesting in years. It recalls Goldsmith's work just enough to remind us of what we're watching, while also moving into new territory.What doesn't work? Well, the humans. They talk, but have nothing of consequence to say. Why is Estella Warren so much cleaner than everyone else, and where did she get that lipstick? And if she's intended to be a love interest for Wahlberg, shouldn't they have a conversation or two? And sadly, we're given only the barest peek at the ape society before our heroes escape and return to the wilderness. I really would like to have seen more of their culture.Now, the ending has already become much-debated and argued over across the Internet and elsewhere. First off, I like the ending. While it may not have quite the punch of the original's, I think it's a good twist for those going in expecting a twist (and weren't we all?). Without revealing too much, let's just say that the screenwriters have obviously read the novel.In conclusion, this is an entertaining and exciting sci-fi adventure. It won't open up your mind much, and it may not be among Burton's best works, but it's a lot of fun, and has a great deal to admire. 7 out of 10.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-07-29</date>
		<username>kismit</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Score one for Marky Mark</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>When I first read that they were going to do this remake I thought it was a ridiculous idea. The original premise was so silly that I thought if there is one movie that did NOT cry out to be remade it was this one. I was incorrect in assuming this. The prosthetic makeup is so much better than the original(you can see the actor's real faces beneath the ape facade)that the biggest hurdle is immediately overcome. Tim Burton excels in working unusual concepts in his film and this is more of the same. Mark Wahlberg fits as the protagonist and while he is not Laurence Olivier the material isn't Shakespeare either. I went expecting little and was pleasantly surprised. With people staying away from the theatre in droves this summer I don't think the film will do that well in the box office but I will recommend it.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2001-07-29</date>
		<username>dgeer80</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>An good movie with a bad ending</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I must say that this version of "Planet of the Apes" is actually pretty good. It's very entertaining. The make-up, the sets, and the battles are all fantastic. The story is also good - up until the end.WARNING!!! SPOILERS AHEAD!!!! DO NOT READ IF YOU DON'T WANT TO BE SPOILED!!!!Anyway, when Leo is flying back through the storm and sees earth, THAT is when the movie should've faded to black and rolled the credits. Thade is still alive, and there could be a sequel that begins with what this movie actually ended with.However, this movie ends with a twist that makes no sense. Somehow, we have a statue of Thade in place of the Lincoln Memorial Statue in Washington D.C., and a planet Earth dominated by Apes. It looks like a great ending, but it doesn't add up. We're not given an ounce of evidence that what happened in this ending could've happened at all. It's like, in Back to the Future Part II, how can we NOT see the Doc toss the sports almanac into the trash, NOT see old Biff steal the book, and NOT see old Biff steal the time machine, and yet still have the same plot? It doesn't work unless those three elements are there. Even seeing old Biff just steal the almanac is good enough. But without any elements to explain how in the heck Biff could've changed the present, it would've been poor writing. It's the same with this ending with Planet of the Apes. It's an ending that should've been seen only at the beginning of a sequel, or if there were elements in the movie's plot to explain how in the world Thade could've done what he did. This ending really hurt the movie. Everything was fine up until we see the statue and the Apes wearing police uniforms, handling guns and driving cars. I can accept that this could've somehow happened. But without a sequel, one has to make up numerous stretches to make it work.Sorry Burton, but you never sacrifice substance for style.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-07-29</date>
		<username>kevin-167</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Burton Delivers!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Let me say first that I am a huge fan of the original Planet of the Apes. When I first heard that Tim Burton was directing the "remake", I was a little concerned. I have been waiting to see this film for quite some time. I finally saw it earlier today and I was not disappointed! ***MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS!!!!!!!***I really enjoyed almost everything about the film. First, the story was good including the surprise twist ending. The performances from Roth to Wahlberg to Carter to Duncan were all top notch. The special effects were about what I expected with a couple of minor flaws. The settings of the villages were realistic and convincing as well. My one complaint would be that the film was a little dark. I am not referring to the mood either, I mean the actual shots were too dark at certain times but it did not take away from the film overall. Really good movie that I would recommend to any sci-fi fan!</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Its a good flick... with a poor ending.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Okay by now I'll assume you've heard there is a "surprise" ending for Apes. I mean in the original story it turned out the "planet of the Apes" was Earth all along, so Burton had to avoid that, and he did, nicely, but he then felt obliged to do his own twist ending and that is where the movie falls apart. This movie was an interesting visual journey with a nice background mystery (how did the apes get this way?) although when all is said and done I am left wondering two things: 1- Where did they get all the horses? And 2- Where is Rod Serling in the end shot? I can almost hear him saying "Picture a man far from home..."</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Good not Great.....</shortDescription>

	<review>
		<date>2001-07-29</date>
		<username>Arkaan Semere (alistair72@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Entertaining, but.... (spoilers)</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>First off, let me say that I found the original overrated. Not bad, but not a 'classic'. When I heard they were remaking it, with Cameron at the helm, I was extremely worried (I dislike everything the man's done in the 90's, with the exception of True Lies, which was fun). When it turned out to be Tim Burton, I felt that maybe he could make this movie truly 'relevant', with sharp satire, and perhaps a little human development. Alas, it wasn't to be. Understand that I think that Burton is a director who's style often overwhelms the substance of any film he's shooting (note, see Sleepy Hollow). That said, he brings enormous creative energy to the film, and is to be respected for massing the talented crew he has. I'm glad to hear the people mentioned Danny Elfman's score, his best. It hooks you from beginning to end, and has the strength to become a contender at this year's oscars. Thunderous, rousing, brilliant, the score is better written then the script for eliciting a dramatic response. Special credit must be given to Rick Baker, the only Hollywood make-up artist whom I've heard of (he's acheived a celebrity status if you will). His simian creations are remarkable, and allow the actors to act through their make-up. Well, that would be more true if the actors had something to act. The script makes no attempt to achieve any form of nuance or subtlety. It eschews what could have been a satire, and asks us to accept fight scenes and stunt work. Discussing the stunt work, it is phenomenal as well. Again, the technical achievements of this film are not to be ignored. The film is fairly entertaining UNTIL..... The climax. What is supposed to be a pulse-pounding scene proves to be a series of cliches, and a horrible use of deux ex machina, and the ending is fairly silly and unnecessary. As for the actors, many attempt to act, but many have nothing to do (the humans). However, the performances by Helena Bonham Carter and Tim Roth are excellent. No kidding, but I think Roth deserves an oscar nomination (as it stands now). His scenery chewing performance as General Thade is energetic and outstanding. Having said that, expect this to win a make-up oscar, and receive a nomination for best score, but it's not a film to rush out and see.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-07-29</date>

Man finds ape planet, man tries to escape ape planet. the ending seemed like a sequel.my Rating 7 out of 10.</fullReview>

It's like, in Back to the Future Part II, how can we NOT see the Doc toss the sports almanac into the trash, NOT see old Biff steal the book, and NOT see old Biff steal the time machine, and yet still have the same plot? It doesn't work unless those three elements are there. Even seeing old Biff just steal the almanac is good enough. But without any elements to explain how in the heck Biff could've changed the present, it would've been poor writing. It's the same with this ending with Planet of the Apes. It's an ending that should've been seen only at the beginning of a sequel, or if there were elements in the movie's plot to explain how in the world Thade could've done what he did. This ending really hurt the movie. Everything was fine up until we see the statue and the Apes wearing police uniforms, handling guns and driving cars. I can accept that this could've somehow happened. But without a sequel, one has to make up numerous stretches to make it work.Sorry Burton, but you never sacrifice substance for style.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-07-29</date>
		<username>kevin-167</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Burton Delivers!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Let me say first that I am a huge fan of the original Planet of the Apes. When I first heard that Tim Burton was directing the "remake", I was a little concerned. I have been waiting to see this film for quite some time. I finally saw it earlier today and I was not disappointed! ***MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS!!!!!!!***I really enjoyed almost everything about the film. First, the story was good including the surprise twist ending. The performances from Roth to Wahlberg to Carter to Duncan were all top notch. The special effects were about what I expected with a couple of minor flaws. The settings of the villages were realistic and convincing as well. My one complaint would be that the film was a little dark. I am not referring to the mood either, I mean the actual shots were too dark at certain times but it did not take away from the film overall. Really good movie that I would recommend to any sci-fi fan!</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-07-29</date>
		<username>Brandon Chance (closefocus@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Should have been straight to video</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>If you want to see a movie with a textbook example of horrible writing, acting and directing, this is it. This film is packed to the hilt with cliches, unrealistic reactions of characters to their situations, and completely uninteresting characters, with the exception of a couple of the apes. The makeup and production design is of course, very good, but, LESSON TO HOLLYWOOD:::: IF THE SCRIPT AND THE CHARACTERS SUCK, NOTHING ELSE IS GOING TO MATTER, NO MATTER HOW MUCH MONEY AND TECHNICAL TALENT YOU DUMP INTO IT. Whew, glad I got that off my chest. The real tragedy here is that James Cameron was going to direct this at one point. What a shame to think of what could have been....</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-07-29</date>
		<username>Animus</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>Its a good flick... with a poor ending.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Okay by now I'll assume you've heard there is a "surprise" ending for Apes. I mean in the original story it turned out the "planet of the Apes" was Earth all along, so Burton had to avoid that, and he did, nicely, but he then felt obliged to do his own twist ending and that is where the movie falls apart. This movie was an interesting visual journey with a nice background mystery (how did the apes get this way?) although when all is said and done I am left wondering two things: 1- Where did they get all the horses? And 2- Where is Rod Serling in the end shot? I can almost hear him saying "Picture a man far from home..."</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-07-29</date>
		<username>(secordman)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Too many flaws</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Planet of the Apes has some major flaws to get over, and despite a solid final 30 minutes, the film has some problems. Mark Wahlberg comes off as a cocky punk, and his acting is so wooden and one-dimensional, you wonder what they were thinking when they cast him. The tendency is for Hollywood to cover all the bases, so you get your generic supermodel, mouthy 12 year old boy, cute little girl, and so on. Roth was fine, but overall the script was nothing special, the battle scenes were uneven, and the preachy subtext about racism/animal rights was as subtle as a hammer on the head. There were some entertaining moments, but add this movie to a long list in the past few years as case studies for "What's wrong with Hollywood" or "How to Monkey up a good idea" or even "Why must Hollywood always Ape old classic movies?".</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-07-29</date>
		<username>Arkaan Semere (alistair72@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Entertaining, but.... (spoilers)</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>First off, let me say that I found the original overrated. Not bad, but not a 'classic'. When I heard they were remaking it, with Cameron at the helm, I was extremely worried (I dislike everything the man's done in the 90's, with the exception of True Lies, which was fun). When it turned out to be Tim Burton, I felt that maybe he could make this movie truly 'relevant', with sharp satire, and perhaps a little human development. Alas, it wasn't to be. Understand that I think that Burton is a director who's style often overwhelms the substance of any film he's shooting (note, see Sleepy Hollow). That said, he brings enormous creative energy to the film, and is to be respected for massing the talented crew he has. I'm glad to hear the people mentioned Danny Elfman's score, his best. It hooks you from beginning to end, and has the strength to become a contender at this year's oscars. Thunderous, rousing, brilliant, the score is better written then the script for eliciting a dramatic response. Special credit must be given to Rick Baker, the only Hollywood make-up artist whom I've heard of (he's acheived a celebrity status if you will). His simian creations are remarkable, and allow the actors to act through their make-up. Well, that would be more true if the actors had something to act. The script makes no attempt to achieve any form of nuance or subtlety. It eschews what could have been a satire, and asks us to accept fight scenes and stunt work. Discussing the stunt work, it is phenomenal as well. Again, the technical achievements of this film are not to be ignored. The film is fairly entertaining UNTIL..... The climax. What is supposed to be a pulse-pounding scene proves to be a series of cliches, and a horrible use of deux ex machina, and the ending is fairly silly and unnecessary. As for the actors, many attempt to act, but many have nothing to do (the humans). However, the performances by Helena Bonham Carter and Tim Roth are excellent. No kidding, but I think Roth deserves an oscar nomination (as it stands now). His scenery chewing performance as General Thade is energetic and outstanding. Having said that, expect this to win a make-up oscar, and receive a nomination for best score, but it's not a film to rush out and see.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-07-29</date>
		<username>gino2013</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Well Done!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I haven't seen the original Planet of the Apes even though i've been meaning to.I just saw the new version brought out 10 minutes ago and I think it was very well done. I'm sure some changes are made for the reason, unfortunately i've seen the ending of the original.Mark Wahlberg was pretty believable as an astronaut who lands on a planet inhabited as Apes who rule it. Tim Roth's character probably ruled the film as an awesome Tim Burton Villain since the Joker with the original Batman. Nothing alike but still wonderfully played.So far one of the best movies of the summer no doubt.I give it a 7.5/10.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-07-29</date>
		<username>Kevin Hasser (OneGarbageman@aol.com)</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>I hope it doesn't turn into a Star Trek</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I saw this film the day it came out with high hopes. My friends told me how great the original was and i could only think of how awesome a writer must be to create such an original story. Oh, i was a fool.Burton has had a successful streak, hasn't he? Batman, Batman Returns, Sleepy Hollow, and the cult favorite Nightmare Before Christmas. Yes it is an awesome life. But every career has a hitch. This is his. Mark Wahlberg's career has also been rising. From the innovative Boogy Nights, to the highly rated Three Kings and The Perfect Storm with another blockbuster (Rock Star) on the way. Maybe this can be an oversight.No matter the director or the stars, our hero, Leo Davidson cannot see that his ape costars are real actors. Whenever speaking to them, he inserts a short pause, as if trying to prove to himself that these are real people. His eyes are blank and emotionless. He plays a hero just as well as Steven Seagal, take that as you will.The apes are frighteningly lifelike, but you can't base a movie on its makeup. The film is dark, very dark (visually) for the first 3/4. As if these future apes couldn't figure out lightbulbs, or even gas lights. The film also uses the rope and pulley system made popular by the Matrix. While it looked new and exciting in Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, and even Romeo Must Die, seeing apes jumping vertically eight feet (from a sit down) is just silly.None of the "human" characters, beside Leo, play an important role. It makes you wonder why he's trying to save them. Apes have evolved into intelligent, thought processing individuals over thousands of years... but what happened to the humans? Did we just stop at a certain point in time, and someone said, "This is enough for you"? The ending is so confusing it's physically impossible. Burton rearranges time so much i think HE get's lost. Overall, it's a 4/10- saved by the makeup and the ape's acting.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-07-29</date>
		<username>kismit</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Score one for Marky Mark</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>When I first read that they were going to do this remake I thought it was a ridiculous idea. The original premise was so silly that I thought if there is one movie that did NOT cry out to be remade it was this one. I was incorrect in assuming this. The prosthetic makeup is so much better than the original(you can see the actor's real faces beneath the ape facade)that the biggest hurdle is immediately overcome. Tim Burton excels in working unusual concepts in his film and this is more of the same. Mark Wahlberg fits as the protagonist and while he is not Laurence Olivier the material isn't Shakespeare either. I went expecting little and was pleasantly surprised. With people staying away from the theatre in droves this summer I don't think the film will do that well in the box office but I will recommend it.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-07-29</date>
		<username>garuda4</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Visually stunning but otherwise same old Hollywood plot line.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Tim Burton presents a magnificent movie for the eyes, but alas opts for the usual poor screen play. I left the movie feeling that I had been well entertained. The magicpecial effects, make-up, musical score all produce a feast of movie fantasy. The ape-ing is inspired. Tim Roth, as the fanatical Chimp General, is worth the price of admission alone. Paul Giamatti has some nice moments, but no-one else is given much to do except to imitate apes or fearful humans. The female chimps look too much like the original Kim Hunter, bereft of facial hair and facial creases.As usual with these kinds of movies the throw away line is ever present, and some make for a good snicker or two. I wonder how many people caught the irony of Charlton Heston defending gun control!It's really best to see this movie with your inner child on your lap, and leave the critical adult home. This is especially true for the ending which gives a momentary smile of pleasure at it's salute to the original, as long as one doesn't think about how it doesn't make any sense!</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2001-07-29</date>
		<username>dgeer80</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>An good movie with a bad ending</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I must say that this version of "Planet of the Apes" is actually pretty good. It's very entertaining. The make-up, the sets, and the battles are all fantastic. The story is also good - up until the end.WARNING!!! SPOILERS AHEAD!!!! DO NOT READ IF YOU DON'T WANT TO BE SPOILED!!!!Anyway, when Leo is flying back through the storm and sees earth, THAT is when the movie should've faded to black and rolled the credits. Thade is still alive, and there could be a sequel that begins with what this movie actually ended with.However, this movie ends with a twist that makes no sense. Somehow, we have a statue of Thade in place of the Lincoln Memorial Statue in Washington D.C., and a planet Earth dominated by Apes. It looks like a great ending, but it doesn't add up. We're not given an ounce of evidence that what happened in this ending could've happened at all. It's like, in Back to the Future Part II, how can we NOT see the Doc toss the sports almanac into the trash, NOT see old Biff steal the book, and NOT see old Biff steal the time machine, and yet still have the same plot? It doesn't work unless those three elements are there. Even seeing old Biff just steal the almanac is good enough. But without any elements to explain how in the heck Biff could've changed the present, it would've been poor writing. It's the same with this ending with Planet of the Apes. It's an ending that should've been seen only at the beginning of a sequel, or if there were elements in the movie's plot to explain how in the world Thade could've done what he did. This ending really hurt the movie. Everything was fine up until we see the statue and the Apes wearing police uniforms, handling guns and driving cars. I can accept that this could've somehow happened. But without a sequel, one has to make up numerous stretches to make it work.Sorry Burton, but you never sacrifice substance for style.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Entertaining, but.... (spoilers)</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>First off, let me say that I found the original overrated. Not bad, but not a 'classic'. When I heard they were remaking it, with Cameron at the helm, I was extremely worried (I dislike everything the man's done in the 90's, with the exception of True Lies, which was fun). When it turned out to be Tim Burton, I felt that maybe he could make this movie truly 'relevant', with sharp satire, and perhaps a little human development. Alas, it wasn't to be. Understand that I think that Burton is a director who's style often overwhelms the substance of any film he's shooting (note, see Sleepy Hollow). That said, he brings enormous creative energy to the film, and is to be respected for massing the talented crew he has. I'm glad to hear the people mentioned Danny Elfman's score, his best. The script makes no attempt to achieve any form of nuance or subtlety. It eschews what could have been a satire, and asks us to accept fight scenes and stunt work. Discussing the stunt work, it is phenomenal as well. Again, the technical achievements of this film are not to be ignored. The film is fairly entertaining UNTIL..... The climax. What is supposed to be a pulse-pounding scene proves to be a series of cliches, and a horrible use of deux ex machina, and the ending is fairly silly and unnecessary. As for the actors, many attempt to act, but many have nothing to do (the humans). However, the performances by Helena Bonham Carter and Tim Roth are excellent. No kidding, but I think Roth deserves an oscar nomination (as it stands now). His scenery chewing performance as General Thade is energetic and outstanding. Having said that, expect this to win a make-up oscar, and receive a nomination for best score, but it's not a film to rush out and see.</fullReview>
