	<review>
		<date>2002-01-04</date>
		<username>The Flickster</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>The best effects-driven action film of summer 2001.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>PLANET OF THE APES (2001) Rating: 8/10Whoa, I think I'm all geeked out now, having just seen what has to be one of the most fun movies out of summer 2001. I wasn't expecting to like it so much, with the reviews being mixed and with some fanboys raging about disappointing this new episode of the Apes saga is. Indeed, the movie has its problems, namely how it eschews the Pierre Boulle novel and the first movie adaptation's political and social allegory. You can still read some commentary on racism, animal rights, or the issues of religion versus science throughout Tim Burton's "reimagined" Planet of the Apes, but it's superficial and inconsequential at best. For better or worst, what we got here is another go at the archetypical story of the loner who rode into town and inspired the weak to stand up against their oppressors. This is the outlaw Josey Wales helping the villagers fight off the Yankees, or Mad Max joining the bunkered people as they strike back at the road warriors, or Braveheart leading the Scots against the English army...The film was written by William Broyles, Jr. (Cast Away) and Mark Rosenthal and Lawrence Konner (Mighty Joe Young) and though they don't delve into much thought-provoking material, their script is relatively tight and engaging enough. It swiftly goes from A to B, simply setting up oppositions and characters along the way, and it pays off with an exciting action climax and a hilarious Bizarro twist ending. In any case, as in most of Tim Burton's movies (except Edward Scissorhands), storytelling and character development are secondary to splendid production design and moody, stylish direction. I loved this new planet, the more complex and detailed Ape City, with chimps everywhere playing b-ball or music, having a drink, getting laid... And what chimps they are! As impressive as the Oscar winning make-up was in the original, it never felt as organic, as natural as what FX whiz Rick Baker has pulled here. His apes not only look great, they also move and act great.I like that the actors are still able to convey emotions through facial expressions despite all the latex and faux fur. It also paid off to have them go through "Ape School", as they now walk, breathe and behave like true animals; even they talk, they'll sometimes revert to groans and high pitch screams. Of course, you also have to credit the cast itself for this. There's Michael Clarke Duncan as a gorilla army goon who conveys real brute force, but also has an interesting character arc that has him questioning his religious beliefs and his loyalties. There's Paul Giamatti's orangutan slave trader, who brings some comic relief. Or what about Helena Bonham-Carter's human rights activists chimp lady and Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa's conflicted gorilla friend, who decide to side with the humans? Last but not least is Tim Roth's rage-fuelled portrayal of General Thade, a cruel and vicious chimpanzee who really loathes humans. Roth's performance is all animal aggressiveness, and his Thade has got to be the coolest movie villain we've seen all year.In the end, maybe that's what it comes down to: if you're as much of a sucker for apes as I am you're in for a treat, but if you're looking for compelling human characters and challenging subtext, you've got the wrong movie. Mark Wahlberg is really good in this movie, I totally believed that he was this Leo guy. More so then the original's badass, Taylor, who was played by Charlton Heston (who, incidentally, has a cameo in the new film, as an ape!). We get really cool looking apes, many tense moments, some funny ones, a thrilling battle between human tribes and the simian army and that funny, funny ending. All that made it so I wasn't bothered by the pedestrian plot and the holes in logic. Burton's Planet of the Apes is not without its flaws, but neither were the films of the original series. What we have here is an expertly crafted adventure just a bit quirkier than your conventional popcorn movie, and I was entertained by it. I mean apes, man, a whole planet of them, how can you not dig this?</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2001-12-22</date>
		<username>sddavis63 (revsdd@gmail.com)</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Very Good, Original Story</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This movies deserves a rating of 8 just for the surprise twist at the end, about which I will say no more.I hadn't really been expecting that much from this when I rented the video; I rather thought that the "Apes" franchise had been done to death back in the late 60's - early 70's, with a collection of movies and a TV series that went progressively downhill and became more nonsensical with each installment. But I was very pleasantly surprised by this movie, which was very entertaining and - if I recall correctly (although it's been many years since I read it) is more consistent with the story of Pierre Bouille's original novel. So, my advice is that if you're either avoiding this or watching it because you expect it to be like the "Apes" movies of thirty years ago, plan to watch it on its own merits instead.The cast was in general very good. Mark Wahlberg did a fine job as the astronaut Leo Davidson, stranded on this nightmare of a planet (for him) with no obvious way of getting home. Tim Roth as his primary ape antagonist, General Thade, was also very good. I had a mixture of reactions to Helena Bonham Carter's role as Ari, the human-loving ape. Her performance was quite good, but, frankly, I found her character to be rather irritating. It's a necessary role. We have to see these divisions in ape society, but the character just didn't appeal to me in the same way as, say, Cornelius and Zera did in the original movie. I also thought the ape makeup was rather weak. Frankly, they did a better job thirty years ago.But those minor criticisms aside, I really did enjoy this movie. It was a fast-paced story that held my attention, there was enough humour to make it fun, and enough drama to make me wonder how Davidson was ever going to get out of this. And - as I said at the start - the end itself is worth watching the whole movie.I rate this as an 8/10.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2001-11-13</date>
		<username>Russell Goodwin (mrmojorisin213@yahoo.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Don't compare to original, don't hold against it</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This reimagining is sheer eye candy, but through the surreal direction of Tim Burton's past features, what is wrong with this? The original 1968 film was heavy on themes of social tension, the hierarchy of class systems, and evolution. In my opinion, there is no need to improve on the first film simply because there was no room for improvement. It seems that this film is designed for popcorn summer entertainment and it does not sell short of this intention. Tim Burton's dark vision is one of the strongest directorial forces of all time. Whether it's the dark comedic tone of "Beetlejuice" or the ethereal romanticism of "Edward Scissorhands", the man is genius and "Planet of the Apes 2001" is no exception. I do forgive him for "Mars Attacks" though.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Tim Burton's worst film to date</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>What ever happened to one of the most innovative and brilliant storytellers of our time? Well, he made the kind of typical summer action fodder that could've been directed by anybody available out of film school...and in fact, they probably would've done a better job. They would've at least have put half of a thought into the dreadful script.Mark Wahlberg plays an astronaut who traveled through some sort of wormhole and landed in a planet ruled by apes. (gasp!) Except this time around, the apes squirm through groan-worthy dialogue, nonsensical plotting, and showy special effects that constantly reinforce in my mind that this money could've been put to about 10 independent films that would have been considered 'masterpiece' next to this tripe.As much as I enjoy the superb acting talent that is Tim Roth, his performance as evil ape leader Thade is nothing more than an intense composition of slouching and heavy breathing. Luckily for him, the makeup allows he as an actor to maintain some dignity and most of the crap-dialogue is hidden behind his groans and sniffles.And alas, the always dependable Hollywood tradition of taking the male and female leads and hooking them up at the end without any relationship development or cause. And the "haha, we're so clever, aren't we?" way that Hollywood intermingles references from the original POTA into this one. Sigh...Instead of seeing this, spend the night in and call up some friends and rent 'Ed Wood', 'Edward Scissorhands', 'Batman', or even to a lesser extent 'Sleepy Hollow', and reminisce about the days when Tim Burton was a man of vision and originality...not shame and ridicule.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2001-10-13</date>
		<username>Mort-31</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>It's hard not to like a Tim-Burton-film</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>ATTENTION, SPOILER!Many people told me that «Planet of the Apes» was Tim Burton's worst movie and apart from that much weaker than the original film. So I decided not to see it. Another friend of mine who hadn't seen the movie yet, advised me to watch it in spite of this because `a Tim-Burton-movie is still a Tim-Burton-movie'. I decided to do it, and I found that he was right.It's clear that a remake of such a famous film as `Planet of the Apes' is automatically influenced by commercial thinking. Still, Tim Burton managed his film to represent his weird playfulness just as well as `Beetlejuice' or `Batman'. If you are already fond of Burton-movies, it's hard not to like one of his films, even if it has some flaws: nerve-racking monkey squeals, over-dressed apes and a leading actor who could have been, without difficulties, replaced by anbody else.What the film gives us in the first place, is an answer to the question: What's the result when Tim Burton is instructed to create a remake? First of all, Burton wouldn't be Burton, if he wouldn't refuse to call it a remake from the start; it's a `re-imagining'. On the other hand, Burton knows that almost every viewer of his movie has seen the very first film version starring Charlton Heston (as human), and he knows that a remake doesn't exist without its model and that the two films will not stop being compared. So all he does is playing with this comparison at every moment of his film, e. g. by referencing to quotes. Concerning the story-line, Burton does a brilliant job by answering open questions of the original first, and then driving the whole audience to despair by destroying this wonderful clarity and ending the movie with ? AND HERE IS THE SPOILER ? Leo coming back to earth and finding himself inside a world that seems to have been ruled by apes forever. Now, this is the burtonesque answer to people's expectations they hold because of the astonishing, shocking ending of the first `Planet of the Apes'. An ending, even more unexpected, more astonishing and: completely confusing, because ? and here I'm disagreeing with various `Planet of the Apes'-homepages and -platforms ? it does not make any sense. There cannot be a meaning to it, or just a so complicated one that it becomes ineffective. Tim Burton is playing his cruel games, he does it with a grin and he does it well. Burton fans will sure like it, others may feel betrayed and complain about some sort of manierism. Well, and I don't think producers will ever ask Burton to direct a remake again?</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>When I heard all the critics bitching about how terrible the new Planet of the Apes movie was, I was unfazed. The movie had great potential; I don't know what went wrong! Mark Whalberg, Helena Bonham Carter and Tim Roth are all spectacular actors, but here they were either cardboard cutouts, or merely annoying. Sleepy Hollow, for example, was not a great movie by any means, but at least it had Burton's flair and imagination. 	<review>
		<date>2001-10-02</date>
		<username>Boris-57 (bonzothegod@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>0.2</score>
		<shortDescription>Visually stunning, but the money is wasted</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Well, it turned out as I expected: visual overload but nothing else added to the original. What did surprise me however was that the storyline was fairly drastically changed compared to the 1968 flick. Initially this awoke my interest, but what eventually surprised was that the new twists and turns (a) were apparently invented in order to present us with a typical Hollywood-like product and (b) made the whole storyline improbable! The 1968 story was breathtakingly straightforward, and included no time-storms or any bogus of that sort: it just stated that when you come home after a long journey, things might have changed a bit. Earth might have fallen in the hands of apes, for example. Like many 'old' movies, it's main ingredient was suspense (hell, does anyone understand that word these days?). In this Burton movie, an attempt has been made to turn the whole thing into an action movie, but at what cost? Surely, the images are overwhelming, and a lot of time and money has been put into the design of a complete ape-culture (even ape-music!), but what's wrong?First, the suspension of disbelief is made very hard, because the apes have a lot of Hollywood-human traits. I refer especially to Ari and the slave-trader. These traits include emotional skills like irony, sarcasm, and an overtly displayed array of 'subtle' emotions. It makes you forget that the apes are apes, which is essential.Second, the humans TALK. Of course, we can imagine that humans will never forget how to speak, but the fact that the apes had speech and the humans didn't made the ape/human role-switching very tangible and stressing in the 1968 version. The wound in the throat that Charlton Heston gets there is essential to his survival and his later regained speech essential to his uniqueness and the interest that Dr. Zira has in him (so, no need for things like human rights activists or ape-human love in order to explain things).Third, the fact that they talk ads a great deal to the implausibility, but is a necessary twist in the new movie, since Capt. Davidson has to play the Hollywood-let's-save-the-whole-world- and-have-a-good-ending-for-everyone- and-still-make-it-to-the-lounge-bar- for-a-cool-diet-coke character. Oh my god, will they never learn? I new it from the start, when there was only one guy who got lost! They were in need of a hero! And then the script writers go on reasoning: we need one guy... so, why would one guy get lost... because he tries to save an ape from an electromagnetic storm... implausible! But it's necessary because it shows the audience that he respects apes! Since, in these modern and politically correct times, we can't have a xenophobic ape-hater like Charlton Heston's 68 character loose on the screen: let's give them a bubblegum version!Fourth, okay, the general twist of the original 'discovering the truth' of the 1968 film to the modern version (he finds that his own mother ship crashed on the planet ages ago and that their lab-apes developed their society, where Heston simply discovered that just, somehow, the apes overtook the earth while he was away) is nicely done. The second, battle-part comes as an anti-climax. That's because this movie has added the first two Planet Of The Apes movies in one plot. Nice try, but the chill you feel when Davidson and you discover that he's lost on the planet forever just washes out due to the uninteresting battle-part.Fifth: the ending!!! For chrissakes, who came up with that?! (a) Davidson crashes TWICE with his escape pod, which seems an unsteerable object, while the chimp manages to simply land gracefully? Come on, who'd believe that? If the pods are really small space crafts (Davidson simply flies off into space at the end) and not merely escape vessels, he might have managed a safe landing at least once, no? And what about that ending???? I mean, in the original film it was clear that everything took place on earth. But here: the whole movie takes place on a distant planet, and suddenly the same (there's a Thade statue) ape culture is on earth??? How come? Did the apes of the far planet evolve technologically, flew into the time storm and colonised earth before Davidson's mission took off? Why is Thade worshiped? Stupid stupid stupid.Helena Bonham Carter is even adorable and beautiful as an ape, but I'd expected no less. I preferred her ape above Estella Warren as a human, but maybe I got some loose wire in my head. Nevertheless, the only convincing apes were Tim Roth as Thade (wonderful!) and Ari's household ape (the ex-general, but I forgot his name).Nonono, a lot of things could and should have been added/altered to the 1968 pic, but not the plot, at least not in that way. It was simple and clear and needed no additional explaining. It was nicely tongue-in cheek and caricatured. Don't stylize everything...</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-09-21</date>
		<username>UberCritic</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Burton spins the boredom out of the original.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I was only seven years old when the original "Planet of the Apes" was released in 1968 and, compared to other films of that era ("2001, A Space Odyssey," "Bullitt," "You Only Live Twice," etc.) I was able to recognize "Planet" for what it was: pure, unadulterated schlock, and boring schlock at that. The sorry parade of Ape movies that followed into the '70s was my first experience with Hollywood's "Sequel System" of pumping as much revenue as possible from any spavined idea that is a hit with audiences. This may, in fact, have been an early iteration of that now-standard practice.Needless to say, I had no expectation of anything more than a mild diversion when I wandered into a matinee showing of Tim Burton's take on this shriveled old chestnut. To my surprise, and despite the fact that Mark Wahlberg sleep-walked his way through the entire movie, it worked a lot better than the original. General Thade (Tim Roth) is by far the most engaging character in the movie, and the only one that overcomes his ape makeup with an identifiable personality. I was almost rooting for HIM by the end of the movie.Burton's portrayal of the preening, officious Ape Elite and their personal habits is a sly look at some of our own human foibles. I recognized a couple of ex-bosses during those scenes. Original cast member and current NRA President Charleton Heston has a cameo that becomes hilarious when he shows son Thade his "proof" of human ingenuity. I wonder how many viewers missed the humor in that because they are ignorant of Heston's NRA activities? It's refreshing to see an actor of his age and station who is able to poke fun at himself.Happily, this "homage" to the original carries enough originality to keep it interesting (let's just say there was never a Statue of Liberty on this planet) and has better pacing and a lot more action than the original. The effects are seamless and there is enough humor to break up any monotony.The movie climaxes about 10 minutes before it ends, which is too bad. The last few scenes are a total throwaway (and perhaps a foreshadowing of the dreaded Sequelitis), but hey, we can't all be Shakespeare all of the time.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2001-09-03</date>
		<username>Glacier571-3</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Burton provides an entertaining yet flawed ape escape</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Tim Burton has a unique, dark style that sets him far apart from other filmmakers of his generation, and he has a knack for getting the best efforts from his crews and actors.His "reimagining" of "Planet of the Apes" is a rare instance in which those qualities never come to the fore. I won't bother with prattle comparing this to the 1968 original, simply because I haven't seen it and don't plan to anytime soon.He brings back nearly the entire crew he worked with on the superior "Sleepy Hollow" ? costume designer Colleen Atwood, production designer Rick Heinrichs, editor Chris Lebenzon, and composer Danny Elfman, but this formidable unit fails to fully click this time around.Makeup guru Rick Baker (the "Nutty Professor" series) is responsible for the impressive simian facades, but most of the time they look instead like very expensive Halloween masks that muddle the actors' voices. The diction left much to be desired; some characters speak too low and fast (I sat in the fourth row and the theater had THX sound), and some baritone-voiced males sound as if they're talking with their mouths full.The acting is adequate but sometimes as stiff as the monkey mugs, starting with a wooden Mark Wahlberg as the centerpiece of the film, Leo Davidson. He is an Air Force captain, yet he works way up in space. The setup for his eventual crash landing onto the Planet of the Apes is flimsy and rushed. When that time comes, he doesn't look too concerned about being alone and stranded, and eventually imprisoned, in a strange new world, and he goes through the film as if this is all small potatoes to him.Thanks to bad dialogue, he inadvertently forges what may turn out to be the new pickup line of the 21st century: "I can show you something that will change your world forever."Needless to say, the simians are the best thespians, and that's not saying much. Tim Roth hams it up to the hilt as the villain Thade, but he can only do so much in a movie of this style. His chief henchman, played by Michael Clarke Duncan, verbally berates and knocks a few humans around here and there, and snarls lines such as, "Get your stinkin' hands off me, you filthy human!" and "Bow your heads!" And, that's it.Helena Bonham Carter is solid as Brit-accented human sympathizer Ari. Coincidentally, out of all the Apes, she looks the most human as well (and is nearly a dead ringer for Michael Jackson). Paul Giamatti, on the other hand, is annoying as Limbo the orangutan, the film's thin attempt at comic relief.The weakest link, as if it isn't too obvious, is Leo's gang of human fugitives, especially an annoying teenage boy and the token Black man whom we all know will get knocked off at some point in the film. They have no personality and serve no purpose in the plot whatsoever except to chip in with a cheesy line here and there. Supermodel Estella Warren, playing a slave girl whose father (Kris Kristofferson) is killed by the Apes, is as pointless as a broken pencil. Her skimpy outfit contained more depth than her screen presence. Most of her activity consists of staring into space with her mouth agape.By the way, I didn't realize the Planet of the Apes contained any beauty salons, because she manages to look like she just stepped out of one whenever she appears on screen.Oh, and Burton brings aboard his squeeze Lisa Marie once again for no apparent reason. This time around, she's buried under an Ape mask. As usual, she has nothing to do here except display her one-dimensional feminine wiles.The cinematography, courtesy of Phillippe Rousselot, does a nice job of stressing the foreboding, moonlit jungle environment. It's the only saving grace of the lackluster action sequences, especially in the beginning just after Leo crash-lands and finds himself in the middle of a wild huntdown of humans by Ape soldiers. Elfman comes through on the music front; because of his powerful score, I loved the opening credits sequence.Unfortunately, while Heinrichs' sets are always a visual treat, they aren't as gripping as his Oscar-winning work from SH. They are small and constricted due to the fact that there are sometimes too many characters cavorting on the screen. Upon seeing the Apes' village for the first time, I couldn't help but think of the planet Endor from "Return of the Jedi." The wreckage of Leo's USAF space station, however, is fantastic. It's also the location of a surprising twist in the story.Now to the plot. The reason why it falters for the most part is what ultimately crippled "Shrek": it has an unpleasant air of preachiness to it. By itself, the plot is as thin as Wahlberg's music career, but in a twist that seems rather uncharacteristic of Burton, "Apes" plays the race card. This I didn't care for. I'm aware that this angle is in the original, but it's a white elephant in Burton's version.And yes, an Ape actually utters those infamous six words...I'm sure you know what they are.The suspense factor is all but nil, and the plot twists leave behind numerous holes, such as, for example, the controls on the destroyed space station being able to work despite the wreck apparently being thousands of years old. (Plus, where did all those horses, the Apes' sole means of transportation, come from?)Then there is the well-publicized "love triangle" between Wahlberg, Carter and Warren that Burton hinted at in interviews. To make a long story short, if you plan to watch this solely on the basis of seeing this angle, you're in for a disappointment.Sorry, but I won't waste my breath on Charlton Heston's forgettable pot-and-kettle cameo.Save for the aforementioned chase sequence after Leo's crash landing, the action and fight scenes are pathetic. Simple punches send both humans and Apes flying a few dozen feet into the air. And don't ask the Apes to hit targets in the water that are two feet from the shore. The huge Apes-humans showdown near the end is a yawner.The much-ballyhooed ending is both surprising and ambiguous. Though Burton has vehemently denied any rumors of his helming a sequel, the conclusion is like that of a comic book and does leave the door wide open for a second installment.The film's most comical moments occurred offscreen. Before shooting began, the actors had to undergo "ape training" to learn primate mannerisms, and spent hours in makeup before stepping in front of the cameras. On "failing" ape school, Bonham Carter quipped, "I was told I had AADD ? Ape Attention Deficit Disorder." On becoming an Ape: "It's flattering to be cast as a chimp, because you know they haven't cast you for what you look like." Duncan hurt his ankle while filming a pivotal scene with Kristofferson, who slipped, fell, crashed into Duncan and wound up having to get stitches. Duncan was rushed to the hospital (yes, rushed for a turned ankle ? that's Hollywood for ya), in full makeup, no less. When he announced himself to a room full of patients, they burst into applause.While "Planet of the Apes" has some major flaws, it doesn't mean it's not entertaining, which it indeed is, but it just doesn't have that signature Tim Burton look and feel to it. It's ultimately just another Hollywood action flick.After all is said and done, his best effort to date still remains "Sleepy Hollow." 7.5/10</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>The least you could say about that remake is it's poorly scripted and it lacks of tempo. Did they need Tim Burton to shoot this? The story is flat with no real tension created in line with most of the characters. Mark Wahlberg is a dull paleface astronaut and Tim Roth is great, unfortunately his character is so foreseeable it adds little to an already poor suspense.The beginning is neither creative nor tense and the subsequent chase scene is hardly impressive. Burton reportedly shot 5 different endings (to pack the DVD with some supposedly creative stuff). Eventually they decided to stuck that one. It's all the less clear and eludes the fact that to impress audiences in the end it should at least be easily understood. So it only aims to revive the image of general Thade (as for King Scorpion in the Mummy) for a possible sequel. Well frankly, we don't know yet. Have a nice holiday!</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>What the hell?!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Well, this film is Planet of the Apes in name alone. Well, and the fact that it's about a Planet. With Apes on it. For anyone who has read the book, the original book, you'll know what I mean. It bares no relation whatsoever to the original premise. The humans talk (wtf?) and the apes appear to have evolved from genetically modified chimps in a few thousand years (yes, all of them. Including the Orangs and Gorillas. There are two types of chimp too). The defined political structure has also been chucked out the window. And the ending? What the hell is that meant to be?Anyway, if you haven't seen the originals (been on Soror for 100 years or something) and haven't read the book, then you might as well see this. 		<shortDescription>Somebody please explain!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>WARNING*** SPOILER ALERT*** While the special effects and makeup in this movie are very well done, the ending of the film leaves you with a sense of "WHAT THE HECK?" 		<date>2001-08-25</date>
		<username>emilyblunt</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Those nostalgic for the original take heart- there's still only one Cornelious</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Show of hands...how many of you were secretly ecstatic over the thought of A. Marky Mark, er, Mark Wahlberg (excuse me) all muddied up running around a Tim Burton set and B. that they were even remaking this accidental classic, which easily is near the top of America's Cheesiest Films Of All Times list (right below Blackula, Killer Tomatoes and Jon Waters' purposely cheesy farces of course).For those too young to remember, Planet of the Apes first appeared in 1968. It was a sensation with audiences and panned by critics. The costumes were state-of-the-art for the times and the sets were as other worldly as they could portray in a sixties Star Trek quazi-realism way.Those who enjoyed the first version(s) even passed up the concession stand goodies for fear of losing that comfy close-up seat. The suspense of what the apes would look with all the modern gizmos the FX folks have at their disposal nowadays was almost unbearable. Like with The Grinch's recent successful transformation into 21st century-gadget- hoopla- infused- bing- bam box-office magic, TPOA does not disappoint on that level.As for the the rest of the film? Well, the plot is as deep as Green Eggs and Ham and the "human" cast is about as exciting as an instructional video on an anal polyp removal from the lower bowel of a brown field mouse, yet still, mad-director Tim Burton left just enough camp to keep it, surprisingly, enjoyable.The story goes...Astronaut; Leo Davidson (Mark "softly spoken" Wahlberg) is aboard a space station USS Oberon, training primates to play Astronaut. One starry night he is told to send one of these Chimps out to research a menacing energy field approaching fast on their starboard side.The "canary in the coal mine" never returns...So, Leo, bored with his mundane duties anyhow, jumps into a delta pod to rescue the fellow, and, surprise, gets transported through time to a place ruled by...He crash lands safely in an eerie swamp. But, before he can shake his banana dry, he is over run by a group of fear-for-their-lives types ricocheting through the forest being pursued by dressed, orating, violent apes. Leo is trapped, along with these ratty anorexic -Mad Max looking- extras each with a perpetual glaze over their faces like deer locked on headlights (or Nick Cage in an emotional scene), and sent to market. The market is run by Limbo (brilliant Paul Giamatti) a sleazy Orang creep.Leo and a boopsie faced tribe gal, Deana (Estella " be careful of bimbo typecasting dear" Warren), meet in one of Limbo's human slave holding cells. She's smitten, but he's focused on his personal inner dialog, his sequel, "Exit El Quicko from the Planet Of The Apes."They end up working together and gather a few others including, human rights activist girly ape Ari (Helena Bonham Carter). They all escape the city and head to "rendezvous" with Leo's space colleagues who have been sending out a signal to him via his space age transmitter he rescued from his sunken space pod. The humans hope Leo is their savior fallen from the sky to save them from the mini-Kongs that suppress them. Leo hopes his friends are waiting for him, just over the mountain range?The fleeing party faces some pretty mean mother-apers en route to Shangri-La! One ape in particular, General Thad, (Tim Roth) hates humans in a Hitler- southern plantation owner-circa 1800 way. He wants the filthy creatures (humans) completely annihilated and is schmoozing with the ape senate to get his wish. Leo is just what the nefarious Thad ordered when praying to their almighty Semos for a sign the humans must all go. With Leo's frightening display of intelligence and back bone, the senate will be scared bananaless into giving Thad the Marshal Law decree he so desires.Will Leo and his new tribal friends make it to the space command center before Thad's wicked army finds and crushes them? Is Leo the god they have waited for all these years? Could the last fight scene be tackier?Don't worry, I'm not ruining anything here for you...It's so telegraphed G.W. Bush would know the ending half way through. Okay, maybe right before the credits at least.The story is a tad blasé. You may find yourself adrift about the screen, looking for something to busy your brain when Mark and crew aren't battling the Apes. Which brings up a kind of humorous point of observation, Wahlberg's "Leo" has like three sentences of dialog in a scene, then smacko, he's immediately in primal combat again; like an odd ballet of film you watch and keep a mental metronome swaying in your head?1-2-3 fight, 1-2-3 fight.TPOA is really all about the visual treats; like watching intense thespian Tim Roth bounce about like an extra at Ringling Bros. &amp; Barnum Bailey Circus of the Cruel in his cute little money, er, ape suit. Tim Roth's "Thad" was super creepy. Hate oozes from his furry little pores to the point were you feared he may really have gone rabid. Even with all the schtuffamagal Roth had burying his features, the feeling and depth from the actor beneath came through. Or Helena Bonham Carter, all made up in ten pounds of latex, a far cry from the West End beauty she is, for sure. Still a lady, even as an ape.Then there's MM Wahlberg. His picture is in Compton's Encyclopedia under "example of the Male Homo Sapiens " -In my version anyway? The man's body is, simply, dare I say, perfect. He's a double cream serving of Pistachio Ice cream with a hidden layer of marshmallow fluff. Scrumptious. Leo was a dull character so MM's signature "whisper" delivery worked. I think I need a Boogie Nights fix...TPOA has quite a few exciting moments. Enough to recommend it. Those nostalgic for the original take heart- there's still only one Cornelious (Roddy McDowall) and this is not a replacement, it's just another look at a pretty wild concept , modernized for the new generation to enjoy.An aside: Danny Elfman, Timmie Burtonski's favorite music man, is back incahoots producing the film's score. As always, Elfman delivers a catchy, flowing gently ominous orchestration of notes.Snack recommendation: Banana nut pound cake and Pistachio ice cream.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Planet of the Bad</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This movie was terrible. I went into it with high expectations, only to get a sneaking suspicion that something had gone terribly awry after the opening credits. These are some of the elements which made viewing this excruciating:1) The set: it looked like a cross between the Wizard of Oz's flying monkeys, the Ewok Adventure and Willow. I know we're dealing with Tim Burton here, but I just couldn't take it seriously. And, it always looked like a SET.2) The cast: Mark Wahlberg, whom I normally like, just seemed too flat and not commanding enough of a character to lead any insurrection. Estella Warren, who plays the 2001 equivalent to the original film's Nova, is so bad it's comic. Check out the first scene in which she's introduced side by side with the Kris Kristofferson character. The look on her face is so vacuous, you wonder how she's supposedly survived this long on the run. And speaking of Kris Kristofferson: why is he in this movie at all? His character is completely wasted.3) Danny Elfman's swollen, distracting score: I felt like I was watching Batman all over again.4) The character development: The human characters are not developed at all. We're supposed to buy that there's chemistry between the Mark Wahlberg character and Daena (Estella)? One doesn't even really know the human characters' names by the end of the film. I had to look them up on IMDB. I didn't care about any of the characters, and hoped they were all killed by the time the movie ended.5) The tacked-on, twist ending: Send this ending back for a rewrite! Let's make some sense here, people.In addition to the points listed above, the dialogue was corny. There were also numerous plots holes and distractions. One of the distractions was how Daena got lip gloss and managed to shave her armpits while living such a primitive lifestyle. It's also a wonder that the enslaved and nomadic humans spoke English so well.Helena Bonham-Carter does what she can with the terrible script. The make-up effects were mixed. The look of the female primates was not to be believed. I assume this was done for Burton's lame satiric elements in the film. The make-up effect on Tim Roth's Thade was more believable. Tim Roth's scenes fare better than others, although he goes way over the top at points.Don't waste your time with this movie. Do yourself a favor and rent the original 1968 classic instead.</fullReview>

		<score>0.1</score>
		<shortDescription>A wasted opportunity</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>My expectations prior to this film were high. Being a big fan of the original film I hoped that this new version would come some way near its excellence. In my opinion it came nowhere near. Many key elements of the original were changed, but why? To cater for today's audiences? So as not to be accused of copying the original? If Tim Burton or anyone else could make a decent copy of the original that would be great. Why were all the humans able to speak? The actors who played humans didn't even have anything decent to say so it would have been preferable to have had them mute. Yeah the script was that bad and surely the muteness was an integral part of the original. The film had some 'to be expected' special effects but no substance while the original had very little in the way of special effects and so much more substance. It seems that Tim Burton used the cover of special effects (like so many other film directors these days) to hide a poor script. There are many other aspects of the film which I could comment on but I don't want to give any of the plot away so I'll refrain. I suppose you must expect a remake to be of inferior quality, you only need to look at the vast majority of remakes to know this. This film, unlike its predecessor, will not stand the test of time. Hire out the original and enjoy.</fullReview>

Wahlberg just played it monotone and flat. I thought he accepted the idea of being in a cage being pulled by other humans while being beaten by talking apes - pretty well. All in a day's work as a chimp-studying space man. And (SPOILERS SPOILERS SPOILERS***********this so called twist ending was like out of a SCTV sketch. The gorillas were amazing, probably the best of the bunch, but the way they tried to make the chimps look a tad more human with that strange nostril configuration was just bizarre and hokey. And I congratulate Estella Warren for giving TWO AWFUL DEAD EYED performances in the same year: first the Stallone stinker"Driven" and now "Apes". My god, yes, she's beautiful, the blond hair, the bee-stung lips, the model's body, but talk about the lights are off and no one is home!!!! NOTHING behind her eyes. Ever. At any point in the movie. She walks badly, she rides a horse badly and the way we're supposed to FEEL anything when her and the female chimp are eyeing each other with jealousy over Wahlberg was ridiculous.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>The biggest diappointment of the millenium.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>It all sounded so good, a "reimagining" of Planet of the Apes. Richard Zanuck returned to helm production and Tim Burton was brought on board to direct. We were so optimistic. The original was a landmark film, could they do it justice? The sequels were so juvenile and simplistic surely they had learned, alas it was not to be. This movie is a train wreck. Poorly concieved, poorly written, poorly acted, preposterous in logic and impossible to follow it defies our hopes and dreams. Even without comparison to the original it fails miserably. But we can't view it without remembering. The fundamental mistake I think is that this is more than just a story about Apes. Its about one mans odyssey, his journey through time and space searching for .... well shall we say the perfect world, only to arrive in a nightmare. The remake conveys none of that. Its a chase movie aimed at the 12 to 18 yearolds who dominate the market. All the critics gush about the wonderfull makeup and effects, really? They are all in denial. They assume that because of the technical advances in the last 30 years it must be better. Well its not. The gorillas are pretty good, but we are forced to watch closeups of Helen Bonham Carter who looks ... well looks like she has a mask on. The sets look like ...sets and the Ape village in the original is 10 times more realistic than the graphic in this version. The ending? it defies any and all explanations. I remember after watching the 68 version staggering out of the dark theater with the rest of my stunned human companions, well I staggered out of the theatre again......in disbelief.</fullReview>

		<date>2001-07-28</date>
		<username>Mike Holmes</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A perfect translation</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I have no idea how people could bash a movie like this. Movies like these (ESPECIALLY Sci-Fi movies) are very rare, and i must admit, when I was walking into the theatre, I thought this was going to be an awful movie ripping off the previous "Planet of the Apes". I was so wrong.The movie starts off with Leo Davidson (Mark Wahlberg) in a USAF Starbase that experiences a strange nebula. The captain sends out one of Leo's monkeys to explore the nebula, but they lose contact with the monkey. Leo jumps in another spaceship and goes looking for the monkey (Which was very strange in the beginning, but they had to get him on the planet somehow, I guess). When he gets trapped in the nebula, he goes forward in time and lands on an alien planet (Unlike the previous movie, where Leo lands on a futuristic earth). He encounters a group of humans who are running from the apes. Leo is very confused, which becomes a major point for the beginning of the movie.The film is a direct remake from the original, but is much darker, thanks to the wonderful directing of Tim Burton. He captured the atmosphere from the previous film perfectly, but he also added a bit of an extra touch by making the apes seem much more menacing. The performances aren't Oscar-worthy, but they aren't bad (Including Mark Wahlberg, who I think was always a good actor since his starring role in the movie "Boogie Nights), and the make-up by Rick Baker is sure to get him an Academy Award. The music by Danny Elfman is amazing (Including the opening theme, which in my opinion is probably one of my top 5 themes) and it perfectly captures the atmosphere in the movie. But probably the most controversial point in the movie is the ending. It was either you understood it, or you didn't. Luckily, I was one of the people that understood it, and it almost made the movie for me. But without spoiling any of the ending, let me just say this: It's very sequel-friendly (Which in my case is a good thing)Review: ****1/2 / *****</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Chimply Awful!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Having just returned home from viewing this film, I remain stunned. This movie was so predictable and lifeless, I don't know where to begin. The so-called "plot", was rife with absolutely fantastic leaps of logic (ie. an accidental one-button location of a space/time warp - puhleeeeze!). Such a pity.The film offered no surprises, other than the guffaws of disbelief from many in the crowded theater. I'm still trying to understand why somebody felt the original movie, deserving of much praise, had to be remade.The primate characters looked like actors wearing rubber masks. Nearly every set looked like... well, a set. Several characters (ie. young warboy), invisible during the development of the story, somehow become important near the end of the film. But without character background, I felt nothing for them. The requisite buxom blonde was easy to look at, but left me wondering why she was even there. 		<date>2005-11-14</date>
		<username>jasonbourneagain</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>This Movie Stunk</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Perhaps I had too high of expectations for this movie. Tim Burton has made some great films -- Beetlejuice, Batman, Edward Scissorhands, Nightmare Before Christmas, Ed Wood and Sleepy Hollow. He also made some turkeys in Batman Returns and Mars Attacks! Put Planet of the Apes down as another turkey, one of his worst.This movie is billed as of the Sci-Fi Action genre, but there is little science in it. We are supposed to believe that a chimp and later Captain Leo Davidson (Mark Wahlberg) flies through a cosmic storm and is instantaneously transported through time into the future. Not only that, the ship that tries to save the insubordinate Davidson ends up crash landing on the same planet but in the present time. They were carrying a cage full of chimpanzees and one of them starts a colony on the planet. Some of the humans who survived start a human species, but yet on this future parallel world, for some unexplainable reason the chimpanzees evolve faster and become masters over the humans. The air and water is equal to that of our own Earth but mysteriously the planet was uninhabited before.Given the chance, Burton can make some great character driven and imaginative movies such as Batman, Edward Scissorhands and Ed Wood. In Apes, he doesn't have a chance with the poorly written script and weak direction. The movie instead focuses more on the action and we don't see a buildup of Wahlberg's character except towards the end. Other characters are introduced, but there are few connections with the audience. Helen Bonham Carter's performance as Ari is worthy, but we don't know exactly why she feels a connection to humans enough to risk losing her life. Kris Kristofferson is there to be killed off. Tim Roth does a creditable job as the angry and malevolent General Thade, one of the descendants of first chimpanzees on the planet. Both Michael Clarke Duncan and Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa are good as Attar, General Thade's friend and trusted warrior Krull who is Attar's foil and Ari's guard.The cinematography, set designs, and technical aspects of the movie are fabulous. Rick Baker and Colleen Atwood does superb and remarkable work as the make up and costumes. Danny Elfman, who won an award for the Batman score, does a fantastic job again with Apes. This was a big budget picture and money was well spent in these areas.The ending made no sense whatsoever. If you get that far, suffice it to say the final scene looked as if it was added just so there would be some storyline in order to make a sequel. I truly hope the producers of this stinker lost so much money, they won't dare try again.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2004-02-19</date>
		<username>nelly3</username>
		<score>0.1</score>
		<shortDescription>Grimly disappointing</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>When Charlton Heston fell to the first planet of the apes, it offered something profound. It neatly and cleverly captured much of the social climate of the late 60s. Though not without its antecedents, it certainly has to stand as one of the more important social commentary films posing as sci-fi. Burton's remake, however, doesn't even seem to have a coherent story line. I first saw the Burton film upon its release and found it sorely lacking then. But I worried that my reaction might be too colored by my affection for the original. Remakes are frequently hated by fans of the original, and I didn't want to spout off with an unexamined emotional outburst. But I just sat through it again (this time on TV) and my loathing hasn't diminished. Wahlberg's performance still strikes me as wooden and lacking in purpose. From the very moment of his arrival to the ape world, his only objective is to escape from the planet. So why did he travel out to the planet in the first place? Heston's character of more than 30 years past at least went to explore (to see if there was anything better than man out there). Baker's ape makeup in the remake was good, but effects alone can't make a movie. The humans were no doubt the worst characters in the remake. Like Wahlberg they lacked any depth, and their passivity to ape domination produced more annoyance instead of sympathy. In the original the humans were primitive mutes whose mannerisms were bestial. They brought on pity one might feel for a hunted animal, which they were supposed to be. Another strikingly annoying element in the Burton film was the strange love triangle formed by Helena Bonham Carter as a chimp (albeit a very cute chimp), the collagen-lipped Estella Warren as a primitive human, and Wahlberg. I have no idea what Burton was going for there. While Burton's early films didn't wow me, they nonetheless didn't annoy me. My first impression was simply that he could churn out glitzy Hollywood pablum. Then he made Ed Wood and I suddenly wondered if I had overlooked a film genius. But the profound lack of substance in Apes convinces me that I was right the first time. (And Big Fish hasn't caused me to alter that view).</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2003-09-17</date>
		<username>JohnIL</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>So AWFUL it surpasses any of the original film's sequels in it's stupidity</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>It's hard to imagine that someone could make a worse ape film then any of the 4 ape sequels that followed the 1968 version, but Tim Burton had somehow managed it. The apes look good, they move around good, but the plot is sooo bad, and the ending....we won't even discuss. It's hard to imagine that this ever even got off the drawing board and made into a film. When you think of what they could have done with this..it's an incredible waste. One of the worst films of 2001.</fullReview>

		<date>2001-12-29</date>

		<fullReview>I've just bought it on DVD and yeah, it is REALLY good and the apes look very real! It's about an ape being sent into some big magnetic storm in outer space. It's being sent to see what that storm is, but it doesn't come back so our hero takes a little spacecraft and heads in the same direction as the ape. When he hits the storm, his spacecraft goes nuts/out of control and suddenly a planet appears. Too late, he regains control, just to crash down into a lake in a rainforest. After he has rescued himself out of the craft, the movie first really begins! He has crashlanded into a world where apes are like humans and humans are like apes, locked up in cages. He get caught, but after a short time, he finds out that there is this one ape that's not like the other apes...I've heard people asking me if this really just ain't either a follow-up or a remaking of the original planet of the apes - the answer is definately no! 		<username>dkar3</username>
		<score>0.1</score>
		<shortDescription>A horrible, absolutely horrible movie</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This movie couldn't be any more bad. Clearly, the creators of this fill were more worried about how to grunt, look, and walk like an ape, than in conveying a story. The dialog is, for the most part, grunts on the part of the apes, and practically non-existent on the part of the humans, with the exception of the lead (male) character. The lead female character has perhaps no more than 3 or 4 lines during the entire movie.As for the story, its ridiculous and unbelievable. Yes, yes, I know -- we're talking about a sci-fi movie where apes rule the world -- how realistic can it be? My answer is this: when we see a movie, we allow the writers/directories to withdraw a certain amount of fantasy from our fantasy bank account. Subsequent withdraws are at the cost of the movies believability. Continual withdraws, as this movie does, have us thinking the writers are idiots and the movie ridiculous. In the case of Plant of the Apes, this couldn't be any more the case.Rating: 1 out of 10.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Great New Visualisation of the "Planet of the Apes" Idea</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>As a fan of the original Planet of the Apes movies, I really enjoyed this new motion picture.Normally, remakes suffer from the fact that they are just copies of the original movie, mostly without the excitement or fun of it.Planet of the Apes is a new attempt to use the idea behind Planet of the Apes. Thus, it is worth to be seen even by die-hard fans of the original movies.Mark Wahlberg can never match the quality of Charlton Heston, and was probably not a good choice, but the Apes are even more realistic and differentiated than in the old movies, as far as their characters are concerned. The girl which was Nova in the 1968 movie is also much more intelligent and has more to offer than just to look good.All the cruelty of manhood is being shown to as like in a fable on the example of the monkeys - sorry, apes! This content alone makes it really hard to create a bad movie upon it.Planet of the Apes (2001) is really worth the money, it has impressive shots to offer, a smooth storyline, interesting characters and an idea which should make us think about ourselves and our history.Only the end is really poor and doesn't fit the rest of the movie. It looks as if this was only added to ensure future sequels. It is very primitive and doesn't match the quality of the actual movie.</fullReview>

		<date>2001-08-04</date>
		<username>orbytal</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Only an adequate outing by Burton...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I found this particular effort by Burton to be not quite up to par with Batman, etc. But, hey, Burton is allowed to falter somewhat occasionally. These comments, however, are not directed at the movie, but at the posters who complain about illogical and inconsistent events in the movie. Some of these are valid such as the engine of the USAF ship being operational years after it crashed. Sure nuclear powered engines can last for hundreds of thousands of years, however, everything else around it would have decayed (circuitry, wires, etc). It's a minor problem, however. The other "problems" can be explained I believe though. SPOILERS AKERT(1) I'll begin with the "origin of the apes" point first. Clearly, the apes (chimps, orangs, gibbons, gorillas) on the planet Leo crashed landed on were not descended from Leo's chimp. They were descended from the apes which were on the USAF ship. After the crash of the USAF ship, the apes (being genetically engineered to be smarter than normal) ran amok and took over. (2) The second point is about the time gap between the sending of the mayday message by Leo in the future and its reception in the past by his crew. Now for those of you who were not paying attention, there is a point in the movie where the USAF ship receives a message emanating from the time warp. It was sent by the captain of the ship, only he appears much, much older. Clearly, it was sent from the future. It's a time warp folks!!!!(3) The third and final point has to do with the conclusion. I have to admit, it was a bit contrived, but like the previous 2 points, I think I can come up with an explanation. The only one I can come up with is that Thade somehow regained control on the ape planet and used perhaps Leo's crashed pod or salvaged pods from the USAF ship, went through the time warp back into Earth's past and conquered the Earthlings. Yeah, I know -- it's a stretch. I can't wait for its elucidation in the sequel, and you know that was a classic sequel setup.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>Tim Burton could've done better, but instead he chose to do this, a remake of a movie that didn't need to be remade (could the reason for the remake possibly be for, oh dare I say, MONEY? Maybe Fox didn't have enough yet?). And while I guess if by some dumb luck Burton is the right choice for a re-telling, but that's not the point. He has made many fine re-makes (Batman the topper, also Mars Attacks, and Sleepy Hollow) but this isn't one of them. This is in the overall view over-flashy, conventional (much, much more than the first if that one had any convention in the first place) and confusing. I mean, at least the ending in the first one was exciting and questioning. This one just almost says the point of this film was Back to the Future (or past) with primates. Dumb logic. Also the characters have less charm, humor and coolness that came with the first one; Wahlberg has nearly no emotions in scenes that parallel the ones in the first, and I can see why Heston is now Sir Heston.Only things to possibly watch for- a hilarious cameo from Sir Charleton Heston himself (I'd just as well sneak in the film for that one scene again), makeup that nearly matches the first one, although the first one was a breakthrough, and some OK visual effects. Some Die-hard Burton fans will find some use here (once in a while it gave a thrill or two), but other than that, keep your damn paws off of this damn, dirty film! Between C- and D+</fullReview>

		<date>2008-02-25</date>
		<username>Michael_Elliott</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Stick with the Original</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Planet of the Apes (2001) ** (out of 4) Lackluster remake of the 1968 film has an astronaut (Mark Wahlberg) crash landing on a planet where apes are kings and humans are slaves. Even though I had heard nothing but negative things about this film I went in with an open mind because most of the bad reviews I heard were from die-hard fans of the original but the film turned out to be a major dud. The most shocking thing is that Burton didn't bring any energy or excitement to the film. The first hour drags by so bad that I was having a hard time staying awake. The film picks up during it's final act but even then the battle scenes aren't as good as they should have been. I did like the ending though. Wahlberg sleepwalks through his role but I enjoyed the supporting cast. I thought Tim Roth and Helena Bonham Carter were very good in their roles and I also enjoyed Michael Clarke Duncan. Kris Kristofferson and Charlton Heston also come off good in their small roles. The screenplay is rather weak and the reworked lines from the original film come off very lame. Burton tries a lot of things in the film but I think he's held back by the PG-13 rating. I think the director should have delivered an R-rated movie and went all out on the various messages that are hinted out throughout the film and made the battle scenes real battle scenes.</fullReview>

		<username>mackman83</username>
		<score>0.1</score>
		<shortDescription>One of the WORST I have ever had the Discomfort of Seeing</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I love Tim Burton movies. I have been a ravenous fan of his since the first of the Batman movies (as we know them today) came out in 1989 (there is another movie made in the 60s based of the classic TV show, starring the one true Batman, Adam West). Furthermore, I loved the original Planet of the Apes. It was one of the most well known, recognizable, and thought provoking movies of all time, with one of the greatest twists in cinematic history. Not only that, but if you look at the series of `Apes' movies, as a whole, you will most likely find that they are one of the greatest, most well fitting together with respect to continuity (if that is even possible to say) franchises ever. So with that being said, could this movie possibly go wrong?Oh it did. It went WAY wrong. This movie is righteous garbage. The twist at the end (not a spoiler) makes absolutely no logical sense, independently. But if it sets up a plot that will be explained in the sequel, then I don't want to know, and have no desire to see it. But what is my major grievance with this movie:Marky Mark. In this movie, he single handedly gives a horrible performance, AS ALWAYS, and disgraces the name of models gone actors, which if you think about it is pretty bad considering they have a bad reputation to begin with. One of the more subtle problems that I have with him, besides his pitiful excuse for acting, is that throughout this and seemingly all of his other movies he has the same facial expression, which is something of a mix between constipation and just got done running a marathon. Even moreso is the fact that throughout the whole movie, he never seems to be surprised at the fact that not only is he in a world completely different than his, nor the fact that it is primarily populated by gigantic, walking, talking apes, nor does he ever seem to ponder, even ask, or want to find out, `hey, what in the righteous heck is going on here?'Here is my breakdown of the other key players in the movie:Helena Bonham Carter ? brilliant actress ? waste of her talent.Charlton Heston ? cultural icon ? waste of his talent.Tim Burton ? one of the greatest and most imaginative, and visually impressive moviemakers of all time ? completely shot himself in the foot for making this garbage.Anyone else remotely involved in the making of this movie - waste of their collective talent.The only redeeming factors of this movie is that Danny Elfman once again provides a good score to the movie and the shot where they look back upon the city (it's the only shot in the movie that is signature Tim Burton). Now I have seen some BAD movies in my day, and not only does this one take the taco, but to categorize it as only a bad movie would be an insult. This is beyond a bad movie. This is a complete waste of your life if you watch it. Please, please, please if you want to see Planet of the Apes, look past the fancy special effects, good makeup and prosthetics job, and the fact that it is a newer movie, and go watch the lower budget, older original. Save yourself the agony.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Tim Burton should be ashamed of himself</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I LOVE Tim Burton. He's original, he's smart, and his movies are usually visually inventive. I guess you can't win 'em all.The story in this waste of time is close to non-existant and doesn't give the talented cast any chance at all of projecting any kind of character. There is one mildly entertaining action sequence, and there is the odd in-joke that works (most notably Charleton Heston's cameo), but that's about it as a MOVIE.As a technical exercise, this film displays little of Burton's usual brilliance, but Rick Baker's makeup definitely deserves special mention. The ape characters are incredible, and show remarkably subtle facial expressions. Had the characters themselves be better written, there's some chance this wouldn't have been a total waste.3/10 for outstanding makeup and a few cool in-jokes.</fullReview>

		<username>dannimac</username>
		<score>0.1</score>
		<shortDescription>The most visually stunning god awful piece of tripe you will ever encounter</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Directed by Tim Burton, this has all the things that you would normally associate with him - fabulous costumes, gothic scenery etc etc. These are visually stunning and serve as an excellent background to the movie. What's missing is a good storyline, good dialogue or (apart from a few notable exceptions which I will come to later) decent actors. It takes the plot of the original film and "updates" it (although why it needed updating, I don't know).Why do I think it is so awful - let's start with the dialogue. From the moment Mark Wahlberg utters the line "I'm going to get my monkey" the script is laughable.Now on to the storyline - well as I said, did it need updating? Take the original, add in some human talking (although it was mostly Wahlberg) and a truly cringe making ending and you have the disaster that was this movie.The acting - I've watched a couple of Wahlberg movies now and I really don't rate him. He seems to think a perma frown relays a pensive side and that if he stomps, he will appear powerful. As a main player, he doesn't convince. Tim Roth - love him but overdone. Helena - don't get me started - ape sensitivity, I don't think so! Michael Clarke Duncan - hang your head in shame. And Estella Warren - god love her, she didn't have a chance. She gets so few lines and is blatantly there as eye candy alone.The human characters who deliver the lines don't even have the decency to look embarrassed. The one exception is Kris Kristofferson who I can pass off without comment, mainly because he wisely keeps his mouth shut for most of the time. The ape actors are well hidden and we won't know if they were embarrassed or not - and they should be. I really respect Tim Roth as an actor but this was ape ham that I was watching - overdone evil, a flat performance. The only decent ape performances that I saw were by Paul Giamatti as the slave trader and the brilliant minute or so that Charlton Heston was on the screen.If you choose to watch this movie, remember you will never get the time it took to watch it back.</fullReview>

		<date>2003-03-01</date>
		<username>Jack the Ripper1888</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Tim Burton's vision is a marvel: exciting, thrilling and explosive.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Wow, how good can a film be? Well, when Tim Burton (the genius behind the secrets of the masterpiece THE NIGHTMARE BEFORE CHRISTMAS) signs on to do a project like PLANET OF THE APES, you just know it's going to be good. The actors are very well cast and everyone fit into their parts perfectally. But, for some very odd reason, most people found this wonderful version to PLANET OF THE APES to be a disappointment. I can't see why, because I enjoyed the film to no end. In my opinion, it couldn't have been made better. This really doesn't seem to me like a project that Tim Burton would sign on to direct, but hey, he did it. And did it well.Mark Wahlberg is tremendous here, and so are remaining cast members: Tim Roth, Michael Clarke Duncan, Helena Bonham Carter, David Warner, Kris Krisstoferson, Chris Ellis and lots more. If you haven't figured it out already, I was entranced by this film.The usual action-adventure will place you in an environment with a highly intelligent creature that will then procede to roam around and kill you off one by one. But, here, Mr. Tim Burton has given us something better. He throws our typical cast of "survivors" into an environment where they are being hunted by a species just about as intelligent as they are. It actually almost resembles the apartheid of the 1930s in a way, only it is in reverse. Instead of the whites in control of the blacks, it is the apes (black people) in control of the whites (but in this case, it would be all humans).The story is well-told and is actually more of another sequel than it is a remake, but either way, Tim Burton's visual gem will be a fun to stun people for generations to come.PLANET OF THE APES: 5/5.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2002-02-18</date>
		<username>k4_pacific</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A bad remake of a good movie</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Well, here we have Tim Burton's latest opus. No, not a short fat penguin, but I'm sure he has a unsettlingly dark and creepy film adaptation of Bloom County up his sleeve somewhere. After all, you saw what he did to poor Batman, once a proud superhero who often found himself in goofy contrived plots fighting pastel colored villains, he now is a dark, scary, menacing type inhabiting the now perpetually nocturnal Gotham City.On the other hand, Tim Burton actually isn't that bad of a director when he's working with original material. I rather liked Ed Wood and I thought that Edward Scissorhands had some good moments. But when it comes to doing remakes of older movies, or film adaptations of television shows, he just plain sucks. Case in point, Planet of the Apes. What once was a fascinating film with a biting, socially relevant anti-war message has become a "Taco-Bell commemorative cup free with purchase of a large soda" kind of movie. Imagine if this kind of thing catches on, someday we may see a remake of Dr. Strangelove with Gary Oldman playing the base commander, Bill Pullman as the president, Tom Arnold as the Joint Chief of Staff, and Will Smith riding the bomb to his death in blazing color, followed by a hip-hop remix of "We'll Meet Again" playing over the closing credits.Anyhow, getting back to the movie. There is one particular scene in this movie I find particularly troubling. Toward the beginning, when the whistle/spaceship thing the hero was flying crashed on the planet, it came in at an acute angle through the trees and crashed in a swampy, wooded area. The ship then subsequently sank. This is a BLATENT rip off of Star Wars. When I saw this scene, I forgot what movie I was watching and was temporarily disoriented when I didn't see Yoda shortly afterward. Now, I know that ideas are sometimes borrowed from other movies, and that's okay. But I would appreciate it if they could at least TRY to change it around a little, or give it a new twist. But no, they didn't. They could have saved some money if they had just reused the scene from Star Wars (which probably cost one-tenth as much to film).Well, it happened, they remade Planet of the Apes, leaving a nasty stain on the rich tapestry of western culture.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>This film is so bad and pointless that I still can't understand how Tim Burton could have had anything to do with it. 		<fullReview>Three good things about this movie: the poster, the score and Tim Roth's Thade. Everything else had me embarrassed for all involved. My number one pet peeve in a movie is when a character does something that makes no sense, but gets the writer out of a jam. This movie is filled with that kind of action.The mixed metaphors of animal rights and civil rights, where humans fill each role as the script demands, are full of cliches, ultimately making this B-O-R-I-N-G. And while I like much of Tim Burton's sense of humor, the over-the-top jokieness here was the saddest, right down to a female ape complaining of a 'bad hair day'--Yuk yuk yuk.Icing on the cake was the 'twist' ending, which would have been cool HAD IT HAD ANYTHING TO DO WITH THE STORY BEFORE IT. Yeesh. Bad.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2001-08-04</date>
		<username>mikhail080</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>"Apes" gone Hollywood</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I remember the original quite well, it having made a great impact on me as a 10 year-old boy. I remember awaiting each sequel as it arrived in theaters in the 70s. Tim Burton's film comes as totally different take on POTA, and this time with mind-blowing makeup and outrageous action sequences.Movie-goers who cannot appreciate the joys of "Planet of the Apes" have become too mired down in investigating plot-points and errors in logic -- all of which could be explained away by any talented sci-fi writer. Tim Burton (surely one of today's greatest film makers) isn't concerned with exposition and plot contrivances -- only in entertaining his audience like a great showman would. And that he does in a big way with this epic-scale adventure, which hardly resembles the original 1968 movie in character or theme, so pre-conceptions best be left at the door.Burton's "Planet of the Apes" supplies more black comedy than the first, often jumping over-the-top in its ability to constantly amaze and amuse the viewer. The scene of a "mixed" ape dinner party has to have the most outrageous and amazing makeup effects ever created. Tim Roth as bad-to-the-bone chimpanzee General Thade is terrifying, evil and ugly and probably gives the best performance among excellent company. Mark Wahlberg makes for a perfect leading man, understated in manners and voice as a contrast to the bizarre and outlandish apes. And Paul Giamatti as Limbo (a stand-in for old orange Dr Zais?) gives one of the best comic performances ever seen.This is "popcorn" style cinema, and it really bends over backwards to amaze and amuse the viewer. Credit must be given to Burton and his art department for the campy sets, costumes and obviously the convincing makeup jobs which trumped any similar ones ever on film. Rick Baker (the great makeup up artist) has taken his art to a higher plane in this monumental effort, and really should be acknowledged for giving audiences such thrilling creatures to view. They're like no others ever seen on the screen, and to watch the expressive faces of these apes is a remarkable experience in viewing. The faces appear so life-like that you begin to believe you're watching actual apes.Kids should love this outing, with the violence all being decidedly PG and usually occurring off-screen. Parents can also sit back and enjoy the trip to this wild planet since its loaded with symbolism and cultural references all cleverly packaged in Hollywood's best style.</fullReview>
	</review>

Tim Burton could have sexed up this simian saga &amp; given the adults in the audience something to look at. Even the chaste Helena Bonham Carter never gets out of her costume which looks like a large curtain. She's cute but all the the love stuff is restricted to anxious looks &amp; a little bitty kiss at the end. As in Artificial Intelligence which discusses inter species sex between robots &amp; humans but never delivers - Planet of the Apes hints at inter species romance between the humans &amp; the apes but only hints. Lisa Marie is the only ape that dares to be sexy. This movie has three great actors Tim Roth, Ms. Carter &amp; Paul Giamatti chewing up the scenery as a trio of apes &amp; they are fun to watch. Superlative make up (a certain Oscar) costumes, sets, music make this the hit summer movie of 2001.</fullReview>

		<username>El Guapo-2</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Rubbish with an awful ending</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Burton has always been one of those directors whose films tend to fall apart in the third act... the exception being "Ed Wood" and "Sleepy Hollow", although "Sleepy Hollow" just about gets by on the "Scooby-doo" style of ending. If my memory serves me, I think Dick Zanuck, who at one time was running mighty 20th century fox, was sitting around and thought to himself, why don't we remake planet of the apes and get an A-list director for it? It's not a bad idea... problem is, the script isn't up to par. In fact, it's pretty bad. Secondly, Mark Walberg is way out of his league trying to carry the lead in this film. I remember reading all the publicity for the film and laughed when Burton and Zanuck tried to compare Walberg to Steve McQueen. Look, I like Walberg, I think he's a decent enough actor, but he's not at the point where he has the emotional gravitas to carry the lead in a film. The story has no emotional pathos. It's just a simple A to B to C, nonstop chase film. And what was the point of trying to keep the ending secret? It doesn't even make sense. They were trying to bring back that feeling of the "oh my god, they were on earth the whole time" feeling from the original POTA, but here it's just absolute rubbish.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Nice Saturday afternoon movie</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>At first, I thought this was a parody movie- Mark Wahlberg, Helena Bonham Carter, Paul Giamatti and Michael Clarke Duncan- I was wrong. Paul Giamatti's character felt like comic relief to me, slightly out of place, but not unwelcome. It was well made, the acting was good and it kept me interested throughout the movie, but no spectacular 'whoa!' moments. I consider this a fine movie and I would watch it again but I wouldn't purposefully go out of my way to find it. All-in-all, a nice movie for a Saturday afternoon.</fullReview>

		<date>2014-11-16</date>
		<username>Phil Hubbs</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Planet of the Apes</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Now I will admit I love Tim Burton and most of his work but I too was shocked and fearful of his agreement to take the helm of this sci-fi action flick revamp/re-imagining. Many directors were considered and to be honest I think many of them would have been perfect for the film but Burton does add his usual unique artistic style which can be glimpsed throughout the film in armour design, landscapes sets etc..So straight to the point I actually liked this Burton version of 'Apes' mainly because its a fun romp which is both silly entertaining cheese and has that classic semi serious sci-fi element to it. First up the visuals in the film are tremendously good and really make the film stand out, total kudos to Rick Baker and his team, the man totally nails the ape look for all the characters to a tee. The best clearly being Roth as Thade with a fantastic makeup job, next up must be Duncan in his gorilla makeup but how about Shadix and Giamatti in their orangutan (I think) makeup...amazing!The film wins with the look for sure, not only is the makeup excellent but the sets are nicely worked, location is well suited, the apes costumes and battle gear is well designed and the space sequences also look and work well. All in all its pretty much like a top class Star Trek film...I mean a good Star Trek film by the way.Casting choices were good accept for Wahlberg who wasn't quite right for me. Thankfully we had no Depp to endure here but the use of many solid character actors such as Warner and the imaginative use Tagawa really help lift the film, who could imagine Tagawa as a gorilla.I really enjoyed the film on my second viewing, my first was on release at the cinema, and I believe its because the 'Apes' classic plot can be made many ways and is open to interpretation from different angles, its not a case of it only works one way like a lot of classic films, 'Apes' is a franchise that you can seem to mould and recreate without upsetting the originals. This Burton vision is simple yet highly enjoyable as a fun sci-fi romp, not too heavy, not just copying the original, touch of artistic license and the attempt at a twist ending which was brave but rather illogical, trying to equal the original but failing there I'm afraid. Still the little use of CGI for much of the film is always nice in my book.7/10</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>Tim Burton re-imagines Planet of the Apes. To put it simply, I enjoyed watching it. The original Apes films are masterpieces of cinema to be sure.
