		<shortDescription>Beats the original!!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Either the NRA has taken over this page, or I saw a different film as most of the other IMDb users. If this film proves anything, it's that Tim Burton is one of the greatest creative minds in cinematic history. When I saw the trailer I feared this one wouldn't be as dark as his previous efforts, but there are still plenty Burtonesque images for the fans to be happy.I saw the original Charlton Heston film and although I appreciated the camp qualities and the shock ending, it was basically nothing more then a long episode of the muppet show. This version has so much more style and the apes are truly impressive, you forget they're just humans, unlike in the original. Rick Baker deserves an oscar for his work. I also think Mark Whalberg makes a much more realistic hero then Heston. While Charlton was happy enough to fight 'them darn monkeys', the only thing Whalberg cares about is to get the hell out of there, with or without the other humans. About the 'twist'ending (don't worry I'm not gonna spoil it), well I didn't see it coming, as did nobody else in the audience.So don't let all the negative reviews scare you, this movie is really worth seeing!!</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2001-09-02</date>
		<username>mentalcritic</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Tim Burton does it again...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>...that is, take an old "classic" and make it more faithful to the source material. From the same man, we've had a Batman who acts more like a real millionaire whose parents were murdered in front of him as a boy would, and a Sleepy Hollow that reads more like a Shakespeare play, highlighting as Washington Irving's original story does how badly this overrated poet's dialogues fail to reflect real human speech. In this new version of Planet Of The Apes, we get to see an air force pilot who behaves like an air force pilot, an ape civilisation that behaves like an ape civilisation, and a metaphor for the civil rights struggle that reads more like the X-Men feature film than the restrained, "don't want to upset the powers that be" style of the television series.I've read on this site that the film is simply rehashed in order to suit those with short attention spans. Not true. All through the film, one thinks of how a simple collection of apes from a research station could have evolved into almost-bipedial, talking ones with more distinctive personalities. The next few sentences may spoil any surprises, so those of you who have not seen the film yet can scroll past them at your leisure. One aspect of the film I found a bit disappointing is the fact that the original talking ape who is referred to as CMOS by his descendants is never fully explained. His origins and the reason he is called that are never really talked about, and I originally thought he would be the monkey that Wahlberg's character shot off into space in order to rescue. I must admit, however, that ending the battle between the humans and the apes by having said monkey land right in the middle of them was a fine touch. The metaphor for religion by showing that CMOS, this figure the apes worship for being the original free ape, got to start his own civilisation by murdering the humans who were originally caring for him, was an ingenious stroke. My only real complaint relates to the ending. I won't spoil it for those who haven't seen it yet, unlike some internet sites, but were I in this pilot's position, I honestly would have stayed. It's not every day that one gets a chance to help build a new civilisation with two very different races are just learning to work with each other. Compared to the planet Earth as it is today, and it shows no signs of ever getting better, it is a real paradise.Given all the displays in the film of appalling behaviour towards humans and each other by the apes, and how they resolve themselves, I think Tim Burton's reinterpretation manages to drive home a point that I seriously doubt the original films and television series would have been allowed to. The fact that not all racism is white-on-black seems a taboo subject in 2001, but one that this film handles metaphorically in an intelligent way. Give it a try without the prejudice of original Apes series fans to blinker you, and it may just surprise you. Encourage yourself to think of a better ending, though. Encourage yourself to think of all the different ways the apes could have evolved, in fact. This is not Planet Of The Apes Lite... it is Planet Of The Apes non-Disney style, something we need applied to more old "family-oriented" piles of cobblers.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2001-09-02</date>
		<username>egd-1</username>
		<score>0.1</score>
		<shortDescription>What a waste of time and money. Give this one a miss.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>***This review contains spoilers.*** You have been warned.I gave this film a 2 out of 10 which means it wasn't *entirely* bad: some of the make-up was reasonable and the music didn't make me ill. That's it for the film's redeeming features.As for the awful bits, where do I start? Let's see:(1) An ultra-politically correct message hangs round this film like a 52,000 ton battleship. We're supposed to bring away the message 'Let's all live together in a nice, warm, and fuzzy multicultural society in which each individual has his own special little contribution to make, etc, etc'. If I wanted to hear such a message, I would read the PC rubbish the UK government puts out. If the apes and humans have to all 'sing from the same hymn sheet', who will determine what the music and words of that hymn are? Who dictates what is in and what is out in this 'multicultural blending'? Living in so-called harmony is *NOT* some 'intuitive, natural' thing -- someone is going to lead, lots of someones are going to follow and that is just the way things are -- and any film that ignores this is just pushing another insipid 'feel-good' fairy story.(2) I object to the insults to men. Both the woman scientist who is in charge of the genetically-modified apes on the ship and Ari (Helena Bonham Carter), the woman-ape 'human rights' activist, make comments about men either being insensitive or making women miserable. It's a sure bet that no such comments would have been allowed if they were to have been made about women. When is Hollywood going to give up its love affair with feminism? When is it going to see that films that contain such insulting material drive men and women -- and I am a woman -- away?(3) The plot, such as it was is a mish-mash. This film could have gone the straight-forward science fiction route, or gone down the path of satire, but instead, it is neither one nor the other. All that happens is that the pilot, Captain Davidson (Mark Wahlberg), goes from one pointless bit of so-called action to another. The plot is also riddled with illogic. Certainly I don't expect films to be completely logical or even mostly so, but I do expect them to have at least a passing acquaintance with logic. How in the blue blazes did horses get on the planet? If the apes are so non-technological, how did they get the armour they wear and how do they manage to build houses and other things? How did the apes even manage to dominate the planet if they are terrified of water?(4) The ending is idiotic. Yes, I know there are x number of possible explanations for Davidson going back in time to Earth to find an 'Ape' Lincoln statue and a world populated by apes, but so what? Certainly I don't want a film to tell me everything -- I want to read between the lines -- but I want some lines, just a few, between which to read. It is clear this 'surprise' ending was just tacked on for the shock effect. It didn't even shock me, though, it just bored me.(5) The acting was boring, boring, boring. Does anyone ever bother to portray a character these days, instead of a few traits labelled 'hero' and 'villain'? The human characters, including Davidson, haven't even the depth and presence of onion skin paper. The apes are just plain silly, and that includes General Thade (Tim Roth). So what if the make-up makes the men look like apes of some sort? It takes acting to make a man into an ape, and acting was clearly beyond anyone in this film.(6) The atmosphere was as bland as low-quality white bread (the type sold so that the masses can always afford something that at least looks bread-like). Part of this is down to the sets, which were surprisingly uninteresting and even minimalist for such a big budget film. Funny thing is that in the low-budget European films of the sixties and early seventies, the sets, although clearly crude, managed to convey a wonderful sense of time and place. It is clear that today's sets are just bad money thrown after a lack of imagination.(7) The 'action' sequences were boring. What I wouldn't give to see a film with the flair for violence that the Spaghetti Westerns had. If there's a fight, I want to see some blood, some guts, some death and pain. The fight sequence at the end looked as if the humans and apes were just slugging it out in a Saturday night pub fight, and a nice, mannerly fight at that. Grown chimpanzees are said to be strong enough to rip a human's arm out of its socket. That would have made a good scene. And why in the world did Davidson wait until after the apes started recovering from the effects of the explosion to tell the humans to go out kill them? The whole point of stunning your enemy is so that you can slit his throat while he is helpless. Doesn't anyone know anything about fighting dirty these days?This list isn't comprehensive: I almost certainly have left out other reprehensible bits. I can't be bothered, however, to make a complete list. Let's face it, this film is a waste of time and money.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2001-08-28</date>
		<username>Line Thy</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Tim Burton does it again!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>'Planet of the Apes' is yet another example of Tim Burton´s excellent director skills. When Burton gives us a movie we can be sure not to get another Hollywood show of their big special effects. Instead we get a movie where the superb effects are just minor details that support the story´s substance.Burton´s "remake" of 'Planet of the Apes' is as surprising as the first because the story is different. Yet the themes are the same: racism and equality being the most important. Another theme in the movie is the complexity of time travel that Burton deals with in the same way as e.g. ex-Python Terry Gilliam did in '12 Monkeys'.The apes are outstanding e.g. because of their walk and their interactions in general. Another thing I truly love about this movie is that the music score has been kept in the same stile as the score in the original Planet of the Apes.All in all an exceptional movie that is a must.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>Mark Alan (mark66@clemsontigers.com)</username>
		<score>0.1</score>
		<shortDescription>Not worthy of the original.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>What a bad film! I like to think of myself as a Tim Burton fan. However, I feel that when he gets a big budget, his work suffers. Ed Wood was his lowest budgeted film and was by far his greatest work. "Mars Attacks" and this "Ape" movie both had big budgets and were really horrible. Someone needs to tell Hollywood, that when you revisit a classic story, bring something new to the story. Special effects alone is not enough. I believe that Hollywood thought that by just having more elaborate costumes and apes, they would have a better movie, wrong! The story was just paper thin and the script was one of the worst ever. The first hour of this film was just a bunch of campy jokes. I have never seen more uninspired performances. However, to be fair, the actors had nothing to work with. The story is just patched together. Few characters are developed or have any importance. Man, this was a bad film. However, people will consider it a smash hit, because of the box office totals. However, most of the money taken in by this film was in the first week, so the negative word of mouth had not gotten out yet. This film has dropped like a rock since week one. Let's hope that Burton can return to actually telling a story and a weird story at that. That was one thing this film was missing, there was no "Burton Weirdness" anywhere. Bland and boring. * out of *****.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-08-27</date>
		<username>Psy Dragon (ahti_pictures@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Fun!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I don't know, what the big fuss is all about! I had a fun night out! I mean, what did you expect from Mr. Glorious (Tim Burton for others...)? The lesson I have learned a long time ago is: Expect the Unexpected. So is it this bad just to make a film for people to entertain? And entertained I was. The script could've been better, the make-up less like the Jacksons and so forth. But all they wanted to do is tell a story the old-fashioned way, by just telling it. I mean, we all know the philosophical backgrounds since 1968, no need in going into them too deeply again.The ending, the ending... I thought it was really brave what they did. They new, they couldn't top the original one. Leaving so many things in the dark by simply not telling them might for some be inacceptable. For me, it was a bold fresh breeze in the mainstream-movie-business.To all those bickering about the ending being "illogical":(for those, who want to get into it stone-cold, please stop reading!) Do you really need an explanation for everything? Just accept the fact, that it happend that way. The film doesn't explain how, just THAT it happend. With all the Time-Jumping around, there are loads of ways the ending works perfectly well. Just use your own imagination! For all those who disagree please send a Mail. I would really want to know, what you have to say to the ending of "2001: A Space Odyssey"...</fullReview>
	</review>

I don't want to give away my interpretation of the ending, you people better start thinking for yourselves. All I could say is you can't forget that time travel is very possible in this movie. Both this POTA and BTTF have their main characters find something changed when they get back their times. I like the adrenaline-pumping plot. The dabbling of humor in it also helps. It dips just enough into the animal-human relations(and relations within the same species) to prevent distorting the plot. OK, it's not possible for Thade and Ari to speak with British accents if their ancestors learned English from Americans but who cares about small mistakes like that?</fullReview>

Also Estella Warren plays the part of a "wild" slave girl brilliantly and the guy who plays Thade...well. Nothing short of brilliance in a all round not too good film. 		<username>badguy-1</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>"Apes" is a fun movie, but not as deep as original.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Even though this version did not try to be as thought provoking as the original, I enjoyed it as an action-adventure version of basically the same story. The makeup by Rick Baker is amazing and the CGI effects are used well. You can hardly tell they're there at all. Tim Roth practically steals the show as General Thade. My quibbles: Mark Wahlberg wasn't the best choice for the lead. Burton should've cast someone a little older, with a little more presence. George Clooney perhaps. The humans being able to speak in this version (as oppossed to the mutes in the original) added nothing to the story as they really had nothing interesting to say. All in all, a fun time at the movies. Peace.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>I spent a long time reading review's of new new Planet Of The Apes here at IMDB. I got the general impression that this movie was a waste of time. Yes, Estella Warren spent the entire movie uselessly pouting with those inappropriately glossed lips. Yes, Mark Wahlberg was not nearly as dynamic and emotional as would be expected for someone crash landing on to a strange planet to find himself suddenly faced with ape-rule.However, I still enjoyed the movie very much. Tim Roth as Thade was a powerhouse, Bonham Carter was good and Michael Clarke Duncan as General Attar was perfectly cast. He actually made a very funny quote which I read about in a newspaper. He said "when my agent called me about a part in this movie, I knew I wasn't gonna be no human!"Anyway back to my comment... this is an entertaining movie, yes it is. Purists, please stop this quest for perfection, it doesn't exist, not anymore anyway. Entertainment is what matters. Planet of the Apes with Charlton Heston is brilliant, and emotionally stirring, but it is history. Appreciate it, but move on. Please.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>awful</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>If you want to see another example of Hollywood dumbing down cinema, then please watch this film.The film completely misses all of the story that made the original compelling. What happened to the compelling points of the original, such as:Relegion vs Science ?Evolution ?Animal Cruelty ?Ethics of Zoo's ?Animal Experiments ?Racism?All of these wonderful points (and more) of the original are left out of the movie, to make way for an awful script, predictable chase and fight sequences, and one awful ending.SPOILER!!!!!!!!!!!Explain to me this, we leap forward in time, to where General Thade etc are, and then, at the end of the movie, leap back again.Yet, at the whitehouse, there is a General Thade statue, and the earth is ruled by apes , and yet, at that point in time, General Thade had not even existed!Whether you take it that the Ape planet was earth or not, the time sequencing of events is a paradox, and completely naff.I loved the first movie, and was hoping that this new version would bring in new arguments (such as genetics and DNA, discussed by another posting here), and yet all we get is another dumbed down picture.Hollywood is showing a contempt for its history, and for the viewing public.A big, big shame.</fullReview>

		<date>2001-08-21</date>
		<username>(curatorfilm@webtv.net)</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Monkey See, Money Do</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This version of Planet of the Apes was obviously not supposed to be like the mature Heston version. The original version had more dialogue in which acting ability was so important. But the old version also moved along at a rapid pace. This version played more like an action version but was also very good. Tim Burton for the first time seems to draw the audience in to the movie unlike his previous films which seemed more rock video. Burton is sure to make many more films and has greatly improved from Sleepy Hollow. I saw this film twice and with the second viewing certain details become more understandable. It is interesting to see how the apes seemed to have imitated human culture. Burton has the apes doing all the things humans do even saying grace. But the ape's have no deeper understanding of anything. If you see the film you will understand. I believe Burton has the apes more as a creation from humans and not an evolved species. The first film has the apes emerge out of a human created disaster of nuclear war. This film treats the creation of apes in a unique way.I have heard more long debates about this film than any other film of the Summer. As far as all the criticism of the ending, it seemed much more clear the second time. SPOILER: I think it was more of a beginning than an ending. And if you look on the plaque you will see the name Thade. Perhaps in the next one we will see a battle by humans to retake a new technologically advanced ape world. SPOILER: Whatever, it may be that the ending may be another example of apes having imitated the human world by finding books. Bring on Apes 2 especially with pretty pouty Bonham in it. Lets put Angelina Jolie in it too.</fullReview>

		<date>2001-08-21</date>
		<username>Jalea</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>A Good Film</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I thought that the film was good. I did not really have any preconceived notions other than the "Burton" touch. His films are usually dark but beautiful spectacles in my opinion.Sometimes I wonder why people take movie plots so seriously.In the original, a lot of political statements were made (not unusual for Sci Fi films of that area). It was safe in that genre to make political statements that would be blasted in other genres.The original Planet of the Apes series adequately addressed the issues of the time. What would be the purpose of reiterating it in 2001?I actually liked the plot. It was an interesting take or twist of the original. There was some tongue and cheek dialogue as well. The ending was the kind the either you liked or thought was really corny. I liked the ending though, even if it did catch me off guard.I really liked the movie and would buy the video when it becomes available. I am really happy though, I saw it on the big screen.The choice of actors was excellent, I think Tim Roth stole the show, he was so convincing and seemed to enjoy every minute. I was impressed with the good job that all the actors did. It did not look easy.I wonder what Tim Burton will do next. He is truly an artist.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2001-08-20</date>
		<username>hotspur95</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Close, but no banana</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Sorry, this is just going to be a re-hash of what others have said, but I just saw it last night and would like to add my two pence worth :) Contains spoilers ... Good costumes, good sets etc, and worth seeing for these things. However (!). The plot has load of holes in it. 1. Marky can't land a space craft to save his life. Both times he totals it in a crash landing. Then the chimp shows him how its done, in a perfect landing, in the middle of a confused battlefield. 2. The space station just happens to crash land a couple of days ride from Markys crash site. 3. When he leaves the planet, three moons are visible suggesting to me he wasn't on earth. 4. All the apes speak English with american accents - fair enough the space station was manned by Americans - but how many generations had passed up to when our hero makes his appearance. Human english has changed alot in the last thousand years. 5. Ok, so the space storm spits out objects at random intervals in time. The space chimp sure chose his moment anyway. A hairy 'Deux Ex Machina' (sorry if I spelt that wrong!) 6. Oooch! People seem to fly about the place, flung by angry apes then just get up again, particularily Mr Whalberg. A gorilla can rip a mans arm off easily.Ok, I'll stop there. I just had the feeling Burton thought, this is Sci-fi, they will buy anything, so I can do whatever I want to push the plot along. I like Mark Whalberg - but he didn't come out very well in this film. The young boy falling under his horse was soooo predictible - we all groaned. Charlton repeating the last lines from the origional was a nice touch though. The other human characters may as well not been there, for all the difference they made. Unlike the book, or even the origional film, this was pretty brainless. Still, It had its moments and clever touches, I thought, and although we only had glimpses of the ape society (which is what the book focuses on), and the film focused on 'hero-on-the-run' action, I would still recommend it, if only for Tim Roth - the antithesis of a PG Tips Chimp.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-08-20</date>
		<username>ego-4 (enggoano@indosat.net.id)</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>A good satire depicting human nature and apes that can act humanely</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I had never seen a good science fiction movie since "Star Wars: Phantom of the Menace" until I saw "Planet of the Apes". Although the two films are about future human interplanetary adventures, "Planet of the Apes" stresses more on human compassion for and understanding of other living creatures. The film is also a good satire on men's foolhardy behavior to launch nuclear wars that could annihilate everything on earth only to find that, in the end, they would be ruled by "wiser-than-human" apes. For such a good film, all the kudos go not only to Director Tim Burton but also to all the crew, particularly the makeup artists, set designers and the actors.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>I had never seen a good science fiction movie since "Star Wars: Phantom of the Menace" until I saw "Planet of the Apes". Although the two films are about future human interplanetary adventures, "Planet of the Apes" stresses more on human compassion for and understanding of other living creatures. The film is also a good satire on men's foolhardy behavior to launch nuclear wars that could annihilate everything on earth only to find that, in the end, they would be ruled by "wiser-than-human" apes. For such a good film, all the kudos go not only to Director Tim Burton but also to all the crew, particularly the makeup artists, set designers and the actors.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2001-08-20</date>
		<username>Anthony Piggott</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Flaws aplenty, but entertaining nonetheless!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>CONTAINS SPOILERS!!!!!! First, I just wanted to say that I haven't yet had the opportunity to see the 1968 version and I'm not one of those people who prefer remakes over originals just because "the effects are better".Anyway.. what can I say about this movie? I'll start on the positive side of things. It was very entertaining and seemed to actually have a bit of intelligence behind it, a rare (but welcome) combination in modern Hollywood. The makeup and special effects were absolutely stunning. The apes looked and moved like apes, yet effectively had the human characteristic of being able to distinguish the characters through face recognition. It made a great combination. This great imagery was backed up by impressive looking sets. Watching the two connect together, it was hard to believe these were human actors in ape costumes acting on a studio set, you get the full impression of a real world. The cast were good enough, Mark was convincing as a lost and puzzled human, the rest of the humans were appropriately primitive-like, Carter portrayed the human-sympathising Ari well and.. well Tim Roth as Thade.. he stole the show every time he appeared, his portrayl of the character echoed frustration and anger and his voice was more than appropriate. The film also had a well suited soundtrack, provided by music magic man, Danny Elfman. The direction throughout this movie was also very strong and of the usual Burton quality.Anyway, onto the bad stuff. There were countless plot problems and issues that weren't explained either fully enough or not at all. The apes rode horses.. however, where these horses came from was unexplained. Mark kisses that blonde woman at the end (whose character is so insignificant, her name isn't even worth remembering) even though he only said about three words to her throughout the whole film, I have no idea.. was there supposed to be some sort of love triangle thing going on with Mark, Ari and the blonde? The part near the end with the chimp arriving in his pod was so coincidental that it just seemed completely unbelievable. The apes were scared of water, for some bizarre reason they couldn't swim, even though they are physically superior to humans. The apes are unable to cross water because they can't swim, so why can't they build a boat? I'm sure there were other plot issues too, but those are the only ones that I can remember. Now onto my comment on the ending, which, if you've seen the film is probably the part you've been waiting for. I warn you, if you haven't seen the movie, then do yourself a favour, don't read the paragraph below, it will completely spoil the almost remote chance that the ending will shock you in a positive manner.Three words: what, the, hell? I've questioned myself over and over about how this ending could make any possible sense whatsoever. As Mark's pod landed and he walked up to the Lincoln statue I thought to myself "Hehe.. it would be funny if we find out that Mark's world is now inhabited by apes.. but then again.. the writers aren't that stupid.. are they?". I actually felt quite gutted the moment where we saw the statue's face, because the rest of the story (despite the plot problems mentioned) actually made sense. I've since heard lot's of interesting theories, but they've all had some sort of reason for not being correct. The most popular theory was that Thade repairs Leo's space pod and goes back through time to Earth and edits the world. First of all, Leo's pod is underwater and apparently the apes can't swim, so it is unaccessible to Thade. Also, even if Thade could get the pod, the apes don't have the technology to repair it. The pod was only big enough to fit Thade in, how could just one ape make such a difference? Finally, if apes did inhabit Earth instead of humans.. what would be the chance of the apes building a city exactly the same as Washington DC with a Thade memorial looking exactly the same as the Lincoln memorial? Pretty damn slim to say the least.Anyway, final verdict: entertaining, but too many plot problems and an appalling ending. If the movie ended the second that Mark's pod takes off at the end, my overall opinion would have been better, let's just hope a sequel will come our way and remedy all our frustrations about that ending. Rating: 6/10.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Very good remake!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>A lot of surprises in Tim Burton's version!Who would have expect an anti-gun message from Mr. NRA himself,or that Helena Bonham-Carter 2nd best performance[after 'Fight Club',of course]would come from her in a monkey suit?! A few words about the twists[Don't worry,I'm not going to reveal them, just provide knowing insight for those who saw them]!! The first one is obviously a tip to Rod Serling's original ending.The second one I think most people could guess from the opening scene,but it's a funny goof on 'Beneath the Planet...'!The final big twist may seem confusing,but I think Tim Burton wanted to set up a sequel based on 'Escape from the Planet...',and I think this may be one to watch for!</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2001-08-19</date>
		<username>Serkan Okar (the_divine_spirit@yahoo.com)</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Apes Rule Once Again</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>What took so long to re-make this 68 sci-fi classic? I had been expecting it since the early 90's! From reading the reviews, however, I get the feeling that it was probably only me who made that prediction. Why did I predict or even insisted that there would be a re-make of Planet Of The Apes? Well, for one thing, I believed that the advanced cinema techniques could add so much flavour to the original screenplay, which was superbly revolutionary (please read my review for the original Planet Of The Apes 68' to see why I consider the original screenplay to be "revolutionary"). I have always thought that the original Planet Of The Apes was full of imaginative thoughts but it lacked juicy action scenes that could have made it even more fun to watch (however even this drawback didn't stop it from becoming a classic sci-fi, probably the best of its genre). The other reason why I expected a re-make was because I wanted to see my most favourite sci-fi saga being re-imagined, as director Tim Burton put it. My Vote: 7/10Things I liked about the movie: In contrast to other people, I liked the screenplay. In fact, I thought that it was brilliant. It was probably the best screenplay that could have been written for this movie without the "it-was-earth-all-along" concept that shocks the audience in the 68' version. I was as much amused by the twists in the end, as I was amused when I watched the original 68' version. Even the last 4-5 minutes were such a great enjoyment. I honestly think the screenplay works. But as much as it works, screenplay was not the best thing about the movie. I personally think that there are mainly two things about this movie that left me in complete amazement, 1) Tim Roth's performance and 2) The original score of the movie, both of which well deserve Oscar Nomination. Tim Roth was the only REAL APE in the movie; the rest were just humans under ape costumes. Tim Roth was the only one who really gave his character an identity. He was not just an ape; he was an ape with a personality. The rest of the cast couldn't even manage to act or even look like apes, except for their costumes, of course. The original score was totally mind-blowing. It is a musical expression of what's going on in the movie. Marvellous achievement!Things I didn't like about the movie: In contrast what other people think, I thought that the apes were too human. They were humans under ape costumes. Most of them didn't even try to act or move like an ape (except for Tim Roth). Obviously, they thought that wearing an ape costume was enough. I could puke at the dinner scene when the elderly ape character was speaking: he was just TOO HUMAN. And again, in contrast what other people think, I wasn't satisfied with the make up. Well, for one thing, the cast put too much trust in their make-ups; they didn't make the slightest effort to give themselves an ape-like personality (a couple of scenes showing them hanging upside down from the ceilings or trees don't redeem that - if they are ape enough to do that then how come they are so much human when talking?). Secondly, the make up in the original version was as good as it could get; it was revolutionary in its time. That's why, there was nothing revolutionary about the make ups in this one. Briefly, it was not better than the make ups in the original 68' version. Lastly, I saw a couple of flaws in the make up. For one thing, the one ape character -the one who sells humans as gifts- hadn't had his eyelids painted; every time he closed his eyes, his eyelids would look white (am I the only one who saw that?). Some of the actors' upper teeth had ape-like appearance, whereas their lower level teeth were obviously human-like. What about the hair of Ari (Helena Bonham Carter)? It looked like she had hair done in a beauty salon; it was too human. And her make up was terribly cheap, as if she was a little girl who didn't know how to put a make up. Maybe, Tim Burton wanted to give story a different respective with these ideas on purpose. But honestly, I don't think they work. My last criticism is the inappropriate sense of humour, which has become the disease of Hollywood in recent years. Directors must be very careful about the timing and the nature of the humour otherwise they spoil the whole movie. There are some silly jokes that work perfectly fine in the genre of comedy (Rush Hour, American Pie, Jim Carrey / Eddie Murphy kind of comedies and the like). But when you use jokes out of these movies in a movie that has a totally different personality, it spoils it. Within that respect, I have found the scene where the elderly ape character is taking his fake teeth out and putting into a jar absolutely inappropriate. Other then these flaws, the movie was a perfect re-make of an old sci-fi classic. Possible Academy Awards Nominations: 1) Best Performance By A Leading Actor In A Motion Picture: Tim Roth. 2) The Original Score: Danny Alfman</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>What Else Left Besides Makeup and Effect?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The biggest problem in the Planet of the Apes is that there are no deep feelings within the characters. Leo (Mark Wahlberg) does not care for any of human on the planet of the apes but himself. His goal was just get himself out of the planet as soon as possible. The director knows too well that he is not a hero, that's why he decided to add a scene of heroic rescue of a young boy in the movie. But it doesn't help to make him a better character but too obvious of an effort. Ari (Helena Bonham Carter) was a confusing idealistic character that she believes ape and human should be equally live together. But the movie fails to show her feeling when she watches human killing her own kind. Instead of an internal struggle inside her, she just blindly help human beat up her own people. And the third main character, Daena (Estella Warren) she was just a pretty figure follows Leo everywhere until the end. It's not her fault that she couldn't act, it's the movie doesn't give her any chance to act. It was a failure when Leo farewells to Ari and Daena in the end, there's nothing there to drive the audiences to any feeling. It's as if we watch some stranger say goodbye?They could have brought up much more than this. They could use the scene when Ari heard about how human treat Apes on Earth (lock in the zoo) as an ironic moral in the movie. But they didn't go further? Everyone agree that the makeup in this movie is awesome. There's no doubt about that. But beside the makeup, Tim Burton directed nothing shine in this remake of sci-fi classic.Everyone agree that the makeup in this movie is awesome, but beside the makeups, there's nothing shine in this remake of sci-fi classic.HinxLinx</fullReview>

		<date>2001-08-16</date>
		<username>Marcus McCormack (marcus.mccormack@virgin.net)</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>HOLLYWOOD NEEDS NEW SCRIPT WRITERS!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I'm gutted, one of my all time favourite movies ?Planet of the Apes' is to be remade by one of my favourite directors ?Tim Burton' at last a film to really look forward to. Oh dear! What's with these filmmakers, why do they seem to pay no attention to the story and script? Planet of the Apes (2001) is a stunning piece of film work with great make-up, effects (a few actors aside) an excellent cast.The first half of the movie is entertaining and builds well though it doesn't take a genius to work out where the story going. The second half comes across as though they ran out of time and were not sure which way to take the movie. Because this it becomes farcical! It looks like they panicked, the problem is the original movie is a classic and easily stands the test of time, the end, still a very powerful image. They concentrate of trying to replicate (in a different way) this but it's desperate. If you're going to see this film try to forget about the original and just enjoy it as a different film. This is difficult because they insist on repeating the classic lines from the first movie. I suppose they were trying to be funny, it was funny but for the wrong reasons. Planet of the Apes is an entertaining movie that does not carry much impact Michael Clark Duncan is big, Mark Wahlberg is good, and Tim Roth is great, though given the costume, setting and make-up not a difficult task! People will not be watching this film in thirty years. Yet another disappointment.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Burton gave us another masterpiece!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>First of all: I'm a HUGE fan of the original 1968 POTA. And this is not a remake of that movie. It's simply a reinvention of the same story, filtered through the eyes of one of the most creative Hollywood directors. Everything in this show work in a perfect way: the screenplay is inventive and brilliant. All the performers gave their best, in particularly Tim Roth portraing the main villain, General Thade, and Helena Bonham Carter under the make-up of the kind chimp Ari. Costumes, art direction, special effects are amazing! Great part of the success of this film is due to the wonderful make-up effects by the genial wizardy of Rick Baker and the complex score composed by the talent of the sublime Maestro Danny Elfman. Main titles (music and images together) are simply astonishing! Absolutely a must see by all the fans of fantastic cinema. Rating: 9/10.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2001-08-14</date>
		<username>mattymatt4ever</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Haven't seen the original, but this is one cool movie</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Not haven't seen the original "Planet of the Apes," I've never been part of the fan club. I wasn't heavily anticipating this remake, like about ninety-percent of the viewing public. In fact, I predicted it would suck. For some reason, I'm not a sucker for all these big-budget Hollywood summer blockbusters. I thought I'd feel the same way about this movie as I did with that borefest "The Mummy Returns." Even action movies can put me to sleep, if flashy special f/x is the only fuel to keep them going. But as it turns out fifty-percent of the time, the movies I least anticipate are the ones I end up liking quite a bit. First of all, it's directed by Tim Burton. I've always been fond of his work (minus "Mars Attacks"). Just like most of his movies, he creates a creepy atmosphere that deeply engages you--sometimes on a conscious level, sometimes on a subconscious level. And also like most of his movies, he adds a nice touch of humor. Some of the humor's pretty silly and obvious and some it's pretty subtle. Whatever route he took, it often worked. The ape costumes are amazingly realistic and the set designs are very impressive. Also we have the great Danny Elfman who composed a great score to help intensify the creepy atmosphere.The premise is quite nifty. A planet run by apes, where the apes rule and the humans are enslaved and put to work and even treated as pets. That I found very interesting. The premise is handled nicely, and it was amusing--sometimes hilarious--to see apes take on a human persona. Playing card games, running shops, etc.In the comic relief department, we have Paul Giamatti who takes on the bumbling henchman role. Just like his enormously impressive debut as Pig Vomit in Howard Stern's "Private Parts" he is absolutely hilarious. Now, my mother saw this movie before me, so she pointed out that Charlton Heston had a cameo appearance. Watching the film and seeing his name absent in the closing credits, I wasn't sure who he played. I had a hunch he played Thade's father, and I was right. The hint that sorta gave it away was when he quotes his famous "Damn you all to hell" speech on his deathbed. I wonder if others caught on that it was Heston in that cameo, because I don't hear much buzz about it. The story's not topnotch. This is overall shallow, predictable entertainment, but it works. I enjoyed it a lot more than expected, though it dragged at points (especially in the third act) and went on a little long. Tim Roth is great as the villain. If I didn't check the credits, I wouldn't have known it was him. He didn't even use his British accent (something he's amazingly good at covering up). And behind all that makeup, he's almost completely unrecognizable. Though I haven't seen the original, I'm pretty sure Heston played a much better hero than Mark Wahlberg. I don't think Wahlberg's a bad actor. It's just, he's one of those actors who doesn't seem to go the whole nine yards for his craft. He speaks in a moderately monotone voice, and never seems to have much substance behind his performances (even in his acclaimed role as Dirk Diggler in "Boogie Nights"). He's good in this movie, but they could've cast a better lead. Someone with a more commanding presence. Please keep in mind I didn't see the 1968 version, so I might be a little sweet on this remake. After seeing this version, I'm more anxious to check out the old version. I heard a lot of buzz about this movie's ending. Though I didn't think it was a bad way to end things, it was...weird. A little enigmatic. Something you might have to ponder for a while. Though it's nothing as subtle as M. Night Shamalyan's ending for "The Sixth Sense." Tim Burton really did an impressive job, this is another score for him. It's good, fun entertainment that doesn't take itself too seriously and leaves sufficient room for comic relief. So I will recommend this movie, but if you're a die-hard fan of the original--please don't get on my case!My score: 7 (out of 10)</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>jon.h.ochiai (jochiai@socal.rr.com)</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Revisionist Ape</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Tim Burton's "Planet of the Apes" is dark, macabre, and visually stunning. William Broyles's screenplay is interesting, but the dialogue has it's moments. A dear friend pointed out for me the low point in writing occurs when Leo (Mark Wahlberg) in an attempt to inspire the humans to battle the attacking apes he says "Come on guys! We can take them..." Whoa! Much of "Planet of the Apes" is like that. It has the trademark Burton brooding, dark settings-- great attention to detail. Though the story is in-cohesive and uneven. And there is some killer over-acting, particularly by Tim Roth as General Thade. Mark Wahlberg is okay as stranded astronaut, Leo, who wants to go home. Human activist, Helena Bonham Carter as ape Ari, is convincing in a strange "romantic" role. Liked Cary-Hiroyki Tagawa as Ari's protector, Krull-- the one really heroic character. All the other characters are forgettable. Even with these weaknesses in writing and acting, "Planet of the Apes" is definitely entertaining. It's pretty much an action picture with a slight social context-- very slight. You have great visuals, chases, explosions, and cool looking apes. Burton's reworked surprise ending is also worth staying for.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Bad taste in your mouth..</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>It's not often that I find a movie that I literally wanted to walk out of during the film. This movie just happens to be one of those movies. Mark Walhberg was not the cause of this movie to stink, nor was it the acting in general. I liked the acting and the special effects. However, the story and script should never had made it past the producers. In fact, I am surprised the ink in the pen wanted to write it out. This whole story does nothing but tarnish the original movies good name. I literally, as soon as I left the cinema went and rented the original Planet of the Apes to wash the bad taste this one left in my mouth.Let's compare the new movie to the old;Actors: Charlton Heston &amp; Mark WalhbergWhile Hestons brand of acting may not appeal to all, it IS brilliant acting. Mark Walhberg is an up and coming star, this is true, but for him to rise to the level that Heston sits upon, Mark is going to have to start looking for some seriously good scripts and take some more acting lessons, maybe even from Heston himself. ADVANTAGE: OriginalSupporting Ape Cast Old &amp; Supporting Ape Cast NewApes are Apes but there are aspects from both the new and old films that I liked. The Original movie had Dr.Zira and Dr.Cornelius and who could forget Dr.Zaius, who were all pretty great characters which added a lot of character interaction and development for Hestons character(Taylor). While the new movie has Ari? An Ape with a serious case of the hots for Walhbergs character(Leo). ADVANTAGE: OriginalSupporting Human Cast Old &amp; Supporting Human Cast NewBased on the fact that the original only had Linda Harrison as Nova, I have to give the advantage for this class to the new movie. ADVANTAGE: New MovieSpecial Effects:While the old has some fantastic sites where they shot the film, we do have to give the new movie the advantage in the special effects department. The only thing I really did not like where the Gorillas that were leaping distances of 30 or so feet. Advantage: New MovieStory:Well this is the big kahuna. The old movie had an amazing script. The new movie was geared too much towards quick action where the old movie was a lot of character development with enough action to keep it interesting. After watching the new movie there were definite aspects that I really would have liked to see in the old movie. Such as the fact that the Apes were using primitive weaponry. Makes sense. Also they lived in the trees, again.. makes sense. I was very dissappointed when the humans in the new movie opened their mouths and could speak perfect english. WOW, it's actually very difficult to see, at least in my point of view, how the apes could regard humans, that can speak just as eloquent english as they.. AS SAVAGES. Or question whether or not they have souls?? Hello?!?! I thought the whole reason they were "savages" was because they could not be taught, were stupid and were almost neanderthalic in behavior. What I saw in the new movie was an excuse to have at least a few more characters for Walhberg to talk to since they did not have the character interacton with the Apes. I liked the idea or Thade.. but he was just a tad bit too insane for my liking, then again, maybe there just wasn't enough character developement for me to like him. Overall.. ADVANTAGE: OriginalIn short, this movie is a waste of time, don't see it, don't rent it, don't buy it. I give it 4 thumbs down</fullReview>

		<username>Lexie Vanderzee</username>
		<score>0.1</score>
		<shortDescription>A horrible, cliched, schmaltzy waste of money.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>As a huge Tim Burton fan, I anticipated greatness and creativity. Imagine my dismay as I sat through a big-budget Hollywood crapfest with the worst dialogue (so laughably bad!). I am thoroughly disgusted by this- he has clearly fallen for the Hollywood method of fearlessly distributing crap, so long as he makes a buck (or a million). DON'T see this trashy, stupid, waste-of-time movie. Mark Wahlberg's acting is totally sub-par and boring. The rest of the characters are background filler and serve no purpose. Tim Burton is capable of so much more. Let's hope he chooses something more substantial with original dialogue next time.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>but it's a very weak story with unremarkable special effects and full of gaping holes. Which is bad. Very very bad.I went in expecting a good movie that would live up to the name of the franchise, despite the presence of Burton in the director's chair.I cannot believe a story resembling an early draft and not much more than a comedy sketch in someone else's production would have received final approval and the go-ahead by an entire studio.When it's available on video (DVD), watch this along with the original 1968 Apes. If you care for nothing more than MTV special effects, maybe you'll come away with a distaste for the original. But if you value any type of consistency and plausible story, in an implausible world, then the newest Apes movie will leave you wanting a lot more. Not even Helena Bonham Carter nor Tim Roth, both whom put forth excellent performances, could save this picture. Paul Giamatti was brilliant - his performance might have been a little too comedic over-all, but again, that was a problem with the writing. His performance was stellar. Mark Wahlberg has chosen far better roles in the past.Ah, Burton signs his name on another ruined production. He certainly has earned his over-rated respect directing this type of swiss-cheesed fluff. The picture does nothing to advance the state of cinematography or story telling. It adds an easily forgettable movie to the Apes line-up. If nothing else, at least a sequel, with someone else handling direction, doesn't stand much chance of being any worse.POTA-2001 earns a solid (1) rating. Wahlberg offers a one liner which would sum this picture. I'm only paraphrasing... "you shouldn't send apes to do a man's job" - and that there points to one of the biggest holes in the entire story. No spoilers though. Watch it for your own opinion, but do yourselves the favor of going in expecting very little.</fullReview>

		<score>0.1</score>
		<shortDescription>Not good</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Very bad. First of all, Mark Wahlberg phoned this one in, and I can't blame him. His character never showed any real concern with the plot, his only concern was to get back to his ship. That is fine, but when the storyline (macro level -ape vs man, micro level the humans on this planets apparent desire to rebel against the apes) hinges on the hope that he will- he is the humans savior. He doesn't care, and any effort to care seems half hearted at best. The writing is terrible, wasteful and at times just stolen and ba****dized. If we aren't supposed to compare this movie to the original, then why did they steal superb lines from the original and force them into this one? Early in the movie, on the spacestation, one of the scientists tells Wahlbergs character that the female apes are the aggressive ones. I thought at that point there would be a female general on the planet of the apes. Was there? No. Did that line ever come into play? No. So why have it in the movie? It didn't further the plot, it wasn't funny, it wasn't interesting, it provided nothing at all. Is this nit picking? Perhaps, but it just goes to show how unattached the people making this movie(and films in general) are to the point of cinema. Shakespeare never wasted a word, and here these people are, using millions of dollars to produce a story and they can't even get a quality script written. All this movie is a chase scene, but the end of the battle scene is ridiculous, the only way the writers could save their hero, and the apparent peace that arises between man and ape is forced because no real discussion of the topic occurs. The ending makes no sense, only cents- it is the launching pad for a sequel to try to explain what the hell happened. I'll only touch on the awful directing (hey Burton- why does everything important have to happen when it is dark) and the complete lack of attention to detail (Estella Warren's character was supposed to be the love interest- but the female ape and wahlberg had more chemistry, ape costumes looked just like ape costumes.) Did anyone else notice that at the bottom of the lake in which Marky Marks spaceship crashed was brighter than the dark jungle in which he crashed? Do the fish in that pond have lightbulbs? This movie was the pits- and if fits right in with the rest of the garbage I've seen this year.</fullReview>

		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Visually stunning, but a disappointment</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Planet of the Apes Tim Burton-style is a disappointment. It's a good film, but I have learned to expect more from Burton than just 'good'. As with all Burton-films though, Planet of the Apes is visually stunning. Costumes, make-up (brilliant!), the production design, the cinematography... Simply amazing. However, the script is seriously lacking pace in the first half hour and the ending is an abomination! One of the worst movie endings in years. Doesn't stand a chance in comparison with the ending in the first Planet of the Apes. After the slow beginning, the movie builds up nicely to a final battle scene, which is great, but that ending... My, my... What a mistake.In a fine cast (though Mark Wahlberg is a bit boring) Tim Roth is certainly the stand-out. He delivers a great performance as Thade.In short, an entertaining sci-fi adventure which is let down by a silly ending and a slow start. Visuals are stunning and well worth the admission price.Could have been such a great film... (6/10)</fullReview>

		<date>2001-08-10</date>
		<username>Walter Frith</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>If it weren't for Tim Roth......</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I really wanted to like this film. I went in pumped up but left feeling disappointed because I probably expected too much. They did a good job distancing themselves from the original film. This film has a surprise ending that's not as good as the one in the original (which is my favourite ending in ANY film) but is still very nightmarish. Unfortunately this movie's mid section drags mercilessly and I wanted to leave the theatre. It starts off very well and ends well in the last 40 minutes or so but about 45 minutes in the middle of the film is just plain bland. Mark Wahlberg wasn't well casted. I didn't buy him as an astronaut and adventurer at all. Helena Bonham Carter, Michael Clarke Duncan and especially Tim Roth all have their characters nailed down perfectly. Roth's General Thade may be one of the top five villains in movie history. The savage nature of his portrayal made him a great sadist and the make-up spoke a lot for him as well. Rick Baker could earn another Oscar for his make-up work but Tim Burton was not the man to direct such heavy material. Burton is good for decorative pop culture stuff found in comic books ('Batman') or heavy indoor and artsy production design stuff like 'Pee Wee's Big Adventure' or 'Beetlejuice' but somehow he just couldn't get me excited enough to embrace this remake of a legendary motion picture.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2001-08-08</date>
		<username>Dan Grant (dan.grant@bell.ca)</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Like Instinct, this should be studied for years to come</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Warning! May contain spoilers.What I have always found incredibly funny and yet at the same time downright scary about us as human beings is our ability to be so stupid and so cruel at the same time. We are the best at cruelty. As far as I know, we are the only species that hunts for sport and kills for pleasure. Everything else in the animal kingdom does so for it's very survival. When lions hunt gazelle, it is to feed their young or to feed themselves. Even the fearsome and loathed Great White Shark hunts and kills for it's very survival. But human beings are nothing but charlatan when it comes to our apparent benevolence. Not all of us of course, but a good majority of us. Even myself, who I consider to be somewhat of an animal lover, will go out and eat the latest slaughtered cow from the supermarket and I can justify that because in mind, that cow has been killed more humanely than a pig ( which I will not eat, have you ever seen the way a pig is killed at a Portuguese barbecue, well it is even worse when it is killed for mass consumption ). Human beings are not magnanimous in the least. We take what we desire, not what is necessary. That makes us gluttonous and that is unacceptable. But no one does anything about it because we are used to living the way that we do and for some reason, we have laws and human rights for criminals ( including rapists, murderers, child molesters and arsonists). But we have very little regard for our next meal and how it dies. Doesn't anyone else out there think it is inhumane to boil a live animal before you eat it? Well?I begin this review of Planet of the Apes with this sanctimonious "holier than thou" sermon because I think this film and the writers do think about these things. Planet of the Apes is a great action film and has some outstanding special effects but the core of the film is one that is perhaps overlooked. This is a film about man's comeuppance and what would happen if another species could do to us what do to them. Battlefield Earth, as awful as it was, touched briefly on this subject matter. Instinct, the under-rated film starring Anthony Hopkins was also critical of man and our abuse of not only this planet but the inhabitants of it. See also the Matrix and even Free Willy. Sometimes movies come out and have outlandish theories and sometimes they thrive at the box office. This is going to be one of those films. But people do not often advocate change after they see these films. They makes hundreds of millions of dollars but that is all they do. They entertain. But maybe films like this are about more than entertainment. Maybe there is a message that Burton and company want us to hear. Maybe what we are watching is not just about entertainment.Spoilers ahead!!!What was fascinating about this film is that the theory that it subscribes to is that this ape world would not have gotten as bad as it did if it wasn't for human beings. When captain Leo Davidson ( Mark Wahlberg ) lands on this distant planet, he travels through time hundreds of years. He is immediately thrust into a chase involving humans and super intelligent and herculian apes. He is captured and brought to their camp and here he learns that the world has been ruled by the apes for years now. He can't understand this because not an hour earlier he was on a his ship that used animals to try and figure out complex problems and to basically use them as guinea pigs. When there is a dangerous mission to embark on, they would send out the monkeys first to see what the danger was. If the monkey did not survive the ordeal, then their human soldiers would not go. So this is a great shock to Davidson. When he asks the humans how the monkeys got like this, they don't understand what he means. To them, it has always been like this.The apes, lead by Thade and his right hand ape, Colonel Attar, rule with an iron fist and want to rid the planet of the humans. They enslave them and put them to work. But there are human rights activists that think the ethical treatment of humans should be advocated by all so for now the humans are allowed to live. But most of them live on the outskirts of the world, cowered in little huts or caves and living like rats. There is great detail that goes into reversing the fortunes of man as we are used as pets. We are chained up at night and kept in cages and it is even a far fetched theory for the apes to believe that we have souls. Humans are also branded like horses and are forced to wear the mark. This is a little like Naziism but more like humanism.Aside from all of the politics of the film, it has to be said that it is a treat to watch strictly from an entertainment form. Burton never lets us down with the action sequences and the team of art directors, costume designers and make-up artists should be nominated for Oscars this year. Rick Baker leads the team of make-up artists and his work here is absolutely incredible. Actors, and that is plural, meaning hundreds of actors, spent six hours in the make-up chair ever day. But it pays off as the apes look fantastic. Michael Clarke Duncan was the most impressive to me. He transformed wonderously into Attar and even though it is not the kind of performance that you would say is Oscar material, it certainly is fun to watch. Others that should get mentioned for their work is costume designer Colleen Atwood. She too should be remembered at Oscar time. The set decorators, Rosemary Brandenburg and Peter Young, created a wonderfully dark and sinister home for the apes from the ground up. It is truly remarkable to see the village and realize that it was once nothing but a vision on some scrap piece of paper.Planet of the Apes is an excellent film in all areas. It is entertaining, action packed, littered with humour and it is a great summer film. It is actually the perfect pastiche of a summer film. It has all the ingredients. But to me it is much more. This is a smart film and it has a little more on it's mind that just talking monkeys. It would be interesting to see a film like this produce more than just hundreds of millions of dollars for 20th Century Fox. It would be nice to see someone out there take a film like this and truly re-examine how we are to the species that we depend upon and for our very survival and abuse in the process. It would be interesting, but impossible. After all, we are human.8.5 out of 10</fullReview>
	</review>

The original held much more of sci-fi instead of the usual us versus them wargames. The original was more thrilling, mysterious, and scary, ominously.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>I have, with trouble, figured out the ending to this movie!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Okay, this would be easier if you all knew about time paradoxes like in Star Trek. Don't stop reading because I mention Star Trek. Here goes: (One thing you have to know first, when Mark goes through this storm in space, he thinks he is taken to another planet, when he is really taken to another time on his). If you remember, when he was crash-landing on the "other planet" (Earth), his digital calendar was moving the years ahead very quickly. He was going into the future. The space-station he came from was pulled in too but not at the same time as him. The space-station got pulled into a time 1,000's of years before him. That space-station was carrying many genetically enhanced chimps. When that station landed (crashed), the apes got out, killed the humans and populated the planet. Since, Mark was sent to a time ahead of that, the apes had already evolved (genetically enhanced). So, they evolved. Remember, this is Earth. Remember that at the end when Mark locks the General in that room he doesn't kill him. So, after Mark leaves to go back to what he thinks is his planet, but is really another time, the General escapes and still has his armies so he exterminates the humans. Mark goes through the time portal and really instead of going to what he thinks is Earth, he goes ahead in time even farther, to where the apes have evolved into a society like ours. The statue (Abraham Lincoln) is of the General because he saved the planet for the apes (by exterminating the humans).</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Does plenty well everything a movie is supposed to do, and does it GRAND!!!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Wonderful movie! Although not without some flaws, but well worthseeing and enjoying. After seeing it this morning, I was surprisedto discover that this evening I felt like seeing it again. So, I'll catch itagain within a week or two.WARNING--SPOILERS The entire gorilla cast was magnificent! Truly and reallyastounding work by the makeup guys-- but more, by the actorsthemselves. Not once did I think-- Hey, there's Roddy McDowell ina gorilla suit! The animal characters were so believable. Thehumans were less than grand, though. Kris Kristoffersen wasamazing-- a welcome and remarkable acting re-appearance, andtotally apt for his role.The blond babe: Whats-her-name, was serviceable, but nothingspecial. Markie Mark -- I mean Mark Wahlberg-- is a fine actor,generally. But here his character is annoying and dumb. I kind ofwanted to see him killed pretty much right away.Helena Bonham-Carter-- all I can say is you've got to see her tobelieve her! Even though any role as a gorilla lady would be,professionally, a bit of a burlesque, she made it into somethingworthwhile. Appropriate to the spirit of the movie-- but I say that hercharacter in this flick outdoes and therefore embarrasses JuliaRoberts, in ANYTHING Roberts has EVER done. Bonham-Cartergets an exquisite performance out of the circumstances, whichspeaks highly of her genius and mastery of acting.The ending, though-- What the F*** was that??? Talk aboutsomething happening simply because the script, or pre-fab cliche,demands it! Knowing critic Roger Ebert's movie law that "No propis featured in a movie without a purpose/payoff later on"-- seeingso much attention paid to the real chimp in the beginning was aclear tip-off that somehow he'd show up later, etc. I also couldguess the secret source of the ape planet within 8 seconds of itsfirst mention. I'm sure most other audience members did as well.But when Wahlberg goes back in time to earth and finds that AbeLincoln is a gorilla dude? That is illogical, even in a 1960's vibesci-fi movie. What's the logic? It makes no sense, and thus hadabsolutely no effect on me.On the other hand-- so what? This great flick does plenty enoughof what a movie is supposed to do, and it does it really well. Maybeit ain't Shakespeare-- but from what I've read, in his time,Shakespeare himself wasn't Shakespeare either.Go see "Planet of the Apes." Be glad; be happy!</fullReview>

		<date>2001-07-24</date>
		<username>Spuzzlightyear</username>

		<shortDescription>Chimply, A great time!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I think first of all, one can easily separate the two POTA movies, as both, while sharing some elements, have VERY different stories. Mark Wahlberg stars as an soldier who is based on a space station which is experimenting with using chimp controlled spaceships. When one chimp is lost in a spacepod during an exploration of a magnetic space field, Wahlberg takes off (unauthorized) to find it. When the pod enters the field, Wahlberg loses control as well, soon he crash lands in a jungle. And he is VERY quickly introduced to the dominant species on the planet ;) The story which follows is very tightly directed by Burton, and is very well acted by Wahlberg. Helena Bonham Carter and Tim Roth are (as usual) excellent and don't let the make up (which is designed by the always outstanding Rick Baker) get in the way of the performances. Finally, as usual, a GREAT score by Danny Elfman.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Literally defines the term LAME</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Tim Burton is my absolute favorite director of all time and he rarely strikes out but when he does, it can be quite embarrassing. Case in question: the 2001 remake of one of the most famous sci-fi films of all time.I do have one confession. I've never actually seen the original 1968 film but I am familiar with the story. Here, astronaut Leo Davidson (played forgettably by Mark Wahlberg) crash lands on a distant planet ruled by intelligent apes. From there, he treks with a small band of outsiders towards these mysterious, ancient ruins which may hold the key for his return home.Where do I begin? Well, the cast is thoroughly wasted and this film has quite a cast (David Warner! Michael Clarke Duncan! Paul Giamattei!), the special effects are pretty generic, and the production design is slimy and claustrophobic. On top of all that, the final battle is very lackluster.Adding to all this, the ending is a joke. While the original film had an ending that was surprising and strangely appropriate, this one feels forced and confusing. Additional sore spots include a bland score by the usually reliable Danny Elfman and a pace that BEGS for a steroid shot.You may be wondering are there ANY redeeming values? Well, Charlton Heston's cameo is pretty good but since it is just a cameo, he's not in long enough to truly save it.What else can I say? This film stinks.</fullReview>

This in itself did not make the stories strength, the strength came from the apes, and that to me is the story. Estella to me just wasn't the right one picked for her character, she was too flimsy... and too blank to be believed. And as for the runt, I couldn't see it he just did not look the type to play a would be hero. Yet besides these flaws i still thought the movie was a great adaptation to the novel, especially the features of the apes and mannerisms. Which to me seemed more real than the old seventies version. Fantastic time to watch this again. If only i could stomach the other two.</fullReview>

		<date>2005-11-12</date>
		<username>Dzoldzaya Kiriyama</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Very cool, under-rated film</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I loved this film, and think that all the bad comments it has received are undeserved. Although I haven't seen the original, this film looks wonderful and dark, and this is surely thanks to Burton's skill as a director. It manages to make the slightly detached characters really work well together, and the acting was great throughout. Very interesting race/ animal rights issues are raised by this film and, although I'm guessing that the original also raised these issues, I suspect it provoked much thought with teenagers who wouldn't dream of watching the original. Of course, you've got to compare it with Burtons other films, and, as far as spooky, Gothic atmospheres go, this doesn't really live up to them. But as an action film it surpasses so many. My favourite character was the Tim Roth evil general. He is the kind of bad guy whose evil has been set so deep within himself that he can no longer control it, and when he kills those gorilla-type creatures it's absolutely amazing. He also emanates pure evil through his wonderfully made facial features. The ending is an issue that raises much debate, but I loved it, the master plan, killing one wave of the enemy with an explosion, was beautifully futile, and the coincidental monkey landing was pleasantly ridiculous. And his return to earth was just really cool. All in all, a great film, watch it. By the way, did anyone else find themselves fancying Helena Bonham Carter in this film. Although, because of the amount of hair and her weird posture, it sounds quite wrong to think that, it just feels so right!</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2005-08-03</date>
		<username>(pierotti@ku.edu)</username>
		<score>0.1</score>
		<shortDescription>Tim Burton has always been overrated</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>It may be a bit late to weigh in on this film, but I feel compelled to if for no other reason than that Tim Burton has just arrogantly messed with another classic, Charlie and Chocolate Factory, and has once again screwed things up. Burton has no concept of plot or acting, his style is entirely visual, and he is dishonest as all get out when he wants to make a point. I'm sorry that Tim had problems with his parents, especially his father, but that does not justify his screwing with classic stories so that he can whine once again about how parents just don't understand you and might even abandon you.Having got that off my chest, I would like to summarize POTA as follows. The movie makes no sense and the reason it makes no sense is that the director has no vision, no sense of a story that he wants to tell. Even the highly touted ape makeup is a mistake, because the director has no idea whether the apes are supposed to be subhuman or better than human. As a consequence they behave in a manner that simply leaves the viewer confused.I am a biologist who has studied behavior in apes, so I might be more picky than most, but I defy any viewer to answer the following question. Why are all the female apes chimpanzees? I have watched the ape village scenes several times and to my view there is not a single female gorilla or orang utan in the entire place. Also these female chimps don't look like chimps, but like some sort of odd chimp/human hybrid, which might explain the attraction between Marky Mark and Helena BC, but otherwise feels just thrown in (This is what I mean by Burton throwing logic out the window to make his themes fit his preconceptions). For example why does the female chimp (Carter) have eyebrows, a trait missing from every primate but humans? Also why do chimps, which seem to make up the vast majority of the apes, walk upright except when they charge? This makes them very ineffective as warriors. They can't hold weapons, so why do they wear armor? The acting in this film is confusing and few characters seem realized, and once again I think Burton is to blame. In Burton films the only actors who are memorable are those willing to create their own characters and overact shamelessly, e.g. Michael Keaton's Beetlejuice, Nicholson's Joker, DeVito's Penguin, Walken's headless horseman. In this film this tradition is carried on by Tim Roth's Thade, a character so psychotic it seems amazing that anyone takes him seriously. The cast includes some good actors, but all are handicapped by bad direction. For example, Paul Giamatti an excellent character actor, tries hard to create a believable character in his whining sycophantic slave trading orang utan, but he is made up as a female rather than a male orang utan, which collapses the character completely.Other actors fare no better. Wahlberg, at best a charming male ingénue, cannot act like a leader, so I was startled by the idea that all the humans would follow his lead when he seems to have no idea as to what he's doing throughout the entire film. The other humans seem to be merely tagging along looking confused. Michael Clarke Duncan, subtle and wonderful in the Green Mile, here plays sort of a King Kong who can talk. As a subtext, why are the Gorillas played by Afrcian American actors, and the chimps by white actors? This leads me to what I think is Burton's greatest weakness, his ability to direct actresses. The only actress who has ever turned in a memorable performance in a Burton film is Michelle Pfeiffer's sly, slinky Catwoman in Batman II. Otherwise excellent actresses have been left to flounder by Burton, e.g. Christina Ricci is Sleepy Hollow, Kim Basinger in Batman. Given this history, I find confusing all of the hostility and crass comments about Estella Warren's performance as Daena, the only human in the film with any personality. Estella Warren is a powerful presence, who in every film in which she appears works from the premise that she is, at the least, the equal of all the male characters and that she is smarter even than most of those. She tries to pull that off in POTA, but she is left to flounder, trying to work off the giant vacuum emitted by Marky Mark. Warren acts using her face to communicate subtle emotions and changes of mood, but that tactic backfires in this film, where subtlety is lost. She gets no perceivable reactions from Wahlberg, who seems lost in his own world, and she has almost no scenes with anyone else. As a result Warren has little to do but look distressed and confused. I think most of the negative comments directed at Warren's acting come from silly insecure young men who feel that a pretty woman should not also be strong and competent, and simply want to ogle her.To summarize, this film is probably the worst big budget film ever made, but don't blame the actors. As they say in Russia, fish begin to stink from the head. In this case the head is the director.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>A Refreshing look on a classic.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Planet of the Apes could perfectly be a part of the selected group of good remakes. This group of films could include movies such a The Fly, The Thing, and some others. The criteria to be a part of this selection would be that every new remake should try to take distance from the seminal classics. Those old and dear movies are classics, there's no sense in make the same movie using the same script and so. If there's any need of release a remake it is necessary a new take on the same tale.Tim Burton has done just that with his version of Planet of the Apes, and also has made the whole myth of this saga his own. Leo Davidson is a hard action astronaut but still he's very innocent just like many of the heroes of Burton. And these Apes who are a distorted image of us as society (greedy, intolerant). The special apes that don't follow these ideologies are the good sensitive beings. I think this is probably one of the most important messages in every good movie of Tim Burton, the special outsider view of the artist in a world who's not sensitive.Owning an amazing design of make-up, scenarios, and lots of practical FX, P.O.A is honest to the old fashion style of Sci-Fi .This is the remake that the seminal classic of 1968 deserves. A great cast of actor and actresses is here and they deliver over the top performances even wearing pound of Makeup! This new version pays homage to the first Planet from the first minute to the last. It deserves an absolute 10.</fullReview>
